headline: MEXICO BREWER RAISES PRICES
abstract: Mexico's largest brewer, Grupo Modelo S.A., raised by 16 percent the average domestic price of its 10 beer labels. That increase could help the company strengthen profits because it is 6 percent higher than the Mexican government's 10 percent inflation target for 2000. The price change does not apply to exports. Modelo exports five of its labels, including Corona Extra, the largest-selling imported beer in the United States.     Sam Dillon

headline: INVESTMENT FIRM TO ACQUIRE METAL CASTINGS COMPANIES
abstract: Carlyle Group Inc acquires Trimin Enterprises Inc and Tritech Precision Inc for 285 million Canadian dollar ($195 million); will pay 7.35 Canadian dollars a share for Trimin and 33 Canadian dollars a share for 55.5 percent of Tritech that is publicly traded (S)

headline: The New York Times: Digital Copyright Issues
abstract: The New York Times: Digital Copyright Issues

headline: Sotheby's Joins Christie's In Revising Its Commissions
abstract: Sotheby's revises its commission rates three weeks after Christie's changed its commissions because of federal antitrust investigation; Sotheby's makes rates nearly identical to those of its rival; two houses are under investigation for possibly colluding to set commissions for buyers and sellers on billions of dollars of fine art they auction every year (M)

headline: New Ads for Gap Use 'West Side Story'
abstract: New ad campaign for Gap Inc, which will make its debut during Academy Awards program, features two teams of dancers competing in modern rendition of West Side Story; instead of the Jets and the Sharks, opposing gangs are the Jeans and the Khakis (S)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: ASIA    AFGHANISTAN: IMPROVING U.N. RELATIONS -- The top United Nations official in Afghanistan, Francesc Vendrell, said the organization now had offices aiding local government and health services and monitoring human rights in four major cities -- Kabul, Kandahar, Herat and Mazaar-I-Sharif. He also said women were again working with relief agencies, after being barred from jobs outside their homes.   Barbara Crossette (NYT)

headline: No revenues, but shares soar. How does Loch Harris do it?
abstract: Market Place column on Loch Harris Co, which has seen its shares soar since announcing that a subsidiary has developed land mine detector that is to be tested in Croatia; says Loch Harris, which has no revenues, has managed to stay in business with unusual financing method; it has had its shareholders sell some of their shares to public and contribute proceeds to company; in return, company gives investors three more shares for each one sold; company is capitalized at $1.6 billion; president Rodney Boone comments (M)

headline: DaimlerChrysler Reports 16% Rise in 1999 Profit
abstract: DaimlerChrylser says its profit for 1999 increased 16 percent, in line with analysts' expectations; says adjusted net income for 1999, its first full year of operation, increased 16 percent, to 6.2 billion euros, or $6.3 billion, compared with $5.4 billion in 1998; adjusted operating profit increased 20 percent, to 10.32 billion euros, or $10.4 billion; revenue rose 14 percent, to $151 billion; for fourth quarter, adjusted net profit increased 32 percent, to $1.6 billion; revenue rose 20 percent, to $41.7 billion (M)

headline: College Savings, Made Easier
abstract: College savings plans that IRS allowed states to set up four years ago are becoming increasingly popular; while plans are not perfect, they provide substantial tax benefits, with federal taxes on all earnings deferred until withdrawal, when they are taxed at the child's rate (M)

headline: Wal-Mart's Chief Steps Down; Trusted Lieutenant Is Successor
abstract: David D Glass, who expanded Wal-Mart Stores from rural discounter to worldwide powerhouse, announces he will step down immediately as chief executive and president, but will stay on for at least year as chairman of the executive committee of the board; he will be succeeded by his long-trusted lieutenant and chief operating officer, H Lee Scott Jr; photos of both men (M)

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: MIDDLE EAST    ISRAEL: HOLDING ON TO VILLAGE -- Prime Minister Ehud Barak decided against transferring a West Bank village abutting Jerusalem to Palestinian control after rightists said the move would erode Israel's hold on the city and endanger Jewish neighborhoods. Anata, where Palestinians already run civil affairs, was to have come under full Palestinian control as part of a planned handover of another 6.1 percent of the West Bank.   Joel Greenberg (NYT)    PALESTINIANS: ISRAELIS ON SYLLABUS -- The Palestinian culture minister, Yasser Abed Rabbo, said he would introduce Israeli authors into the Palestinian curriculum after a storm in Israel over the addition of a Palestinian poet to the high school syllabus. Yossi Sarid, Israel's education minister, said he and Abed Rabbo were ''partners in the struggle against people living in the past.''   Deborah Sontag (NYT)

headline: Rival Scottish Banks Increase Takeover Bids for NatWest
abstract: Bank of Scotland and Royal Bank of Scotland raise their bids for National Westminster Bank PLC; rival Scottish banks are in heated bidding war for NatWest; Royal Bank raises its bid first, increasing it by 6 percent, to 22.8 billion pounds, or $36.8 billion; offer includes 1.6 billion pounds in cash; Bank of Scotland offers 24.1 billion pounds, or $38.9 billion; its offer is for 14.41 pounds a share, or $23.27, of which 3.56 pounds is in cash (M)

headline: Software That Translates English to 10 Languages
abstract: Babylon.com offers free software to non-English speakers on Web; software translates English into 10 other languages, pulling information from database of more than 3 million words; photo (S)

headline: Three Big Technology Offerings
abstract: Three Big Technology Offerings

headline: PORTUGUESE BANKS CANCEL MERGER
abstract: Major Portuguese banks, Banco Espirito Santo and BPI SGPS, scrap plans for $3.4 billion merger; graph (S)

headline: SAMSUNG CHAIRMAN HAS CANCER
abstract: Samsung Group chairman Lee Kun Hee, who is currently staying in Houston, has lung cancer and has been undergoing chemotherapy in US since Jan 9; photo (S)

headline: Bermuda Move Allows Insurers To Avoid Taxes
abstract: Half-dozen American insurance companies are exploiting loophole in federal tax law by moving headquarters to Bermuda or being acquired by Bermuda insurer to avoid paying income taxes; are exploiting ability to send premiums collected from customers to corporate parents in Bermuda and treat transfer as business expense, even though money is only shifted from one part of company to another; can use savings to offer lower prices to customers or keep prices steady and earn higher profits for shareholders; advantage could force companies based in US to cut prices to compete, resulting in decline in profits; four of biggest insurers--Chubb, Hartford, Kemper and Liberty Mutual--have asked Congress to eliminate tax shelter; say arrangement, while legal, threatens to drastically reduce government's revenues and discriminates against any property and casualty insurer that maintains headquarters in US; Treasury officials estimate all property and casualty insurers could shelter $40 billion annually by shifting operations to Bermuda, avoiding $7 billion in taxes annually; Treasury would be deprived of 4 cents of every dollar income taxes currently collected from corporations of all kinds; state governments would suffer similar financial consequences; chart (M)

headline: Ecuador Coup Shifts Control To No. 2 Man
abstract: Ecuadoran Vice president Gustavo Noboa Bejarno assumes control of government after dissident military officers and Indian groups overthrow elected president Jamil Mahuad; takes office after armed forces chief Gen Carlos Mendoza dissolves three-man junta that briefly led government; Mendoza says move is aimed at preventing international isolation of Ecuador; threats by US and Latin American countries to impose sanctions if constitutional rule was not preserved noted; Noboa becomes sixth chief of state in four years; says he has support of armed forces and national police; Mahuad condemns coup but acknowledges Noboa's authority; coup is Latin America's first overthrow of sitting civilian president in more than decade; comes amid Ecuador's worst economic crisis in more than 70 years; economy contracted by 7.5 percent in 1999, and inflation was more than 80 percent for second consecutive year--worst economic performance in Latin America; country defaulted on half of its $13 billion foreign debt in September 1999; map; photo (M)

headline: Polo Ralph Lauren, NBC Set Internet Venture
abstract: February 7, 2000

headline: SMURFIT-STONE TO BUY ST. LAURENT IN LATEST PAPER DEAL
abstract: Smurfit-Stone Container Corp to buy St Laurent Paperboard Inc for about $1 billion in cash and stock (S)

headline: REVIEW; A Child's Guide to the World of Knowledge
abstract: SIMON & SCHUSTER NEW MILLENNIUM CHILDREN'S ENCYCLOPEDIA AND REFERENCE LIBRARY DELUXE 2000 (Simon & Schuster Interactive; $29.95; Windows 95, 98; ages 8 to 12.)   IF you tend not to read the instructions before you dive into a new piece of software, be prepared: this disc-based encyclopedia's many customization and interactivity options will test the patience of even the most skilled user.

headline: Berkshire Lists Some Holdings In U.S. Filing
abstract: Berkshire Hathaway Inc, company controlled by Warren E Buffett, in Securities and Exchange Commission filing, reports stakes in Citigroup, Liz Claiborne, Jones Apparel Group and Dun & Bradstreet, among others (S)

headline: Airline Wants to Take Web All the Way
abstract: February 8, 2000

headline: Glaxo and SmithKline Agree To Form Largest Drugmaker
abstract: British drugmaker Glaxo Wellcome reportedly agrees to buy one of its chief rivals, SmithKline Beecham, for about $76 billion, creating the world's largest pharmaceutical company; combined company, Glaxo SmithKline, will be a powerhouse in Europe and US, with stock market value of $186 billion and a research and develolpment budget of more than $3.6 billion a year; deal may result in elimination of overlapping jobs among combined companies' 106,000 employees worldwide, but Glaxo SmithKline's ambitious expansion plans in US should mean that few of its nearly 22,000 jobs there will be at risk; table (M)

headline: Personal-Finance Sites, In Search of Novelty
abstract: Numerous Web sites that allow investors to track their investments keep growing, by some accounts there are now 15,000; with so much financial advice, many of new sites are trying to differentiate themselves by zeroing in on specific investment subjects, narrow strategies and esoteric tools; surge has created something of cottage industry as companies vie to track various sites; one of largest is Investorama, which has links to more than 14,000 sites and plans to add 1,800 links soon (M)

headline: LAURA ASHLEY SURGES
abstract: Shares of troubled British retailer Laura Ashley Holdings PLC surge 17 percent after it says that sales in holiday season were better than had been expected; sales rose 11 percent in eight weeks ended Jan 22 at stores open longer than one year (S)

headline: AMERICAN TOPICS : Ivy League Isn't Top Path to Riches
abstract: Is an Ivy League education — which today can cost dollars 120,000 or more — the best investment in terms of future earning capacity? The answer is not as clear as it once appeared.

headline: JAPANESE VEHICLE SALES FALL
abstract: Domestic new vehicle sales fell 1.8 percent in December from a year earlier and 8 percent for all of 1999 as the lingering effects of Japan's recession discouraged consumer spending. Automakers sold 294,397 new cars, trucks and buses for the month and 3,987,731 vehicles in 1999, the third straight yearly decline, the Japan Automobile Dealers Association said.

headline: U.S. Rejects China's Taiwan Views
abstract: Clinton administration and Congress sharply criticize threat by China to forcibly reunify Taiwan with mainland if Beijing determines that negotiations between two are dragging on too long; senior lawmakers say threat could increase chances that Congress will approve legislation expanding ties between US military and Taiwan, despite Pres Clinton's veto threat (S)

headline: END SEEN FOR DAEWOO MOTOR SALE
abstract: Creditor banks and committee overseeing restructuring of South Korea's ailing Daewoo Group plan to complete talks on selling Daewoo Motor Co by Aug or Sept (S)

headline: BMW Shares Soar on Possible Rover Sale
abstract: Shares of BMW AG soar 13.7 percent amid widespread expectations that BMW wil decide on March 16 to sell Rover Cars, its loss-plagued British subsidiary (S)

headline: The Tax Maze Begins Here. No, Here. No . . .
abstract: Much of tax aggenda that Republicans promised in Contract With America has been enacted, but contract's tax breaks have come at price that millions of Americans are discovering as they prepare their tax returns: ever greater complexity; Federal tax laws and regulations filled 40,500 pages when Republicans took charge of Congress in 1995, according to CHH Inc, publisher of tax information; in last five years, 6,400 pages have been added; much of complexity is restimony to political horse-trading by which such tax laws get written; article offers look at some ways tax law has grown muddier over last few years; photos; chart shows income levels where various tax phase-outs begfin (L)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)

headline: Microsoft Said To Offer Plan For Settlement
abstract: Microsoft reportedly presents formal written proposal to settle antitrust suit filed by Justice Department and 19 states that would restrain some of its business practices; proposals are reportedly for changes in conduct; issues in case reviewed; range of remedies proposed by plaintiffs, notably breakup of company, discussed (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Crude oil plunges more than 8 percent after Iran and Saudi Arabia signal that OPEC will produce more oil; in New York, crude oil for April delivery falls $2.87, or 8.4 percent, to $31.26 a barrel; graph; chart (S)

headline: Catching the Technology Tsunami to a Robust '99 Finish
abstract: catching the technology tsunam

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of January 23 Private Sector column about takeover battle involving Societe du Louvre

headline: Interbrew Work For McCann
abstract: Interbrew SA expands its relationship with units of McCann-Erickson North America by assigning creative and media buying duties for several Labatt Breweries beer brands to McCann offices in New York and Toronto; total billings estimated at $45 million (S)

headline: Lucent Wins $100 Million in China Deals
abstract: Lucent Wins $100 Million in China Deals

headline: S3 Sets $500 Million Gain on Taiwan Chipmaker Deal
abstract: January 5, 2000

headline: MEXICO BREWER RAISES PRICES
abstract: Mexico's largest brewer, Grupo Modelo S.A., raised by 16 percent the average domestic price of its 10 beer labels. That increase could help the company strengthen profits because it is 6 percent higher than the Mexican government's 10 percent inflation target for 2000. The price change does not apply to exports. Modelo exports five of its labels, including Corona Extra, the largest-selling imported beer in the United States.     Sam Dillon

headline: INVESTMENT FIRM TO ACQUIRE METAL CASTINGS COMPANIES
abstract: Carlyle Group Inc acquires Trimin Enterprises Inc and Tritech Precision Inc for 285 million Canadian dollar ($195 million); will pay 7.35 Canadian dollars a share for Trimin and 33 Canadian dollars a share for 55.5 percent of Tritech that is publicly traded (S)

headline: The New York Times: Digital Copyright Issues
abstract: The New York Times: Digital Copyright Issues

headline: Sotheby's Joins Christie's In Revising Its Commissions
abstract: Sotheby's revises its commission rates three weeks after Christie's changed its commissions because of federal antitrust investigation; Sotheby's makes rates nearly identical to those of its rival; two houses are under investigation for possibly colluding to set commissions for buyers and sellers on billions of dollars of fine art they auction every year (M)

headline: New Ads for Gap Use 'West Side Story'
abstract: New ad campaign for Gap Inc, which will make its debut during Academy Awards program, features two teams of dancers competing in modern rendition of West Side Story; instead of the Jets and the Sharks, opposing gangs are the Jeans and the Khakis (S)

abstract: ASIA    AFGHANISTAN: IMPROVING U.N. RELATIONS -- The top United Nations official in Afghanistan, Francesc Vendrell, said the organization now had offices aiding local government and health services and monitoring human rights in four major cities -- Kabul, Kandahar, Herat and Mazaar-I-Sharif. He also said women were again working with relief agencies, after being barred from jobs outside their homes.   Barbara Crossette (NYT)

headline: No revenues, but shares soar. How does Loch Harris do it?
abstract: Market Place column on Loch Harris Co, which has seen its shares soar since announcing that a subsidiary has developed land mine detector that is to be tested in Croatia; says Loch Harris, which has no revenues, has managed to stay in business with unusual financing method; it has had its shareholders sell some of their shares to public and contribute proceeds to company; in return, company gives investors three more shares for each one sold; company is capitalized at $1.6 billion; president Rodney Boone comments (M)

headline: DaimlerChrysler Reports 16% Rise in 1999 Profit
abstract: DaimlerChrylser says its profit for 1999 increased 16 percent, in line with analysts' expectations; says adjusted net income for 1999, its first full year of operation, increased 16 percent, to 6.2 billion euros, or $6.3 billion, compared with $5.4 billion in 1998; adjusted operating profit increased 20 percent, to 10.32 billion euros, or $10.4 billion; revenue rose 14 percent, to $151 billion; for fourth quarter, adjusted net profit increased 32 percent, to $1.6 billion; revenue rose 20 percent, to $41.7 billion (M)

headline: College Savings, Made Easier
abstract: College savings plans that IRS allowed states to set up four years ago are becoming increasingly popular; while plans are not perfect, they provide substantial tax benefits, with federal taxes on all earnings deferred until withdrawal, when they are taxed at the child's rate (M)

headline: Wal-Mart's Chief Steps Down; Trusted Lieutenant Is Successor
abstract: David D Glass, who expanded Wal-Mart Stores from rural discounter to worldwide powerhouse, announces he will step down immediately as chief executive and president, but will stay on for at least year as chairman of the executive committee of the board; he will be succeeded by his long-trusted lieutenant and chief operating officer, H Lee Scott Jr; photos of both men (M)

headline: U.N. Trade Meeting Brings Rich and Poor No Closer
abstract: United Nations conference on developing nations concludes, Bangkok, Thailand, with expressions of good will but no real narrowing of differences that split meeting of World Trade Orgn in Seattle in December; delegates offer only general expressions of hope that rich and poor nations might eventually agree on formula that would allow them to share benefits of global trade (M)

headline: Nortel Has Record Quarter
abstract: Nortel Has Record Quarter

headline: @Home Puts Speed Limits on Uploads by Subscribers
abstract: January 21, 2000

headline: JAPAN RATES COULD RISE
abstract: Japanese Finance Min Kiichi Miyazawa stuns bond market by suggesting during testimony before Parliament that long-term interest rates will rise; Miyazawa's comments undercut government's first sale of bonds with five-year maturity, which was intended to attract buyers to market but which produced less demand than expected (S)

headline: Chase in Talks to Buy Robert Fleming, a Surviving British Bank
abstract: Chase Manhattan Corp is negotiating to acquire British asset management and investment banking firm Robert Fleming Holdings; executives close to talks say announcement of purchase could come within a week, though companies might still decide to abandon effort (M)

headline: Muzzle Chafes Chechen War Media
abstract: Two struggles are under way in Chechnya: fierce fight between Russian military and thousands of rebels, and more subtle tug of war between Russian high command and nation's media; every day Russia's journalists do battle with military press service, which regulates access to battlefield and is determined to put out message that Kremlin's war is going according to plan (M)

headline: SOUTH KOREA RAISES RATE
abstract: South Korea's central bank raises one-day call rate, key index for short-term interest rates, to 5 percent from 4.75 percent, first increase since an economic crisis started in December 1997 (S)

headline: By Any Measure, a Big Deal
abstract: Press release issued by Time Warner Inc and America Online put merger at $350 billion; but few, if any, media reports agree on value; most estimates are close to value of $165 billion that New York Times placed on deal (S)

headline: Police Turn Over Mexico University to Professors and Students
abstract: Federal police withdraw from Mexico's national university after three-day occupation, returning control to administration officials who have been exiled since April by student strike (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: US dollar is little changed on expectations that inflation will be kept in check; in New York, euro settles at 96.02 cents, down from 96.41; dollar trades at 106.90 yen, down from 106.93; graph; chart (S)

headline: Russia Sees Imminent Capture of Grozny, and of Rebels Inside
abstract: Russian military says it has thwarted rebel attempt to break out of besieged city of Grozny and will soon capture it (M)

headline: Dana Decides to Sell a Truck-Parts Unit
abstract: Dana Corp, world's biggest maker of light-truck axles, agrees to sell truck-parts unit to affiliate of Hidden Creek Industries; financial terms undisclosed (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Dow Industrials Drop 3.7% On Worries About Profits  The Dow Jones industrial average plunged 374.47 points, or 3.7 percent, to 9,796.03, on investor fears that rising oil prices combined with higher interest rates may do significant damage to corporate profits. Broader market averages fared a bit better. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index lost 2.6 percent of its value, and the Nasdaq composite index lost 1.2 percent.    The decline began when Procter & Gamble said that its earnings in the current quarter would come in well below Wall Street expectations. Adding to investor anxiety, oil prices soared to $34.13 a barrel. [Page A1.]

headline: INVESTING WITH: Steven L. Kirson and Michael J. Mufson; Putnam OTC Emerging Growth Fund
abstract: investing with: steven

headline: World Briefing
abstract: EUROPE    NORTHERN IRELAND: TRIMBLE CHALLENGED -- David Trimble will face a bid to oust him as leader of the Ulster Unionists at a meeting of the party council in Belfast tomorrow from a fierce opponent of the peace accord. Mr. Trimble will be challenged by the Rev. Martin Smyth, above, a former grand master of the militantly Protestant Orange Order. The move threatens further damage to the pact, now stalemated over paramilitary arms.   Warren Hoge (NYT)

headline: Battle Over I.M.F.
abstract: President Clinton has vowed to block the man Europe wants to head the International Monetary Fund, a German finance ministry official, setting off a contest for control of the institution. But the United States is not yet backing an alternate candidate who is an American.  Business Day, Page C1.

headline: NEXT NEW ERA; Spinning Off Can Mean Big Money, but Big Danger Too
abstract: Article on problems faced by brick-and-mortar companies seeking to establish Internet retail presence; they face urgent problem of how much distance to put between themselves and their online operations; decision by Wal-Mart to set up Internet outlet discussed (Special Section, E-Commerce); photo (M)

headline: NATO General Hopes G.I.'s Will Return to Kosovo Town
abstract: Senior UN and Western officials say Pentagon has refused to allow American troops to return to northern Mitrovica, section dominated by Serbs in divided town that has become flash point for ethnic tensions in Kosovo, Serbia; Gen Klaus Reinhardt, German commander of NATO-led peacekeeping forces who has worked to internationalize troops in Mitrovica, says negotiations are continuing; Americans have been criticized for aggressive tactics during recent weapons search, during which they were attacked by angry Serbs and withdrew; maps; photo (M)

headline: A Pioneer, Unheralded, In Technology And Activism
abstract: Profile of Frederick Moore Jr, founder of Homebrew Club in 1975, in which he presented computers as way to help pull world together and advocated use of personal computers in political organizing; says Moore's original communitarian vision of power of personal computers has re-emerged to challenge computer industry's status quo, in form of free software movement; regrets that Moore, who had seminal impact on computer industry and antiwar movement in 1960's, did not receive an obituary in any of three major Bay Area, San Francisco, newspapers when he was killed in traffic accident in 1997; Moore photo (M)

headline: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: AMERICAS; ONLINE TRADING ADVANCES IN MEXICO
abstract: Securities regulators in Mexico announce rules governing online trading, effective April 3; nation's largest bank, Grupo Banamex-Accival, which in January became first to offer Internet stock trading in Mexico, says rules issued by securities commission will lead to expansion of online trading (S)

headline: Chief Leaving No. 2 Online Bookseller
abstract: Barnesandnoble.com's chief executive Jonathan Bulkeley announces his departure; Stephen Riggio, brother of Barnes & Noble Inc chairman-chief executive Leonard Riggio, will step in as acting chief executive until replacement is found (M)

headline: RENAULT EXAMINES SAMSUNG
abstract: Four-member team from French carmaker Renault arrives in Seoul to look over ailing Samsung Motors Inc; companies have been in takeover talks since December (S)

headline: Russian City Buries Hero, Firm in Faith in the War
abstract: Capt Roman Sokolov and seven other Russian soldiers who were killed in Chechnya are buried in Pskov, Russia; they are among 84 Russian soldiers who died in single action in early March in one of Russia's worst defeats in its Chechen campaign; photo (M)

headline: Artists Find Scientific Support for High-Tech Projects
abstract: February 3, 2000

headline: $3.47 Billion Bid for Italian Conglomerate
abstract: Compart, Italian holding company, offers to pay $3.47 billion for 100 percent ownership of Montedison, one of Europe's biggest energy and food conglomerates (S)

headline: CHOICEPOINT AGREES TO BUY DBT ONLINE FOR $423 MILLION
abstract: ChoicePoint Inc acquires DBT Online Inc for about $423 million in stock (S)

headline: Presidential Election Could Alter Shape of Tribune-Times Mirror Deal
abstract: Fate of Tribune Co's largest television stations and Times Mirror's largest newspapers in Tribune's acquisition of Times Mirror may depend on presidential election; Vice Pres Al Gore favors keeping current restrictions on companies that own both television stations and newspapers, which would likely force merged company to sell papers or stations in New York, Los Angeles and Hartford; Gov George W Bush, apparent Republican nominee, is tilting against current rules (M)

headline: BARAK PARTY TOLD IT IS UNDER INQUIRY OVER ITS FINANCES
abstract: Prime Minister Ehud Barak's party is fined and placed under criminal investigation after state comptroller, Eliezer Goldberg, issues a blistering account of what he calls violations of campaign finance laws during 1999 elections; Goldberg does not implicate Barak personally, and there is no immediate political threat to him; but Goldberg holds him accountable for what he describes a 'trampling of the law' by his One Israel Party, and fines party $3.2 million; Goldberg charges that Barak's associates systematically circumvented strict campaign finance restrictions by channeling illegal contributions into host of nonprofit orgns; photos of Barak and Goldberg (M)

headline: Week's Schedule Of Equity Offerings
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:    Allscripts Inc., Libertyville, Ill., 2.4 million shares. Goldman, Sachs & Co.

headline: NATIONAL COMMERCE TO BUY CCB FINANCIAL
abstract: National Commerce Bancorporation, parent of National Bank of Commerce, acquires CCB Finanical Corp of Durham, NC, for $1.95 billion (S) y

headline: Siemens-Mannesmann Link Is Set
abstract: Siemens says its auto-parts unit plans partnership with VDO, Mannesmann's auto-parts business; Siemens and Mannesmann's Atecs unit will reportedly hold equal stakes in VDO (S)

headline: Boat People Losing (Uneasy) Haven
abstract: Hong Kong announces that it will close its last remaining camp for Vietnamese refugees, ending drama that began in May 1975, month after fall of Saigon, when first boat laden with refugees came ashore in Hong Kong; about 224,000 Vietnamese refugees came to Hong Kong; most of these went on to settle in United States, Canada and other countries; at its peak in 1979, there were 68,695 refugees crowded into camps throughout colony; photo (M)

headline: Productivity In 4th Quarter Revised Higher
abstract: Labor Department reports worker productivity in fourth quarter of 1999 grew at fastest pace in seven years and labor costs fell for second consecutive quarter; productivity rose at revised annual rate of 6.4 percent, up from 5 percent in third quarter; Federal Reserve says consumer debt surged $17 billion in January, biggest rise in almost five years; unit labor costs fell in fourth quarter at 2.5 percent rate, after 0.3 percent drop in third quarter; graph (M)

headline: Shopping With Priceline: Promise and Problems
abstract: David Donner letter on Michelle Slatalla's Jan 6 article details his problems shopping for groceries on Priceline.com

headline: Top Executive Quits Penguin To Take Over AOL Division
abstract: Michael Lynton, the executive who traded Hollywood movies for New York book publishing, shifted industries again yesterday to become president of the international division of America Online.    After more than three years as the chief executive of Pearson's book publishing arm, the Penguin Putnam Group, Mr. Lynton, who is 40, said yesterday that he was leaving to explore his fascination with the Internet.

headline: Miscellany
abstract: The Ad Store, New York, formed an alliance with World Writers Ltd., London, to form Ad Store Wideworld, London, which will develop the creative part of campaigns for Ad Store clients in Europe and around the world. Simon Anholt, president at World Writers, will lead the venture as president.

headline: World Briefing
abstract: EUROPE    GERMANY: CHRISTIAN DEMOCRATS ELECT AIDE -- The embattled Christian Democratic Union elected Friedrich Merz, left, a 44-year-old financial expert, to lead its parliamentary group. Mr. Merz replaces Wolfgang Schauble, who quit after admitting taking illicit cash payments for the party. The successor to Mr. Schauble in the separate, and more important, post of party chairman will be decided in March.   Roger Cohen (NYT)

headline: My Web: An Unscientific Shopping Sampler by Intel Science Talent Search Finalists
abstract: Lucas Hanft, finalist in Intel science talent search, comments on some advantages and disadvantages of e-commerce (Special Section, E Commerce); photo (S)

headline: A World Without End For Fans of Jane Austen
abstract: Fans of English novelist Jane Austen have taken to Web to extend her limited oeuvre, creating online libraries of hundreds of stories inspired by her six completed novels; stories are example of widespread Web phenomenon known as fan fiction, creative writing using existing characters; photos (M)

headline: Reflection of the Decline of British Cars
abstract: Article on decline of British auto industry in wake of Ford Motor Co's acquisition of Rover Group PLC from BMW AG and Alchemy Partners' takeover of Rover's Longbridge plant outside Birmingham in central England; photo (M)

headline: Severance Package Set for Mirage Chief
abstract: Mirage Resorts chairman Stephen Wynn is eligible for $11.3 million severance package, triple his annual pay, when casino company MGM Grand completes its planned $6.4 billion acquisition of Mirage; Wynn can also require MGM Grand to buy his home and furnishings, situated on exclusive golf course that Mirage owns outside Las Vegas; Wynn has right to buy Mirage Resorts' Gulfstream III aircraft and company's apartment in Manhattan (S)

headline: Hollywood Greets Online Entrepreneurs
abstract: Yahoo Internet Life Online Film Festival in Hollywood attracts some 50 companies that offer some form of online films, and a host of partnerships or acquisitions are announced; photos (M)

headline: Thomson Set To Sell Off Newspapers
abstract: NEW YORK—  Thomson Corp. said Tuesday it would sell its remaining newspapers except for its flagship Toronto daily, The Globe and Mail, completing its reorientation from a publisher to an information provider for businesses.

headline: NatWest Is Said To Concede It Will Be Bought
abstract: National Westminster Bank PLC privately concedes defeat in its effort to stave off hostile suitor, Royal Bank of Scotland; NatWest reverses its opposition to merging, acknowledging that Royal bank's 22.8 billion pound ($36.9 billion) bid will prevail; NatWest has been battling hostile bids by Royal Bank and Bank of Scotland; it is increasingly likely that Royal Bank will be able to claim victory by Feb 14, deadline for NatWest shareholders to tender their shares (M)

headline: Out There in Never-Bell Land; Where Phone Service Is Way Above Average, and Competitive
abstract: More than 1,000 small, independent telephone companies like Richmond Telephone Co in Massachusetts still do business, mostly in rural areas of country; each incumbent, as they are known in industry, handles as few as 60 access lines or as many as 50,000, and altogether they serve nearly five million customers; many are family-run companies, dating to early 1900's, that were never part of Ma Bell system, were never bought out by competitors and were basically left to their own devices; how Richmond Telephone is beginning to compete with Bell Atlantic throughout Berkshire County, Mass, discussed; chart; photos (M)

headline: Former G.M. Executive Forms Web Site for Minority Suppliers
abstract: Roy S Roberts, former General Motors executive, announces formation of Internet company called M-Xchange.com that will aim to make it easier for largest American companies to buy parts and suppliers from minority-owned companies; start-up company has backing of Rev Jesse Jackson; site is expected to begin service in mid-July (M)

headline: Palestinians Given Own Internet Domain
abstract: March 22, 2000

headline: Short-Term Treasury Prices Rise Amid Optimism on Inflation
abstract: Most Treasury securities rise in price; benchmark 30-year bond slips 4/32, to 101 20/32; yield rises to 6.13 percent, up one-hundredth of a percentage point from Feb 23; graph on Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp participation certificates; chart on US key interest rates (M)

headline: New Electronic Stock Market to Be Formed
abstract: Archipelago, electronic trading network, says it will form what it calls first fully electronic stock market with Pacific Exchange, nation's number 4 stock exchange in terms of activity; new market will match buyers and sellers electronically and challenge traditional markets like New York Stock Exchange and Instinet Corp of Reuters Group; Archipelago will operate Pacific Exchange's equity market (M)

headline: SOCIETE GENERALE TO LIST
abstract: Societe Generale SA, number 3 French bank, plans to list its shares on Tokyo Stock Exchange on Feb 1, becoming first company to join foreign section of exchange in three years (S)

headline: A German-Canadian Fights Extradition: He's a Key Figure in Kohl Case
abstract: Karlheinz Schreiber, millionaire German arms broker, is fighting extradition from Canada to testify in corruption investigation of former Chancellor Helmut Kohl; Schreiber acknowledges handing envelope stuffed with one million marks to Christian Democratic emissaries in Swiss restaurant in 1991, but says it was campaign money, not bribe; photo (M)

headline: Filing Offers a Way to Find Microsoft Violated the Law
abstract: Laurence Lessig, Harvard legal scholar and software expert, tells Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson, judge in Microsoft Corp antitrust case, that Microsoft's decision to bundle its Web browser into Windows operating system has 'obvious benefits' to computer programmers and consumers; but he then proceeds to provide legally innovative road map for determining that bundling strategy violated the law; court filing offers 45-page analysis of how antitrust law on product 'tying' should apply to case; antitrust experts say wide-ranging document will probably provide both sides with some legal ammunition (M)

headline: An international design agency's name becomes a shadow of itself in a move to bolster its identity.
abstract: International design and image firm, Desgrippes Gobe & Associates, will be renamed d/g* effective April 4 as part of campaign to heighten awareness of agency's services (M)

headline: In the Beginning: The Origins of the Internet
abstract: J D Biersdorfer reviews television program tracing origins of Internet, The Internet: Behind the Web, on History Channel; photo (M)

headline: Dell, It Turns Out, Has a Better Idea Than Ford
abstract: Article on General Motors Corp's decision last week to seek growth through alliances and partnerships; says decision is similar to strategy developed by Dell Computer Inc that does not use distributors or retailers and spares expense of inventory of finished goods; holds its supplier system keeps investment in materials to bare minimum, depending on close tracking of customer demand and sharing that intelligence with its suppliers; photo (M)

headline: Plan for Free Access in Britain
abstract: March 7, 2000

headline: As They Say, a Good Mentor Is Hard to Find
abstract: Article on Gerald Abood, senior director at Wisconsin Electric Power Co, focuses on how his daughters, Natasha Schmidt, Madonna Boyd, Lori Poirier and Tami Keller, have been influenced by his management expertise; photo (M)

headline: More Bodies Found From Uganda Cult; Murder Is Suspected
abstract: More Bodies Found From Uganda Cult** Ugandan police discover 153 additional bodies of members of doomsday cult Movement for the Restoration of the Ten Commandments of God in shallow graves on land belonging to sect outside headquarters in Kanungu, where hundreds recently died in fire in makeshift church; say victims, including at least 59 children, were murdered; say mounting mounting evidence indicates fire at church was not mass suicide as first believed (M) previously believed (M)

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; Panel Rules Against Interpublic Group
abstract: American Arbitration Association rules against Interpublic Group of Companies in contract dispute with Martin Sloves, former top agency executive; Sloves was chairman of Lowe & Partners/SMS, unit of Lowe Group division of Interpublic now known as Lowe Lintas & Partners; after Sloves retired in late 1998, Lowe lost $125 million account of longtime client, Mercedes-Benz, to Merkley Newman Harty; Interpublic accused Sloves of persuading Mercedes-Benz to leave Lowe and refused to pay him under terms of consulting agreement; association rejects Interpublic's claim that Sloves breached his contract and rules in favor of Sloves in counterclaim against Interpublic (S)

headline: Citigroup Plans To Purchase Schroders Unit
abstract: Citigroup will acquire last independent investment bank in London from Schroders PLC for about $2.21 billion; purchase of Schroders investment banking business is being structured as merger of that operation with Citigroup's Salomon Smith Barney investment banking unit; in Europe, combined operation will be known as Schroders Salomon Smith Barney and will co-managed by executives from each firm; Citigroup reports net income for fourth quarter rose to $2.62 billion from $677 million in fourth quarter of 1998; corporate and investment bank, which includes Salomon Smith Barney, earned $1.31 billion, more than double $553 million a year earlier; consumer businesses had profit from operations of $1.17 billion, up 35 percent from $872 million; Paine Webber Group also posts better-than-expected quarterly earnings; fourth-quarter earnings increased 66 percent, to $166.3 million from $100.4 million; revenue increased 27 percent, to $1.39 billion from $1.1 billion in year-earlier quarter; Charles Schwab Corp reports fourth-quarter net income of $170 million, up 60 percent from $106 million; revenue rose 43 percent, to $1.13 billion (M)

headline: Russian Justice: Crime and Harassment
abstract: Interview with Timur Dakhkilgov, who was born in Grozny, Chechnya, and was arrested and imprisoned by Russian police for series of bombings in Moscow despite innocence, before he was exonerated and released after three months; he is among many from Causasus who are routinely stopped for document checks, forced to pay bribes to corrupt policemen and apprehended on slightest suspicion; photo (M)

headline: NYT Article
abstract: Gates Unveils Latest Version of Windows

headline: Group of 7 Nations Seek Their Own Paths to a Common Goal
abstract: Leaders of Group of Seven industrialized countries meet in Tokyo; issue statements that underscore fact that, despite their collective expressions of good will, global economy still remains subservient to national interests (M)

headline: Flood Survivors Find Only Ruin In Mozambique
abstract: Floods in Mozambique washes away approximately one-third of country's crops, drowns more than 40,000 head of cattle and wipes out 141 schools in devastation that will have staggering economic consequences; gross domestic product is likely to shrink significantly in country heralded as one Africa's success stories as thousands find themselves without work or place to live; ongoing relief efforts discussed; photos; maps (M)

headline: HIGHEST KOREAN GROWTH IN 12 YEARS
abstract: Bank of Korea says South Korea's economy recorded highest growth rate in 12 years in 1999; nation's economy grew 10.7 percent, rebounding after contraction of 6.7 percent in 1998, during economic recession; gross domestic product rose 13 percent compared with fourth quarter of previous year (S)

headline: Hitting It Big
abstract: Have an idea to sell something over the Internet: furniture, groceries, greeting cards, junk? In a year of Internet frenzy, paper millionaires were minted almost daily as companies with nary a profit and often no sales issued stock to the public and watched it soar. But the most likely route to riches seemed to be creating a company that would provide services to other companies exploiting the Web.    Akamai Technologies hit it right with a process to speed up delivery of content over the Internet. It was begun by an M.I.T. professor, Thomson Leighton, and a student, Daniel Lewin, each of whom held 9.6 million shares, according to a regulatory filing. If they have held on, those stakes are now worth $3.145 billion each. The stock rose 458 percent on its first day of trading in late October, and by the end of the year, it was up 1,160 percent. On average, I.P.O.'s gained 67 percent in their first day of trading this year.

headline: RADIO ONE TO BUY 12 CLEAR CHANNEL STATIONS
abstract: Radio One Inc acquires 12 radio stations for $1.3 billion from Clear Channel Communications Inc; Clear Channel is selling stations to win regulatory approval for takeover of AMFM Inc; Radio One will own 48 stations after close of Clear Channel purchase and two other acquisitions announced on March 13 (S)

headline: Officials Identify 1 Computer Site
abstract: Law enforcement authorities say computer system at University of California at Santa Barbara was used as conduit in recent attacks on several leading Web sites (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Japanese yen falls to five-month low against dollar and three-week low against euro on concern Japan's economy is slipping back into recession; yen falls to 109.35 a dollar from 108.78 in New York trading; graph; chart (S)

headline: How You Know It's Time to Sell
abstract: Car, British auto magazine, in article prior to BMW's success in finding someone willing to take Rover off its hands, noted that if BWM had paid each of Rover's employees 30,000 pounds to stay at home last year, the company would have lost less money (S)

headline: U.S. Official Dims His View of Russia's Future
abstract: Deputy Sec of State Strobe Talbott presents wary assessment of Russia in annual review, hinting at possible return of some Soviet habits; says war in Chechnya and transfer of power to Acting Pres Vladimir V Putin raises questions of how resurgence of Russian nationalism will assert itself; says one consistent theme among many of Putin's inconsistencies is his desire to see Russia regain its strength and its sense of national pride and purpose (M)

headline: Israeli Says U.S. Fears Endanger Major Purchase of Apache Copters
abstract: Israeli Maj Gen Eitan Ben-Eliahu says US reluctance to share secret military software with Israel threatens possible $800 million Israeli purchase of Boeing combat helicopters (M)

headline: Talks Stall At Boeing, And Engineers Go On Strike
abstract: More than 16,000 engineers and technical workers at Boeing Co go on strike after contract negotiations break down over wages and health care coverage; walkout, only second in last 56 years for Society of Professional Engineering Employees in Aerospace union, is not expected to hurt Boeing's in the near-term; photo (M)

abstract: the turmo4

headline: CLARIANT TO BUY BTP
abstract: Clariant AG, Swiss specialty chemical giant, will buy a British rival, BTP PLC, for $1.8 billion in cash, cementing its lead in the $36 billion market for base chemicals supplied to manufacturers of drugs (S)

headline: Orthodox Branches Join for Holy Day
abstract: Religious

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: THE EURO GAINS. The dollar tumbled against the euro as sinking United States bonds pulled down stocks and curbed demand for dollars. In New York, the euro settled at $1.0259, up from $1.0092 on Friday.

headline: Times Company Digital Selects an Agency
abstract: Times Co Digital, New York Times unit, names Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide to handle its United States advertising account (S)

headline: George Foerstner, 91, Amana Founder and Advocate of the Microwave Oven
abstract: George Foerstner, entrepreneur who founded Amana Appliances during Depression and led it for 48 years while introducing microwave oven and side-by-side refrigerator, dies at age 91; photo (M)

headline: Intel to Build $2 Billion Chip Plant in Arizona
abstract: Intel to Build $2 Billion Chip Plant in Arizona

headline: New Director May Shake Up Meeting of Mattel's Board
abstract: Embattled board of Mattel Inc, which will meet on March 30, faces agenda that is likely to include company's depressed stock price, unsuccessful search for new chief executive and any further problems that might be lurking at Learning Company, troubled computer software subsidiary; company has been rudderless since chief executive Jill E Barad resigned in February (M)

headline: Optimist Then. Optimist Now.
abstract: Market Insight question-and-answer article with Laszlo Birinyl Jr, who runs his own research firm and serves as global strategist for Deutsche Bank Securities; Birinyl last year correctly forecast levels that came close to what markets actually did in 1999; discusses his 1999 forecasts; photo (M)

headline: Inefficient English Programs Being Revised : Koreans Redouble Efforts To Conquer Language Bar
abstract: SEOUL—  In a country where everyone studies English grammar from primary school through high school, Koreans are awakening to a disturbing reality: No one can speak it without private language lessons, and the ability to use it has become a requirement for everything from college to the workplace.

headline: CHILE ENTERS RECESSION
abstract: Chile's economy contracted 1.1 percent in 1999, country's first recession since early 1980's (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: CRUDE OIL GAINS***Petroleum prices surge to highest levels since Persian Gulf war, raising concerns about worsening inflation; crude oil gains 69 cents, or 2.4 percent, to $29.54 a barrel; graph; chart (S)

headline: Expansion Provided 387,000 New Jobs In U.S. Last Month
abstract: Labor Department reports number of new jobs jumped in Jan by 387,000, while unemployment rate fell to 4 percent, lowest level in 30 years, from 4.1 percent; Labor Sec Alexis Herman says labor market, despite low unemployment, is not inflationary, interview; holds ususually warm mid-Jan weather drove up job growth; employment graphs and tables (M)

headline: Major Overture Toward Iran Expected in Speech by Albright
abstract: United States Secretary of State Madeleine K Albright will make a major overture to Iran on March 17 by announcing that Clinton administration will lift several sanctions on Tehran; administration officials say she will also acknowledge that United States was shortsighted in its support for Iraq during Iran-Iraq war and its involvement in 1953 coup in Iran (M)

headline: I.L.O., Long in Eclipse, Regains Some Prominence
abstract: International Labor Organization, marginalized by decades of obscure work and lack of enforcement power, has recently gained some renewed prominence for possible future role in helping police way nations protect workers' rights; organization, in rush of public concern over globalization, has found that its work to promote basic labor rights in all countries is suddenly relevant; part of reason is debate in both rich and poor nations over whether minimum labor standards can or should be linked to trade; unions are pressing for stronger worker protection in global trade pacts, idea resisted by developing countries; debate comes as organization is striving to change under new leader Juan Somavia; photo (M)

headline: Acquisition by Lucent
abstract: Lucent Technologies acquires DeltaKabel TeleCom of Netherlands; financial terms undisclosed (S)

headline: India Tries to Plug a Cash Drain: Its Power System
abstract: Indian state of Uttar Pradesh refuses to back down in its move to break up State Electricity Board and turn over power distribution to private companies; throughout India, billions of dollars worth of electricity is stolen each year by consumers in league with utility workers, bureaucrats and politicians; in Uttar Pradesh, more than 40 percent of power generated is pilfered; hope is that private companies would not tolerate unbridled thefts of power that would endanger their bottom lines (M)

headline: In Chechnya's Shattered Capital, Survivors See Their Own Reflection
abstract: Article on plight of Grozny residents following fall of Chechen capital to Russian soldiers; notes that Human Rights Watch says it has confirmed killing of over 40 Chechen civilians by Russian soldiers in one Grozney district alone; photos (M)

abstract: January 14, 2000

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Gold falls to its lowest price in three and a half months after report that French government is under pressure to sell some reserves; in New York, gold for April delivery falls $4.60, to $280.50 an ounce; graph; chart (S)

headline: INVESTMENT GROUP TO BUY MAJORITY STAKE IN RIGHTWORKS
abstract: Internet Capital Group Inc acquires majority stake in RightWorks for $657 million in stock and cash (S)

headline: Former iVillage Officials Sue the Company
abstract: Data Network to Use Code to Insure Privacy

headline: Montreal Journal; Trudeaumania Lingers but the Policies Fade Fast
abstract: Mystique of former prime minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau remains strong among Canadians, three decades after Trudeaumania swept country; has been fed partly by celebrations for his 80th birthday, his reclusiveness and sympathy for death of youngest son; he ranks as best prime minister of century in poll of Canadians, who also rank him fourth in poll for person of millennium; while his big-government economic policies are in retreat and his bilingual policy has failed to blunt Quebec separatism, preoccupation with his legacy reflects how much Trudeaumania stamped two generations that will lead Canada into new century; photo (M)i

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Is the Online Auction King Ebay Going Once? Twice? Not Likely
abstract: Financiers close to eBay says sale of company to Yahoo is unlikely; they say eBay is still trying to figure out deal that would let it tap into Yahoo's huge audience of Internet users, as it has already done with America Online and Disney's Go Network; outright sale is far less likely, because eBay's $26 billion market value makes it expensive acquisition (Market Place column) (M)

headline: U.S. INTERACTIVE AGREES TO BUY SOFTPLUS FOR $372 MILLION
abstract: US Interactive Inc, Internet consulting firm founded by Vice Pres Al Gore's technology adviser Eric Pulier, acquires SoftPlus Inc for about $372 million in stock, cash and new debt (S)

headline: The New York Times - Reporter Biography: Pamela Mendels
abstract: Pamela Mendels, a Manhattan-based writer, covers education, government, censorship and civil rights issues for CyberTimes.

headline: Disney to Focus Go.com on Entertainment Segment
abstract: January 27, 2000

headline: The Murky Tale of Taiwan: Island With an Unruly Past
abstract: While China, US and most countries worldwide hold that Taiwan is part of China, its connections with mainland historically have been tenuous; island's relationship with China, dating back to 1683, discussed (S)

headline: U.S. and Mexico Are at Odds Over Truth About Lie Tests
abstract: Rep John L Mica, chairman of House committee with oversight over drug policy, says Mexico canceled program of giving its anti-drug agents lie detector tests, embarrassed that its agents were failing tests; Mica's assertions come on same day Mexico is officially certified by Pres Clinton as reliable partner in war against drugs; Mexican government denies Mica's claim (M)

headline: Moscow Takes Step To Ease U.S. Fears On Plutonium Use
abstract: Russia promises to stop making plutonium out of fuel from its civilian power reactors, in major agreement aimed at safeguarding nuclear fuel that could be used to make weapons; agreement is part of $100 million joint research and aid package from US; represents Energy Department's first major attempt to secure Russia's huge civilian stockpile of plutonium, from which 3,000 nuclear weapons could be made; Clinton administration and arms experts laud agreement; say it will place added pressure on other nuclear powers to follow suit; part of accord is contingent on end to new sales and transfers of nuclear technology to Iran which US believes is helping Teheran to acquire nuclear weapons (M)

headline: Resorting to Typing
abstract: My Job column profiles Ann Berrios, secretary at State University of New York at Stony Brook; Berrios comments; photo (M)

headline: Agreement Bars Using Children as Soldiers
abstract: Negotiators in Geneva agree on new international accord barring use of child soldiers in war; US drops opposition to setting 18 as minimum age for sending soldiers into combat, after months of pressure from Pentagon to keep age 17 as option; Joint Chiefs of Staff accept compromise allowing recruitment and training of 17-year-olds as long as 'all feasible measures' are taken to keep them out of combat; new minimum will have little real effect on US military (M)

headline: Starcom Changes In Europe and China
abstract: Starcom Worldwide, media services unit of Leo Group, is making changes in Europe and China; Starcom will merge its British operations with Motive in London, media services unit of Bartle Bogle Hegarty, which is 49 percent owned by Leo; merged media agency, Starcom Motive Partnership, will handle accounts with billings estimated at $700 million; Mark Cranmer will become managing director for Starcom Motive and Starcom Europe, Middle East and Africa (S)

headline: How 'The Big Mo' Took the Top Prize
abstract: Mark Hulbert (Strategies) article on merits of momentum investing; says each of newsletters atop the performance rankings of Hulbert Financial Digest for the 5,10 and 15 years through 1999 uses a momentum-based strategy; notes two factors researchers link to success of momentum stocks; says newsletters consider stock to have momentum it it has outperformed market over previous 6 to 12 months; graph (M)

headline: RPC TO SPIN OFF CHAPARRAL, A BOAT BUILDER
abstract: RPC Inc to spin off its Chaparral Boats Inc unit to shareholders in third quarter and focus on its service and equipment business for oil fields; companies will trade separately on New York Stock Exchange (S)

headline: Harare Journal; Zimbabwe's Sad Lack: Land to Bury AIDS Victims
abstract: Granville Cemetery in Harare, Zimbabwe, is filling up much faster than expected because of continued devastation of AIDS; disease is taking 2,500 lives a week, and quarter of country's 6 million adults are believed to be infected with HIV virus; no country in Africa has been harder hit by AIDS over last two decades; photo (M)

headline: 3 Copyright Lawsuits Test Limits of New Digital Media
abstract: Entertainment industry is struggling to protect its products and profits in Internet age, while consumer groups accuse industry of interfering with free speech and people's rights to control their watching or listening experience; three lawsuits now in play deal with different aspects of protecting copyrighted works; at heart of each is question of what framework will govern distribution of digital content; right to make personal copies of music, movies and other programs is at issue (M)

headline: China's Statement: 'The Right to Resort to Any Necessary Means'
abstract: Excerpts from statement by Chinese Government warning Taiwan against indefinite postponement of decision to reunite with mainland (M)

headline: Treasuries Rise Slightly Despite Study On Production
abstract: US Treasury securities, with exception of 30-year bond, are mostly higher in choppy trading; price of 30-year bond falls 9/32, to 101 10/32; yield rises to 6.15 percent from 6.14 percent; chart on US key interest rates (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: METROMEDIA FIBER NETWORK INC., White Plains, a fiber optic cable company, acquired the closely held network builder M.I.B.H. Inc. for about $51 million in cash and stock.

headline: MANAGEMENT: Joy for Second-String M.B.A.'s; Elites and Internet Change Face of Campus Recruiting
abstract: Major consulting firms and investment banks once recruited almost exclusively among students at top business schools, but as more of them are lured by Internet start-ups, firms are turning to lesser-known MBA programs like Indiana University's Kelley School of Business; graph; photo (M)

headline: DVD Killed Video's Star; A Digital Step in Making the VCR Obsolete
abstract: Like many movie lovers, Victor Rosa has run through most of the titles available at the local video store.     But not long ago, Mr. Rosa, the assistant manager of a fast-food chain restaurant in midtown Manhattan, found himself at a Blockbuster outlet near Times Square renting  ''Enemy of the State,'' a 1998 thriller he had watched on his VCR before. Now, thanks to a Christmas gift from his wife, he was eager to see the movie again.

headline: Western Suitors Appear Victors in Polish Bank Bids
abstract: Citigroup will acquire Bank Handlowy in $900 million deal and Deutsche Bank will acquire BIG Bank Gdanski AS; both will become key players in Poland's banking industry; merger terms noted (M)

headline: Stocks Drop Sharply Amid Concern Over Rates
abstract: Stock prices fall sharply in very heavy trading as investors shed positions in wide array of sectors, but especially technology, in expectation that Federal Reserve will soon increase short-term interest rates; Dow Jones industrial drops 243.54 points, to 11,008.17; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index drops 39.83 points, to 1,401.53; Nasdaq composite index drops 139.32 points, to 4,096.08; graph; table (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Crude oil rises on expectations that oil producers will not increase production next month enough to avoid shortages; in New York, crude oil for April rises 43 cents, or 1.4 percent, to $31.69 a barrel; graph; chart (S)

headline: Taking a New Look At Some Easy Targets
abstract: Despite conglomerates having a bad image as inefficient, study by Larry Shulman of Boston Consulting Group, refutes those perceptions; Shulman looked at performance of Value Line Diversified Companies Index, proxy for conglomerates, and compared it with Standard & Poor's 500-stock index for 10 years through 1997; found conglomerate index was the winner in average annualized return, 18.6 percent to 17.6 percent; also found that from 1989 to 1996 conglomerates that broken up were just as likely to underperform market as to outperform it; photo (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: WELLS FARGO & CO., San Francisco, the seventh-largest United States bank, said it would buy back as many as 81 million, or 5 percent, of its shares, worth as much as $2.77 billion at current prices.

headline: DIEBOLD PURCHASES EUROPEAN A.T.M. BUSINESSES
abstract: Diebold Inc agrees to buy automated teller machine operations and products of Getronics NV of Netherlands and Groupe Bull of France for about $160 million (S)

headline: Cisco's Revenue and Profit Soar, as Do Its Shares After Hours
abstract: Cisco Systems surpasses earnings estimates and reports 53 percent gain in revenue for second quarter ended Jan 29, prompting investors to send it shares to 52-week high; for quarter, Cisco reports earnings of $825 million, nearly three times $282 million in period a year earlier; sales rose 53 percent, to $4.35 billion, from $2.85 billion in 1999's second quarter; company also announces 2-for-1 stock split, its ninth since going public in February 1990 (M)

headline: Thomson Expected to Buy Sylvan Testing Unit
abstract: Thomson Corp is expected to announce $775 million acquisition of Sylvan Prometic, computer-based testing company owned by Sylvan Learning Systems (M)

headline: Fiat and GM Are Poised to Form Alliance
abstract: ROME—  General Motors Corp. and Fiat SpA are expected to announce a strategic alliance and stock swap in the auto sector, which would end the Italian company's long isolation as a lone carmaker lacking the critical mass to prosper on global markets.

headline: Survey Shows Americans Love Their Computers and the Net
abstract: Survey sponsored by National Public Radio finds Americans--especially working Americans--are having 'love affair' with computers and the Internet; says about 87 percent of adults under 60 say computers are making life better for Americans and more than 80 percent of all adults surveyed do not expect that it will eliminate their jobs (S)

headline: MARKS & SPENCER SPECULATION
abstract: The shares of Marks & Spencer P.L.C. rose after The Daily Telegraph said Alan Leighton, a Wal-Mart Stores executive, had been approached by an investment bank that may bid for Britain's largest clothing retailer. Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, reviewing opportunities at Marks & Spencer for the investor Philip Green, made informal contact with Mr. Leighton, the head of Wal-Mart's European operations, the newspaper said, without disclosing sources. Mr. Green, who bought the British retailer Sears P.L.C. a year ago, said in December that he was considering an offer for Marks & Spencer.

headline: Japanese Shareholder Activist Loses 2nd Battle With Company
abstract: Japanese shareholder activist Yoshiaki Murakami, whose failed effort to buy Shoei Co in Japan's first hostile takeover fight attracted widespread attention, suffers second defeat when company rejects his requests to raise its dividend and make him a director (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: FTI CONSULTING INC., Annapolis, Md., a litigation and claims-management consulting company, agreed to buy Policano & Manzo L.L.C., Saddle Brook, N.J., for about $50 million in cash and stock. Policano & Manzo provides bankruptcy-related consulting to large corporations and lenders.    TEAM AMERICA CORP., Worthington, Ohio, a human resources management services company, agreed to be acquired by Global Employment Solutions Inc. for $33 million in cash.

headline: Production Surged 1% In January
abstract: Federal Reserve figures show US industrial production in January posted its largest gain in 18 months as factories, utilities and mines all increased output; production rose 1 percent, after gaining 0.4 percent in December; plant-use rate rose to 81.6 percent from 81.1 percent in December, which had first been reported as 81.3 percent; graphs (M)

headline: S.E.C. Charges a Hedge Fund With Fraud
abstract: The Manhattan Investment Fund, hedge fund controlled by Michael W Berger, is charged by Securities and Exchange Commission with inflating assets and returns while losing $300 million by betting against Internet-related stocks; SEC accuses Berger and fund of trying to hide losses by sending false account statements to investors (S)

headline: Print Shops Move Online as Paper Endures in a Digital Age
abstract: Many studies show that e-mail, Web pages and such are generating more paper, not less; they are creating greater need for printing and delivery services they were supposed to make obsolete; in new approach, document is created electronically, sent out in bits and bytes, and recipients make hard copies as needed; this could create problem if recipient's computer is incompatible with sender's; several Internet start-ups now accept documents in electronic form, print them, and deliver them to as many recipients as customer will pay for; photo (M)

headline: For Some, Retirement Begins The Instant the Check Clears
abstract: Dan Brekke profile of Jerry Baker, one of still-exclusive but growing group of people who retire young and rich from successful businesses; Baker comments on transition from workaholic entrpreneur to early retiree; cites difficulty of finding people that have same amount of free time; photo (special section, Retirement) (M)

headline: Governors Speak on Internet Voting
abstract: Governors Speak on Internet Voting

headline: Business Travel; Rosenbluth, a trend spotter among travel agents, believes it has found a new one. Think Internet.
abstract: Rosenbluth International last month started Rosenbluth Interactive subsidiary, business-to-business travel-booking service that sets up custom online travel-booking sites; American Society of Travel Agents petitioned Justice Department last week to look into possible antitrust violations by major airlines who announced last month that they would particpate jointly in new Web site that would offer low-cost tickets; spokesman for Web site says there is no merit to complaint (Business Travel column) (M)

headline: As Camera Sales Soar, Polaroid Waits for Gains to Reach Bottom Line
abstract: Polaroid Corp's sales were up 20 percent in fourth quarter from year earlier and revenue rose to $650 million, but gains failed to filter down to bottom line because increases came from new cameras, whose market longevity is untested; profits will have to come from film, but even if film does well, profits may take a while to catch up; many analysts say it will take a while before Polaroid can manufacture I-Zone film profitably (M)

headline: U.S. INDUSTRIES TO SELL UNIT TO VENTURE-CAPITAL GROUP
abstract: US Industries Inc plans to sell its diversified business unit to Vectura Holdings PLC, a Citicorp venture-capital unit, for about $600 million in cash and notes; unit will also assume $9 million in debt; US Industries will retain 18.6 percent interest in unit and 25 percent stake in unit's Rexair vacuum cleaner business (S)

headline: Oracle to Expand Venture Capital Fund
abstract: Oracle to Expand Venture Capital Fund

headline: S.E.C. to Ease Year 2000 Monitoring
abstract: With confidence rising that the securities industry had conquered the Year 2000 computer flaw, the Securities and Exchange Commission said today that it would step down its monitoring efforts.     ''We are very pleased that the securities industry has transitioned so smoothly into the year 2000,'' said Robert Colby, deputy director of the commission's division of market regulation, in a prepared statement.

headline: CINAR SUES INVESTMENT FIRMS
abstract: Cinar Corp, beleaguered Canadian producer of children's television programs, is suing three investment companies in Bahamas and principal, Robert Daviault, to recover $76 million it is missing; Cinar said last month $122 million had been invested without approval of its board; since then, about $45 million has been recovered from Norshield International Ltd and its affiliates (S)

headline: How Big a Part Of G.D.P. Are Office Pools? Make a Bet?
abstract: Article on Furnimex manager Jake Williams, who organizes office betting pool for NCAA basketball tournament; Williams says his role as numbers man is good for business, good for workplace morale and even good for his family life since he enlists help of his wife and son in tabulations; photo (M)

headline: Janus Capital Likes Apple
abstract: Janus Capital Corp, mutual fund group, raised its holding in Apple Computer to 9.99 million shares as of end of 1999 based on company's performance under its chief executive, Steve Jobs (S)

headline: For the Small Retailer, Life on the Internet Is One Big Bazaar
abstract: Free-for-all is developing in on-line retailing with growing number of shopping platforms from which small businesses can choose; small retailers are being forced to make careful decisions about how to expand companies; Michelle Donahue-Arpas, owner of GeniusBabies.com, comments; photo (M)

headline: AUTO TRADE PACT
abstract: Brazil and Argentina reach agreement on contentious economic issue of trade in automobiles; five-year accord will establish equal balance of imports between both countries, in addition to shared tariff of 35 percent on imports from outside Mercosur trade bloc (S)

headline: South Africa Preparing to Sell Its 4 Big State-Run Companies
abstract: South Africa, eager for more foreign investment; is preparing to sell its four big state-run companies--Eskom, Transnet, Telkom South Africa and Denel; taken together, four companies are valued at between $16 billion and $20 billion and employ roughly three-quarters of people working for state enterprises; need to attract capital is expected to take heavy job toll (M)

headline: Judge Says Old Rule on Libel Suits Applies Online
abstract: March 31, 2000

headline: Online Pharmacies Try to Fend Off Government Regulation
abstract: March 21, 2000

headline: Speaker Fines Kohl's Party $21 Million Over Illegal Payments
abstract: German Parliament Speaker Wolfgang Thierse imposes $21 million fine on former Chancellor Helmut Kohl's Christian Democratic Party for accepting illegal financing; fine is largest in history of federal republic (M)

headline: In an Outcast's Story, Defiance of Iran's Mullahs
abstract: Hossain Khorram, whose family's huge fortune was wiped out in Iran's Islamic revolution in 1979, describes his riches-to-rags tale; his father was executed by firing squad, and he was imprisoned and threatened with death many times; he now lives, nearly penniless, with his family in Tehran; he thinks mullahs are finished, having failed to keep their promise to give Iran's poor a better life; says they, like shah before them, have lost their connection to the people; fact that Khorram dares to say such things publicly is measure of how Iran is changing; clerical establishment will face its sternest challenge on Feb 18, when 30 million voters go to polls in parliamentary elections; if reform candidates prevail, they could begin moving Iran toward greater democracy and respect for human rights; photo (M)

headline: GQ's Cover War May Be a Pyrrhic Battle
abstract: Conde Naste's chairman, S I Newhouse Jr, is trying to remake his GQ and Details magazines in image of Maxim, sex-saturated magazine from Dennis Publishing that has circulation of more than 1.6 million copies an issue; he hired Maxim's editor, Mark Golin, to become editor in chief of Details and urged GQ's editor, Art Cooper, to insert Maxim-style oomph into GQ's pages; last several issues of GQ featured near-naked women on cover; new direction at GQ has alarmed advertisers and momentarily bewildered some members of GQ's staff, who see GQ as one of last men's magazines with literature and urbanity as its editorial mandate; photos (M)

headline: An Austrian's Rise Is Stirring Passions Both Left and Right
abstract: Europe is up in arms over rise in Austrian politics of rightist Jorg Haider, who has expressed pro-Nazi sentiments, as his party seems set to join government; all of Austria's 14 partners in European Union, as well as Israel, are weighing diplomatic options; Haider's Carinthia party seems poised to lead coalition government after Social Democratic Party, which won October 1999 elections and has been in power since 1970, has failed to form coalition government after three months of bickering with traditional partner, business-oriented People's Party; photo; map (M)

headline: Feminist Coalition Protests U.S. Stance on Sex Trafficking Treaty
abstract: Unusual coalition of women's groups, family-planning advocates and conservative Republicans protests what it describes as Clinton administration effort to weaken international laws against trafficking of women and children for prostitution; at issue is new United Nations treaty on sex trafficking, and administration's support for wording that would define 'forced prostitution'--but not other types of prostitution--as form of 'sexual exploitation'; those opposed to wording fear that definition would not cover those who prey on and profit from economic desperation of women, girls and their families by securing their 'consent' (M)

headline: An Update for the Innards of the Net
abstract: An Update for the Innards of the Net

headline: Lowe Lintas to Close Its Chicago Office
abstract: Lowe Lintas & Partners Worldwide in New York will close its Chicago office after losing account of its largest client there (S)

headline: Web Attacks Have Government Revisiting Laws and Security
abstract: Justice Department Deputy Attorney General Eric Holder, expressing concern about economic damage caused by attacks on leading Web sites this week, says tougher criminal penalties may be necessary to prevent malicious disruption of Internet commerce, news conference; Federal Bureau of Investigation spokesman says four field offices have opened formal investigations; White House has been holding meetings for last two years with leaders in computer industry to discuss security and another meeting is set for next week (M)

headline: Suitor for Iridium Backs Out, Moving Company to the Brink
abstract: The cellular telephone pioneer Craig O. McCaw said today that he was dropping plans to acquire Iridium, the troubled global satellite telephone company that filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection last August.    In a statement, Mr. McCaw's private investment group, Eagle River Investments, said the company had decided to focus its investing on satellite services that had high-speed data capabilities.

headline: KERR-MCGEE PLANS TO ACQUIRE TWO CHEMICAL PLANTS
abstract: Kerr-McGee Corp buys titanium dioxide plants in Savannah, Ga, and Rotterdam, Netherlands, from Kemira Oy, Finland's biggest chemical maker, for $403 million; purchase will make Kerr-McGree world's third-largest producer of pigment; its share of market will rise to 16 percent from 10 percent (S)

headline: The New York Times: Technology - Circuits
abstract: February 10, 2000

headline: Compressed Data; Ready-to-Wear Access to the Web
abstract: Charmed Technology, which licenses technology of MIT's Media Lab, demonstrates wireless, wearable Web-access computers that might be inexpensive enough to be given away, with users paying a service fee; photo (S)

headline: THE BOSS; Cheers for Work! Rah! Rah!
abstract: The Boss column profiles Charlotte St Martin, executive vice president for marketing at Loews Hotels; St Martin comments; photo (M)

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: EUROPE    RUSSIA: FUNERAL IN ST. PETERSBURG -- Under heavy security because of a rumored assassination plot, President Vladimir V. Putin, left, attended the St. Petersburg funeral of his mentor and that city's first elected mayor, Anatoly Sobchak. Mr. Putin said Mr. Sobchak, who fled Russia from 1997 to 1999 after being accused of corruption, was a democratic visionary destroyed by persecution. Mr. Sobchak died after a heart attack last weekend.   Michael Wines (NYT)    SERBIA: MORE POLICE FOR KOSOVO -- Responding to the need for more civilian police officers in Kosovo and for other peacekeeping missions, the United States said it would create a permanent reserve of 2,000 officers to be available without delay. ''The recent slowness in deploying desperately needed civilian police to Kosovo provides only the latest evidence that present international capabilities are not adequate,'' said Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright.   Elizabeth Becker (NYT)

headline: Small Firms Express Dismay At Plan for Nasdaq Spinoff
abstract: Some small brokerage firms express hostility to National Association of Securities Dealers' plan to issue stock and spin off Nasdaq stock market later this year; NASD executives predict deal will pass membership vote easily; Alan Davidson, president of Independent Broker-Dealer Association and member of NASD board, recommends that small brokerage firms vote against deal; Sirota & Sirota partner Howard Sirota says class-action suit against NASD could come within a week (M)

headline: Lehman's Profits More Than Double on Investment Banking Gains
abstract: First-quarter profits at Lehman Brothers Holdings more than doubled, driven by surge in trading revenue and gains in investment banking; net income for quarter ended Feb 29, rose 157 percent, to $541 million from $211 million a year ago; net revenue doubled to $2.2 billion from $1.1 billion (M)

headline: US Airways Facing Threat of Disruption
abstract: In an unusual job action, the 10,000 unionized flight attendants at US Airways are threatening to disrupt flights on 49 of the airline's busiest routes on Saturday.

headline: Interpublic's changing of the guard replaces a senior statesman of advertising with a veteran.
