abstract: John J Dooner Jr, McCann-Erickson World Group executive who helped triple size of agency company and initiated creative turnaround at its flagship agency, is officially named to succeed Philip H Geier Jr as chief executive of McCann-Erickson's parent, Interpublic Group of Companies; Donner will take over as president and chief operating officer on April 1 and as chief executive on Jan 1, 2001; no successor has been named for Dooner at McCann-Erickson; photo (M)

headline: ASPECT COMMUNICATIONS TO ACQUIRE SOFTWARE PRODUCER
abstract: Aspect Communications Corp, maker of online customer-service software, acquires PakNetX Corp for $55 million (S)

headline: Does Deal Signal Lessening Of Media Independence?
abstract: Merger of Time Warner with America Online renews concern that news outlets are losing their independence; it fans newer concerns that Internet has become prey to corporate consolidations; worry is not that there are fewer media outlets--opposite is true--but that fewer people have ultimate control over them (M)

headline: Prices Rise For Treasuries As Shares Slip
abstract: Treasury bond prices rise as stocks sink; rise is also aided by expectations that Alan Greenspan, Federal Reserve chairman, will reaffirm that Fed will raise interest rates to rein in economic growth (M)

headline: Dow Rebounds as World Watches : Asian Markets Join European Sell-Off
abstract: In some of the sharpest market movements since the Asian financial crisis ended last year, stock prices across Asia and Europe plunged Wednesday in response to major falls in U.S. markets Tuesday.

headline: After Air Raids, Beirut Returns to Power-Deprived Routines
abstract: People of Beirut seek to cope with loss of electric power after Israeli planes attack three power stations in Lebanon; one of severely damaged plants is at Jamhur; it is third time in less than four years, and second time in little more than seven months, that Israeli planes have hit plant; map; photo (M)

headline: RUSSIA DEBTS DOWN, TAX REVENUE UP
abstract: Mikhail Kasyanov, Russia's first deputy prime minister and finance minister, says Russia has reduced its debt obligations to 109 percent of gross domestic product from 150 percent a year ago, attributed in part to more effective tax collection; Russia's acting president Vladimir Putin and Kasyanov announce that businesses will be able to deduct from their taxes a far more significant portion of their expenditures on employee training, advertising and entertainment than they do now (S)

headline: Agencies See a Shakeout on the Horizon for Dot-Com Land
abstract: MADISON AVENUE is bracing for the Internet version of Darwinism, a winnowing process that could be called SurvivaloftheFittest.com.    After a record advertising blitz during the fourth quarter, particularly among electronic commerce Web sites anxious to stimulate holiday sales, agencies are wondering whether the new year will bring a shakeout. The e-tailers that spent the most on campaigns in mainstream national media did not necessarily attract the most shoppers, according to preliminary data, a setback threatening to jeopardize the continued flow of money from clients to agencies.

headline: OFFICE SUPPLIES RETAILER EXTENDS STOCK REPURCHASES
abstract: Office Depot Inc approves $100 million increase to its previous $500 million stock repurchase program (S)0

headline: Head of Wireless Unit to Leave AT&T
abstract: AT&T Corp says Daniel Hesse, president and chief executive of its wireless services unit, will leave just weeks before planned initial public offering of portion of company's wireless business; Mohan Gyani, chief financial officer of AT&T Wireless Group, will succeed Hesse; Hesse will join TeraBeam Networks as chief executive (S)

headline: U.S. Welcomes Iranian Election Results
abstract: Clinton administration welcomes election results in Iran, which it interprets as unequivocal demand for greater freedom within the country and for improved relations abroad (M)

headline: Corrections
abstract: Business Diary Dec 5 column about companies with word 'century' in their name misstated name and location of mutual fund company; former Twentieth Century is now American Century Investments, not American Century Funds; its headquarters are in Kansas City, Mo, not St Louis (S)

headline: Criticism for Company Offering Free Computers to Schools
abstract: February 2, 2000

headline: AMOCO TO BUY BURMAH CASTROL
abstract: BP Amoco will acquire Burmah Castrol for 3 billion pounds, or $4.7 billion, taking control of world's best-selling motor oil, Castrol; BP is paying 74 percent premium for Burmah Castrol; BP Amoco executive David Baldry says takeover will result in 1,700 jobs cuts; adds BP Amoco also expects to dispose of Burmah's specialty chemical businesses; photo (S)

headline: Putin Tells Why He Became a Spy
abstract: Acting Pres Vladimir V Putin of Russia says he was smitten with romance of working for secret service when he saw The Sword and the Shield, 1968 movie depicting the heroic deeds of a Soviet double agent in Nazi Germany (M)

headline: Those Distasteful Cookies
abstract: Letter by Brian Jacobsmeyer on Feb 24 article on cookies (computer files); says Mac users should look into new iCab browser developed by small German company

headline: DIVIDEND MEETINGS
abstract: A partial list for this week.    MONDAY  Agree Rlty Corp  Wrigley Wm Jr Co    TUESDAY  Bandag Inc  Brush Wellman Inc  United Dominion Rlty Tr Inc

headline: FreeMarkets Posts Smaller-Than-Expected Loss
abstract: February 1, 2000

headline: Investors Overreact to Deal, Analysts Say
abstract: Tribune Co's agreement to buy Times Mirror Co spells bad news for Tribune shareholders; Tribune's stock falls $6.375, more than 17 percent, to $30.8125, its lowest level in more than a year; but some big investors and stock analysts say worries that $6.45 billion deal will hurt Tribune's profits were overdone; chart (M)

headline: REFCO GROUP TO BUY DISCOUNT FUTURES BROKERAGE FIRM
abstract: Refco Group, lï

headline: SILVER GIANT RESUMES PRODUCTION
abstract: Mexico's Industrias Penoles SA, world's largest producer of refined silver, resumes full production after authorities forced it to cut back by as much as 50 percent for a year because more than 4,000 children living near its main plant were found to have dangerous levels of lead in their blood; Penoles paid more than $35 million to sweep nearby neighborhoods for lead dust and build enclosures around polluting sites (S)

headline: CISCO TO BUY MAKER OF INTERNET VIDEO SYSTEMS
abstract: Cisco Systems Inc to acquire SightPath Inc, which makes systems delivering television-quality video to Internet and corporate intra nets, for $800 million in stock (S)

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Letters to the Editor

headline: Fed to No Longer Adopt Policy Bias Toward Rates
abstract: Federal Reserve has dropped its practice of adopting policy bias toward raising or reducing interest rates, and from now on it will signal its assessment of inflation risks through formulaic public statement after each meeting; Fed says it is making changes in response to 'unanticipated confusion' among investors and economists over its previous practice, put into effect last spring, of disclosing whether it was formally leaning toward shift in monetary policy; chart (M)

headline: Britain's Granada Says It Is Considering Bids for Media Rivals
abstract: Battle to rule Britain's commercial television industry begins when Granada Group says it intends to spoil recently planned $6.6 billion merger between Carlton Communications and United News and Media by trying to buy one of media companies; Granada says it will request permission from regulatory authorities to bid for either company; in November, Carlton and United News announced that it would create largest commercial television concern in Britain; at stake is control of Britain's Independent Television Network, or ITV, principal nationwide commercial television network; seven companies currently own ITV, including Granda, Carlton and United News (M)

headline: Many Questions Remain On Pinochet's Condition
abstract: Spanish news reports, citing confidential British doctors' examination of Gen Augusto Pinochet, leave unanswered many medical questions about what ails him (M)

headline: Israel Greets Pope With Considerable Warmth, and a Little Heat
abstract: Reporter's Notebook vignettes from Pope John Paul II's visit to Holy Land (M)

headline: INFINITY BROADCASTING PLANS ANOTHER STOCK BUYBACK
abstract: Infinity Broadcasting Corp says that it will buy back up to $500 million of its class A stock (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: ITEQ INC., Houston, a maker of natural gas and liquid processing equipment, agreed to sell its HMT storage tank-maintenance unit to a company led by the closely held Nassau Point Investors L.L.C. for $40 million.

headline: Buyback at Capital One
abstract: Capital One Financial Corp to buy back up to 10 million shares, about 5.1 percent of shares outstanding, over two years (S)

headline: NYT Article
abstract: Wine Sellers Toast E-Commerce Craze

headline: A Legendary Hero Guides a Reborn Kyrgyzstan
abstract: The Manas, an oral Kyrgyz epic poem dating back centuries, has become textbook of moral values for Kyrgyzstan since it emerged from debris of Soviet Union in 1991; photo; map (M)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.  MONDAY  Existing-Home Sales Feb.    TUESDAY  Consumer Confidence March

headline: BREAKAWAY SOLUTIONS TO PURCHASE CONSULTING COMPANY
abstract: Breakaway Solutions Inc acquires Eggrock Partners in all-stock deal valued at about $250 million (S)

headline: Bountiful Harvest Seen In Managerial Suites
abstract: Pearl Meyer & Partners study finds chief exec

headline: STRONGER RESULTS AT ADIDAS
abstract: Adidas-Salomon AG reports surprisingly strong 1999 results; earnings rose 11 percent, to $225 million, on 6 percent increase in sales, to $$5.3 billion (S)

headline: Corrections
abstract: The Stocks in the News listing on the DataBank page last Sunday misstated the name of a company whose stock price fell after it said first-quarter sales and earnings would fall short of analysts' expectations. It was Lucent Technologies, not Lucent Technology.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: ACX TECHNOLOGIES INC., Golden, Colo., a consumer-product packaging maker, will close two Graphics Packaging Corp. unit plants in Saratoga Springs, N.Y. and Boulder, Colo., affecting as many as 400 jobs.    CANADIAN IMPERIAL BANK OF COMMERCE, Toronto, Canada's largest bank by assets, signed a deal to buy St. Anthony Bancorp Inc. and a unit St. Anthony Bank, Cicero, Ill., a federally chartered savings bank. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: Mac Users Can Now Say 'I Love You' Out Loud
abstract: IBM's ViaVoice for Mac software features continuous speech recognition system, allowing user to speak in natural rhythms and not pause uncomfortably after every word (S)

headline: Plans for Mexican Salt Plant Are Canceled
abstract: Mexican government and Mitsubishi of Japan, yielding to pressure from environmental groups, cancel plans to build giant salt factory at a pristine Pacific Coast lagoon; campaign to block proposed plant at Laguna San Ignacio, spawning ground for gray whale set in breathtaking Baja California desert, galvanizes unusually broad coalition of environmental groups (S)

headline: Ford's campaign for its Focus car will be remade into a hybrid of television and online media.
abstract: Ford Motor Co is overhauling highly visible element of big campaign for new Focus car line as company seeks to become part of hot new trend: transforming television advertising into hybrid of TV and online media that could be called dot-commercials; Ford and J Walter Thompson plan to introduce next month series of live commercials with interactivity as core element (M)

headline: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING -- AMERICAS; MEXICO INTERNET VENTURE
abstract: Telefonos de Mexico and Microsoft Corp to begin offering Internet gateway service for Mexico (S)

headline: The Case of the Flickering Pixels
abstract: Most computer users are aware that reading text from computer screen does not offer same quality as it does from printer paper; while there have been number of efforts to improve monitors themselves, technical limitations of monitors is shifting the effort to improve text display to software changes; two leading software alternatives are ClearType from Microsoft and ClearView from Ductus; both software applications try in different ways to make screen type easier to read; ClearType will work only on LCD (liquid crystal display) screens; photos; graphic on how LCD screens handle pixels (M)

headline: Term Life: The Safety Net Comes at a Higher Price
abstract: New regulations requiring insurers across the country to set aside more money to cover potential payouts have resulted in rates for term life policies rising 20 to 50 percent; regulations, which do not affect whole life policies, are being adopted state by state, bringing prices elsewhere in the country closer to levels in New York State, where prices have long been highest in the nation; most experts say basic question to ask about the need for life insurance is whether your death will leave your dependends in financial lurch; various strategies for buying life insurance discussed; chart on premiums charged by some insurers (M)

headline: U.S. Says Gasoline Prices to Continue Rising Through the Summer
abstract: US Energy Department predicts gasoline prices will continue to rise sharply, hitting average of $1.56 a gallon in peak summer driving season, but they will come down by this time next year; says steep increase in gasoline costs is unavoidable in near future even if oil-producing countries agree soon to increase production significantly because worldwide crude oil supplies are so low; believes that motorists will pay average of 35 cents more a gallon from April through September than they did in period a year earlier; graph on futures trading

headline: Microsoft Issues Lengthy Response to Judge in Antitrust Case
abstract: Microsoft Corp delivers legal arguments that it hopes will stave off adverse antitrust ruling, taking issue with Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson's conclusions about case and restating many arguments that he has already rejected; Microsoft's 70-page conclusions of law, sent to Jackson and published on its Web site after stock market closed, contends that case law does not support either government's charges or judge's findings of fact, published in November; filing does not directly assail Jackson (M)

headline: RATE RISE IN HONG KONG
abstract: Hong Kong Association of Banks follows lead of US Federal Reserve and raises interest rates by quarter point (S)

headline: Gomitogo Journal; Undependable Rains Bring Seasonal Exodus
abstract: Slumped in the shadow of a mud wall, any desire he might have had to stand up drained by the midday sun and the Ramadan fast, Mamadou Tombo explained the simple truth about his village of rice farmers.    ''When there was good flood and rain,'' said Mr. Tombo, the mayor, ''there was no exodus.''

headline: The Flashing Pen That Thinks It's a Ringing Cellular Phone
abstract: Flashing Fone Pen, marketed by BUCA, silently alerts user when call comes in to nearby mobile phone; pen doubles as actual writing instrument; photo (S)

headline: China's Arrest of Pennsylvania Librarian Alarms Scholars
abstract: Western scholars are alarmed at arrest in Beijing of Yongyi Song, Pennsylvania-based Chinese researcher, as he collected documents from Maoist era; say it imperils academic research and exchanges with China; 101 China scholars, including many who favor broader ties with China, release letter to Pres Jiang Zemin calling for Song's immediate release; letter warns that Song's arrest--on vague charges of providing confidential information to foreigners--could undermine support for academic exchanges that China has fostered over last two decades, as it seeks to modernize and end its former isolation; scholars are from universities in United States, Australia and Britain; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; U.S. Accuses 3 Companies Of Violations
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission accuses All-Tech Direct Inc, one of leading providers of rapid-fire day-trading services, of violating regulations governing practice of lending money to customers to buy stocks; Investment Street Co is accused of similar loan violations, indicating that practices of such firms remain under close scrutiny; SEC contends that David M Mobley Sr, manager of Maricopa Investment Fund Ltd and three related hedge funds, defrauded investors of at least $59 million; defendants in three cases listed; photo of All-Tech founder Harvey Houtkin (M)

headline: Taipei Journal; In Weighty Times, an Island Lampoons Its Jitters
abstract: Exuberant elections are evidence of Taiwan's transition from dictatorship to democracy, but an unsparing and hilarious satire of politicians on ther air weekday nights on cable television in Taipei may be the ultimate proof; with Taiwan's presidential election nearing, show, called An Appointment With the Chairman, satirizing leading politicians, helps dispel jitters; photos (L)

headline: Market Analyst Concedes Recession Forecast Was Off
abstract: It is best to offer regrets quickly and keep them short, and that is what Edward Yardeni did this week.    Mr. Yardeni, the chief economist at Deutsche Bank Securities, had predicted that Year 2000 computer problems would cause a recession this year by disrupting global supply chains, collapsing earnings expectations for thousands of companies and popping the stock market bubble.

headline: BRAZIL CAR SALES
abstract: Brazil's automotive sales rose 1.5 percent in December, to 73,495 vehicles, as conditions improved for borrowers. For 1999, however, sales fell 9.5 percent and production decreased 15 percent.   Simon Romero

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of March 19 article on Allied Owners Action fund, mutual fund devoted to shareholder activism

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction to Feb 20 article on career paths of Stanford Class of 1993 which misspelled surname of graduate who now works for an Internet startup after having turned down previous opportunity at another Internet firm; she is Diane Barram, not Barum

headline: COMPUTER ASSOCIATES TO BUY STERLING SOFTWARE
abstract: Computer Associates International Inc acquires Sterling Software Inc for $4 billion in stock (S)

headline: A Chapter 11 Filing by Charter Behavioral
abstract: Charter Behavioral Health Systems files for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection from creditors; Charter, which is 90 percent owned by Crescent Operating Inc, company led by Richard E Rainwater, says it made filing to 'ensure continued services to patients' in its units; Charter lists less than $50 million in assets and more than $100 million in debts; Crescent Real Estate Equities Co, real estate investment trust also led by Rainwater, already owns buildings used by Charter's hospitals and treatment centers; since 1999, Justice Department and Health and Human Services Department have been investigating Charter and Magellan Health Services Inc, which once owned chain, for Medicaid billing fraud and patient abuse (M)

headline: ENRON AND NORTHERN BORDER BUY STAKE IN CMS ENERGY
abstract: Enron Corp and Northern Border Partners LP acquires 49 percent stake in gas-gathering system in northeastern Wyoming from CMS Energy Corp for $65 million; Enron will own 10 percent and Northern Border 39 percent of 100-mile system of pipes that collect gas from wells in Powder River Basin (S)

headline: I.B.M. Profit Off, but It Beats Expectations
abstract: IBM says earnings during fourth quarter of 1999 fell more than 11 percent from previous year, but Wall Street had expected even worse; company earned $2.09 billion, down 11.1 percent from $2.35 billion a year ago; revenue was off 3.8 percent, to $24.18 billion from $25.18 bilion last year (M)

headline: Text Messages, Though Short, Catch On With Cell Users
abstract: March 14, 2000

headline: Takeover May Increase U.S. Control of Internet in Europe
abstract: America Online Inc's acquisition of Time Warner Inc may increase US cultural dominance of World Wide Web in Europe; merger is likely to increase pressure among rivals in Europe for alliances and mergers (M)

headline: An Atlanta Developer Returns to Downtown
abstract: Letter by Meryle Secrest responds to March 5 article on Atlanta developer John Williams; says Williams's ideas on revitalization of downtown Atlanta gave her moment of rueful reflection about her birthplace, Bath, England

headline: Implosion of Kingdome Will Be Live on the Net
abstract: Implosion fans can watch Seattle Kingdome go down this Sunday, one day before the dome turns 25; event will be shown online at windowsmedia. msm.com/preview/kingdome/kingdome.asp; other buildings scheduled for implosion that can also be viewed on site noted; photo of destruction of Sears building in Kansas City, Mo (S)

headline: GORE BACK IN STEP WITH WHITE HOUSE OVER CHINA TRADE
abstract: Vice Pres Al Gore, day after reassuring union leaders that he would negotiate tougher trade deal with China if elected president, writes letter to National Association of Manufacturers reiterating his support for trade agreement that Pres Clinton is trying to push through Congress; letter underscores difficult position Gore finds himself in as he tries to mollify two groups he needs in election, business executives who have pressed for accord and union members who want to defeat it (M)

headline: From Calgary to Near a Summit in Hollywood
abstract: Profile of Robert A Iger, new president and chief executive of Walt Disney Co, discusses the coolness under pressure he displayed at ABC in late 1980's (M)

headline: Cisco Takes Internet Phones to Next Stage
abstract: Cisco Systems is set to announce an office telephone system that transmits voice calls in the electronic language of the Internet, a move that could push company to the top of the budding Internet-telephone market; photo (M)

headline: MAIL-WELL TO ACQUIRE AMERICAN BUSINESS PRODUCTS
abstract: Mail-Well Inc to acquire American Business Products Inc for $20 a share, or $295 million in cash; will also assume debt of about $39 million (S)

headline: Morgan Stanley Net Up 49% in Quarter
abstract: Morgan Stanley Dean Witter's net income in first quarter ended Feb 29 rose 49 percent, making it fourth investment bank to post stronger-than-expected earnings; firm earned $1.54 billion, compared with $1.04 billion a year earlier; net revenue was $7.41 billion, up 39 percent from $5.34 billion in first quarter of 1999; chief financial officer Robert Scott says firm has postponed its plan to raise prices for customers of its original online-trading system, which was called Discover Brokerage; firm is rolling that operation, which charged basic commission of $14.95 a trade, into its new service, which charges $29.95; photo of chief executive Philip Purcell (M)

headline: The Microsoft-U.S. Negotiations: Tough Talk in Chicago
abstract: Private deliberations between Microsoft and Justice Department over antitrust suit are at settle-or-fold stage and odds are against settlement; both sides remain far apart despite efforts of mediator Judge Richard A Posner, leading antitrust scholar, to find common ground; main stumbling block is Microsoft's continuing rejection of charges that tying its Internet Explorer Web browser to industry-standard Windows operating system unfairly squelched competition, and its insistence that it should be free to innovate unfettered by government oversight; ruling by federal Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson in November 1999 found company is monopolist, whose business practice stifles competition and harms consumers; possible remedies in case and high stakes for both sides discussed; photos (M)

headline: Streamlining A German Blimp; Deutsche Bank Strains to Be Nimble in a Modern Market
abstract: Deutsch Bank chairman Rolf-Ernst Breuer is considering giving up controlling stake in his own branches; Deutsche Bank has 1,500 local offices and 7 million retail banking customers; it has biggest branch network in Germany, but network barely ekes out profit and consistently drags down bank's overall performance; Germany has far too many banks partly because it has huge sector of nonprofit savings banks owned by state and local governments, which keep margins low; having separated Deutsche Bank's retail network into stand-alone company, called Deutsche Bank 24, Breuer has pleaded in vain for rivals to buy in as minority partners; few analysts say Deutsche Bank will sell off its branch network; but Breuer is clearly impatient and also seems convinced that traditional banking is withering and radical changes are necessary to survive; graphs; photos (M)

headline: Uncovered Short Sales Drop More Than 8% on the Nasdaq
abstract: National Association of Securities Dealers says open positions of short sales on Nasdaq stock market dropped more than 8 percent in the most recent month ended Jan 15; uncovered short sales in all 4,707 Nasdaq securities totaled 2.4 billion shares compared with 4,688 securities and 2.6 billion shares previous month; chart (S)

headline: Anheuser Stock Buyback
abstract: Anheuser-Busch Cos plans to buy back up to 50 million shares, 11 percent of outstanding shares (S)

headline: The Water Is Clear. The Future Isn't.
abstract: William A Orme Jr The Business World column on Eden Springs, Israeli mineral water company on Golan Heights threatened by possible peace plan that would return area to Syria; map; photo (M)

headline: The New Economy's Currency Is Stock, Stock and Stock
abstract: Current horde of business-to-business contractors who make deals with high-technology companies are trading services for equity; consultants, public relations agencies, executive search firms, commercial landlords and others have joined law firms that have long taken slices of clients' companies on top of regular fees; photos (M)

headline: Another 3Com Spinoff May Be in the Works
abstract: March 16, 2000

headline: Senate Fight Snags Aid Bill For Kosovo And Colombia
abstract: $9 billion spending bill to help Colombia combat drug traffickers and to pay for US military operations in Kosovo is imperiled because of opposition from Sen Trent Lott and fiscal conservatives in House and Senate (M)

headline: Fiber Optics Maker To Acquire a Rival
abstract: JDS Uniphase Corp, world's largest maker of fiber optic equipment parts, acquires rival E-Tek Dynamics Inc for about $15 billion in stock (S)

headline: US Airways and Union Talking as Strike Deadline Passes
abstract: Negotiators for US Airways Group and Association of Flight Attendants continue contract talks past strike deadline on request by Ernest W DuBester, chairman of National Mediation Board; threat of shutdown of nation's sixth-largest carrier sows tension and chaos in airports nationwide; thousands of passengers rush to change reservations or seek refunds on tickets; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Euro comes close to its psychological $1 level, with dollar trading at 1.0092 a euro, compared with 1.0166 on Thursday; graph (S)

headline: AETNA FENDS OFF A TAKEOVER OFFER AND PLANS A SPLIT
abstract: Aetna Inc rejects $9.9 billion takeover offer from Wellpoint Health Networks and ING Group, and announces plans to split company into independent health care and financial services organizations, with each having its own stock; will sell some overseas health care units and use money to help reduce debt and buck bay stock later in year; securities analysts say move is unlikely to satisfy investors, who have been clamoring for breakup of company and sale of various divisions, possibly in auction; graph (M)

headline: Ulster Leader Holds On, but Power Lessens in Unionist Vote
abstract: David Trimble holds off surprisingly strong challenge to his leadership of Northern Ireland's Ulster Unionist Party, but emerges with his authority and his room to maneuver in conducting peace negotiations diminished; strong vote for Rev Martin Smyth indicates deepening division over going forward with Apr 1998 peace agreement and sharing power with Catholic minority; delegates say they were particularly angered by Trimble's suggestion in Washington on March 17 that he would be willing to take party back into government with Sinn Fein without prior disarmament of Irish Republican Army (M)

headline: Ads and Promotions At New High on TV
abstract: 1999 Commercial Monitoring Report, sponsored by American Association of Advertising Agencies and Association of National Advertisers, finds that average hour of prime time on four biggest broadcast networks contained record 16 minutes and 43 seconds of commercials and promotions, up 59 seconds from previous record, 15 minutes and 44 seconds, set in 1998; daytime network ads rose to record 20 minutes and 53 seconds an hour on average, up 52 seconds from 20 minutes and 1 second in 1998 (S)

headline: Sharon Cautions West Against Aid to Syria in Any Peace Deal
abstract: Ariel Sharon, leader of Israel's opposition Likud Party, begins campaigning against Western aid to Syria that would be part of any deal arising out of Israeli-Syrian peace talks (M)

headline: Advocates for Children Joining U.N. Peacekeeping Missions
abstract: United Nations, for first time in history of its international peacekeeping missions, begins assigning full-time advocates of children to operations centers abroad; move follows horrific reports from range of United Nations agencies and private relief orgns detailing plight of children in era of civil wars (M)

headline: People
abstract: James G Hackett, director for national sales at USA Weekend, New York, part of Gannett Co, is named to new position of vice president for advertising (S)

headline: Clinton Fever: A Delighted India Has All the Symptoms
abstract: Analysis of Pres Clinton's skillful address to Indian Parliament, during which he managed to entertain, flatter and inspire much of country's political leadership, even as he tactfully told them things they would rather not have heard--including United States's disapproval of India's decision to test nuclear weapons in 1998; Clinton seems to be making headway in convincing Indians that US genuinely wants to befriend them, and Clinton mania has seized press as well as ordinary Indians (M)

headline: Burmese Rebels Seize Hostages in Thailand
abstract: Armed rebels from Burmese insurgent group called God's Army reportedly cross border into Thailand and seize local hospital, taking as many as 200 people hostage and demanding medical care for their wounded (S)

headline: Lucent Warns First-Quarter Earnings Will Disappoint
abstract: January 6, 2000

headline: Some Risks Are Worth the Reward
abstract: Team of young prison inmates at Montgomery County Detention Center, Rockville, Md, takes second-prize in imaginary stock-picking contest, in competition against teams of high students in Maryland and District of Columbia; spokesman for detention center says he is not surprised because people in jail are 'risk-takers' (S)

headline: 1,000 Crates of Sprinkles With That?
abstract: It's official business-to-business e-commerce is where the money is, or at least will be soon. Most of the projected growth is likely to take place in what analysts call ''e-marketplaces,'' or ''net markets'' - Web sites that bring together many buyers and sellers on a single site. Some will serve different industries, while others will operate within a narrow specialty. What they'll look like in 10 years is anyone's guess, but some current forms are outlined below. While Jane's Ice Cream is a fictional company, its evolution has plenty of parallels in the real world of e-business.   STEPHEN MIHM

headline: That's Alan, With an A, The Guy Who Sets Rates
abstract: Comment on WealthHound.com's Web page dedicated to news related to Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan; photo (S)

headline: Farewell Forever: Odes to Burning Bridges
abstract: Lawrence Van Gelder (On the Job) article offers six stories of memorable farewells and exit lines by delivered by persons who either resigned or were let go from their jobs (M)

headline: Carbon-Copy Madness
abstract: Letter by David M Barnert responds to Feb 10 article on e-mail, noting he always uses Bcc when sending mail to various people who may not know one another; says this practice should be used with care

headline: A Strange Brew's Buzz Lingers in Silicon Valley
abstract: Silicon Valley computer industry is still shaped by basic tensions ever since Homebrew Computer Club copied Microsoft's first computer program in 1978 and distributed it, enraging founder William Gates; industry is also driven by more ethereal and in many ways purer motives rather than by outlaw subculture; photos; graph (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)

headline: Tough, but often humorous talk as Madison Avenue confronts the subject of diversity.
abstract: Stuart Elliott's Advertising column on recent meeting of Advertising Club of New York, which dealt with provocative issue of diversity in advertising (M)

headline: Solemnity and Flash In the Land of Jesus
abstract: In a beautiful, almost ethereal scene, about 2,000 Christians quietly ascended the Mount of Olives as midnight approached. Following a lighted crucifix, they carried votive candles that flickered in the still darkness of a city devoid of any official celebration of the millennium.     At the top, they planted the crucifix and gathered round, moved by the serenity. Then, switching in a flash from the sublime to the cheesy, it turned into a Dick Clark New Year's Eve special with a Fellini-esque cast, set in the heart of the Holy Land.

headline: PALESTINIAN TALKS MAY MISS DEADLINE, ISRAELI AIDE SAYS
abstract: Oded Eran, Israel's senior negotiator, says Israel and Palestinians will intensify peace negotiations during next few weeks, but says it is increasingly unlikely framework agreement will be reached by mid-February deadline; still believes full permanent peace accord can be forged by September, final deadline set in most recent interim accord and date by which Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat has threatened unilateral declaration of statehood if talks are not completed; Israelis and Palestinians remain far apart on every issue before them, namely: borders, Jewish settlements in West Bank, status of Jerusalem, Palestinian refugees, security and water (M)

headline: Judge Declines to Halt Paper's Distribution
abstract: Judge Robert Kelly refuses to limit distribution of Metro, a new free newspaper in Philadelphia, only to areas where other papers are sold; refusal, if it stands, will eventually allow Metro to be distributed on station concourses, bus platforms and subway stations under Southeastern Pennsylvania Transportation Authority, which are off-limits to other publications; suit was brought by Knight Ridder, New York Times and Gannett Co (M)

headline: Taiwan Industry Adopting Transmeta Chip
abstract: Taiwan Industry Adopting Transmeta Chip

headline: CLINTON WILL MEET SYRIA'S PRESIDENT ON  ISRAEL  ISSUES
abstract: Pres Clinton will meet with Syrian Pres Hafez al-Assad in Geneva on March 26 in effort to bridge differences between Syria and Israel and allow for resumption of peace talks that broke down in January; warns against high expectations, even though US and Israeli officials suggest Washington is reasonably confident that encounter will produce new round of talks that could well lead to final agreement; meeting is seen as necessary prologue if agreement between Israel and Syria is to be reached during remainder of Clinton's tenure and by July time frame Israeli Prime Min Ehud Barak says he prefers (M)

headline: Central Bank's Statement On Interest Rate Increases
abstract: Text of statement by Federal Open Market Committee, Federal Reserve's monetary policy panel, after its decision to raise short-term interest rates

headline: Europeans Move Toward Backing German to Lead the I.M.F.
abstract: European Union appears set to back Caio Koch-Weser, longtime World Bank official who currently serves as state secretary in German finance ministry, to head International Monetary Fund, giving boost to candidate Clinton administration officials privately argue is ill-suited for job; European foreign ministers, meeting in Brussels, reach information consensus that Koch-Weser should succeed Michel Camdessus as director of fund; French, who have been viewed as cool to Koch-Weser, issue statement saying that they will not block European choice (M)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: EUROPE    ITALY: ELECTION REFORM VOTE -- The constitutional court gave the go-ahead to seven referendums between April and June, including one that its supporters say would end political instability by abolishing election by proportional representation to a quarter of the seats in Parliament's 630-member lower house. In a vote last April, some 90 percent favored doing away with proportional representation. But the ballot was declared void when the turnout reached only 49.6 percent.   Elisabetta Povoledo

headline: Indonesian General Denies Guilt in Timor Abuses
abstract: Indonesian Gen Wiranto denies that he was responsible for human rights abuses in East Timor and sidesteps suggestion by Pres Abdurrahman Wahid that he resign (M)

headline: U.S. and 19 States Issue Stinging Reply to Microsoft
abstract: US Justice Department and 19 states suing Microsoft Corp for allegedly violating antitrust laws jointly issue stinging and disdainful rebuttal to Microsoft's legal arguments last week that it did not violate antitrust laws (M)

headline: When the Company Asks for Volunteers
abstract: Letter by Larry Kirkpatrick responds to Feb 20 article on Bank of America request that its employees volunteer their time to take care of automated teller machine; says companies have destroyed what once was wonderful relationship between employer and employee

headline: Helmet Law Leaves Italy's Motorbikers Hotheaded
abstract: Motorbikers in Italy are irate over new law requiring helmets for riders; Italy is last European Union nation to pass such a law; photo of scene in Rome (M)

headline: BELL ATLANTIC MAY REPURCHASE 80 MILLION MORE SHARES
abstract: Bell Atlantic Corp says its board authorized repurchase of as many as 80 million common shares to help value of its stock, which has fallen 12 percent in last year; new buyback will cost $4.4 billion based on March 1 closing price and represents about 5.2 percent of shares outstanding as of Dec 31 (S)

headline: STRAYER EDUCATION HIRES ADVISER TO STUDY POSSIBLE SALE
abstract: Strayer Education Inc, holding company for Strayer University, hires Legg Mason Wood Walker Inc to advise it on strategic alternatives, including sale of company (S)

headline: Treasury Is Set to Auction Bills This Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three-  and six-month bills.    By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 5.62 percent, and a six-month bill was 5.75 percent.

headline: This Week's Equity Offerings
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:     Abgenix Inc., Fremont, Calif., 2.5 million shares. Robertson, Stephens & Co.     Allscripts Inc., Libertyville, Ill., 2 million shares. Goldman, Sachs & Co.

headline: Jack Morton to Acquire Unit From Caribiner
abstract: Jack Morton Co will acquire all assets of communications division of Caribiner for $90 million in cash (S)

headline: Down to Zero
abstract: Letter by Luke Bonanno on Feb 24 article on Internet providers offering free access; says he believes reason free access has not caught on in America may be due to poor quality of free services

headline: Will Kohl Name Names? No, Report Is a Hoax
abstract: Scandal surrounding secret payments to Germany's Christian Democratic Union takes bizarre turn with hoax in which statement is falsely issued in name of former Chancellor Helmut Kohl saying he would reveal names of donors who gave him more than $1 million (M)

headline: SOFTBANK STOCK TUMBLES
abstract: Shares of Softbank Corp post their third worst drop ever, on concern that company's purchase of failed Nippon Credit Bank Ltd and doubling of its share price in just two months means stock is overvalued; Nikko Salomon Smith Barney Ltd lowers its rating; graph (S)

headline: Fattening Up a World Body
abstract: Kofi Annan might think he runs the United Nations, but no, at the moment, it is George Lang, the New York restaurateur (Cafe des Artistes) and entrepreneur. At the least, Mr. Lang is in charge of the delegates' dining room.    Back in his native Hungary, Mr. Lang and the financier Ronald S. Lauder are assembling an empire that includes vineyards, a paprika factory, a foie gras factory and Gundel's, the fabled Budapest restaurant. Lest that empire lack for attention, for much of this month Mr. Lang has brought in Gundel's manager, five chefs and, of course, the restaurant's publicity director to turn the dining room at U.N. headquarters in Manhattan into Gundel's West.

headline: People
abstract: Gail C. Day was named publisher at Playboy magazine, New York, and executive vice president at the Playboy Publishing Group, part of Playboy Enterprises Inc., succeeding Richard Kinsler, who became vice president and publisher at Popular Science magazine, New York, part of the Times Mirror Magazines unit of the Times Mirror Company. Ms. Day had been publisher at Sports Illustrated for Kids, New York, part of the Time Inc. unit of Time Warner Inc.

headline: Patents; Carry your computer's brain around in your pocket? Perhaps it's only a few years away.
abstract: Xybernaut Corp patents idea for portable computer core that has everything necessary to operate except monitor and power source, is smaller than hand-held electronic organizers and works with varying kinds of enclosures; Donald Duncan patents reversible shoe sole to be used on one side for general wear and other for wet-weather wear (M)

headline: With Stock Lagging Badly Borders Hires an Adviser
abstract: Borders Group, one of the nation's leading booksellers, said yesterday that it had hired Merrill Lynch & Company to explore steps it might take to bolster its faltering stock price.     Gregory P. Josefowicz, the chief executive of the book chain, said in a statement that the alternatives ''could include a recapitalization, a leveraged buyout or a business combination with another company.'' Analysts said they expected that stock buybacks and perhaps a sale of part of the company's money-losing Internet operation, Borders.com, would be high on the list.

headline: Rates Soar As Traders Grow Warier
abstract: Interest rates soar on US Government bonds; price of 30-year bond falls 1 3/32, to 92 31/32; yield jumps to 6.67 percent, from 6.59 percent; graph on yields of selected Treasury securities; chart on US key interest rates (M)

headline: INDONESIAN GROWTH OUTLOOK
abstract: Indonesia's economy will expand 3 to 4 percent in 2000, after growing an estimated one-tenth of 1 percent last year, the central bank said. It warned, however, that problems including banking and corporate reorganization and rising debt could derail recovery. Indonesia is emerging from financial crisis and economic recession.

headline: Deja Vu All Over Again For New Deja.com Site
abstract: Revamped Deja.com Web site offers product buying service featuring user ratings, technical specifications, price comparisons, industry reviews and links to online stores (S)

headline: Learning to Think Smaller at Coke
abstract: Interview with new Coca-Cola Co head Douglas N Daft on his plan to restructure company, pushing worldwide decision-making down to local level; company's recent woes discussed; graphs of slowing sales growth and of stock price; drawing; photos (M)

headline: Hans Schwerte, 90, Ex-SS Man Who Hid Identity
abstract: Hans Schwerte, an authority on literary history who admitted in 1995 that under another name he had been an SS officer, died on Dec. 18 in a retirement home in Marquartstein, Germany. He was 90. His death was announced by the Aachen Technical University.     By the time that he acknowledged his SS role under his original name, Hans-Ernst Schneider, Dr. Schwerte had retired as a professor at the university, where he was rector from 1970 to 1973, and had received a high German decoration for his postwar contributions to German scholarship.

headline: Help! My Brain's Being Eaten by a Zillion Dot-Com Ads!
abstract: Interviews with some advertising executives and clients about advertising created during past year for dot.com retailers (Special Section, E-Commerce); photos (M)

headline: Clinton Hails OPEC Decision to Sell More Oil
abstract: Pres Clinton welcomes OPEC decision to increase crude oil production and urges oil companies to pass savings quickly along to consumers, news conference; Republicans in Congress, hoping to get political mileage from steep increase in gasoline prices this year, continue to attack administration on energy issues (M)

headline: Driven by Fear, Colombians Leave in Droves
abstract: Many people are fleeing Colombia and its political and criminal violence, and many of them are headed for US; exodus is particularly alarming because the people emigrating are highly educated professionals; working-class Colombians are also leavign in growing numbers; photo (M)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY -- Consumer Borrowing  Dec.    TUESDAY -- U.S. Productivity  4th Qtr.

headline: TECHNOLOGY EXTENDS MINE'S LIFE
abstract: South Africa's diamond mining company De Beers says it will build $94 million treatment plant that will prolong life of its mining operations in Kimberley by at least 28 years; with new technology, company will be able to mine previously unprofitable underground ore reserves and to recycle marginal dump reserves (S)

headline: Mortars Fired in Iran Near a Military Base
abstract: A day after a democratic reformer was wounded in a shooting in Tehran, the Iranian capital was the scene of another attack when mortar shells were fired into a residential complex near a military base.

headline: Bankruptcy Filings Fell in '99, Study Notes
abstract: University of Maryland study shows personal bankruptcy filings fell 8 percent last year; says number of individuals seeking bankruptcy protection in US courts fell by about 112,000 in 1999, to 1.3 million, from record 1.4 million in 1998; study is being hailed by critics of Congressional efforts to toughen bankruptcy laws (S)

headline: Marketing, as Taught By Credit Card Issuers
abstract: Credit card industry is more aggressively targeting college students and young adults in hope of recruiting them into becoming lifelong customers for their cards and other financial products; despite students' limited incomes and lack of credit history, market is gold mine for card marketers; Student Monitor, marketing research firm, NJ, says more than half of students at four-year colleges have at least one credit card, usually by end of their first year; photo; chart on credit cards carried by students (M)

headline: JAPANESE OUTPUT IS UP
abstract: Japan's International Trade and Industry Ministry reports nation's industrial output rose in January and is expected to increase for third straight quarter; output was up 0.9 percent in January from December, seasonally adjusted, and probably gained 2.7 percent in February; says while unemployment was stuck at 4.7 percent in January, more jobs are being offered and workers are working more overtime (S)

headline: After 16 Months of House Arrest, Pinochet Quits England
abstract: Gen Augusto Pinochet is allowed to fly home to Chile after Britain drops extradition proceedings against him and puts an end to his 16 months of house arrest in England; Home Sec Jack Straw tells House of Commons that because of Pinochet's failing health, he is ending complex legal and judicial case in which four European nations had been seeking Pinochet's extradition; case reviewed; chronology of events during Pinochet's time in England; photo (M)

headline: MCN TO SELL APPALACHIAN GAS ASSETS FOR $180 MILLION
abstract: MCN Energy Group to sell its Appalachian natural gas exploration, production and pipeline properties for about $180 million; most of deal is with Consol Energy Inc; Equitable Resources Inc will buy about $10 million of assets (S)

headline: SANTANDER DEAL WITH SOCIETE GENERALE
abstract: Spain's largest bank, Banco Santander Central Hispano, will cooperate with Societe Generale SA of France on asset management and other services; two banks will try to benefit jointly from Banco Santander's strength in Latin America and Societe Generale's strength in Asia; Banco Santander's co-chairmen say deal is not prelude to merger; Societe Generale will buy 3 percent stake in Banco Santander, worth about 1.1 billion euros, and Banco Santander will purchase nearly 2 percent more of Societe Generale, worth about 410 million euros, to increase its stake to 7 percent (S)

headline: David Williams Jr., 78, Energy Industry Executive
abstract: David R Williams Jr, industrialist and engineering innovator, dies at age 78 (S)

headline: CISCO PURCHASING SCOTTISH SOFTWARE COMPANY
abstract: Cisco Systems Inc acquires Atlantech of Scotland for $180 million in stock (S)

headline: A Yankee in Europe's Court?
abstract: Airbus, Europe's largest aircraft manufacturer, has fought its way to control of about half the world market for commercial jetliners in hard-fought struggle with Boeing Co; Airbus's success is in large measure result of efforts of John J Leahy, senior vice president for sales; Leahy, veteran of deregulation and consolidation of airline industry in United States, says success of Airbus is not one-man effort, but rather efforts of 500-person sales team in seven regions around the world; European airlines have in recent years turned to American executives who have experience in dealing with turmoil in US airline industry; photos, including Leahy (M)

headline: RUSSELL SAYS IT WILL ELIMINATE 800 MORE JOBS IN U.S.
abstract: Russell Corp, maker of Russell Athletic sportswear, is cutting 800 more jobs in United States as part of its plan to move more than 90 percent of its assembly plants to Honduras and Mexico by the end of the year; company has eliminated 4,241 US jobs over last 18 months (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   9.00   8.75   7.75       Discount rate   5.25   5.25   4.50       Federal funds   5.81   5.82   4.79       3-month T-bills   5.74   5.78   4.36       6-month T-bills   5.85   5.89   4.35       10-yr. T-infl.   4.16   4.16   3.90       10-yr. T-note   6.13   6.18   5.15       30-yr. T-bond   5.97   6.00   5.54       Telephone bd.   8.10   8.15   7.29       Municipal bds.   6.04   6.06   5.18          (Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Telerate; The Bond Buyer)

headline: AXA REVENUE UP 22%
abstract: Axa SA, world's largest insurer, says fourth-quarter revenue rose to 18.6 billion euros ($18.3 billion), or 22 percent, from 15.3 billion euros a year earlier; full-year revenues rose 17 percent, to 66.5 billion euros, or 10 percent when adjusted for acquisitions (S)

headline: Sibling Rivalry at Advance Publications
abstract: Mary Berner, new chief executive at Fairchild Publications, has poached more than 15 staff members from her former employer, Glamour, a corporate cousin, and plans to introduce new magazine that would compete with Vogue and still other corporate cousins; all are owned by Advance Publications; photo (S)

headline: Why a Victory in Taiwan Wasn't Enough for Some
abstract: Hsieh Tsung-min, hero of Taiwan's democracy and independence movement, says his dream came true with end of Nationalist rule and election of opposition leader Chen Shui-bian as president; Koo Kwang-ming, another movement hero, says he wants more complete assertion of independence from China; photos (M)

headline: Troops in Grozny Measure Their Gains in Yards
abstract: Blitz by Russian forces against Chechen capital of Grozny apparently falters, after rebels put up fierce resistance; Russians recover body of Maj Gen Mikhail Malofeyev, one of commander of Grozny operation who vanished during fighting; intense fighting continues; photo; maps (M)

headline: Revisions at TheStreet.Com Include Free Use of News Site
abstract: TheStreet.com Inc, financial Web site based in New York, says its news services will be free while some of its other sites will require fee-based subscriptions (S)

headline: IN MY...BRIEFCASE: MARSHA JOHNSON EVANS
abstract: Contents of briefcase carried by Marsha Johnson Evans, national executive director of Girl Scouts of the USA, described; Evans photo and photo of briefcase contents (S)

headline: In China's Legal Evolution, The Lawyers Are Handcuffed
abstract: Liu Jian was an idealistic new lawyer when his Nanjing firm sent him to a rural town 200 miles away to represent a local official accused of taking bribes.    Stationed in the town, Binhai, he worked round-the-clock doing what defense lawyers do to prepare for trial: interviewing witnesses, examining documents and -- when the police would allow -- brainstorming with his client.

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Graph depicts gain by euro against dollar on currency market on February 11 as sharp decline in stock prices in US discouraged demand for dollars

headline: TXU AGREES TO ACQUIRE FORT BEND COMMUNICATION
abstract: TXU Corp acquires Fort Bend Communication Companies for $167 million in stock and cash (S)

headline: Under Fire, Japan Sect Starts Over
abstract: Interview with Fumihiro Joyu, leader of reviled Aum Shinrikyo religious sect, which carried out poison gas attack against Tokyo subway system in 1995 killing 12 people; insists sect no longer poses threat to Japanese society; photo (M)

headline: Welch, in the Air . . .
abstract: Boeing Co and General Electric have formed business jet venture at behest of GE chairman Jack Welch, with GE ordering first two jets; total of 38 jets have been delivered, with 56 on order (S)

headline: U.S. to Offer Strategy on Money Laundering
abstract: US Treasury Department plans to introduce heavily promoted antimoney laundering program as part of Clinton administration's effort to combat international financial crime; program detailed (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Mexican Retail Group Buys Remainder of CompUSA  A retail group controlled by Carlos Slim Helu, the Mexican billionaire, said it was buying CompUSA, the American chain of personal computer stores, marking one of the biggest Mexican purchases of a prominent American business. Mr. Slim's retailing chain, Grupo Sanborns, already owns 14.8 percent of the common shares in CompUSA, a Dallas-based network of computer stores that has been struggling with losses and declining sales.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Greenspan Hints That Fed Will Increase Rates More  Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, said the economy showed few signs of slowing despite four interest rate increases in eight months, and he warned in unusually direct terms that the central bank would probably raise rates further to avert inflation.    In testimony to the House Banking Committee, he also set what amounted to a speed limit for Wall Street, saying that wringing the risk of inflation out of the economy would require that stock and other asset prices rise no faster than household incomes.   [Page A1.]

headline: China Anoints a 'Living Buddha,' but the Dalai Lama Dissents
abstract: Chinese authorities preside over enthronement of 2-year-old Soinam Puncog as an important 'living Buddha;' he is designated seventh Reting Lama, reincarnation of sixth lama in politically important line who died in 1997; move comes after 17th Karmapa Lama, ordained in 1992 with approval of Beijing authorities and Dalai Lama, fled to India on January 5; photo (M)

headline: EVANS SYSTEMS AGREES TO BUY I-NET HOLDINGS
abstract: Evans Systems agrees to buy I-Net Holdings for $142.5 million in stock as part of its plan to become a provider of Internet marketing services to the convenience-store industry (S)

headline: The Death of Grammar
abstract: Letter by Murray Lesser responds to March 9 article on review of usage manual for Net communication; says terms mentioned in review of manual appear to have originated with early users of computer-driven Bulletin Board Systems

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: FRONTIER AIRLINES INC., Denver, a low-fare airline, has signed a contract to buy 11 Airbus Industrie planes for about $420 million, with options for 9 more, as the airline phases out Boeing 737's.

headline: Gateway to Use Chips by Advanced Micro
abstract: Gateway Inc., the computer maker that last week blamed supply problems with the Intel Corporation for an earnings shortfall, plans to announce on Monday that it will again use microprocessors produced by Intel's archrival, Advanced Micro Devices .    Gateway executives said that the new machines using Advanced Micro's chips would be available through its stores, World Wide Web site (gateway.com) and toll-free number (800-846-4208).

headline: U.N. Members Slow to Accept An Invitation From Helms
abstract: Members of Security Council ponder invitation to Washington from Sen Jesse Helms, who has been leading critic of United Nations; diplomats are concerned about how image of powerful panel trundling off to Capitol Hill would play around world; Clinton adminstration officials are trying to broaden scope of visit, adding meetings with high-level State Dept and perhaps White House officials, capped by social evening with international guests; Secretary of State Madeleine K Albright sends her own invitation to 15 ambassadors on Security Council, urging them to make trip to Washington (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: BLACK HILLS CORP.,  Rapid City, S.D., an energy and communications company, said it had sold its natural-gas marketing business in Allentown, Pa., to Conectiv Inc., Wilmington, Del., which owns electric utilities, for an undisclosed price.

headline: PERSONAL BUSINESS; Those Stock Options Are for Outsiders, Too
abstract: As freelance work gains in popularity, stock options, once an employee-only perk, are becoming choice of payment for many in freelance workforce; Gabor Gurai, partner in law firm that specializes in compensation issues, says 'e-commerce companies are feeding this trend because they want to preserve cash and align their own interests with those of people who work for them'; other experts say it is vital for freelancers to view any equity-for-pay deal in same way they would an investment; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Regulators Impose 15-Month Moratorium On All Rail Mergers
abstract: Surface Transportation Board sets 15-month moratorium on all rail mergers to provide time to devise merger rules to tighten performance standards and bar kinds of service interruptions that have plagued recent mergers; stalls proposed merger of Burlington Northern Santa Fe Corp and Canadian National Railway, agreeing with competing railroads that merger would likely set off wild round of consolidations that would limit competition; Burlington and Canadian National score move; Canadian National challenges move, Federal court; railroad stocks rise; photo (M)

headline: For-Profit Web Sites Give New Meaning to Campaign Financing
abstract: Back in October, when Voter.com was pressing the two Democratic presidential campaigns to pay for space on its new for-profit Web site, the sales staff sent campaign aides e-mail messages saying the other camp was about to sign contracts with the site.    The tactic, according to campaign officials, prompted an unusual exchange: a campaign aide for Vice President Al Gore called the office of Bill Bradley to ask if the former New Jersey senator's campaign was really about to sign. The Bradley campaign had no such plans. Now, neither organization plans to do business with Voter.com.

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Euro rises against dollar on speculation that report will show increased business confidence in Germany, bolstering confidence in Europe; in New York, euro settles at 98.12 cents, up from 97.96 cents; graph; chart (S)

headline: World Bank Unit to Join In Internet Start-Up Finance
abstract: World Bank's International Finance Corp unit is teaming up with Softbank of Japan to create $200 million fund to finance Internet start-ups in 100 developing nations; International Finance Corp will also join Softbank's existing plan to invest $300 million in internet companies in China and Latin America; new venture, Softbank Emerging Markets, will provide seed capital to entrepreneurs, seek to transfer successful e-commerce business models and train managers to apply them; World Bank president, James D Wolfensohn, cites growing digital divide as impediment to development (M)

headline: Patent No. 6,003,018, For Asset Allocation
abstract: Richard Michaud and his son, Robert, receive patent for what pair call 'first serious improvement in portfolio construction and asset allocation technology in almost 50 years'; Michauds' method discussed (S)

headline: Microsoft Shares Slip After Report the Company May Be Broken Up
abstract: January 12, 2000

headline: The End of the Game; Tiger Management, Old-Economy Advocate, Is Closing
abstract: Tiger Management head Julian H Robertson Jr says he is shutting down operations; after chalking up outstanding investment record, Tiger Management is closing because of sharp reversal of fortunes; of $5.2 billion left, it will distribute 75 percent in cash and 5 percent in shares of 11 stocks; Tiger will keep its stake in five stocks to sell later; difficulties began in early fall of 1998 when Russia defaulted on its debt; Tiger lost $1.6 billion on bad currency bets that year, producing decline of almost 4 percent for 1998; things got worse in 1999 when technology stocks soared and value of shares tumbled; Tiger's returns plunged 19 percent; so far this year, funds are down 13.5 percent; graph; charts; photos (M)

headline: Even as Deals Fly, Wireless Remains a Tower of Babel
abstract: Telecommunications analysts and wireless telephone executives seem apathetic to Vodafone Airtouch PLC's $183 billion acquisition of Mannesmann AG; collective yawns may have only underscored how quickly communications industry is changing and how important wireless sector--once a backwater--has become; mulitbillion-dollar wireless deals have come so fast and furious over last year that Vodafone-Mannesmann agreement seems only to fit into pattern in what is perhaps fastest-growing segment of global telecommunications industry (M)

headline: U.S. MOVES TO HALT $30 BILLION UNION OF OIL COMPANIES
abstract: Federal Trade Commission votes 3 to 2 to seek preliminary injunction against BP Amoco's $30 billion proposed acquisition of Atlantic Richfield Co; commission officials say that merger would be anti-competitive and could lead to rises in price of crude oil for refiners in California and other West Coast states; say vote makes proposed merger largest to be challenged by government; photo (M)

headline: Bed Is Latest Weapon in Airline Perk Wars
abstract: Airlines are putting beds into their planes' business class sections on trans-Atlantic routes; business travelers, who buy only 20 percent of all tickets but account for about half of industry profits, have said they would rather snooze during long flights than dine on fine wine and caviar; Virgin Atlantic, British Airways and American Airlines lead the way; photo (M)

headline: Coke Recalls Hi-C Beverage
abstract: Coca-Cola Co recalls some of its Hi-C beverages because drinks have peculiar taste; International Brotherhood of Teamsters says some of recalled drinks are made at plant in Auburndale, Fla, operated by US unit of Sucocitrico Cutrale; about 200 Teamsters went on strike at plant last month; union said it was striking because company would not address safety concerns (S)

headline: SDL MAKES ACQUISITION TO EXPAND IN OPTICAL EQUIPMENT
abstract: SDL Inc acquires Veritech Microwave Inc for $590 million in stock (S)

headline: Bavarian Glimpses Vacancy at German Center Stage
abstract: Ambitions of Edmund Stoiber, conservative premier of Bavaria, to lead Germany have never been much of a secret, but with Christian Democratic Union in turmoil, he has abruptly emerged as formidable national force; Stoiber, whose politics stand at right edge of mainstream German conservatism, heads sister party of Christian Democrats called Christian Social Union (M)

headline: KeySpan Prices A Unit Stake
abstract: KeySpan Corp says it hopes its stake in Houston Exploration Co will sell for at least $25 a share, or about $384 million; $25-a-share offer would value entire oil exploration company at about $600 million; KeySpan owns 64 percent; KeySpan has signed confidentiality agreements with 19 companies interested in buying Houston Exploration (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Advertising assignments are announced by Oceans Resorts, Click2Asia and NowDocs.com Inc (S)

headline: STEEL PROFITS SURGE
abstract: Profits at Companhia Siderurgica Tubarao, one of Brazil's main steel exporters, surged to 99.8 million reais, or $55.8 million, in the fourth quarter of 1999, compared with loss year earlier; revenue more than doubled to 451 million reais, or $252 million (S)

headline: Media Talk; Online Hiring Evaluator (or Ego Deflator)
abstract: Media Talk column on popular Web site Vault.com, which provides career information and feedback about resumes to job seekers; photo (M)

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: ASIA    CHINA: PAKISTANI VISITS -- Gen. Pervez Musharraf, the nation's military ruler, arrived in China for his first visit outside the Islamic world since seizing power on Oct. 12. He met with Prime Minister Zhu Rongji. China has helped Pakistan's nuclear weapons program, and the general applauded China as Pakistan's ''most reliable and trusted friend.''   Barry Bearak (NYT)    PAKISTAN: SHARIF TRIAL REOPENS -- The treason and hijacking case against the ousted prime minister, Nawaz Sharif, began again after a judge quit the proceedings last week. Judge Rehmat Hussain Jaffri has taken up his predecessor's efforts to force prosecutors to share evidence with defense lawyers, a difficulty that has delayed the trial's start for more than a month.   Barry Bearak (NYT)

headline: AMAZON.COM TO BUY INTO NET HOME-FURNISHINGS SELLER
abstract: Internet retailer Amazon.com Inc agrees to acquire 18 percent interest in Living.com Inc, closely held Internet home-furnishings retailer, for undisclosed amount (S)

headline: Expensive Super Bowl spots seem to work for many dot-coms as traffic to their sites grows.
abstract: Madison Avenue advertising industry is closely watching results of performance of advertisers that spent huge sums required to run commercials during Super Bowl, especially ads for Internet sites; study by Media Metrix shows traffic to dot-com sites soared on Super Bowl Sunday and Monday after Super Bowl compared with average figures for three weeks before game; Media Metrix will be watching Web sites over next six to eight months; chart (M)

headline: NYT Article
abstract: Chess Star Kasparov Plays E-Commerce

headline: Dell Reduces Its Quarterly Profit Estimate
abstract: Dell Computer Corp, which has grown rapidly to become biggest personal computer maker in US, warns that its sales and profits will fall well below expectations for quarter that ends Jan 31; company says it is being hurt by shortages of some components and because sales to big corporations are not rebounding this month after having slowed at year-end as corporations became distracted with repairing Year 2000 problems; chief financial officer Thomas Meredith says he expects both problems to clear up in coming months (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Japanese yen edges lower after Bank of Japan sells currency to keep its strength from impeding economic growth; in New York, dollar settles at 105.57 yen, up from 105.05 yen; graph; chart (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: FRONTIER INSURANCE GROUP INC., Rock Hill, N.Y., a property and casualty insurer, laid off 71 employees, including 60 from its corporate headquarters. The cuts reduced the company's staff to about 640 in Rock Hill, 15 miles north of Middletown, and 1,200 nationwide.    USINTERNETWORKING INC., Annapolis, Md., which rents software through the Internet, has agreed with the AT&T Corp., New York, to market business services together to reach more customers. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: Debating Retirement's New Lines
abstract: Paul J Isaac letter comments on Fred Brock's Jan 2 column, which suggested that raising retirement age to 70 would be difficult for Americans whose jobs require hard physical labor

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   8.75   8.75   7.75       Discount rate   5.25   5.25   4.50       Federal funds   5.75   5.72   5.10       3-month T-bills   5.69   5.62   4.57       6-month T-bills   5.82   5.75   4.58       10-yr.
