headline: Small Brokers Courted in Nasdaq Vote
abstract: National Association of Securities Dealers member Alan Davidson says he will urge brokerage firms to vote against $1 billion plan to convert group's Nasdaq stock market into for-profit company; Davidson comments as association chairman Frank G Zarb announces that group has begun its April 14 vote on plan by sending proxy materials to 5,500 member firms (M)

headline: Heartening Sounds
abstract: Gregor Benko letter on Jan 20 article hails progress in developing laser reader for phonograph record grooves

headline: DEUTSCHE BANK TO CUT JOBS
abstract: The retail banking unit of Deutsche Bank A.G. said it would cut 1,200 jobs and invest in Internet services as the bank, Europe's second biggest, tries to generate more profit from the German market. The unit, Deutsche Bank 24, said it would spend 500 million marks, or $262 million, as it cuts the number of branches to 1,300 from 1,500 and slashes 6 percent of its staff.

headline: Tantalizing Hope: Looking for Yeti
abstract: In the past nine months, the  SETI@home screen saver has become a huge hit. The program has been loaded onto more than one and a half million home and office computers, where it is eagerly crunching through recorded radio signals from space (distributed via the Web) looking for signs of extraterrestrial life.    So far not a single alien sitcom has come wafting through the ether. The site, however, has proved that there is life on the Internet: it has spawned a Web spoof, YETI@home.

headline: Wall Street After Dark; Extended Hours Hold Promise for Markets, Pitfalls for Investors
abstract: David Barboza article presents overview of after-hours stock trading; many brokers say opening markets to small online investors after 4pm is next move in revolution sweeping Wall Street, toppling old-boy network and providing new opportunities for average investors, but warn investors about jumping in since market is thin and very volatile; photos; graphs; charts (L)

headline: Modems in Love
abstract: Letter by Stewart Dean responds to March 23 Q&A column; says article did good job of explaining horrendous squawking modem sounds

headline: U.S.-North Korea Talks on Missile Program Set for March
abstract: State Dept spokesman James P Rubin says North Korea will send high-level delegation to US in March 2000, opening way for talks on North Korea's missile program, spread of nuclear weapons and terrorism; describes visit as important step forward in improving hostile relations bwtween two countries; announcement comes at end of seven days of meetings in Berlin between US and North Korea (M)

headline: TWO MAKERS OF COMPUTER NETWORK EQUIPMENT TO MERGE
abstract: Apex Inc and Cybex Computer Products agree to merger valued at $1.14 billion that will bring together two rival makers of equipment for managing computer networks (S)

headline: Latin Stocks: A Wild but Upbeat Ride?
abstract: Clifford Krauss (Investing) article discusses volatility in Latin American stock markets in 1999; cites stock recommendations offered by James Upton, Latin American equity strategist at Credit Suisse First Boston; graph on Latin American stocks in 1999 (M)

headline: Exchange-Traded Funds Are the Hot Ticket Now
abstract: THE traditional mutual fund industry may be in a funk, but the interest of the money management business in so-called exchange-traded funds, indexed offerings that trade like stocks, is soaring.    Two big money management firms are poised to introduce dozens of new exchange-traded funds, or E.T.F.'s as they are sometimes known, in the next few months, according to government filings.

headline: Shankar Dayal Sharma, 81, Former President of India
abstract: Shankar Dayal Sharma, the emotional but decisive president of India in the turbulent years from 1992 to 1997, died on Dec. 26 in a hospital in New Delhi. He was 81 and lived in New Delhi.    A longtime member of the Congress Party, he was its president for a time. Dr. Sharma, whose doctorate was in law from Cambridge, was elected, with support from Congress and leftist groups, ninth president of India. That role is is largely ceremonial, though its powers include discretion in choosing a prime minister if no party has a parliamentary majority.

headline: VOLKSWAGEN WALKOUT ENDS
abstract: Factory that makes Volkswagens for much of southern Africa to reopen, ending weeklong shutdown from wildcat strike by assembly workers angry at union's suspension of shop stewards (S)

headline: INPRISE, A SOFTWARE CONCERN, TO SELL ITS HEADQUARTERS
abstract: Inprise Corp, software concern being acquired by Corel Corp, agrees to sell its Scotts Valley, Calif, headquarters to ScanlanKemperBard Cos for $47 million, and to sign long-term lease with ScanlanKemperBard to rent back 44 percent of building (S)

headline: Tainted Trust and Mideast Peace
abstract: Criminal inquiry into campaign practices of Prime Min Ehud Barak threatens to undermine Israelis' trust in him and his ability to make peace with Arabs without compromising security; Barak himself was not implicated by comptroller's report, which found that his associates systematically channeled illegal contributions through nonprofit organizations, but comptroller did hold him responsible for their actions, and a new poll shows that a majority believe Barak was well aware of what they were doing (M)

headline: Virtual Publishing: From Arthur Clarke To Psoriasis Tales
abstract: Traditional literary community warms to new electronic book market, formerly scoffed at as little more than vanity press profoundly flawed by absence of professional vetting and high quality writing; prominent authors, such as Arthur C Clarke, and many agents are submitting short works or out-of-print books scorned by traditional publishers to Fatbrain.com, digital publisher at vanguard of electronic market; Web site has become literary refuge for amateur writers yearning for outlet to display works; its unlikely literary patrons are investors like Microsoft co-founder Paul Allen and Highland Capital partners, who have backed it with $35 million in financing; site has existing list of 6,000 titles; photos (M)

headline: U.S. Program Takes Technology to Undeveloped Nations
Growth in Jobs At End of Year Beats Estimates
abstract: Labor Department reports 315,000 new nonfarm jobs were created in Dec, 75,000 more than expected; reports unemployment rate remained at 4.1 percent; says unemployment averaged 4.2 percent in 1999, down from 4.5 percent in 1998 and lowest rate since 3.5 percent in 1969; average hourly earnings for Dec rose 0.4 percent; graphs; tables (M)

headline: An Option for Deaf People
abstract: Yitzi Jacob letter on Feb 3 article on cell phones for deaf notes many deaf people use two-way interactive pagers instead of TTY (S)

headline: U.S. ENDING A FEW OF THE SANCTIONS IMPOSED ON IRAN
abstract: United States will end several of its economic sanctions against Iran, as Secretary of State Madeleine K Albright declares commitment to taking extensive steps toward ending two decades of hostility 'if Iran indicates a desire and commitment to do so'; Albright's speech is characterized by Clinton administration officials as most explicit overture to moderates who triumphed in Iran's parliamentary elections last month; Albright stops short of mentioning resumption of full diplomatic relations; she acknowledges, without apologizing, variety of American errors in past dealings with Iran, including Washington's support of 1953 coup that restored Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi to power; Albright says deeper removal of sanctions will come only after forces in Iran that support terrorism and try to obtain nuclear weapons technology loosen their hold on security apparatus (M)

headline: DUPONT SAYS IT HAS REJECTED SEVERAL DRUG VENTURES
abstract: E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, the largest United States chemical company, said yesterday that it had rejected several large pharmaceutical joint ventures with other drug makers after it could not agree on financial terms. DuPont has been seeking ways to bolster its pharmaceutical unit, which is considered relatively small in the consolidating drug industry. Separately, DuPont named Kurt M. Landgraf chief executive of its DuPont Pharmaceutical unit. Mr. Landgraf had been executive vice president and chief operating officer of the parent company. Shares of DuPont rose $3.75, to $71.50.

headline: As Mergers Get Bigger, So Does The Danger
abstract: Economic View column examines many risks of corporate megamergers; chart (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: US dollar is mixed against the euro and the Japanese yen; in New York the euro settles at 95.90 cents, down from 96.09 cents on March 3; dollar trades at 107.53 yen, down from 107.87; graph; chart (S)

headline: Sunbeam to Close a Plant
abstract: Sunbeam Corp will close Mr Coffee factory near Cleveland and dismiss plant's 339 employees to cut costs (S)

headline: Lama's Escape Inflames Buddhist Rivalry
abstract: Ugyen Trinley Dorje, 14-year-old high-ranking lama, fled Chinese-controlled Tibet on Dec 28, 1999 and arrived in Dharmsala, India, home to Tibetan government-in-exile on Jan 5; his sudden presence, while ticklish matter between India and China, has been cause for rejoicing among most Tibetans; he is considered third most revered figure in Tibetan Buddhism, after Dalai Lama and Panchen Lama; there has been less joy in New Delhi, home to rival faction that insists it is one with genuine incarnation of Karmapa, one of Tibetan Buddhism's holiest figures; he is Trinley Thaye Dorje; map; photos (M)

headline: A Town That Russians Allow Chechens to Police
abstract: Urus-Martan is only town in Russian-controlled Chechnya that is policed by Chechen militia, motley group of locals and former separatists allied with Moscow; map; photo (M)

headline: Saying It With Insurance
abstract: Insurance industry shifts into high marketing gear around Valentine's Day to get people to insure jewelry gifts that are not protected by most homeowners and rental policies (S)

headline: Leader of Troops in Chechnya Is Replaced
abstract: Col Gen Vyacheslav Ovchinnikov, commander of Russian Interior Ministry troops in Chechnya, is replaced as forces encounter stiff resistance in Chechen capital of Grozny; military says it has taklen control of one-third of capital in intense house-to-house fighting; maps; photo (M)

headline: A Capitalist Venturing in the World of Computers and Religion
abstract: On a late Friday afternoon in December, when most Silicon Valley executives were heading to their Napa Valley estates for the weekend, Vinod Khosla was tucked away in his office in Menlo Park, Calif., talking about God.    As an 11-year-old growing up in his native India, he says, he came to believe that organized religion was just a centuries-old form of social control; a fear of God was the only way to make an unruly population behave.

headline: Broadband: How Broadly? How Soon?; A Technology's Promised Arrival May Finally Be Here
abstract: After years of promises of imminent access by consumers to high-capacity, high-speed information services, known as broadband, such pipelines are finally reaching at least some American homes; converging Internet, cable TV and telephone industries are spending billions of dollars to make broadband a reality--at an estimated construction cost of $500 to $600 a household; some 1.4 million US homes now enjoy broadband access to what was once quaintly referred to as information highway; recent merger agreement between Time Warner and America Online is seen as major concession by AOL that future of cyberspace for everyday consumers is not in phone-line modems and dialup connections on which AOL has built its 20-million-subscriber base; for all industry monentum, though, it will take years, perhaps decades, for broadband data connections to become as common in US homes as telephone lines; photo; chart comparing cable and DSL Internet connections (L)

headline: Monuments to the Thai Debt; Real Estate Fiascoes Rear Their Heads On Bangkok Skyline
abstract: Some 300 unfinished buildings in Bangkok, Thailand, from skyscrapers to single-family dwellings, dot city's skyline, grim reminders of problems that still loom over economy; unfinished buildings are vestiges of Bangkok's recent property calamity; most of unfinished buildings represent collateral behind nearly 2 trillion baht (around $53 billion) in nonperforming loans still encumbering Thailand's financial system; charts; photos (M)

headline: When Young Managers Deliver the Pink Slips
abstract: Article on tips for beginning mangers who find themselves in position of having to lay off a worker; chart; photo (M)

headline: At Home, Even if Only From Afar
abstract: I have three business trips looming in the next five weeks. In addition to the usual arrangements -- plane reservations, hotel reservations, car rental, driving directions -- I find myself worrying about one thing more: Will there be access to a fax machine at about 5 o'clock Eastern Standard Time, so my third grader can fax me his homework?    There's a trend at our house when it comes to business travel. When my husband does it, someone back home always gets sick. Bruce was in Vienna when our older son was ordered to spend an immobile weekend on the couch because of an inflammation of his hip, and he was in San Jose, Calif., when that same son spent another weekend on the same couch because of a broken leg, so there was a lot of consulting and consoling done long distance.

headline: SURGE IN OIL PRICES IS RAISING SPECTER OF INFLATION SPIKE
abstract: Surge in oil prices in US ignites debate about whether they could spark inflation and threaten economic expansion; conventional view until recently has been that economy is being driven by technology, not manufacturing, and is not as dependent on energy as it once was; economists and OPEC watchers are split on whether oil problem will persist, since it might take oil-producing countries a couple years to drill for new oil even if they relax production cutbacks; Clinton administration is debating whether and how to intervene in market and push prices down; photo (M)

headline: British, Irish and Americans Scramble to Save Ulster Power-Sharing
abstract: Britain, Ireland and US are struggling to preserve power-sharing government in Belfast after David Trimble, first minister of Northern Ireland Assembly, says shutting down two-month-old government is 'inevitable' because Irish Republican Army is unwilling to disarm (M)

headline: As It Takes On Corruption, China Executes an Official
abstract: China executes former provincial vice governor for taking bribes; Hu Changqing is highest official put to death for corruption in 50 years since Communists came to power; execution follows Prime Min Zhu Rongji's promise to stamp out rampant corruption that extends to highest ranks of Communist Party; some Western diplomats say those in party elite are being protected; note wife of Beijing party chief, who was linked to $10 billion smuggling ring, is being spared, probably to protect her husband's career (M)

headline: In a Look at Low Taxes, High Marks for Wyoming
abstract: Bloomberg Personal Finance magazine evaluates tax bite of each state and District of Columbia for four hypothetical families; says Wyoming took smallest amount of taxes and ranked first in survey; rankings for some other states noted (S)

headline: CORNING TO SELL SHARES TO PAY FOR ACQUISITION
abstract: Corning Inc plans to sell 13 million shares to pay for its $1.4 billion acquisition of fiber optic businesses of Siemens AG (S)

headline: Putin's Litmus Test: Handling the Kremlin's Inner Circle
abstract: Russian businessmen and foreign investors believe the test of whether Acting Pres Vladimir V Putin is serious about putting Russian economy under the rule of law, with equal opportunities and conditions for all, will be his treatment of oiligarchs who helped put Boris N Yeltsin and increased their wealth and influence under him; Putin has said that this class 'will cease to exist,' but there are signs that he remains engaged with Yeltsin's inner circle; photo (M)

headline: An Adventure Wears Its Art on Its Sleeve
abstract: Charles Herold (Game Theory) article evaluates computer game Isabelle, from Belisa Media of France; $35 for Windows 95 and 98; photos (m)

headline: ANACOMP PLANS TO EXPLORE SALE OR MERGER OF COMPANY
abstract: Anacomp Inc is exploring merger or sale of company and has hired investment banker Allen & Co to help it evaluate alternatives (S)

headline: NYT Article
abstract: Sony's New Playstation to Spur DVD Industry
