headline: To Be Michael Jordan's, Or, Perhaps, Not to Be . . .
abstract: Gene H and Joe Silverberg, owners of recently closed Michael Jordan's Restaurant, Chicago, are in legal dispute with Jordan, basketball legend; brothers claim in addition to Jordan giving Silverbergs sole right to use his name on restaurant, he abandoned restaurant by refusing to make frequent visits and unreasonably blocking move to Palmer House Hotel; attorneys for Jordan dispute charges; complicating issue, Jordan is partner in One Sixtyblue, more upscale restaurant nearby (M)

headline: President-Elect Deplores Pinochet Welcome
abstract: Chile's president-elect Ricardo Lagos harshly criticizes hero's welcome staged by armed forces for Gen Augusto Pinochet, who returned from England after 16 months of house arrest on request by Spain for his extradition to stand trial for war crimes committed during era of military rule of early 1970's; welcome by top army commanders and elite special forces disturbes many Chileans; reopens old concerns about military's influence and engenders new debate about whether Pinochet will attend Lagos's upcoming inauguration; photo (M)

headline: Berlin Journal; Poking Fun, Artfully, at a Heady German Word
abstract: Berlin Journal reports on furor in Germany over proposed work of art for refurbished parlimentary building, Reichstag; perversion of language by Hitler still burns in Germany; Reichstag inscription says 'To the German People,' phrase that is associated with identity-through-blood; Hans Haacke, German artist living in New York, proposes for northern courtyard of Reichstag, above a trough filled with earth from throughout Germany, 'To the Population'; photos (M)

headline: MORTGAGED LIVES: A special report.; Profiting From Fine Print With Wall Street's Help
abstract: Special report, Mortgaged Lives, notes that scores of consumers have complained to state regulators about First Alliance Corp, national home-equity lender based in Irvine, Calif; over dozen homeowners have already sued; they assert that company has used deceptive sales pitch to lure homeowners into high-cost loans that expose them to threat of foreclosure and financial ruin; company has also been sued by AARP and by regulators in several states; Washington State seeks to suspend it from doing any business there; First Alliance still has some very important supporters, including Wall Street investment banks that help it raise money lent to people; investigation by New York Times and ABC News program 20/20 shows they have pumped hundreds of millions of dollars into First Alliance in recent years, even as lawsuits and state inquiries have raised questions about its practices; company was founded by Brian Chisick and his wife Sarah in 1971; photos (M)

headline: BBDO Worldwide makes changes in top management, mostly on the 'suit' side.
abstract: Top management of New York office of BBDO Worldwide is revamped, mostly on the account management or 'suit' side; William L Katz is promoted to president and co-chief executive; Jeffrey A Mordos is promoted to chief operating officer; changes raise some questions in regard to when Philip B Dusenberry, BBDO's longtime chairman, might begin making succession plans (M)

headline: Lebanon Grants Political Asylum to 1 of 5 Japan Terrorists
abstract: Lebanon grants poltiical asylum to Kozo Okamoto, member of Japanese Red Army who helped carry out masssacre in which 26 people died at Israeli airport in 1972; Beirut then orders deportation to Jordan of four to her members of Japanese Red Army, terrorist organization among world's most feared from early 1970's to late 1980's; Okamoto and other Japanese were arrested for being in Lebanon illegally in 1997; Japanese government has pressured Beirut to extradite all five members to Japan for trial on charges of terrorism and offenses against the state; Beirut says it granted Okamoto's request for political asylum because of suffering he endured while in Israeli prison (M)

headline: Annan Wants U.N., Not Saddam, to Control Money for Mecca
abstract: UN Sec Gen Kofi Annan devises plan to pay for Iraqi pilgrimages to Mecca without letting government of Saddam Hussein disburse money; Iraq, whose foreign earnings are controlled by UN, is permitted to draw money for pilgrimages from oil sale earnings and is seeking $49.4 million deposit in central bank account to be disbursed by government to approximately 24,700 pilgrims; is not normally given such large sum to handle as it wishes; Security Council is discussing Annan proposal to give pilgrims $250 each for trip out of Iraq, to be supplied through UN offices in Baghdad; remaining funds would be deposited with designated agencies in Jordan or Saudi Arabia to be drawn on by Iraqis when they arrive there; there is concern that Iraq may provoke confrontation if denied money on its terms (M)

headline: Two Top Researchers Join the Disney Exodus
abstract: Bran Ferren and Danny Hillis, two of Walt Disney Co's top research scientists, say they are leaving to form their own technology company; they are latest in series of defections from company; analysts say departures are partly because of cost pressures or difficulty in working for Disney's chief executive, Michael D Eisner; also note Disney executives are highly sought after by other companies (M)

headline: With Africa Watching, Senegal Casts Votes That Count
abstract: Senegal's presidential election is being watched around Africa because it offers voters choice among four credible candidates; loss by Pres Abdou Diouf, who seeks fourth consecutive term, would be significant on continent becoming increasingly impatient with democracies that offer no real choices; map; photo (M)

headline: Jack E. Brown, 72, a Computer Industry Lawyer
abstract: Jack E Brown, lawyer prominent in several early cases concerning computer industry and intellectual property, dies at age 72 (M)

headline: BRAZIL BOND OFFERINGS
abstract: Brazil's National Bank of Economic and Social Development sells $190 million of securities backed by proceeds from jet exports; after financing sale of jets by Empresa Brasileira de Aeronautica SA to AMR Corp, bank will back two-and-a-half-year bonds with accounts receivable from deal (S)

headline: Seagate to Be Taken Private in Intricate Buyout
abstract: Seagate Technology, world's largest disk drive company, will be taken private by investor group led by Silver Lake Partners, Seagate executives and Texas Pacific Group; merger terms discussed (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)

headline: Alternatives For Passengers
abstract: Article on possible air travel alternatives for passengers if in the event of strike and shutdown at US Airways (S)

headline: HENRY BLODGET
abstract: THE life of Henry Blodget shifted into a higher gear in December 1998, when he made a prescient prediction about Amazon.com

headline: The New York Times - Reporter Biography: Katie Hafner
abstract: Reporter Biography: Katie Hafner

headline: U.S. APPEALS STEEL RULING
abstract: US appeals World Trade Organization ruling that it erred in imposing countervailing duties on lead and steel products from British company that had been subsidized by government; US officials argued that duties were necessary to compensate for government subsidies that skewed competitive advantage of British companies (S)

headline: Pain Relief Underused For Poor, Study Says
abstract: Report by International Narcotics Control Board, UN agency based in Vienna, focuses on severe shortage of morphine and other painkillers in poor countries, where many are left to die in agony from cancer and other diseases; finds great disparity in access to strong painkillers among poor and in poor countries, usually, but not always, for economic reasons; cites cultural and social attitudes as well as medical philosophies; says there is no evidence that painkillers are widely diverted for illicit use, and that there is no reason to caution against increased production (M)

headline: Israeli Killed in Lebanon, Spurring Calls to Retaliate
abstract: Israeli soldier is killed and seven are wounded in southern Lebanon in latest of series of deadly guerrilla attacks that have intensified pressure on Prime Min Ehud Barak to mount significant retaliatory strike; Iranian-backed Hezbollah, or Party of God, claims responsibility; is trying to oust Israel from nine-mile-wide buffer zone Israelis regard as crucial to prevent cross-border attacks; death brings to five number of Israeli soldiers killed in southern Lebanon in past two weeks, posing urgent problem for Barak; he is eager to resume peace talks with Syria, and seems reluctant to unleash large-scale military strike, despite public clamor, that could hurt chances of returning to negotiating table; map; photo (M)

headline: NORTHERN STATES TO BUY EASTERN POWER PLANT INTERESTS
abstract: Northern States Power Co agrees to buy four coal-fired power plants and stake in two others from Conectiv Inc, which sells power in four Eastern states, for $800 million (S)

headline: INDONESIAN CENTRAL BANK PLAN
abstract: Finance Minister Bambang Sudibyo said the Indonesian government would recapitalize the central bank in March, but the exact amount of the funds was still being calculated. A recent audit showed that the central bank was close to insolvency. Officials have tried to restore confidence, saying the government is determined to restore the bank's capital position.

headline: General Electric Launches Personal Finance Site
abstract: General Electric Launches Personal Finance Site

headline: Business Officials Urge Extension of Internet Tax Ban
abstract: Business Officials Urge Extension of Internet Tax Ban

headline: MARTHA STEWART TO BUY BACK SOME SHARES FROM TIME INC.
abstract: Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia Inc to repurchase about 1.4 million of its shares from Time Warner's Time Inc for $23.79 each--below current market value--in transaction valued at $32.5 million; Time Inc will retain 1.22 million shares for about three years; Time Inc also agrees to extend terms of its magazine distribution, fulfillment and service agreements with Martha Stewart for additional three years (S)

headline: New Design For Processor To Test Intel
abstract: Transmeta Corp, ending almost five years of secrecy, announces new microprocessor design that promises tough competition for Intel Corp; new chips are compatible with Intel's products while consuming substantially less power and costing less; Transmeta's processors, by emphasizing software, are intended to improve on portable versions of Pentium-class microprocessors that power personal computers; company says it is also pushing toward widely anticipated post-personal computer era of mobile Internet computing; chips are already being manufactured by IBM, which expects to begin shipping them by middle of year; chart; photo (M)

headline: NatWest Says It Wants to Stay Independent
abstract: National Westminster Bank, Britain's third-biggest bank, says it is determined to remain independent, even as its biggest shareholders prepare to side with one of two hostile bids by Scottish rivals, Bank of Scotland and Royal Bank of Scotland Group (S)

headline: A Look at How the Kremlin Slid Into the Chechen War
abstract: Interview with former Russian prime minister Sergei V Stepashin, who describes behind-the-scenes debate in Kremlin that led to escalation of Russian military involvement in breakaway province of Chechnya; says original plan was to seal borders of Chechnya, re-occupy pro-Russian parts and to stem flood of kidnappings in region, but that Russian generals, humiliated by 1994-96 war, were pressing for decisive fight to settle old scores; decision by acting president Vladimir V Putin to occupy all of Chechnya is seen reflecting resolve to assert traditional Russian interests and his closeness with Russian security establishment conducting war; even Putin's close associates are questioning whether strategy can deal rebels early knockout blow as fighting has dragged on; photo (M)

headline: Schedule of Equity Offerings for This Week
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

headline: The Death of Grammar
abstract: Letter by Alex Hays responds to March 9 article on review of usage manual for Net communication; notes debate over plural of word mouse

headline: Details Emerge in Kosovo Girl's Slaying
abstract: Army Staff Sgt Frank J Ronghi appears at military hearing in Kosovo on charges of committing indecent acts with Merita Shabiu, 11-year-old Albanian, and then murdering her; photo (M)

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: EUROPE    IRELAND: COPING WITH REFUGEES  To cope with more than 1,000 requests for political asylum every month, the government is to spend $86 million to build temporary housing for 8,000 refugees. The accommodations will include so-called flotels, housing blocks on barges moored in ports. Most of the refugees come from Eastern Europe and Africa.   Brian Lavery (NYT)    NORTHERN IRELAND: I.R.A. REBUFF  Sinn Fein's president, Gerry Adams, rebuffed a call for an Irish Republican Army declaration that violence is ended in the province, saying the request from the Northern Ireland secretary, Peter Mandelson, was ''absolute nonsense.'' Mr. Adams said the only way to guarantee that war did not break out again was to restore home rule government, suspended after the I.R.A., which Sinn Fein represents, failed to begin disarming.   Warren Hoge (NYT)

headline: Computer Briefs
abstract: Compressed Data: From Victim to Entrepreneur

headline: Leon Radzinowicz, 93, Leader in Criminology
abstract: Leon Radzinowicz, a scholar of criminology who played a major role in the development of the field, died on Dec. 29 at his home in Haverford, Pa. He was 93.    For most of his career, Mr. Radzinowicz, who was knighted by Queen Elizabeth II in 1970, taught law at Cambridge University, where he also founded the Institute of Criminology in 1959; he retired in 1973 after serving as its first director.

headline: BULGARIA TO GET TV STATION
abstract: News Corporation wins right to establish Bulgaria's first nationwide private television station and to broadcast in country for 15 years, giving company foothold in Balkan region; News Corp says it will invest initial $15 million in Bulgaria (S)

headline: Merrill Lynch Is Set to Move Into Banking
abstract: Merrill Lynch & Co is preparing to make its biggest push to compete with banks for customers' deposits; Merrill is taking advantage of recent changes in national banking laws to roll out new banking services, including federally insured, interest-bearing account tied to its customers' investment accounts; Merrill executives also are developing first new version of firm's Cash Management Account, which broke new ground 25 years ago by combining interest-bearing checking with standard brokerage account that held stocks and bonds; new version will allow customers who are queasy about mixing investments and savings to choose how to segregate various assets within account; vice chairman John L Steffens comments (M)

headline: Digital Commerce; If the AOL-Time Warner deal is about proprietary content, where does that leave a noncommercial directory it will own?
abstract: Denise Caruso (Digital Commerce) article says proposed purchase by America Online of Time Warner is deal for control over as much of the system as possible for high-speed delivery of digital entertainment; notes that with such huge assets at risk, neither company knows--or seems particularly eager to learn--about operating in an environment like the Internet, which defies control and confounds planning for the future (M)

headline: Sears in Dispute With Focus Media
abstract: Sears, Roebuck & Co is ending ties with Focus Media, one of its media buying agencies; sues Focus for breach of contract; Young & Rubicam Advertising will assume duties from Focus (M)

headline: An Airline Executive Who Missed the Boat
abstract: Virgin Group chairman Richard Branson says he erred in deciding not to own stake in JetBlue Airways, new low-fare airline, interview; photo (M)

headline: Economic Scene; The golden formula for Hollywood success. It only happens in the movies.
abstract: Virginia Postrel 'Economic Scene' column on strategies used by motion picture producers and studios for success at box office; focuses on studies by University of California Prof Arthur De Vany and University of Hong Kong Prof W David Walls that show even major film stars canot guarantee success of a film and there is no formula for success; photo of actress Michelle Pfeiffer and her husband, writer-producer David E Kelley (M)

headline: NETGROCER.COM SELLING 22% STAKE TO PARMALAT
abstract: NetGrocer.com Inc will sell 22 percent stake to Parmalat Finanziaria for $30 million to help finance its expansion (S)

headline: Increased Bids Are Foreseen In NatWest Takeover Fight
abstract: Royal Bank of Scotland Group and Bank of Scotland are expected to increase their bids for National Westminster Bank; Royal Bank will have to pay at least $3.24 billion more to surpass Bank of Scotland's offer of $39.23 billion; NatWest has rejected both bids and issued statement that both suitors lack management resources and experience to take over NatWest on their own (M)

headline: I.B.M. Achieves Advance In Memory for Computers
abstract: Group of IBM scientists say they have achieved technological breakthrough that could result in disk drives capable of holding more than one trillion bytes of data--more than 100 times capacity of today's most typical hard drives; in article published in journal Science, researchers say they discovered chemical reactions that cause tiny magnetic particles, each no larger than few thousand atoms, to assemble themselves at precise intervals (M)

headline: Kohl Resigns German Party Post After He Is Rebuked for Scandal
abstract: Helmut Kohl resigns as honorary chairman of Germany's opposition Christian Democratic Party after he is accused by leadership of violating his duties by refusing to identify donors who secretly gave him more than $1 million when he was chancellor and party leader during 1990's; says Christian Democratic Party will remain his political home; will retain seat in lower house of Parliament, which shields him from criminal prosecution unless Parliament votes to lift immunity; Wolfgang Schauble, party's current leader, says Christian Democratic Union is in one of worst crises of its history as result of disclosure of secret cash payments, overseas accounts and other irregularities during Kohl's 16-year tenure; has also admitted accepting $52,000 payment from fugitive arms broker and is also expected to resign; photos (M)

headline: Davos Forum Opens With Qualified Exuberance
abstract: World Economic Forum opens in Davos, Switzerland; Pres Clinton and Britain's Prime Min Tony Blair are among politicians scheduled to attend; photo (M)

headline: Jewelry:The Art of Expressing the Personal
abstract: ATHENS—  Some say it's a southern thing, but Greek women are rarely caught without jewelry. In contrast to the gems flaunted on one-night-diamond-stands like the Oscars, however, cool design here goes beyond conventional flash.

headline: Consumer Confidence Hits an All-Time High; Jobs Called 'Plentiful' : Clinton Sees An Early Payoff of U.S. Debt
abstract: WASHINGTON—  On a day when consumer confidence was reported at a record high, President Bill Clinton seized on the prolonged U.S. economic expansion Tuesday to propose paying off the government's public-held debt by 2013, two years sooner than had been expected.

headline: Israel Reports Abuses in Past Interrogations of Palestinians
abstract: Official Israeli report made public on Feb 9 says Shin Bet security service committed systematic abuses while interrogating prisoners during Palestinian uprising and that its agents had lied about their actions in court; report was submitted in 1995 by then Israeli Comptroller Miriam Ben-Porat (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Shrinking Treasury Debt Creates Uncertain World
abstract: US Treasury's plan to reduce debt is roiling financial markets and raising prospect of far-reaching, unintended effects on economy and investors; economists say one immediate effect of shrinking debt market is to make it tougher for Federal Reserve Board to cool economy because as it raises short-term interest rates, long-term rates are not raising in tandem; debt securities that remain in shrinking market are expected to be much more prone to wild swings in price and thereby riskier for investors; corporations will probably issue more debt to fill public demand for bonds, creating debt burden that could make it much more difficult for nation to shake off downtown in economy (Market Place column) (M)

headline: Ambon Journal; A Year of Holy War Among Neighbors
abstract: A

headline: FOOTSTAR PLANS TO PICK UP SOME ASSETS OF JUST FOR FEET
abstract: Footstar Inc plans to acquire some of assets of its money-losing rival Just for Feet Inc for about $70 million; Footstar will pay $69.7 million in cash for Just for Feet's brand name, 79 superstores, 23 specialty stores, its Internet business and corporate headquarters; it will also assume $2.9 million in Just for Feet debt (S)

headline: U.S. Courting India in Hope Of Restarting Trade Talks
abstract: Clinton administration will court India as ally in trying to restart global trade talks with collapsed in Seattle in December; few expect close friendship to be forged overnight, but officials hope high-level visits can send message that rift between developing and developed countries was confinedto chaotic Seattle meeting, and does not reflect broader breakdown in globalization (M)

headline: Xircom Shares Get Slammed After Earnings Warning
abstract: March 24, 2000

headline: Judge Says Companies May ´Deep Link´ to Rivals
abstract: Judge Says Companies May 'Deep Link' to Rivals

headline: G.E. Joins Effort to Advance Financial Literacy
abstract: Compressed Data: G.E. Joins Effort to Advance Financial Literacy

headline: Sony Vaio Player Puts Music in Your Pocket
abstract: Several new audio players have the look and feel of anything but digital technology; one example is the Sony Vaio Music Clip, which has the weight and dimensions of pen and can be carried in shirt pocket of dangling like pendant from your neck; price is $299; photo (S)

headline: BAAN EQUITY SHORTFALL
abstract: World Business Briefin

headline: Trailblazing Textiles Lure Clients Who Revel in Color and Texture : With Exotic Fabrics, Designers Meet a Desire to Break Away
abstract: MILAN—  One remarkable trickle-down effect of Italian ready-to-wear fashion has been the general availability of well-designed, well-cut garments for all purses. As a result, Italian women in general are reliably elegant. Yet such reliability conceals the grub of predictability. And this provokes reaction.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Agreement on Digital TV Appears Unfinished, Again  Under threat from the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, the cable television and consumer-electronics industries have said, once again, that they have solved a vexing problem slowing the transition to digital TV, how to connect a digital television set to a digital cable box.   But the issue is not fully resolved. Hollywood and the industries have not decided on a copy-protection standard, making the whole agreement hollow, some analysts say.   [Page C9.]    Ashes of the Year 2000 Problem  There is still widespread debate on just how great the threat of Year 2000 computer problems ever was. One clear example of how disruptive Year 2000 could have been, had no one taken precautions, involved a credit-card payment system made by Cybercash. Some owners of small businesses that use Cybercash, including Tzu Ming Yang, who owns a restaurant in Baltimore, did not update their system software and unwittingly billed their customers day after day for the same transaction. Because of special rules aimed at discouraging Year 2000 litigation passed last year by Congress, lawyers say it will be spring at the earliest before lawsuits emerge involving the Cybercash breakdowns or any others.   [C5.]

headline: Personal Business; Food Fights
abstract: For overworked Americans, the two-martini lunch has turned into the two-minute lunch, or a series of hurried snacks, consumed at the desk or in a Spartan break room. Etiquette hasn't kept up. Half-eaten sandwiches are stolen from their owners' desks, while office mircrowaves and refrigerators ooze with months of grime. And few workplaces seem to have any desktop-dining rules. Send your spiciest stories to On the Job, Money & Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43rd Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by e-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com Include your name and telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

headline: Kariel Gardosh, 79, Who Created Israeli Icon
abstract: Kariel Gardosh, Israeli political cartoonist who captured national psyche in depictions of his country as an innocent boy in a tough neighborhood, dies at 79; photos (M)

headline: AKAMAI PLANS TO BUY CLOSELY HELD SOFTWARE COMPANY
abstract: Akamai Technologies Inc acquires Network24 Communications for $200 million in stock and cash (S)

headline: Making Your Way Through the Maze of Medicare Options
abstract: Larry Katzenstein article on getting most from Medicare coverage; explains basic choices and reasons for making them, or not making them; photos (special section, Retirement) (M)

headline: Madrid Airport's a Noisy Nightmare, Say Protesters in Pajamas
abstract: Victory of Jose Maria Aznar and his conservative party in Spain's elections could be bad news for residents of 16 Madrid suburbs who filed suit against planned expansion of Madrid's Barajas Airport, arguing that it presented health and safety dangers and would inhibit urban planning; Aznar favors extension; he has opposed calls for new airport, further from city center, despite continuous media complaints about airport delays and protests against noise (M)

headline: C.I.A. Tells Clinton An Iranian A-Bomb Can't Be Ruled Out
abstract: CIA reportedly informs senior Clinton administration officials that Iran may now be able to make a nuclear weapons, touching off a sharp debate about Iran's nuclear capacity and the CIA's ability to monitor it; evaluation is apparently not based on evidence that Iran's indigenous efforts to build a bomb have achieved a breakthrough, but rather on fact that US cannot track with great certainty the increased efforts by Iran to acquire nuclear materials technology in international black market; US has made little headway with efforts to weaken longstanding strategic relationship between Iran and Russia, which is still brimming with stockpiles of nuclear fuel and weapons related technology and has long sold sensitive nuclear and missile technology to Iran; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Dollar hits five-month high against yen; graph (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Euro hits its lowest level ever against US dollar in New York, at 96.65 cents, but gains slightly late in day; euro finishes at 97.28 cents, down about 16 percent since its introduction in January 1999; graph; chart (S)

headline: 4th-Quarter Loss Grew at Fruit of the Loom
abstract: Fruit of the Loom reports fourth-quarter loss from operations widened to $327.8 million from year-earlier $32.4 million; puts net loss at $398.5 million, compared with $11 million year-earlier loss (S)

headline: Andersen Consulting to Aid Employees
abstract: Andersen Consulting says it will invest $200 million in electronic-commerce companies this year and distribute proceeds to employees; in company years, Andersen plans to invest $100 million annually on behalf of long-term and top-performing workers; investments will be made through Andersen Consulting Ventures, a $1 billion fund formed in December (S)

headline: Thief Reveals Credit Card Data When Web Extortion Plot Fails
abstract: A mysterious computer intruder has tried to extort $100,000 from an Internet music retailer after claiming to have copied its collection of more than 300,000 customer credit card files, which could be used by others to charge purchases online or by telephone.    Because the company, CD Universe, has refused to pay blackmail, the anonymous intruder has released some of the credit card files on the Internet. He also claims to have used some other credit card numbers to obtain money for himself.

headline: Shopping on Priceline
abstract: Letter from Robert Rahtz comments on Jan 6 article on Priceline shopping (S)

headline: Earnings Rise 59% at Reader's Digest
abstract: Reader's Digest Association Inc says second-quarter profit rose 59 percent; reports net income rose to $96.8 million from $60.8 million; says revenue rose 3 percent, to $844 million from $817 million (S)

headline: Justice Department Investigating eBay
abstract: February 4, 2000

headline: DELTA TO BUY BACK STOCK AND TAKE CHARGE FOR AIRCRAFT
abstract: Delta Air Lines Inc will buy back as much as $500 million of its shares and take pretax $320 million second-quarter charge for early retirement of 24 aircraft (S)

headline: After Fleeting Reunion, Austrian Coalition Shatters Once Again
abstract: after fleeting reunion, austrian coalition shatters once again**Austria's old ruling coalition, reunited after three months of wrangling, abruptly falls apart again; Chancellor Viktor Klima of Social Democratic party will try to form minority government with cabinet of non-party members, but talks with People's Party have collapsed, giving new leverage to Jorg Haider and his right-wing Freedom Party S)

headline: In Numbers, the Heavy Now Match the Starved
abstract: Study of global trends by Worldwatch Institute finds number of overweight people currently rival number of hungry and underfed; says 1.2 billion people, largest number ever recorded, are underfed and undernourished, and that additional 1.2 billion are eating too much of wrong food and have become probably fastest-growing group of malnourished (S)

headline: To Spur Market Share, G.M. Offers Coupons
abstract: A new and potentially costly marketing struggle broke out in the auto industry today as the General Motors Corporation announced discount coupons on almost all of its vehicles even as several other automakers said their sales remained fairly strong in December, capping a record year.    G.M., which is struggling to stem a slide in market share, said that it would mail the coupons to all owners of its vehicles and to anyone who had recently expressed an interest in buying a G.M. car or light truck through the company's toll-free telephone numbers or its Web sites.

headline: GENERAL CABLE IS SELLING SEVERAL BUSINESSES TO PIRELLI
abstract: General Cable Corp, in move to reduce debt, to to sell its energy cable businesses in Europe, Africa and Asia to Pirelli Cavi e Sistemi of Italy, a unit of Pirelli SpA, for $216 million (S)

headline: What Are They Saying?
abstract: Letter from Rosalie Sennett on Microsoft's newest television ads (S)

headline: Reporters Square Off Over Clinton Scandal
abstract: Michael Isikoff and Jeffrey Toobin are arguing about Toobin's portrayal of Isikoff in his new book, A Vast Conspiracy: The Real Story of the Sex Sandal That Nearly Brought Down a President; Isikoff claims Toobin paints him as vindictive enemy of Clinton's; Isikoff was first to discuss Clinton's relationship with Monica S Lewinsky; his book, Uncovering Clinton: A Reporter's Story, was published in 1999 (M)

headline: AVERSTAR TO BE BOUGHT BY TITAN, A CONSULTANT
abstract: Titan Corp acquires AverStar Inc for about $140 million in stock and about $65 million in debt (S)

headline: G.E. Settles Shareholders' Suit Over Kidder
abstract: General Electric Co will pay its stockholders $19 million to settle class-action lawsuit that contended that actions by Joseph Jett, bond trader for Kidder, Peabody & Co, former GE subsidiary, inflated Kidder's net worth and deceived shareholders about value of GE stock; investors had said they overpaid for GE stock in 1993 and 1994 because Jett created phony profits that overstated Kidder's financial performance by $350 million; Kidder exists only on paper now, with no current operations; GE sold Kidder's main operations in 1994 to Paine Webber Group Inc (S)

headline: Jerome Goldstein, 77, Founder Of a Furniture Polish Maker
abstract: Jerome Goldstein, who built modest business selling homemade wood restorer into multimillion-dollar, publicly traded company called Scott's Liquid Gold, dies at age 77 (S)

headline: Ex-Official Challenges China's Limits on Speech
abstract: Bao Tong, former senior Chinese official who spent seven years in prison for sympathizing with democracy advocates, challenges authorities to abide by the Constitution and stop restricting his freedom to speak out; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Euro gains on dollar, heading into its first anniversary as currency; graphs (S)

headline: Report Says Privacy Challenges Are Significant
abstract: Report Says Privacy Challenges Are Significant

headline: Cable Company Blocking Fox Programs
abstract: Cox Communications Inc., the fifth largest cable operator in the United States, has blocked 500,000 customers from seeing local programming from News Corporation's Fox Entertainment Group Inc. after the two companies failed to reach a new distribution agreement.    Cox customers in Cleveland; Dallas; Houston; Austin, Tex., and Fairfax County, Va., have been unable to view Fox programming, including National Football League games and local news, since Jan. 1 unless they have an antenna or satellite.

headline: Shopping With Priceline: Promise and Problems
abstract: Steven Martin letter on Michelle Slatalla's Jan 6 article notes Priceline shoppers sacrifice privacy

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; Microsoft and Telmex Plan A Latin Region Web Portal
abstract: Microsoft Corp chairman William H Gates joins forces with richest man in Latin America, Carlos Slim Helu, in battle to dominate Internet in region by creating portal site that combines expertise of Microsoft with communications reach of Telefonos de Mexico; Gates says portal site, called tlmsn.com, began with six million users; Spanish-speaking subscribers to Prodigy, Internet service to Telefonos de Mexico, or Telmex, and to Microsoft's msn.com are automatically channeled to new portal; Gates says Web explorer program on all personal computers with Microsoft operating software sold in Latin America will have tlmsn.com as first port of entry to Internet; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Natural gas prices fall 4.5 percent after mild weather is forecast for most of country next week; natural gas for March delivery falls 11.8 cents, to $2.515 for a million BTU's; graph; chart (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)

headline: MP3.com Plans to Let Users Store Music Files on Its Site
abstract: MP3.com, which operates popular music Web site, plans to start service that will enable customers to store music online, move that threatens recording industry's attempts to control distribution of music online; while service will employ password security system, it could make easier swapping of copyrighted music over Internet by users who decide to share their passwords and thus music they have stored (M)

headline: Cruise Line Expands Fleet
abstract: The Carnival Corporation, the world's largest cruise operator, has exercised an option to have a $375 million cruise ship built, continuing a fleet expansion to meet growing demand for cruise vacations. The 2,112-passenger Carnival Legend will be delivered to the Miami-based company in 2002, it said. The ship will be built at the Kvaerner Masa shipyard in Helsinki. Carnival Legend is one of 11 new ships being built for Carnival, at a total cost of about $4.3 billion.

headline: OXY PETE SELLS CANADIAN AFFILIATE
abstract: Seven-month standoff between Occidental Petroleum Corp and its 29 percent-owned Canadian affiliate, Canadian Occidental Petroleum Ltd, has been resolved through sale of Occidental's stake for $822 million; affiliate will pay $592 million for 20 million of its own shares; Ontario Teachers Pension Plan Board will pay $600 million for 20.2 million shares (S)

headline: Several Media Companies Form Web Site Partnership
abstract: Brill Media Holdings, which publishes Brill's Content magazine, agrees to form partnership with CBS, NBC, Primedia, Ingram Book Group and EBSCO, company that provides magazine subscription services and databases of already-published magazine content; partnership will introduce Web site called Contentville.com in second half of year that will sell books, magazine subscriptions, transcripts, scholarly monographs, and access to previously published magazine articles, among other materials; CBS, limited partner, will own 35 percent equity position in exchange for $40 million in advertising and promotion over three years; Brill Media Holdings, managing partner, will own 34 percent; NBC, Primedia, Ingram and EBSCO will each own 5 percent to 10 percent of partnership; venture raises issue of whether Brill is compromising Brill's Content magazine's independence (M)

headline: Scudder Kemper Cuts Number of Fund Offerings
abstract: Scudder Kemper Investments Inc is merging 23 mutual funds and shutting 6, as it seeks to strengthen its partnership with AARP, formerly American Association of Retired Persons, and reverse withdrawals of $3 billion last year; total number of funds will be reduced to 43 (M)

headline: Visa Program Would Rise by 45,000 Under Smith Bill
abstract: Visa Program Would Rise by 45,000 Under Smith Bill

headline: Wish List Woes
abstract: Sydney Rubin letter lauds Feb 3 article on online gift registries for paying so much attention to privacy issue

headline: Show Business Dailies Brawl at Sundance
abstract: Competition between two show business dailies, Daily Variety and The Hollywood Reporter, gets nasty after each carries embarrassing article about behavior of other's reporter at Sundance movie festival (S)

headline: AMERICAN INTERNATIONAL PLANS A $2.2 BILLION BUYBACK
abstract: American International Group will buy back up to 25 million of its shares, worth more than $2.2 billion at current price (S)

headline: As Rates Surge, Survival Strategies
abstract: Gretchen Morgenson article discusses impact of Federal Reserve's raising interest rates on investors and consumers; includes six bylined articles that offer advice on dealing with rising rates in areas of stocks, bonds, foreign investments, loans, charitable gifts and impact on consumers vis-a-vis overall economy; graphs (L)

headline: Kana Communications to Buy Silknet Software
abstract: February 7, 2000

headline: Campaign to Oust Elitist Politicians Picks Up Steam Before Vote : In South Korea, a Quiet Revolution
abstract: SEOUL—  The young people believed they had the perfect spot to push their message: the plaza in front of Seoul Station as crowds rushed to board trains for the three-day holiday marking the beginning of the Lunar New Year.

headline: Barbie PC: Fashion Over Logic
abstract: Critics say Mattel's Barbie PC, intended for girls, comes with fewer educational programs than Mattel's Hot Wheels PC for boys does; Mattel spokeswoman denies distribution of software is unfair to girls; says larger number of popular Barbie programs, like Barbie Fashion Designer, left less room for educational titles on girls' computer (M)

headline: Video, Audio and AOL TV
abstract: Peter H Lewis column on new products shown at Consumer Electronics Show, Las Vegas; notes most important products are evolutionary rather than revolutionary, with small devices getting smaller, big devices bigger and cheaper and many products offered in choice of colors; drawing (M)

headline: NATO Says Milosevic Incites Violence Covertly in Kosovo
abstract: US and NATO officials accuse Yugoslav Pres Slobodan Milosevic of fomenting violence in Kosovo and infiltrating plainclothes police into province in deliberate attempt to thwart alliance's peacekeeping efforts; report detecting direct radio links between Milosevic's special police in Serbia and Serbian militants in ethnically divided city of Mitrovica; say Milosevic is encouraging plainclothes police to travel to Mitrovica, and has ordered buildup of special units along border between Kosovo and rest of Serbia; are concerned that Milosevic may be doing everything possible to undo NATO's control of Mitrovica (M)

headline: Storing Data Long-Term
abstract: Q&A article on floppy disks and recordable CD's

headline: Scale of Serial Murderer's Crimes Shocks Britain
abstract: LONDON—  The trial of Dr. Harold Shipman, accused of murdering 15 elderly patients by injecting them with fatal doses of heroin, had captivated Britain for four months as people wondered whether a respected family doctor could really be a serial murderer.

headline: What Putin's Rule Portends for Russia
abstract: Recent criticism of Russia's federal Railways Ministry by Vladimir V Putin suggests that he may shake things up as country's new acting president; his promise of strong central government raises fears among Westerners that he will crack down on civil liberties or bring back authoritarian rule, but his admirers insist that what he truly wants to crush is the fantastically corrupt Russian bureaucracy and economy (M)

headline: Honeywell Is Expanding Its Presence on the Web
abstract: Honeywell plans to work with Microsoft to increase reach and offerings of its MyPlant.com Web site, which serves plant managers, engineers and other operations people; plans to begin charging for services; says site's key purpose will still be to generate more customers for Honeywell products; is talking with competitors about joining forces on site; Microsoft, which bought small stake in site, sees its participation as way to introduce its technology to more industrial customers and help some of its own customers interact with industry (M)

headline: Government Officials Join Voices Urging Caution on Internet Oversight Vote
abstract: March 8, 2000

headline: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFINGS: AMERICAS; AIRLINE WORKERS PROTEST
abstract: Employees at Mexico's third largest airline, Taesa, block two principal thoroughfares in Mexico City during protest march to demand government rescue of company, after airline's executives temporarily suspended labor relations with its 3,700 employees; although company employees are told not to return to work until further notice, Taesa executives insist that no workers will be laid off and insist airline is not on brink of bankruptcy (S)

headline: U.S. Victims of Chile's Coup: The Uncensored File
abstract: Censored portions are restored to previously released State Department files on Charles Horman and Frank Teruggi, two Americans who were killed in Chile in 1973, and new material reveals, as the censored version did not, that department concluded almost from the beginning that government of Gen Augusto Pinochet killed the men and that it would not have done so without a green light from American intelligence; CIA releases a 22-year-old letter denying any role by agency and says it will show public files on case in spring; Freedom of Information Act, under which files were first released, allows censoring on grounds of national security and executive privilege, but restored material suggests that it was withheld so as not to embarrass government; photos (L)

headline: AMERICAN TOPICS
abstract: In Maryland, state legislators are calling on Governor Parris Glendening to apologize for the state's history of slavery, apparently a first at the state level.

headline: Taking Virgin's Brand Into Internet Territory; Richard Branson Says the Web Is Ready for His Style of Business
abstract: Richard Branson discusses his new drive to expand year-old Virgin.com Web site into worldwide e-commerce portal; says site, while having many Virgin products to sell, will also offer competitors products and services; table of top British Internet sites; photos (M)

headline: CREATIVE BIOMOLECULES TO MERGE WITH BIOTECH FIRMS
abstract: Creative BioMolecules Inc will merge with Ontogeny Inc and Reprogenesis Inc to form one of biggest companies working on stimulating human tissue growth to treat problems from broken bones to baldness; new company will be called Curis Inc (S)

headline: Pennzoil-Quaker in Deal
abstract: Pennzoil-Quaker State Co acquires Sagaz Industries Inc for undisclosed price (S)

headline: For AT&T's Chief, a Redefined Cable Landscape
abstract: Interview with C Michael Armstrong, AT&T chairman, on America Online's deal to acquire Time Warner, which should have a larger impact on AT&T than on any other communications or media company; photo (L)

headline: Indian Pilot Tells Why He Had to Obey Hijackers
abstract: The hijackers, jumpy and brusque, shoved the nose of the gun to the pilot's head. Take off in 30 seconds or die, they told him. Then they began a panicky countdown: ''30, 29, 28, 27.  . . .'' When they reached 2, Capt. Devi Sharan opened up the power on Indian Airlines flight 814 and took off.    As the Airbus lifted into the sky at 7:49 p.m. on Christmas Eve, any possibility that a crack Indian commando team could storm the plane and try to rescue the 184 passengers and crew members ended. The jet was leaving Amritsar, in India, and heading across the border into what many Indians consider enemy territory: Pakistan.

headline: Pope Is in Egypt, Tracing Moses' Path and Urging Dialogue
abstract: Pope John Paul II, beginning a pilgrimage to retrace steps of Moses, arrives in Egypt seeking to use ancient biblical symbols to reduce modern religious tensions; John Paul, making first visit to Egypt by a modern pope, pays back-to-back calls on Coptic pope, Shenouda III, leader of major Christian church in Egypt, and Muhammad Sayed Tantawi, sheik of Al Azhar, highest authority of Sunni Muslim faith; photo of Pope with Pres Hosni Mubarak (M)

headline: SOUTH AFRICAN GOES ALL-BOEING
abstract: South Africa's flagship airline, state-controlled South African Airways, will spend about $770 million on new aircraft from Boeing Co and make American company sole supplier of planes for its fleet (S)

headline: AOL and Time Warner Share Prices Rebound
abstract: Two-day slide in shares of America Online reverse as its stock jumps 7.5 percent, to $64.50; shares of Time Warner rise $4.35 to $84 (S)

headline: Shaky Concerns Are the Talk of Chat Rooms
abstract: Gretchen Morgenson (Market Watch) column says current craze du jour of online chat rooms is stocks of companies that are currently insolvent; notes chatterers seem to view these companies' depressed shares as bets worth taking; says that according to investors who specialize in distressed companies, odds of common shareholder ending up with anything of value once reorganization is complete are close to zero; graph (M)

headline: Putting MP3 Music Files Into Your Car's Dashboard
abstract: Unitech Electronics offers product to bring MP3's to family car; its product, called Rome, has 32 megabytes of memory, enough for half-hour of near-CD-quality music; photo (S)

headline: Microsoft Grades Windows 2000 Debut
abstract: Microsoft Corp says it has distributed more than one million copies of Windows 2000 since introducing software upgrade for business computers and networks Feb 17; also says Windows 2000 has generated fewer support calls than any other Microsoft operating system (S)

headline: JAPAN'S SURPLUS SHRINKS
abstract: Japan's current account surplus shrinks in November, as demand for raw materials drives up imports at triple the pace of exports; stronger yen is also making imports cheaper and slowing export growth; current account surplus falls 15.2 percent from October, to 982.7 billion yen ($9.3 billion) (S)

headline: SCANSOFT TO ACQUIRE CAERE, A DIGITAL IMAGING RIVAL
abstract: ScanSoft Inc acquires Caere Corp for $143.4 million in cash and stock (S)

headline: Trade Shows Without Borders
abstract: Peter Nathan has made his reputation pushing the frontiers of trade shows, and he is now embarked on organizing a medical equipment and pharmaceuticals show in Cuba; photo (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)

headline: For the Well Connected, All the World's an Office
abstract: Increased use of wireless devices and variety of services they provide has resulted in an unprecedented degree of flexibility to the workday; at same time, whatever line people have drawn between work and leisure, between the office and home, is growing thinner than ever as sense of obligation to stay connected to work at all hours continues to grow; social scientists and business experts are beginning to study the cost to an employee's well being if that employee is constantly within reach; reactions of some people electronically connected to their jobs discussed; photos; chart on variety of ways people can get e-mail (L)

headline: Ramon Mitra, 72, Foe of Marcos Regime During Martial Law
abstract: Ramon Mitra, who rose from rural poverty to become leading politician and democratic foe of Marcos dictatorship in Philippines, dies at age 72; photo (M)

headline: MediaTalk; P.R. Newswire Ruffles Some Journalists
abstract: Group of journalists protests plans by PR Newswire to inform public relations professionals about which journalists open their press releases on Press Room Web sites; in response, PR Newswire says no report will include names of journalists or news organizations unless they have explicitly allowed themselves to be tracked; photo (M)

headline: Sites and Events This Week
abstract: Browser: Sites and Events This Week

headline: ZIMBABWE REBUFFS LONGTIME LEADER
abstract: Zimbabwe voters reject draft constitution that Pres Robert Mugabe's opponents say would have entrenched his powers; voters demonstrate that they want nothing to do with strengthening hand of leader who many believe to be responsible for country's dismal economic plight; official results for referendum show that almost 55 percent of voters opposed proposal, and that opposition in cities ran as high as four to one; referendum, in addition to constitutional reforms that would have allowed Mugabe to dissolve Parliament without cause, also proposed giving government power to seize white-owned commercial farms without compensation; map; photos (M)

headline: As Investors Balk, YankeeNets Reduces Loan and Raises Rate
abstract: YankeesNets LLC, owner of New York Yankees and New Jersey Nets, will issue $200 million in seven-year bonds paying interest of 12.75 percent; company originally wanted to borrow $250 million at 11.75 percent, but met resistance from investors (M)

headline: VIRATA, A CHIP MAKER, TO PURCHASE SOFTWARE COMPANY
abstract: Virata Corp acquires Inverness Systems Ltd for about $114.9 million in stock; Virata will pay 850,000 shares (S)

headline: Alfred R. Zipf, 82, Pioneer in Electronic Banking
abstract: Alfred R Zipf, pioneer in computer technology and electronic banking and former executive at Bank of America, died on Jan 1 at age 82; photo (M)

headline: DISAPPOINTING FORECAST FOR EIDOS
abstract: Shares of Eidos PLC, Europe's largest video game maker, drop by about half after company announces slowing sales and forecasts much lower profit; photo (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: DOLLAR FALLS***US dollar falls against Japanese yen on speculation Japan will not get commitment from Group of Seven to help stem yen's strength; dollar slips to 105.36 yen from 105.72 yen (S)

headline: Time Warner Reports Gain In Results for Fourth Quarter
abstract: Time Warner Inc says fourth-quarter profit from operations rose on higher magazine advertising sales and new subscribers to cable channel HBO; says it had profit from operations of 20 cents a basic share, up from 11 cents a year ago; does not report corresponding dollar figures; revenue rose 9.9 percent, to $7.99 billion, from $7.27 billion, and cash flow before gains and charges rose 12 percent (M)

headline: CADBURY SCHWEPPES PROFIT
abstract: Cadbury Schweppes reports 9 percent gain in 1999 earnings; posts annual pretax profit of 686 million pounds, or $1.10 billion, up from 628 million pounds a year earlier; graph (S)

headline: MEXICAN MERGER DEAL
abstract: Mexico's Grupo Imsa agrees with creditors of Altos Hornos de Mexico SA to restructure $1.8 billion in Altos Hornos debt, paying way for two companies to merge; if companies merge, Imsa will control combined company and assume some of Altos Hornos debt (S)

headline: DIAGEO PROFITS RISE
abstract: Diageo PLC says demand for hard liquor pushed first-half profits up 3.5 percent, to $1.2 billion (S)

headline: In Geneva, Clinton Bet That Assad Would Bend, and Lost
abstract: Senior Clinton administration official says Syrian Pres Hafez al-Assad was immovable during his meeting with Pres Clinton in Geneva, and appears to have arrived with misconception that Mr. Clinton was in position to give him what he wanted from Israel; says administration knew meeting was gamble but believed it had better chance of success than proved to be case; photo (M)

headline: Who wants to buy ad time on reality programming after the 'Multimillionaire' debacle?
abstract: Madison Avenue advertising agencies are joining in chorus of catcalls being heard by Fox Broadcasting in wake of embarrassing end to ratings sweeps special, Who Wants to Marry a Multimillionaire? but opinion is divided over whether hasty demise of once-promising show will break up relationship between television and genre known as reality programming (M)

headline: In Protest, French Truck Owners Blockade Borders
abstract: Truck owners blockade highways and border crossings throughout France; protest rising gasoline and labor costs they say leave them unable to compete against truckers from other European nations; huge traffic jams spur ire of foreign truckers (M)

headline: If Only Stocks Were Votes . . .
abstract: Gary Bauer may be out of the race for the White House, but victory is still apparently his. Last year, according to his disclosure forms, he held some of the market's best performers, including Qualcomm (a $15,000-to-$50,000 stake as the year began, according to the forms) and i2 Technologies ($50,000 to $100,000). For the year, Qualcomm gained 2,683 percent, and i2, 542 percent (with a Friday sell-off still leaving it above last year's close). The value of his entire portfolio gained 183 percent,  he says.     How could he campaign for president and still triumph in the market? ''Maybe that was the secret of my success: I've been so busy I didn't have any time to sell last year,'' Mr. Bauer said in a telephone interview from Washington. There, he is chairman of the Campaign for Working Families, a political action group he started four years ago that supports conservative candidates.

headline: Uncovered Short Sales Rise
abstract: Open positions of short sales on Nasdaq stock market surge 34.8 percent during month ended March 15 (S)

headline: Longing For a Return To Value
abstract: Interview with Vanguard Group mutual fund manager James P Barrow, who comments on stock market shift away from value investing toward technology stocks whose sky-high price-to-earnings multiples result in market capitalizations that can exceed entire industry sectors; photo (M)

headline: E-Commerce Report; Traditional manufacturers are grappling with the pros and cons of direct sales on the Internet.
abstract: JUST as Amazon.com has, for better or worse, led millions of would-be entrepreneurs toward the e-commerce promised land, so too has the success of the Dell Computer Corporation led countless manufacturers to believe that their future success rides on the ability to sell directly to consumers over the Internet.    The benefits are manifest: tighter control of inventory, better information about customers and, most of all, a simpler distribution system with no retailers or distributors to inflate the price of the product.

headline: Expose of Brutal Prison Jolts France's Self-Image
abstract: Dr Veronique Vasseur jolts France' self-image with her book Chief Doctor at at La Sante Prison, which exposes appalling conditions at La Sante Prison in Paris; Vasseur's book has just hit the stands, and though she has worked at La Sante seven years, she is not sure she will be able to stay, given uproar it has created; she reports that within days of her arrival at prison, she met inmates who were so deranged or depressed they had swallowed rat poison, forks or drain cleaner; she found skin diseases rampant because showers were available only twice a week, though temperatures sometimes soared to more than 100 degrees in cramped cells holding four prisoners each; other horrors described; Vasseur comments; photos (M)

headline: Micron in Deal For Kiosk Sales
abstract: Micron Electronics Inc reaches deal to put kiosks for ordering personal computers in 357 Best Buy stores (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: THE EURO SLIPS***Euro edges lower as unexpected decline in German factory output dampens optimism about faster growth in euro zone; in New York, euro settles at $1.0311, down from $1.0322; graph; chart (S)

headline: De Beers Tries to Ensure Gems Don't Finance Insurrection
abstract: DeBeers, stung by accusations that diamond trade has supported war against governments in Africa, says it will give written guarantees that its stones do not come from rebel groups in continent; announcement coincides with wider efforts by world's diamond industry as United Nations panel prepares report for next month chronicling use of diamonds to finance wars in Angola, Sierra Leone, Congo and elsewhere (M)

headline: A Good Secretary Is Hard to Find
abstract: Lawrence R Ricciardi, senior vice president and general counsel at IBM, is taking credit for bringing Robert Rubin, former Treasury Secretary, together with Sandy Weill and Citigroup, where Rubin took position; Weill photo (S)

headline: Secure or Not, the Internet Has Become a Part of Life's Routine
abstract: Vandalism that hobbled popular sites like Yahoo, Amazon and eBay raises concerns about the fast pace at which people are being enticed to put more of their personal, political, financial and even medical lives online (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Traditional Sponsors Score Biggest in the Super Bowl  The Ad Bowl, interrupted at various times by Super Bowl XXXIV on Sunday, was emblematic of a new era for Madison Avenue. For instance, there were more commercials aimed at women, the first paid public service announcements and a larger presence for media outlets. The most significant change was the proliferation of dot-com spots, as 17 of the 36 marketers buying national commercial time during the game came from the Internet world, including an ad from Monster.com, above.

headline: Neoforma Skyrockets Almost 300% in Its Trading Debut
abstract: January 24, 2000

headline: Taiwan Nationalists Ousted After Half-Century Reign
abstract: Chen Shui-bian is elected president of Taiwan, ending more than half a century of Nationalist rule and risking dangerous new tensions with mainland China, which warned Taiwan against electing an advocate of independence; reaches out to China in his victory speech, saying he will seek deeper economic ties and a permanent peace and promising not to declare independence or hold a referendum on the issue unless Taiwan comes under attack; he adds, however, that he will not let Taiwan become another Hong Kong or Macao; Pres Clinton hails election as demonstration of vitality of democracy and an opportunity for Taiwan and China to open new dialogue; photos (M)

headline: SHADOWS OF TORMENT/A special report.; Pinochet Case Reviving Voices of the Tortured
abstract: It was only when Mario Fernandez saw the headline, ''Pinochet Under Arrest,'' that the dam broke and he finally found it possible to talk about the beatings, the electric shocks, the cigarette burns, the terrible sense of humiliation and alienation.    ''My body froze; I had an intense allergic reaction, and I didn't know whether to laugh or cry,'' said Mr. Fernandez, trembling at the memory. He ran to his wife and wept on her shoulder, and, at long last, took her advice to seek therapy.

headline: Exodus and KeyLabs In $43 Million Deal
abstract: Exodus Communications Inc agrees to acquire KeyLabs Inc for $43.5 million in stock (S)

headline: Corporate Gift Etiquette
abstract: Dianne K Olsen letter on Dec 19 article holds corporate policies on receiving gifts from vendors and other outside sources should focus on unethical power deals, not small gifts

headline: Icahn Holds Out 2 Carrots to Nabisco Shareholders
abstract: Investor Carl C Icahn, in letter to Nabisco Group Holdings Corp board, appeals to shareholders to take over troubled company, just 15 days after being rebuffed by board; Icahn offers shareholders premium of 40 percent for 100 million shares that would give him control of company; he offers $13 a share, up from stock's closing price of $9.3125 on March 29; Icahn says once in control, he would try to sell company at what he says he expects would be 'very attractive price' (M)

headline: DEUTSCHE BUYS STAKE IN BROKER
abstract: Deutsche Bank AG agrees to acquire 16.3 percent stake in online broker, National Discount Brokers, for $136 million, with option to buy additional 3 percent; Deutsche Bank and National Discount Brokers agree to form online brokerage alliance; agreement calls for companies to build brokerage Web sites outside US (S)

headline: Want to get yourself some opera tickets? Just go down to the soda machine and swipe your card.
abstract: New technology now makes it possible to place multiple Web-based marketing on vending machines, ATM's and even office equipment; one such device, e-Port, has been developed by USA Technologies and is backed by IBM; it enables customers to order items from Web sites using device that can be attached to machine that dispenses soft drinks, for example; device offers marketers opportunity to use interactive advertising outside the home, particularly in high-traffic locations (M)

headline: Reading the Signals Of a Baffled Bond Market
abstract: market watch: reading the signals of a baffled b

headline: Top Tax Expert Calls for Tougher Penalties to Deter Corporate Cheating
abstract: Lindy L Paull, chief of staff for Congressional Joint Committee on Taxation, says tough penalties Congress enacted to discourage abusive corporate tax shelters are so riddled with loopholes that they fail to deter tax cheating by large companies, testimony before Senate Finance Committee; calls for tightening of penalties and also for imposing penalties on professionals who prepare abusive tax returns for both individuals and companies generally at least as high as those imposed on taxpayers themselves; Sen William V Roth Jr, chairman of committee, describes tax shelters as serious problem; also says he is worried that new laws sought by Clinton administration to crack down on sham transactions will give too much power to IRS agents (M)

headline: Supervising the Graybeards
abstract: Abby Ellin column on the special challenges that managers in their 20's and early 30's face when they supervise or do business with people who are their parents' or even grandparents' age; drawing (M)

headline: New College Sticker Shock: Junior's Credit Card Bill
abstract: James Schembari article says that as credit cards become increasingly available on college campuses, some students are piling up sort of debts that only their parents can pay; cites survey by New England Education Loan Marketing Assn (Nellie Mae) that found 35 percent of recent graduates who were repaying Nellie Mae loans had other debt payments, unrelated to their education, of more than $1,000 a month; notes credit card issuers say they are providing service that students want, and that they try to educate them about using cards wisely; says it is important that parents discuss finances with their children; list of some resources for parents in offering financial guidance to their children (M)

headline: For Demanding Devices,Try Powering Up That Bus
abstract: For Demanding Devices, Try Powering Up That Bus

headline: Islamists' Policies Win Allies in Malaysia State
abstract: KUALA TERENGGANU, Malaysia—  Side-by-side in the corridors of the state capital building here are men wearing flowing robes and pin-striped suits, turbans and silk ties.

headline: DOLE FOOD PLANS TO EXPLORE STRATEGIC ALTERNATIVES
abstract: Dole Food Co has hired investment firm Goldman, Sachs & Co to explore strategic alternatives (S)

headline: WISCONSIN SAVINGS INSTITUTION BUYS A RIVAL
abstract: Mutual Savings Bank, closely held Milwaukee-based savings institution, acquires public rival, First Northern Capital Corp, for $133 million (S)

headline: Treasury Prices Advance as Investors Seek a Safer Haven
abstract: US Treasury prices rise; price of benchmark 30-year bond rises 1 21/32, to 105 9/32; yield falls to 5.87 percent from 5.97 percent; graph on tax-exempt yields; chart on US key interest rates (M)

headline: Investor Fear of Rising Rates Sends Stock Market Plunging
abstract: Leading stock indexes plunge 3 percent, and technology issues finish much lower as investors focus on stark prospect of rising short-term interest rates; decline in stocks is across the board, with technology stocks joining sell-off; Dow Jones industrial average falls 295.05, or 2.8 percent, to 10,219.52; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index drops 42.17 points, or 3 percent, to 1,346.09; Nasdaq falls 137.18 points, or 3 percent, to 4,411.74; graphs (M)

headline: New Chinese Guided-Missile Ship Heightens Tension
abstract: China's first Russian-built guided-missile destroyer is expected to arrive in East China Sea, enhancing Beijing's ability to threaten US aircraft carriers in future encounters over Taiwan; photo (M)

headline: U.S.-INDIA AGREEMENT
abstract: US reaches trade agreement with India; US trade representative Charlene Barshefsky says agreement calls for India to remove barriers on more than 1,400 kinds of imports; pact is result of case before World Trade Organization, which had ruled that India maintained unfair restrictions on trade in numerous agricultural and manufactured goods; photo (S)

headline: Attired in Black Pantsuit, She Takes on Uniform of Power : Hillary Gets Down to Business
abstract: WASHINGTON—  When Hillary Rodham Clinton made her candidacy for the U.S. Senate official, she did so dressed in a sleek black trouser suit. For the occasion, her blonde hair was swept away from her face in a polished and sophisticated manner. As she stood before a crowd of cheering supporters, she looked very much like the strong, independent career woman that the media have, from the beginning, made her out to be.

headline: Credit Offerings This Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week includes today's regular weekly auction of new three-  and six-month bills and a 52-week bill being auctioned on Tuesday.    At the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 5.16 percent and on the six-month issue, 5.48 percent. The rate for the 52-week bill was 5.63 percent.

headline: Mannesmann Said to Weigh Dropping Opposition to Vodafone Bid
abstract: Mannesmann AG reverses its opposition to talks with Vodafone AirTouch PLC and begins to consider face-saving friendly merger; executives say there is growing feeling within Mannesmann that company cannot defeat $156 billion hostile takeover bid from Vodafone, especially after Vivendi SA, ally of Mannesmann, joined alliance with Vodafone on Jan 30 (M)

headline: OLD MUTUAL REACHES DEAL
abstract: South African insurance company Old Mutual PLC acquires British financial services concern Gerrard Group PLC for $857 million; Gerrard Group owns stock brokerage firm and fund manager Greig Middleton & Co, as well as discount brokerage subsidiary and other fund-management operations; graph (S)

headline: Protest Filed In Schwab Bid For U.S. Trust
abstract: Inner City Press/Community on the Move, community activist group in Bronx, is protesting proposed $2.7 billion acquisition of US Trust by Charles Schwab, charging that US Trust has weak record of lending in poor neighborhoods; Schwab is seeking federal approval to take over US Trust; group's director Matthew Lee comments (M)

headline: A Day in the Life of a PC Trouble-Shooter
abstract: It's 8 a.m. on a recent Wednesday on the Piscataway, N.J., campus of Telcordia Technologies, and Jeffrey Horning, one of the company's 11 trouble-shooting computer techies, is waiting for his first emergency call of the day.    Mr. Horning knows there will be plenty of problems that the ''help desk'' can't fix by phone. Just because Telcordia's stock-in-trade is technological wizardry -- it provides consulting and engineering services to the telecommunications industry -- doesn't mean the 2,000 employees at this site alone can't become befuddled at a PC's refusal to do what it is told. For them, he is more than just a wizard or, in some cases, a scapegoat; he's also part doctor, part psychologist and always the diplomat.

headline: New Access to America Online E-Mail
abstract: America Online Inc says it will give its more than 20 million subscribers access to electronic mail using hand-held organizers made by Compaq Computer Corp, Casio Computer Co and Hewlett-Packard Co (S)

headline: GREENSPAN NAMED TO A FOURTH TERM AS FED CHAIRMAN
abstract: President Clinton nominated Alan Greenspan today to a fourth four-year term as chairman of the Federal Reserve, insuring that a familiar hand will continue steering the economy even as a new administration takes office next year.    Three weeks after John D. Podesta, the White House chief of staff, first broached the subject confidentially with Mr. Greenspan, Mr. Clinton formally asked the Fed chairman to stay on during a meeting this morning. Mr. Greenspan, who is 73, immediately said yes.

headline: Party Audit Finds Shortfall in Kohl Era
abstract: FRANKFURT—  Germany's scandal-shaken conservative party, which Monday confirmed that it cannot account for more than 12 million Deutsche marks in political funds, said that it was mired in an "existential trial" and would begin a national campaign to win back public trust.
