headline: NETDIRECT, INTERNET RETAILER, ENDS TAKEOVER ACCORD
abstract: The Netdirect Corporation International, an Internet retailer of electronics, said yesterday that its board had decided to terminate an agreement to be acquired by Compositech Ltd. because of a change in strategy. Netdirect, based in Minneapolis, said it planned an acquisition of HardwareStreet.com for about $32 million as part of a new focus on strategic partnerships as a way to lower costs and improve profit and revenue. Compositech and Netdirect agreed in December to a stock swap with a value put at $175 million at the time.

headline: St. Petersburg Times Debt Is Paid Back by Its Parent
abstract: In a move that ensured the durability of one of the country's most unusual newspaper ownership arrangements, the company that publishes The St. Petersburg Times has paid off a $30 million debt to the nonprofit institute that owns it.    Andrew Barnes, chief executive of Times Publishing, parent of The St. Petersburg Times, said in a Dec. 26 letter in the newspaper that the debt to the Poynter Institute for Media Studies had been paid.

headline: HomeGrocer.com Makes Middling Debut
abstract: March 10, 2000

headline: Amazon Loss Soared 543% In 4th Quarter
abstract: Amazon.com says it lost $323 million in fourth quarter of 1999, more than expected and 543 percent more than it lost in quarter a year earlier; sales in quarter increased 167 percent, to $676 million; Amazon says it cost $19 in marketing to acquire each of its 3.8 million new customers in quarter, far less than other online businesses; says its 14 million active customers spent average of $116 for the year, up from $106 in 1998 (M)

headline: Fighting Cyber Crime Starts With Industry, Official Says
abstract: Fighting Cyber Crime Starts With Industry, Official Says

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of Mar 5 article on prospects for investing in Cuba

headline: Digital Commerce; Control over content: The case of an Internet TV provider illustrates the entertainment industry's copyright power.
abstract: Digital Commerce column on case of Internet TV provider, iCraveTV.com, that illustrates entertainment industry's copyright power; iCraveTV.com, Canadian company, redistributes live broadcast television programming on it Web site; business is legal in Canada but not in US, where Motion Picture Assn has sued company for not first obtaining permission from programs' owners; content industries seem to have successfully secured legal means by which they will be able to enforce perfect control; drawing (M)

headline: BANK ONE PLANS TO CUT WORK FORCE BY 5,100 JOBS
abstract: Bank One Corp to cut 5,100 jobs, about 5.6 percent of work force, to cut costs; says it gave chairman and chief executive John B McCoy $10.3 million severance payment and $3 million annual pension when he resigned in Dec (S)

headline: STORAGE TECHNOLOGY PLANS TO CUT UP TO 600 MORE JOBS
abstract: Storage Technology Corp says it will cut 500 to 600 more jobs and that its chief executive David E Weiss will step down; says it will cut its number of units to two from six and will try to stay independent (S)

headline: GERMAN COMPUTER SERVICE DEAL
abstract: Deutsche Telekom buys 50.1 percentg of DaimlerChrysler Corp's Debis Systemhaus software business for 5.5 billion euros ($5.3 billion); Deutsche Telekom chief executive Ron Sommer comments; photo (S)

headline: I.B.M. to Introduce Advance in Chip Manufacturing
abstract: IBM technologists will describe new details of their next-generation chip-making system that uses beams of electrons, rather than light waves, to etch circuits onto chips; company believes technology will make it possible in future to shrink individual circuits to size nearly as small as atoms; new system is being developed in cooperation with Nikon Corp; it is creating excitement in semiconductor industry, since cost of light-wave etching is rising to levels that may soon be prohibitive (M)

headline: Prosecutors Portray the Strands Of a Bin Laden Web of Terror
abstract: Federal prosecutors, in series of little-noticed court filings, paint most detailed picture yet of worldwide terrorism conspiracy allegedly directed by Saudi exile, Osama bin Laden; papers detail how bin Laden's organization allegedly used international companies and Kenyan relief agency as cover for its operations, obtained blank passports from government of Sudan, recruited people living in US, and communicated by fax, satellite phone and coded letters often using not-so-veiled language; federal government has been investigating bin Laden's operations for nearly five years and has charged him and 16 other people with conspiring to attack Americans, specifically in embassy bombings in Tanzania and Kenya that left more than 200 dead and thousands wounded; disclosures follow challenge by lawyer of defendant Wadih el-Hage, bin Laden operative arrested in 1998 after Kenyan police, accompanied by American investigators, raided Nairobi home and seized personal papers and computer; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Japanese yen rises against dollar on hopes that coming survey will show upturn in Japanese business sentiment; in New York, dollar settles at 105.88 yen, down from 106.87; graph; chart (S)

headline: EL PASO TO BUY NATURAL GAS BUSINESSES OF P.G.& E.
abstract: El Paso Field Services Co, unit of El Paso Energy Corp, agrees to acquire natural gas businesses of three PG&E Corp units for about $279 million; it will also assume debt of $561 million; El Paso Field Services will assume businesses of PG&E Gas Transmission, Texas Corp and PG&E Gas Transmission Teco Inc (S)

headline: It's a Video Game, Certainly, but Is It Art?
abstract: Dr Henry Jenkins, director of comparative media studies program at Massachusetts Institute of Technology, says video game pastime will soon shake off its label as diversion for adolescent boys and gain respect for its asthetic and cultural value; says he has only to look at his students, first generation of adults who grew up playing games, to see influence games have had; says ten years ago most of his students wanted to direct films, but now more of them are interested in being game designers; discusses various asthetic developments games still need; Digital Software Association says day is not long off when money spent on video games will be on par with money spent on movie tickets (M)

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction to Feb 6 article about personal-finance issues that arise from receiving windfall, like $1 million prize on television quiz show; article misstated federal tax rule about exemptions for children

headline: INSURANCE EXECUTIVE TO LEAVE
abstract: Prudential PLC says Les Cullen, finance director, will leave company in April; Cullen is third senior executive to announce his departure from Prudential in last two months (S)

headline: Consumer Prices Rise Just 0.2%
abstract: Labor Department reports Consumer Price Index rose 0.2 percent in December, even as the economy continued toward record for uninterrupted expansion; rise in CPI lifts 1999 inflation rate to 2.7 percent; graph on industrial production 1998-1999 (M)

headline: TECHNOLOGY: Out on a Limb as Technologies Converge; 'E-Conversion' Paying Early Dividends at Oracle
abstract: In June, Lawrence J. Ellison, the chairman of the Oracle Corporation, announced that the company would reinvent itself as an e-business -- a company that uses the power of the Internet in every aspect of its operations. He set a goal of reducing annual costs by $1 billion in 12 to 18 months.    At the time, many analysts brushed off the announcement as more hyperbole from a chief executive known for same. But as the months passed, it became clear that Mr. Ellison was putting his money where his mouth is -- and reaping some early returns on the investment. In the quarter ended Nov. 30, Oracle exceeded Wall Street's earnings estimates, in large part because of a 5.5 percent gain in profit margin that the company attributed to cost-cutting.

headline: South Korea Pursues A Space-Age Future
abstract: Article on South Korea's plans to develop space rocket noted

headline: THOMSON WILL BUY RACAL
abstract: Thomson-CSF SA of France agrees to acquire Racal Electronics PLC of Britain for $2.17 billion in cash, in latest round of consolidation in the European military industry (S)

headline: Lehman Paid Its Chief $16.8 Million in '99
abstract: Lehman Brothers Holdinÿ

headline: Chechen Rebels Announce Retreat From Battered Capital
abstract: Chechen rebels say they are abandoning Grozny and will carry out attacks on Russian forces from mountains and countryside of breakaway republic; map; photo (M)

headline: Judge in Brunei Limits Royal Allowance : Prince Becomes a Pauper (on $300,000 a Month)
abstract: SINGAPORE—  Even by the lofty standards of corporate America, the allowance looks pretty generous: $300,000 a month for a prince in the sultanate of Brunei to support his four wives and 35 children — and his playboy lifestyle.

headline: Key Officer at Gap Resigns To Be Chief of Wal-Mart.com
abstract: Jeanne Jackson, Gap executive who is credited with building Banana Republic division into retail powerhouse and who started Gap's online store, resigns to become head of Wal-Mart.com (M)

headline: DYCOM TO BUY RIVAL NIELS FUGAL FOR $84.1 MILLION
abstract: Dycom Industries to buy Niels Fugal Sons for $84.1 million in stock (S)

headline: Two Online Companies Sign Up With Agencies
abstract: Prism Communications Services, owned by Comdisco Inc, names New York office of Saatchi & Saatchi as agency of record for national expansion of Red, its Internet service provider; billings estimated at more than $60 million; Deutsch LA, part of Detusch Inc, is named agency of record for two units of eCompanies: eMemories.com and eParties.com; billings for eMemories estimated at $10 million to $20 million and billings for eParties estimated at $15 million to $20 million (S)

headline: Power and Phone Companies Form Fiber-Optic Network
abstract: Power and Phone Companies Form Fiber-Optic Network

headline: Bodies in Pit Suggest Slayings at Uganda Fire
abstract: Forensic investigators at site of fire that burned over 400 people to death in Kanungu, Uganda, discover bodies of several others who appear to have been murdered and dumped into pit; count 330 bodies and estimate that over hundred others may have died in chapel controlled by cult called Movement for Restoration of Ten Commandments of God; it is largest mass suicide-murder since 1978; map; photo (M)

headline: PRIME HOSPITALITY AGREES TO BUY LEASES FROM SHOLODGE
abstract: Prime Hospitality Corp, owner of AmeriSuites and Wellesley Inns hotel chains, agrees to buy leases of 27 Sumner Suites hotels from ShoLodge Inc and convert hotels to AmeriSuites; ShoLodge expects to receive $54 million in cash at purchase's closing and $3 million in rent payments later for 27 hotels (S)

headline: Rothschild Partner Plans to Set Up Own Firm
abstract: Wilbur L Ross Jr says he is leaving investment bank Rothschild Inc at end of month to form his own investment firm W L Ross & Co (M)

headline: WARBURG, PINCUS AFFILIATE TO BUY CENTENNIAL
abstract: Centennial HealthCare Corï

headline: HONG KONG NET VENTURE
abstract: HSBC Holdings and Cheung Kong (Holdings) form venture valued at 3 billion Hong Kong dollars ($385 million) to help companies trade goods and services over the Internet; venture will be called iBusinessCorporation.com; photo (S)

headline: U.S. Says It Plans to Buy Back Some Debt
abstract: US Treasury Sec Lawrence H Summers outlines plan by which Treasury Dept for first time will become buyer as well as seller of government bonds; Treasury, following some standard Wall Street tactics, will start intervening in open market to manage its $3.6 billion trillion debt (M)

headline: Anti-Hacker Software
abstract: Letter by Don Hilde responds to Feb 17 article on protecting a home PC from hackers; describes his experience in downloading free software to accomplish this

headline: Moving Out of Bonds
abstract: Financial Research Corp reports bond mutual funds experienced net redemptions of $12.8 billion, Dec; net inflows into stock and bond funds totaled $6.3 billion in month (M)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: EUROPE    BRITAIN: TORIES EXPEL ARCHER -- Jeffrey Archer, a flamboyant member of the House of Lords and best-selling novelist, was expelled from the Conservative Party for five years for having concealed damaging details of a 1986 scandal involving a prostitute that forced him to give up his candidacy in November for the first elected mayor of London. The party's ethics and integrity committee said his behavior was ''reprehensible.'' He called the punishment ''grossly unfair.''   Warren Hoge

headline: Sempra to Cut Dividend
abstract: Sempra Energy plans to reduce its quarterly dividend and buy back 15 percent of its shares in initiatives to raise earnings and give company greater flexibility to expand; will cut dividend to 25 cents a share from 39 cents a share (S)

headline: It's Mostly Business as Usual For the Taiwanese in Beijing
abstract: Most Taiwanese living in Beijing say they are happy and feel at home in China despite its warning that it 'would not sit idly by' if Taiwan moved toward formal independence; photo (M)

headline: Aon Stock Tumbles On Profit Shortfall
abstract: Stock of Aon Corp loses more than quarter of its value after it says earnings for fourth quarter and 2000 will fall short of Wall Street's expectations (S)

headline: United takes a warmer, fuzzier course after a campaign unsettles customers and employees.
abstract: MAJOR new campaign for United Airlines, replacing a contentious recent series of advertisements carrying the theme ''Rising,'' has no theme. But if there were one, it might proclaim ''United we stand, divided we fall.''    Of course, ''fall'' is not quite the type of word fliers want to see invoked in airline advertising. But as it turned out, ''Rising,'' as in rising above the difficulties that vex customers, was not a word they -- or United's almost 100,000 employees -- welcomed either.

headline: Compressed Data; Isolated, Maybe, But Not So Divided
abstract: Comment on controversial Stanford University survey on impact of Internet, which concluded that rise of global computer network is leading to new wave of social isolation (S)

headline: INTEL TO ACQUIRE BASIS COMMUNICATIONS FOR $450 MILLION
abstract: Intel Corp acquires Basis Communications Corp in transaction valued at $450 million in cash and assumed options (S)

headline: Brazil Having Second Thoughts About Foreign Bank Inroads
abstract: Perhaps no trend has made its mark on Sao Paulo's changing cityscape more than the proliferation of foreign-owned banks. After a wave of takeovers and heavy investments in recent years, many Brazilian banks have been nudged aside by institutions with un-Portuguese sounding names, like Santander, HSBC and BankBoston.    However, the growth of these banks -- with their colorful nameplates, billboard advertisements and increasing clout in this nation's financial services industry -- is coming under criticism. Fearful of the encroachment of foreign financial institutions, some of Brazil's most powerful bankers are urging the government to limit the power of foreign financial institutions.

headline: Patents; A California company tweaks an artificial nose in an attempt to sniff out ailments.
abstract: Patents column on scent detection device patented by Cyrano Sciences that could be used by physicians in diagnosing disease; photo (M)

headline: Marketing With Martha
abstract: Letter by Helen Rosen on March 2 article on Martha Stewart's retail Web site; says items on sale are often not in stock

headline: An Old-Boy Network, Coming Up for Air
abstract: Bruce Kluger article spoofs Oxygen Media's all-women-all-the-time mission; says he will start his own network, just for men, called Blowhard Network; offers inaugural lineup of offerings (M)

headline: Thanks to the Web, Campus Radio Is Casting a Much Wider Net
abstract: Article on decision by WBTU, Boston University's student radio station that abandoned airwaves to broadcast over Internet (Special Section, E-Commerce); photo (S)

headline: $147 Billion Purchase Underscores Internet Power : AOL to Buy Time Warner In Biggest Corporate Deal
abstract: NEW YORK—  America Online Inc. said Monday that it would buy Time Warner Inc. for about dollars 147 billion in stock and assumed debt, the largest corporate acquisition on record and a vivid illustration of the importance of the Internet.

headline: Bain de Soleil To Weiss Stagliano
abstract: Schering-Plough Health Care Products expands its agency roster by naming Weiss Stagliano Partners as creative agency of record for Bain de Soleil line of sun care products (S)

headline: Olympics.com Signs Sponsorship Deal
abstract: Olympics.com Signs Sponsorship Deal

headline: Transforming Art Into Enterprise
abstract: Article on Wendell Castle, one of America's foremost furniture makers, who has started business called Icon Design that will market 'budget' line of his works; Castle comments on his business plan for achieving quantity and maintaining quality; photos (M)

headline: 'Boiler Room' Critics Find A Debit Even in the Credits
abstract: Manhattan District Attorney Robert M Morgenthau and Manuel Asensio, short-seller who has had run-ins with penny-stock promoters, preview movie Boiler Room, film about penny-stock abuses on Long Island; both men agree that outside of scenes in boiler room, film leaves lot to be desired; John Tepper Marlin, chief economist for NYC comptroller, files suit against New Line Cinema to block release of film, which he contends defames him; name of corrupt brokerage firm in film is JT Marlin, and film's director, Ben Younger, worked in comptroller's office in 1994 and 1995; Morgenthau photo (S)

headline: Genzyme to Buy Biomatrix for $738 Million
abstract: Genzyme Corp acquires Biomatrix Inc for about $738.5 million in cash and stock; Genzyme plans to combine Biomatrix with its Genzyme Surgical Products and Genzyme Tissue Repair units, to create company called Genzyme Biosurgery (M)

headline: Young Filmmakers Seek The Next 'Blair Witch'
abstract: In light of success of low-budget, Internet-hyped movie Blair Witch Project, many young persons with desire to express themselves are flocking to film schools and film industry; once they have film to show, they often head to Sundance Film Festival or other gatherings elsewhere and stage all manner of pranks to become known; some young, enterprising filmmakers discussed; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Euro rises after Swiss central bank raises its interest rate target band, bolstering expectations for higher rates in Europe; in New York, euro settles at 97.19 cents, up from 96.02 cents; graph; chart (S)

headline: Mass Graves In Turkey Put Attention On Terror Cell
abstract: Turkish police officers searching for victims of Hizbullah, religious-oriented terrorist group, find four bodies beneath villa in central Turkish town of Konya; discovery brings to 17 number of bodies exhumed; earlier discovery of victims beneath group's Istanbul hideout following shootout with police noted; police say all victims, believed to be Kurds, bore signs of torture; estimated 200 residents of southeastern Turkey, most businessmen unsympathetic to cause of militant Islam, have disappeared since August 1999 and Hizbullah is considered prime suspect; lone woman among victims identified as writer Konca Kuris, who had often portrayed Islam as permissive religion that demands freedom for women (M)

headline: A Revolution Built In Mr. Ford's Factory
abstract: Tom Redburn (Economic View) article credits Henry Ford and his Model T with helping transform economic inequality that existed before World War I into an era in which workers themselves came to own much of means of production; says Ford not only paid his workers well, but helped to create mass consumer market at same time he was offering something to satisfy it: an inexpensive automobile; says mass-production automobile broke the traditional boundaries that held people in place, providing independence, mobility and freedom; also says that despite environmental ills automobile has brought, nothing else so represents the empowerment of ordinary people (M)

headline: Sun Plans to Start Shipping Operating System Next Month
abstract: Sun Microsystems Inc, moving to maintain its hold on Internet, says that Solaris 8, latest version of its operating system, will ship on Feb 28; announcement comes as Microsoft Corp prepares to ship Windows 2000 on Feb 17 (M)

headline: KOREAN PRICES RISE
abstract: Consumer prices in South Korea have risen 0.3 percent in March, after 0.3 percent gain in February; from year ago, prices have risen 1.6 percent; economy expanded 2.8 percent in fourth quarter of last year from third quarter, capping year in which gross domestic product grew 13 percent (S)

headline: ANGLO AMERICAN BUYS ZIMBABWE MINE
abstract: Expanding its already dominant position in the world's metal markets, Anglo American P.L.C. has agreed to buy Zimasco Ltd. of Zimbabwe for an unspecified price. With the acquisition, Anglo, the world's largest mining company, will control all of Zimbabwe's ferrochrome production and a significant part of the country's platinum output. Anglo owns slightly more than 50 percent of the world's biggest platinum producer, the Anglo American Platinum Corporation, and 40 percent of the world's biggest ferrochrome producer, Samancor Ltd.     Henri E. Cauvin

headline: MGM Grand Makes $3.3 Billion Unsolicited Offer for Mirage
abstract: MGM Grand Inc, casino company controlled by Kirk Kerkorian, offers to buy Mirage Resorts Inc, innovative-if-struggling casino company created by Stephen A Wynn, for $3.3 billion; MGM holds it seeks friendly merger; says merger would create gambling industry powerhouse; photos (M)

headline: Not Just a Monitor: The Price of Coolness
abstract: Samnsung Electronics, having decided against reducing price of its high-cost flat-panel computer monitors, offers new line of devices that allow for alternative uses; photo (S)

headline: iVillage Soars Past Expectations
abstract: January 27, 2000

headline: Luxury Wheel Turns to Europe; On U.S. Premium Car Sales, the Continent Sets the Pace
abstract: After capturing a big share of the American market for small and midsize cars in the 1980's, Japanese automakers set their sights a decade ago on Cadillac and Lincoln, which had dominated the American luxury market since the 1930's. Detroit watched and worried.    Cadillac and Lincoln, respectively the luxury divisions of General Motors and Ford, held their lead through most of the 1990's -- until last year, when they were passed by not one but two other carmakers, with a third close on their bumper.

headline: Israeli Jets and Hezbollah Renew Attacks in Lebanon
abstract: Conflict in Lebanon continues to heat up as Shiite Muslim guerrillas kill sixth Israeli soldier in two weeks, and Israeli warplanes retaliate less than 24 hours after their first bombardment shut down civilian life in Lebanon; Prime Min Ehud Barak defends Israeli air strikes, but Arab and some European countries condemn them (M)

headline: WARNING BY CHINA TO TAIWAN POSES CHALLENGE TO U.S.
abstract: China's abrupt shift to more aggressive stance on Taiwan reportedly leaves Clinton Administration scrambling for response and struggling to temper increased pressure for new arms sales to Taiwan; Administration officials say China gave them no hint of shift, announced days after visit to China by high-ranking American delegation that urged restraint over Taiwan; United States ties with China now seem to be entering extraordinarily delicate phase, with elections in Taiwan, other events threatening to worsen them dramatically (M)

headline: NIKE SHIRTS CALLED NOT HAZARDOUS
abstract: Germany's consumer protection office says Nike soccer jerseys that were removed from store shelves last week after reports they contained dangerous chemical do not represent any health hazard; says substance. tributylin (TBT), used in shirts to reduce odors from sweating, should be banned (S)

headline: Shopping on Priceline
abstract: Barbara Walker letter on Jan 6 article on Priceline grocery shopping (S)

headline: NO SANCTIONS FOR TALISMAN
abstract: Report for Canadian government by John Harker, Canadian diplomat, into activities of Talisman Energy Inc in Sudan, country which has been devastated by civil war, is critical of company's role in providing indirect support to government forces; Canada will not impose any sanctions against Talisman or against Sudan (S)

headline: U.S. CONCRETE AGREES TO ACQUIRE A TEXAS COMPETITOR
abstract: US Concrete, Houston to acquire Beall Industries, Dallas-Fort Worth area, for undisclosed terms (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Excite@Home, Redwood City, Calif., an Internet company that combines online content and navigational services, to Gillespie, Lawrenceville, N.J., part of the Interpublic Group of Companies., to handle its direct marketing, which had been at Lowe Fox Pavlika, part of the Lowe Group unit of Interpublic. Billings were estimated at $5 million.  * Rug Doctor, Plano, Tex., a provider of carpet cleaning products and rental machines, to Levenson & Hill, Dallas, to handle its account, which had been inactive. Billings were estimated at more than $2 million.  * Roper Starch Worldwide, New York, a research company, to Heitner Weiss, New York, to handle its first account. Billings were estimated at $1 million.

headline: SAGE GROUP OF BRITAIN TO PURCHASE SOFTWARE COMPANY
abstract: Sage Group will buy Best Software Inc for $445 million in cash; Sage is offering $35 for each Best share (S)

headline: Noted Hacker Speaks Before Senate Panel
abstract: Noted Hacker Speaks Before Senate Panel

headline: The View From GreenMountain; Financier Mixes Business, the Environment and Politics
abstract: Profile of Sam Wyly, financial backer of Republican presidential candidate George W Bush, chairman of GreenMountain.com, which markets alternative energy sources, and founder of $4 billion hedge fund, Maverick Capital; says Wyly's $2.5 million advertising campaign that attacked environmental record of Sen John McCain has raised questions about Wyly's tactics; says though Wyly and his brother, Charles, are among Bush campaign's biggest contributors, Wyly insists ads attacking McCain were also effort to promote his environmental interests; photo (M)

headline: VerticalNet to Buy Privately Held Tradeum
abstract: March 8, 2000

headline: More Now Leaving Silicon Valley Than Arriving
abstract: More Now Leaving Silicon Valley Than Arriving

headline: At Trade Forum, Clinton Pleads for the Poor
abstract: Pres Clinton appeals to chief executives and national leaders attending World Economic Forum, Davos, Switzerland, to make global trade work for poor; warns failure to listen to concerns of those who have not benefited from globalization would spur protectionism; demonstrators, kept away from forum site, break windows in nearby McDonald's restaurant; forum organizers increase security; photo (M)

headline: Boxed In: Exploring a Big-Box Store Online
abstract: Online Shopper column by Michelle Slatalla appraises Wal-Mart's redesigned Internet site; photo (M)

headline: Red Hat Revenues Jump but Losses Increase
abstract: March 27, 2000

headline: A Visible Chief Has a Head for Numbers
abstract: Brief profile of Diana D Brooks, who resigned as president and chief executive of Sotheby's; photo (S)

headline: No Direct Talks Set by 2 Sides In Boeing Strike
abstract: Representatives of Boeing Co and 17,000 engineers and technical workers represented by Society of Professional Engineering Employees in Aerospace union are expected to meet separately with federal mediators this week amid signs that tensions between two groups is escalating; workers walked off their jobs Feb 9 after contract negotiations broke down over wages and health care coverage (M)

headline: String Games: More Than Just Child's Play
abstract: Number of Web sites are available to those who enjoy string games; Mark Sherman, who runs Web site for 200-member International String Figure Association (www.isfa.org) comments on history of string figures; other string-game Web sites noted; photos (M)

headline: Tentative Pact Made to End Boeing Strike
abstract: Boeing Co reaches tentative accord with Society of Professional Engineering Employees in Aerospace to end strike that has delayed jet deliveries; pact calls for 8 percent wage increase this year and 4.5 percent raises in next two years, as well as cash bonuses of up to $2,500; Boeing will distribute part of raises as merit pay; photo (M)

headline: Action Plan For a Reluctant Greenspan
abstract: Economic View column on Irrational Exuberance, book by Yale University economist Robert J Shiller, which warns of economic perils posed by overvalued stock prices and discusses possible remedies for problem, besides imposition of higher interest rates; graph (M)

headline: Pope Makes Virtual Visit To Iraqi Site He Must Skip
abstract: Pope John Paul II is unwilling to surrender his dream of beginning his Holy Land pilgrimage in Iraq, so he makes 'virtual pilgrimage' to Ur, ancient city that is traditionally held to be birthplace of Abraham; Pope was forced to renounce visit to Iraq after prolonged negotiations with government of Pres Saddam Hussein broke down; instead, ceremony is held at Vatican as pope and others view film of biblical sites (M)

headline: ALITALIA TO CUT FLIGHTS
abstract: Alitalia, Italy's national airline, will reduce flights and stop hiring after delays in switching routes to new airport at Malpensa near Milan hurt its profit; Alitalia's strategy, and its alliance with KLM Royal Dutch Airlines, center on transferring business to Malpensa from Linate airport in Milan; transfer was halted in December after European Union said it discriminated against some airlines (S)

headline: Charges Expected in Attack on a Web Site
abstract: FBI seized computer two weeks ago from 17-year-old New Hampshire resident who Los Angeles Police Department says will be charged in connection with attacks on Web site of antidrug organization, DARE America; teenager hacker, who goes by nickname Coolio, is not suspect in last month's attacks on Yahoo, eBay and other major e-commerce Web sites; Coolio, whose real name is not released because he is juvenile, is expected to be arrested next week (S)

headline: ALCAN PROFIT JUMPS
abstract: Montreal-based Alcan Aluminium Ltd finished 1999 strongly, as operating profit in fourth quarter more than doubled to $153 million from 70 million a year earlier; nonperforming gains raised total profit by $40 million (S)

headline: Conservative Fidelity Fund Manager Resigns
abstract: George Vanderheiden, manager of $29 billion Fidelity Advisor Growth Opportunities Fund and $7 billion Fidelity Destiny I fund, resigns effective Feb 1; Advisor Growth fund will pass to Bettina Doulton; Destiny I fund will be managed by Karen Firestone (M)

headline: Siblings, and a Rivalry
abstract: Priceline.com sues Microsoft Corp and Expedia, electronic travel service Microsoft spun off in November, contending patent infringement; charges that Microsoft has spent year trying to learn as much as possible about Priceline.com's on-line grocery shopping business; notes chairman of Expedia, Gregory Maffei, former executive with Microsoft, is brother of Anne Maffei, who took post with Priceline unit affiliated with Priceline.com; Gregory Maffei photo (M)

headline: Israeli President Under Fire After Reports of Big Gifts
abstract: President Ezer Weizman, a crotchety outspoken political veteran, faces pressure to resign after his endorsement of an Israeli withdrawal from the Golan Heights and disclosures that he has accepted substantial undisclosed financial gifts from a French executive.     A blunt opinionated 75-year-old who has ignored the constraints of his supposedly nonpartisan post, Mr. Weizman outraged the right wing last week when he announced that he would ''go home'' in disappointment if the public voted down an eventual Israeli-Syrian peace deal. Several legislators demanded that he resign immediately instead.

headline: Marriott Companies in Settlement Of Lawsuit Brought by Investors
abstract: Marriott hotel chain tentatively agrees to pay more than $400 million to settle series of lawsuits that contend it defrauded investors who had bought interests in its hotels in late 1980's; Marriott International and Host Marriott, closely related companies that manage and own Marriott hotels, sign settlement with lawyers representing thousands of limited partners who had sued companies; bulk of settlement, $372 million, will go to buy out two of worst performing limited partnerships, which own about 120 Courtyard by Marriott hotels; about $62 million will be paid to investors in other partnerships; J W Marriott Jr, chairman of Marriott International, and investor Don Burklew comment; photos (M)

headline: European Lender and Aspirant for I.M.F.
abstract: Profile of Horst Kohler, German head of European Bank for Reconstruction and Development who is German Chancellor Gerhard Schroder's nominee to be managing director of International Monetary Fund; controvery surrounding Kohler's nomination and opposition to it discussed (M)

headline: Stock-Option Warriors
abstract: Segal Co, in it annual executive compensation report on companies with more up to $200 million in revenue, finds most chief executives are asking for and receiving stock options as predomninant form of long-term incentives (S)

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: A partial list for this week.    MONDAY  Ampco-Pittsburgh Corp  Synovus Finl Corp

headline: 3 Rules of D.S.L.: Location, Location, Confusion
abstract: Many computer users are having problems getting DSL (digital subscriber line) service, which delivers fast Internet connections to homes and businesses over ordinary phone lines; phone companies, locked in fierce competition with cable and satellite companies to offer high-bandwidth Internet links, can only offer service within 17,500 feet of central phone upgraded for digital service because signal weakens with distance; map showing areas of Los Angeles where service is available; photos (M)

headline: 37 Popeyes Outlets Bought
abstract: Interfoods of America buys 37 Popeye's Chicken & Biscuits restaurants in Mississippi and Louisiana for $34 million from Ellis Enterprises (S)

headline: Recycling 'Millionaire' (Minus the Money)
abstract: Michel Marriott (Game Theory) article on some CD-ROM games that are fashioned on television-and movie-based entertainment; photos; chart offers details on games cited (M)

headline: Two Wireless Issues Join Parade of High-Flying IPOs
abstract: January 28, 2000

headline: U.N. Food Agency Says Famine Threatens 8 Million in Ethiopia
abstract: United Nations and independent relief officials say at least eight million Ethiopians are likely to suffer hunger or starvation this year, crisis that could rival 1984-85 famine that killed at least million people; aid experts hope world will not wait this time until television images show bone-thin children dying in the dust in midst of another prolonged drought; UN's World Food Program will make worldwide appeal to raise $50 million in emergency aid, and Save the Children announces it has opened Ethiopian famine fund (M)

headline: More Top Web Sites Brought Down
abstract: More Top Web Sites Brought Down

headline: Company Will Offer Free D.S.L., But Service Will Come With Ads
abstract: The marketing frenzy of the past year has brought offers of free computers and free Internet service. This year, make way for free high-speed access.    Broadband Digital Group, a start-up company in Newport Beach, Calif., announced a new service this week called FreeDSL. Starting in April, the company plans to provide people in several major metropolitan areas with free access to digital subscriber lines, commonly known as D.S.L., in exchange for information about their demographics and their attention to advertisements. In most markets, subscribers are now paying $30 to $50 a month for D.S.L. service.

headline: Let the Sun Shine In, And Install a Superfast Line
abstract: Abby Ellin (Preludes) column on growth of e-communes, communities of real, live people who share fascination for all things digital; says what started as digitized communes of university students has evolved to e-communes in apartment buildings with high-technology features such as DSL connections to Internet; says one such complex is Walden Intrernet Village, Houston, Texas, whose high-tech offerings include poolside connections to Internet; says about 85 percent of residents of this 200-unit village are men, with age range generally 23 to 35; photos (M)

headline: Taiwan Calm, So China's Bid for Entry Into Trade Group Gains
abstract: Rare burst of moderation on both sides of Taiwan Strait fortifies proponents of granting China permanent trading rights in United States as Senate committee formally tales up trade measure today; Clinton administration officials say prospects of passage had improved; several members of Congress say that China's low-key reaction to election of Chen Shui-bian of independence-leaning Democratic Progressive Party as Taiwan's new president offers some reassurance that Beijing will take 'wait and see' attitude toward new government (M)

headline: In the Words of Helms: 'A Lack of Gratitude'
abstract: Excerpts from Sen Jesse Helms's speech to United Nations Security Council (M)

headline: Pfizer and Warner-Lambert Are Seen in Merger Deal
abstract: Pfizer Inc reaches tentative agreement to buy Warner-Lambert Co for sweetened price of $87 billion; Warner-Lambert must win approval of American Home Products Corp, partner with which it already has merger agreement; no deal is guaranteed until boards of companies have approved it (M)

abstract: Article on online computer game for girls, The Adventures of Josie True, being developed for girls by University of Buffalo professor Mary Flanagan; she is seeking to tap overlooked educational software market for girls (Special Section, E-Commerce); photos (M)

headline: As War Intensifies in Chechnya, Rising Casualties Worry Kremlin
abstract: Lying in Hospital No. 1458, a few miles north of Chechnya, Nikolai Tarasyuk is not alone. Most of the original 100 men in his company have been wounded or killed, or felled by sickness, he said, and many were also in the hospital.    The 20-year-old sergeant said the hospital, which is near the sprawling Russian military base here, was pretty good. But on this day it was clearly working at more than capacity. The hospital was designed to accommodate 150 patients, but tents have been set upin a nearby field so the medical staff could serve twice that number. Bandaged soldiers crowded the waiting room.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Shares of Palm Pilot Maker Soar on First Day of Trading  Continuing a wave of enthusiasm for companies involved in the Internet and wireless communications, investors snapped up shares of Palm, the maker of the Palm Pilot handheld devices. The shares traded as high as $165, more than four times the offering price of $38, before retreating to slightly more than $95.    At that price, the market is valuing Palm at $53.3 billion, far more than the value of its parent, 3Com, which still owns most of the company. Palm's market value is higher than that of many far larger companies, including Ford, General Motors and Chevron.   [Page A1.]    Inquiry Clouds Sotheby's Report  Sotheby's Holdings could do little to dispel investors' concerns over the outcome of a federal antitrust investigation as it discussed its Internet prospects and posted better-than-expected fourth-quarter results. While William F. Ruprecht, the company's new chief executive, spoke optimistically about Sotheby's future in holding auctions over the Internet, he acknowledged fierce competition and the challenges of proceeding in the face of an investigation and the threat to its reputation. Last week, the company's chairman, A. Alfred Taubman, and its president and chief executive, Diana D. Brooks, abruptly resigned as the company and its archrival, Christie's, were accused of colluding to fix commissions.   [C2.]

headline: U.S. Report Harshly Criticizes China for Deterioration of Human Rights; Russia Also Faulted
abstract: State Department issues annual report on human rights that sharply criticizes China; says China's poor human rights record deteriorated markedly throughout 1999, as government intensified efforts to suppress dissent; also faults Russia for indiscriminate use of force in breakaway province of Chechnya that resulted in many deaths; findings discussed (M)

headline: INDIA  INTENSIFIES HIJACKING DISPUTE
abstract: India today intensified its efforts to blame Pakistan for the Indian Airlines hijacking, announcing that four accomplices had been seized in Bombay and that they had identified the five hijackers as Pakistanis and acknowledged official Pakistani sponsorship of the hijacking.    The home minister, Lal Krishna Advani, said at a news conference here that the statements of the four reported accomplices -- an Indian, two Pakistanis and a Nepali -- and other ''telltale pointers'' conclusively established Pakistan's role in the seizure of the Airbus. The plane was hijacked as it flew from Katmandu, Nepal, to New Delhi on Dec. 24 with 178 passengers and 11 crew members on board.

headline: Internet Board Agrees to Overhaul Election Plan
abstract: March 10, 2000

headline: Market Place; DOW VS. NASDAQ: As technology stocks outperform again, it's the smaller players that are doing the heavy lifting.
abstract: Market Place column on recent success of small technology stocks; notes technology-saturated Nasdaq composite index had its best week ever relative to Dow Jones industrial average, index that has long been identified with blue chip stocks; says divergence reflects continued speculation in small technology stocks at time when rising interest rates have hurt many stocks, even blue-chip technology stocks; chart (M)

headline: Lipizzaner Stallions Dance Into Trade Brawl
abstract: If one-trick ponies dream, they dream of being Lipizzaners.     But in the age of globalization, even dreams of white horses need their fine print scrutinized by lawyers. Both the European Union and the World Trade Organization have been drawn into a dispute over what exactly makes a horse an official descendant of those first bred in this mountain hamlet in 1580.

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Graph plots decline of euro against dollar in New York on March 29 after report showing stagnant wages in Europe

headline: Orangina's owner still wants to sell brand, if the price is right.
abstract: French conglomerate Pernod Ricard SA says it still wants to sell its Orangina brand two months since French government halted Coca-Cola Co's two-year effort to acquire brand; Pernod Ricard executives they want to get decent price, even though Coca-Cola's offer fell from $840 million initially to $733 million; photo (M)

headline: 2 Large Insurers in Britain To Merge in $12 Billion Deal
abstract: CGU PLC and Norwich Union PLC, two of Britain's best-known insurance companies, announce they will merge in $12 billion stock swap that analysts depict as shield against European predators; deal would create Europe's fifth-largest insurer, with market value of around $28.3 billion; under deal, Norwich Union shareholders would receive 0.48 of a share in new company, to be called CGNU, while CGU shareholders would receive one share for each CGU share; deal would give CGU shareholders 58.5 percent of combined group while Norwich Union shareholders would control about 41.5 percent (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Euro rises for second day against US dollar in advance of report that is expected to show business confidence rising in Germany; euro rises to 98.68 cents from 98.12 cents; graph; chart (S)

headline: Executive Resigns At Hill, Holliday
abstract: Chuck Kushell is resigning as president of Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos to become chief executive at Internet consulting firm he is forming with five other executives; David Wecal will act as head as Hill, Holliday seeks successor (S)

headline: The Death of Grammar
abstract: Letter by Dan Woog responds to March 9 article on review of usage manual for Net communication: says he has noticed number of his high school students writing formal papers in much same style as they use on the net, with plenty of abbreviations

headline: SWEDISH MATCH ADDING BRANDS OF NATIONAL TOBACCO
abstract: Swedish Match AB will buy brands owned by closely held National Tobacco Co for $165 million (S)

headline: Kuwait, in a Switch, Agrees to Consider Increasing Output of Oil
abstract: Kuwait agrees to at least consider raising oil output levels, joining other major petroleum exporters that appear to be leaning toward more production; change of position by Kuwait, one of most important producers in OPEC, comes during visit by US Energy Sec Bill Richardson, who has been touring OPEC and non-OPEC member nations as part of campaign by Clinton administration to seek higher production; graph; chart (M)

headline: 2 Salmon-Farming Giants to Combine
abstract: Nutreco Holding says it is in talks to buy seafood unit of bigger rival, Norsk Hydro, for about $420 million (S)

abstract: Dry cleaning experts comment on stain removal using at-home dry-cleaning product (S)/

headline: F.T.C. Expected to File Complaints Over Generic Drug Delays
abstract: Federal Trade Commission is expected to file civil complaints contending that four drug companies harmed consumers when they made agreements that delayed sale of low-cost generic drugs; Andrx Corp says commission is expected to file case against it and Aventis, created with merger of Hoechst AG and Rhone-Poulenc SA, over 1997 agreement between Andrx and Hoechst; FTC is also expected to settle charges with Abbott Laboratories and Geneva Pharmaceuticals, generic drug company owned by Novartis (M)

headline: People
abstract: Recent promotions and appointments in advertising industry noted (S)

headline: 2 Reporters Preparing Books on Giuliani
abstract: Two New York journalists who have had difficult relations with Mayor Rudolph W Giuliani are writing books about him that are scheduled to be published this summer, just as his race for United States Senate against Hillary Rodham Clinton would be heading into stretch; Andrew Kirtzman's book is Rudy Giuliani: Emperor of the City, and Wayne Barrett's book is Rudy: Gotham's Goliath; photo (M)

headline: A Million Protesters in Spain Denounce Terrorism's Return
abstract: Approximately one million people march in Madrid, Spain, in protest against Basque separatist group ETA, suspected in two car bombings in city in which army officer died; march is led by Prime Min Jose Maria Aznar and three former prime ministers and caps weekend of nationwide protests; bombings appear to reignite separatist violence after 18-month lull; photo (M)

headline: Extensive Genealogy Package With a Focus on Ellis Island
abstract: Sierra Home offers 21 CD-ROM set on Ellis Island, which includes extensive collection of data from the Ellis Island station, including immigration records, census images and ship's passenger lists; expected price is $69.95 (S)

headline: Protests on New Genes and Seeds Grow More Passionate in Europe
abstract: Article in series, Redesigning Nature, examines ongoing debate over genetically modified foods that has grown more passionate and more intense in Europe compared with US, where nearly two-thirds of products on supermarket shelves contain genetically altered ingredients, and few Americans seem to notice; debate may have progressed beyond level of rational discussion in Europe, where increasing numbers of retailers have banished products from shelves; American farmers remain undeterred as big food processors have agred to buy modified grains and keep them separate from traditional ones; focus of European fury is technology that borrows genetic code from plants and animals and transfers it to plant to make it resistant to pests and increase crop yields; while opponents concede no one has been harmed by genetically modified foods, they argue that environmental threats are real and that more research is needed on long-term safety; European opposition attributed to myriad factors, including jingoism about food, scare campaigns by environmentalists, arrogant American responses and anti-Americanism; photo (M)

headline: Stop, Thief! You've Got Mail
abstract: For decades, home security companies have been wiring houses with central nervous systems of motion sensors and computer controls; now those installations are employing more sophisticated wireless technology, allowing them to be used to automate electronic equipment and appliances for houses that are smart as well as secure; photos (M)

headline: What About Last Year's Refund?
abstract: Refund checks for 1998 are still due to 100,000 taxpayers; checks totaling $72 million were returned to IRS by Postal Service (S)

headline: ANGER OVER DELAYED TRADE DEAL
abstract: South Africa's Pres Thabo Mbeki lashes out at European Union, criticizing it for not carrying out free-trade accord with his country because of objections by Greece and Italy to use terms grappa and ouzo in labeling wines and spirits; both countries contend South Africa should not be able to use the terms; Mbeki says European Union has shown bad faith in raising objections after accord was signed, speech to World Economic Forum, Davos, Switzerland (S)

headline: Judge Orders Preliminary Injunction Against Canadian Web Site
abstract: Judge Orders Preliminary Injunction Against Canadian Web Site

headline: AMBEV TAKES COKE TO COURT
abstract: Brazil's largest beverage company, Companhia de Bebidas das Americas, or AmBev, takes legal action in Rio de Janeiro court against Coca-Cola Co, accusing company of unfair practices; AmBev, combination of Brazil's two largest beverage concerns under deal announced last year, says Coke unfairly sought to influence Brazilian public against merger; AmBev's competitors, including Companhia Cervejarias Kaiser brewery, in which Coke owns minority stake, have raised concerns about size of proposed merger; Kaiser says it will counter AmBev's complaint with its own legal action (S)

headline: Another Boom in Biotechnology Stocks
abstract: Stocks of leading biotechnology firms are experiencing run-up of kind experienced in 1991; American Stock Exchange's Biotechnology Index is up 25.6 percent just this year as investors warm to stocks like Amgen and Genentech; Jeffrey Casdin, president of Casdin Capital Partners, fund that owns several kinds of biotechnology stocks, says average investor would be wise not to put all their money into genomics; one tactic is for investors to buy fixed dollar amount at regular intervals to take advantage of any market pullbacks; graph on biotech stocks performance 1999-2000 (M)

headline: NISSAN GIVEN 'JUNK' RATING
abstract: Credit rating of Japan-based Nissan Motor Co is lowered below investment grade by Standard & Poor's Corp after company says weak performance in its home market will pull down its operating profit (S)

headline: Faded Supermarket Dynamos Chase Varying Growth Strategies
abstract: Consumer goods companies have become victims of their own past success and of significant shifts in consumer buying patterns; these masters of brand image have been beaten at their own highly sophisticated game by retailers, very companies that used to be at their beck and call; growth has slowed at these companies for variety of reasons, both internal and external; US population is growing just 1.5 percent annually; several years of low inflation have left these companies unable to raise prices as they had in years past; growth from foreign operations has plateaued as well; strong dollar is hurting them, since they calculate foreign profits in US currency; companies have to find profit growth some other way, by cutting costs or by acquiring faster-growing companies; financial problems at some major companies, including Coca-Cola Co and Procter & Gamble discussed (M)

headline: Report Seeks Big Changes in I.M.F. and World Bank
abstract: US Congressional commission will recommend that International Monetary Fund and World Bank should be radically shrunken and overhauled because they often do more harm than good in developing world; also asserts that both organizations waste billions of dollars making loans to middle-income countries that could rely on private capital instead; says institutions should sharply curtail their lending programs, that they often interfere too much in domestic policy and even politics of countries that they seek to help and that they generally failed to lead nations out of poverty; US Treasury Sec Lawrence H Summers, anticipating main thrust of report's conclusions, proposed plan late last year to streamline monetary fund and is also conducting study of World Bank (M)

headline: Fears Encircle War Games on India-Pakistan Border
abstract: More than 100 Indian tanks are churning up billowing clouds of sand as they rumble across Rajasthani desert this week in war games about 60 miles from India's border with its longtime foe Pakistan; just a month before Pres Clinton visits region, Indian military's very public rehearsal of its limited-war strategy is yet another sign of heightened tensions between these nuclear-armed neighbors (M)

headline: Havana Journal; On Show in Cuba: Marvels of American Medicine
abstract: Nearly 100 companies are taking part in United States Health Care exhibition in Havana this week, first American trade show held there in four decades; photo (M

headline: Financial Spinoff Is Postponed
abstract: Kansas City Southern Industries delays spinoff of Stilwell Financial, its financial-services businesses, because of regulators' questions about its Janus Capital unit that could scuttle deal; Securities and Exchange Commission may require Kansas City to recast Janus as equity investment rather than consolidated subsidiary; that may lead Internal Revenue Service to re-examine if Kansas City Southern should be entitled to tax-free spinoff for Stilwell, which was first scheduled for 1998 (S)

headline: Cleaning Up the Dry Cleaners; High Cost of Going Green Limits Promising Technology
abstract: Hangers Cleaners is trying to sell dry-cleaning industry and its customers on radically different technology that does not use hazardous or toxic chemicals; Hangers uses biodegradable soap dissolved not in water but in liquefied carbon dioxide, substance so safe it is used to decaffeinate coffee and inject fizz into soft drinks; backers of Hangers see it as high-profile model of 'green chemistry,' unofficial name that government officials gave to various programs in 1991 aimed at weaning society from its reliance on noxious chemcials; Micell Technologies owns technology and Hangers name; Hangers has opened only handful of stores, rather than 500 outlets and $50 million in sales it expected by end of last year, providing strong evidence that environmental benefits matter only after customers are satisfied about cost, quality and convenience; cost of each machine is about $150,000, compared with $60,000 for top-of-the-line perc system handling similar-sized loads; graph; chart; photo (M)

headline: Who Is Minding Your Own Business?
abstract: Jeffrey L Seglin (The Right Thing) article, citing announcement by Doubleclick, Internet advertising and consumer tracking data firm, that it would begin linking its trove of heretofore anonymous data about people's Inernet activities with real names, addresses and profiles of consumers in database it acquired; says Doubleclick's defense against firestorm of criticism its announcement provoked fails to get at ethical underlying issues surrounding assembling of dossiers on people for commercial gain (M)

headline: Marks & Spencer Looks Afar To Find an Executive Savior
abstract: Marks & Spencer offers $22 million package to lure the Belgian-born Luc Vandevelde from Promodes, France-based grocery chain, to be its new executive chairman, a post traditionally kept within a coterie of longtime Marks & Spencer executives; Vandevelde is credited with raising Promodes share price sixfold since joining company in 1995 and has reportedly bridled at taking No. 2 slot after merger with Carrefour; Marks & Spencer is increasingly desperate to reverse its ailing fortunes, which have not only sullied its one-time image as the flagship of British retailing but also inspired talks of a takeover bid; photo (M)

headline: STOCKS FALL HARD ON EARNINGS FEARS
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average plunges 374.47 points on investors' fears that rising oil prices combined with higher interest rates might do significant damage to corporate profits; fall begins when Procter & Gamble, one of nation's biggest and best-known companies, says that its earnings in current quarter will come in well below levels expected by Wall Street analysts; warning shocks investors; they dump P&G shares, wiping out $36 billion, or nearly 31 percent, of company's value; Dow falls 3.7 percent, to 9.796,03; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index loses 2.6 percent of its value, while Wilshire 5000 Total Market Index declines 2.1 percent; graph (M)

headline: Shopping With Priceline: Promise and Problems
abstract: Peter Staley letter on Michelle Slatalla's Jan 6 article scores Priceline.com's grocery ordering process as deceptive

headline: Kansas Suspension:'System Run Amok'
abstract: THE AMERICAN Civil Liberties Union, concerned that students' rights may be jeopardized by the strict application of zero-tolerance-type policies, was heartened by a recent court victory in Kansas.

abstract: Andrx Corp will acquire Valmed Pharmaceutical Inc, distributor of generic drugs; terms not disclosed (S)

abstract: Mexican cell-phone operators Pegaso PCS and Grupo Iusacell announce their customers will be able to link to Internet through cellular telephones, starting in April, beating market leader Telcel in race to offer PC-free mobile Web access in Mexico (S)

headline: Treasury to Auction Bills This Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to the today's regular weekly auction of three-  and six-month bills.    By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 5.75 percent and a six-month bill was 5.72 percent.

headline: U.N. Council Urged to Debate Political Future of Kosovo
abstract: Bernard Kouchner, director of UN administration in Kosovo, urges Security Council to debate political future of Serbian province, where local elections are scheduled for before end of 2000; invites 15-member council to travel to area to see situation on ground (M)

headline: A Once Glorious City, Overlooked by Time
abstract: ''Timbuktu 2000! Timbuktu 2000!'' cried 3-year-old Aboubacari Sidiki, as he dangled from the bumper of a truck parked on a sand-filled street here.    The words meant nothing to him. The boy was simply parroting the slogan that city promoters had been using to draw in Westerners to mark the end of an era at the end of the world.

headline: Jergens Chooses Kirshenbaum Bond
abstract: Andrew Jergens Co, subsidiary of Kao Corp, names Kirshenbaum Bond & Partners to handle its Biore skincare line; billings estimated at $30 million to $40 million; Deutsch Inc resigned account in October (S)

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: THE AMERICAS    ECUADOR: EMERGENCY DECLARED  Faced with a collapsing currency and the threat of renewed strikes and street protests that his government attributes to groups seeking his ouster, President Jamil Mahuad, left, has declared a national emergency for the fourth time in less than 18 months in office. The currency has depreciated by 15 percent against the dollar this week, leading to fears of higher prices and unemployment. The decree gives the government special powers to put troops in the street to monitor protests.   Larry Rohter (NYT)    VENEZUELA: SOLDIERS INVESTIGATED  Prosecutors have begun an investigation into complaints by a human rights group, Provea, that security forces committed abuses during relief efforts after deadly floods and landslides last month. The group accuses soldiers of summarily executing thieves who were looting abandoned homes, beating residents of storm-damaged neighborhoods, illegally entering homes and restricting freedom of movement. Minister of Defense Raul Salazar has denied the charges.   Larry Rohter (NYT)

headline: Talks at US Airways Go On Past Deadline
abstract: US Airways and its 10,000 flight attendants continued to negotiate as the deadline passed at 12:01 a.m. today. The airline had said it would suspend operations if no settlement were reached or if talks were not extended to avoid disruptions that the union had threatened. Passengers were awaiting the outcome nervously and trying to switch airlines.    Business Day, Page C1.

headline: Report of China Delay Hurts Qualcomm
abstract: Qualcomm Inc shares fall 4.9 percent after report says China has delayed plans to build digital mobile telephone network using company's technology; Qualcomm has been counting on China to increase its revenue and profit; chief executive Irwin Mark Jacobs signed licensing agreement last week with China Unicom, country's number 2 phone company (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: A Complex $19 Billion Deal To Take Seagate Private  In a complex $19 billion deal, Seagate Technology, the disk drive company, will be taken private by an investor group led by Silver Lake Partners, Seagate executives and the Texas Pacific Group.    Under terms of the deal, Veritas Software will buy back its one-third stake held by Seagate and redistribute the assets to Seagate's stockholders. The investor group will acquire Seagate's disk drive business. [Page C12.]

headline: Senate Ratifies Nomination Of Greenspan to 4th Term
abstract: US Senate, 89-4, confirms Alan Greenspan's nomination to fourth term as chairman of Federal Reserve after members of both parties laud his performance over last dozen years in nurturing economy's long expansion; four votes against Greenspan come from liberal Democrats who say he is too focused on fighting inflation threat that is more theoretical than real, and doing os behind cloak of excessive secrecy at Federal Reserve (M)

headline: For Home Users, No Need To Rush Out for Windows 2000
abstract: Most home users can safely ignore Windows 2000, which goes on sale today as newest version of Microsoft Corp's operating software system; Windows 2000 is mainly intended for large corporations and network-intensive businesses (S)

headline: NATO Chief Makes a Plea for More Kosovo Peacekeepers
abstract: NATO's senior commander, Gen Wesley K Clark, appeals to NATO countries to quickly dispatch as many as 1,800 additional peacekeeping troops to Mitrovica, where ethnic tensions are high; Clark says he is concerned that some nations have refused to send troops, already based in Kosovo, to Mitrovica; that city has become flash point between Serbs and Albanians; refusal to comply with requests reflects lack of enthusaism for putting NATO troops into such an unpredictable situation; photo (M)

headline: Turkey Seems On the Brink Of Upheaval In Leadership
abstract: Turkish Prime Min Bulent Ecevit, leaving for state visit to India, leaves behind country that suddenly seems on edge of political upheaval; warns that he is concerned about continuation of government; warning follows turbulent session of Turkey's Parliament; session was called to consider constitutional amendment that would allow Pres Suleyman Demirel to serve another five years in office, but it dissolves into partisan battle that may bode ill for country's stability (M)

headline: 3-Way Merger Dance for Communications Companies
abstract: Lawyers for Qwest Communications International Inc and Deutsche Telekom of Germany explore ways to unravel Qwest's pending agreement to acquire U S West Inc in effort to set up three-way merger among companies; pending deal to acquire U S West is preventing Qwest from selling company to Deutsche Telekom, Europe's biggest communications carrier; unless U S West decides to walk away from its deal with Qwest--considered unlikely--Deutsche Telekom is saddled with having to negotiate with both companies at once; Deutsche Telekom must decide if it wants to acquire Qwest so badly that it will take on less attractive U S West, and at what price (M)

headline: A Run for Office Can Mean a Run on Your Money
abstract: Financial sacrifices person must make in running for one of estimated 513,000 local, state and federal offices discussed; in any given year, between 100,000 and 150,000 seats are up for grabs; Ron Faucheux, editor of Campaigns and Elections magazine, says those planning to run for office can expect to spend between $15,000 and $200,000 to conduct successful citywide campaign in mid- to large-size city and between $25,000 and $300,000 for state legislative office; profile of Alberta Hipps, who left secure career as hospital staff director, to become become member of Jacksonville, Fla, city council; her photo (M)

abstract: KUALA LUMPUR—  The prime minister of Malaysia, Mahathir bin Mohamad, delivered unusually firm words on the importance of democracy Tuesday in a meeting with Pakistan's military leader, General Pervez Musharraf.

headline: A Day's Surge in Shares Can't Erase a Weak Month
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average gains 201.66 points, or nearly 1.9 percent, to close at 10,940.53; Nasdaq composite index closes at 3,940.35, up 53.28; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index advances 34.40 points, or about 2.5 percent, to 1,394.46; graphs; chart (M)

headline: Iran Reformers' Gains Reflected In Homages to Outspoken Cleric
abstract: Election returns indicate that Iran's reformers should have a significant, probably dominant, place in new Parliament, and they signal their confidence by paying homage to Abdullah Nouri, the most outspoken clerical advocate of change and democracy; Nouri is serving sentence for apostasy but is allowed home for a few days; his visitors include chief of staff of Pres Mohammad Khatami, several ministers, head of Iran's Central Bank, and a few provincial governors; photo (M)

abstract: Concord Communications Inc acquires FirstSense Software Inc for $101 million in stock (S)

headline: More Data Disclosed On Web Site Use
abstract: Nielsen Net Ratings, Internet measurement service, releases data indicating that computers users visited many Web sites of dot-com companies that advertised during Super Bowl; finds number of people visting Web sites of dot-com advertisers rose 15.7 percent, compared with increase of 10.7 percent of all site; two of largest gains were registered by Oxygen.com, Web site of Oxygen Media, and Hotjobs.com (S)

headline: Czech Poll: Harassment Of Women Is Common
abstract: Recent study commissioned by Czech daily indicates that almost half of working women in Czech Republic have been subjected to sexual harassment in workplace; reports from other post-Communist countries indicate that sexual harassment, though seldom identified as such, is widespread; in Czech Republic, 45 percent of women say they were sexually harassed, many of them repeatedly; women's rights advocates say real figures are probably higher; note that term often used by Czechs for sexual harassment, translated, means 'sexual buzz,' with tacit understanding that whoever complains about harassment is making unnecessary fuss (M)

headline: Some Foundations Choose to Curb Donations and Pay More Taxes
abstract: Some foundations are paying federal excise tax at 2 percent rate on investment income for failing to maintain or increase their level of giving, instead of 1 percent rate paid by those that meet criteria; foundations have long complained that two-tier tax is poorly designed and overly complicated, discouraging large increases in giving; little-noticed provision of Pres Clinton's 2001 budget would replace two tiers with flat 1.25 percent tax; some charity advocates hold change would eliminate only incentive to keep giving in line with rise in value of invested assets (M)

headline: Israeli Lawmakers Hold Quick Debate on Nuclear Arms
abstract: Israel's Parliament holds its first public discussion in over 35 years about country's long-secret nuclear arms programs; debate is relatively brief but often bitter; Israeli Arab legislator, Issam Makhul, says that Israeli citizens are kept in dark about nation's nuclear arsenal and conditions at aging Dimona reactor; photo (M)

headline: Annan Faces Growing Split Over Arms Inspector for Iraq
abstract: Russia, joined by France and China, takes lead in marshaling growing opposition to UN Sec Gen Kofi Annan's nomination of Rolf Ekeus as new chief arms inspector for Iraq; want nominating process reopened so candidate more favorable to Iraq can be found; experts see stalemate as crisis for Annan and Security Council; Richard C Holbrooke, US representative, says that issue will remain in council, whose members are displaying unanimity in preference to support Annan but lack onsensus; photo (M)

headline: People
abstract: Gil Bashe is named chief executive at Healthquest Global Communications Partners; Steve Collins is named president of Martin/Williams Advertising, succeeding Dave Sloren, who will remain chairman and chief executive at Martin Williams Inc; Tom Kellly, senior vice president and creative director at Martin/Williams Advertising, becomes executive vice president and executive creative director, succeeding Lyle Wedemeyer, who will retain some creative duties with selected clients; Marcia Stone is named to new post of deputy creative director at Bates North America; David Reyburn, senior vice president and creative director at Bates USA Midwest, succeeds Stone, with title of senior vice president and executive creative director (M)

headline: American Topics : Raised From the Ashes — an Art Form
abstract: Walk through the glass doors of Commander's Gallery in Biloxi, Mississippi, past the conventional oil and pastel paintings, past the green curtains and you will find a new art medium — human ashes.

headline: Israel Expands Daylight Time, and a Religious Dispute Erupts
abstract: Interior Min Natan Sharansky says 'summer time' will be 34 days longer in Israel this year, rescinding tradition of accommodating prayer schedules of some religious Jews (M)

headline: Lucent to Acquire Ortel for $2.95 Billion
abstract: February 07, 2000

headline: A Financial Lesson In Harsh Storms
abstract: Insurers, hurt by falling premiums, hope that storms that swept across Europe last week will give them standing to raise insurance rates; claims from these and other natural disasters last year will probably increase premiums by 5 to 15 percent (S)

headline: Curbs Off, Investors Rush to Malaysia
abstract: KUALA LUMPUR—  For stock-market watchers in Asia, 2000 has begun with a paradox. The Kuala Lumpur stock exchange, the market that investors loved to hate, is now Asia's best performer, up 17 percent since the year began.

headline: Ex-Chief of United Way Owed $4.2 Million
abstract: United Way of America owes its imprisoned former president, William V. Aramony, the full $4.2 million in his deferred compensation plan because the plan did not include a clause forfeiting the money if Mr. Aramony committed a felony, a Federal judge ruled yesterday.    Judge Shira A. Scheindlin of United States District Court in Manhattan ruled, however, that United Way can withhold $2.02 million in salary, investigative costs and interest that Mr. Aramony owes the national organization, which he ran for 19 years. She also ruled that Mr. Aramony is not entitled to legal fees due the lawyer who won the case, Dennis Houdek of Flacone, Houdek & Curd in Manhattan.

headline: Big Board Reports Quarterly Loss
abstract: New York Stock Exchange had its first quarterly loss in almost a decade in fourth quarter of 1999; net loss was $800,000, compared with profit of $7.4 million in period a year earlier; fourth-quarter revenue fell about 2 percent, to $184 million, compared with $188 million a year ago; net income for 1999 declined 26 percent to $75 million while revenue rose 1 percent to $736 million (M)

headline: Oracle to Build Market Site For Sears and French Chain
abstract: Oracle Corp says it will join with Sears, Roebuck & Co and Carrefour of France to create global online marketplace for retail industry; other retailers will be invited to join founding partners in new venture, which will be called GlobalNetXchange; joint venture will initially focus on combined $80 billion in purchases that Sears and Carrefour make from 50,000 suppliers, partners and distributors (M)

headline: S.E.C. Recommendations on Central Market
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission asks public comment on six alternative plans aimed at reducing fragmentation in United States stock markets, including formation of central market for customer orders; plans seek to break down competitive barriers and improve investor access to best possible prices; SEC also issues New York Stock Exchange proposal to scrap rule that bars its brokerage members from trading many large stocks off exchange floor (M)

headline: Three big advertising agencies kick off a worldwide partnership.
abstract: Partners in world's newest advertising agency, company formed by merger of Leo Group, MacManus Group and Dentsu Inc, gather in Chicago to kick off new entity, which will be known as B Com3 Group; merged entity plans initial public offering in next 12 to 18 months, and Dentsu plans one in fall of 2001; diagram (M)

headline: A Boardroom Shares Its Art on the Net
abstract: Starting this month series of drawings and sketches hanging on walls of boardroom of Corning Inc will also be on the Internet for limited time on arthistorytv.com, with commentary provided by Michel Whitmer, New York art dealer; some of the major works displayed noted; photo (S)

headline: Accompanying a Robot on an Antarctic Quest
abstract: News Watch: Accompanying a Robot on an Antarctic Quest

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Letters to the Editor

headline: Netscape and Rodale Hire Key Executives
abstract: Netscape Communications names John Heins to new post of vice president for sales and international operations; Rodale Inc names Steven Pleshette Murphy president and chief operating officer, succeeding Robert J Teufel, who is retiring (S)

headline: Reds and Whites, And Shipping Blues
abstract: Michelle Slatalla (Online Shopper) article on pros and cons of buying wine over the Internet; says there exists a mishmash of state laws that govern liquor distribution and, as a result, wines are for sale in some states but not in others; says even people who are paid to understand how this system works told her they often could not; photo (M)

headline: Ford Plans Job Cuts At Plant in England
abstract: Ford Motor Co plans layoffs of more than 1,000 workers at giant assembly plant in Dagenham, England, and may close entire factory; says pound's strength relative to euro has made it expensive to manufacture in Britain for sale in Europe (S)

headline: Honoring a Heretic Whom Vatican 'Regrets' Burning
abstract: Hundreds of people gather at statue of Giordano Bruno at Campo dei Fiori in central Rome, where he was burned alive in 1600 as heretic, to commemorate man many Italians revere as martyr of free thought; Pope has marked this Holy Year as time for church to apologize for past errors and excesses, from Inquisition to persecution of Jews; Cardinal Angelo Sodano, Vatican secretary of state, says that church 'regrets' that it had resorted to violence in Bruno's case, but points out that Bruno's writings were 'incompatible' with Christian thinking, and that he therefore remains a heretic; photos (M)

headline: Dow Gains 124 Points, Ending Slide; Treasury Prices Fall
abstract: Stock prices halted their early-year slide yesterday but finished little better than mixed after the Nasdaq composite index pulled out of a big hole only to fade late in the day.    The Nasdaq ended the session down 24.15 points, or 0.6 percent, to 3,877.54. The Dow Jones industrial average, however, held on to much of its gain and ended up 124.72 points, or 1.1 percent, to 11,122.65, recovering about one-quarter of its steep decline during the first two trading days of the year. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 2.69 points, or 0.2 percent, to 1,402.11.

headline: BROADCOM WILL EXPAND CHIP BUSINESS THROUGH MERGER
abstract: Broadcom Corp acquires BlueSteel Networks Inc for about $123.2 million in stock (S)

headline: UTILICORP UNITED TO PURCHASE TRANSALTA'S ALBERTA UNIT
abstract: UtiliCorp United Inc to buy TransAlta Corp's Alberta electric utility for $450 million to expand its reach in Canada (S)

headline: In New York, Just a Cabby. In India, a School's Hero.
abstract: Article on Om Dutta Sharma, immigrant from India who is also New York City cab driver, who has given his poor village of Doobher Kishanpur school for girls named for his late illiterate mother; photos; map (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Fed Raises Interest Rates In Effort to Slow Economy  The Federal Reserve clamped down a bit more on the economy, raising interest rates by a quarter-point in an effort to prevent an outbreak of inflation. It was the Fed's fifth quarter-point rate increase since June.    The move was no surprise to economists and investors, who had heard repeated hints over the last month from Alan Greenspan, the central bank's chairman, that he intended to stick to his policy of raising rates in small, steady steps until the economy slows. [Page A1.]

headline: Qwest Explores Renegotiating Its Agreement With U S West
abstract: Qwest Communications International Inc's top executives are said to be interested in selling company, even as they explore renegotiating Qwest's agreement to acquire U S West Inc; leading candidate to acquire Qwest, Deutsche Telekom of Germany, has reportedly cooled its negotiations, having become newly aware of many factors that would complicate such a deal; Deutsche Telekom has re-invigorated acquisition talks with other companies, including Global Crossing Ltd of Bermuda; Qwest's merger deal with U S West has not gone smoothly; underlying source of tension in Qwest-U S West relationship is that it would be far easier for Qwest to sell itself to Deutsche Telekom had Qwest not already agreed to acquire U S West (M)

headline: Particle Physicists Getting Closer To the Bang That Started It All
abstract: Scientists in Geneva have re-created primordial form of matter that physicists believe last existed in abundance when universe was exploding fireball only fraction of second old; new material is highly compressed gas of particles called quarks and gluons, building blocks of ordinary particles like protons and neutrons within atoms in universe today; achievement will be announced on Feb 2 at CERN, European particle physics laboratory where work was carried out; diagram (M)

headline: 2 Kohl Party Contenders Have Strong Ties to Ex-Communist Region : German Politics Opens Up to the East
