abstract: FRANKFURT—  In what could herald a growing role for Eastern Germany, both front-runners for the chairmanship of the tainted Christian Democratic Union are from the former Communist region.

headline: Putin Takes Charge, Firing Yeltsin's Daughter and Others
abstract: Acting President Vladimir V. Putin began to put his own imprint on the Kremlin administration today, showing the door to Tatyana Dyachenko, who wielded considerable influence in the administration of her father, Boris N. Yeltsin.    Mr. Putin also moved aside several other staff members who had been loyal to Mr. Yeltsin. But as one television commentator said tonight, the changes amount to a ''freshening up'' of the administration rather than a revolution inside the Kremlin.

headline: Selcuk Journal; In These Prizefights, Camels Wrestle for Carpets
abstract: Camel fighting grows in popularity in Turkey, reflecting desire of many Turks to hold on to Asian identity even as they turn toward Europe; three-month fighting season is in full swing in Selcuk, where thousands arrive each weekend to watch competitions; sport developed as diversion in winter, when cold weather makes farming impossible and forces nomads down from mountainside pastures; photo; map (M)

headline: THAI BANKRUPTCY RULING EXPECTED
abstract: Thailand's benchmark stock index climbs 2.6 percent on speculation that bankruptcy court will decide in favor of petition by bankers to take over management of Thai Petrochemical Industry after collapse of more than two years of talks on restructuring company's $3.5 billion in debt; court is due to issue decision on March 15; graph (S)

headline: Grey Advertising Gets Robitussin
abstract: Whitehall Robins Healthcare expands its relationship with Grey Advertising by naming Grey's New York office to handle domestic account of Robitussin brand cough medicine; billings estimated at $35 million (S)

headline: WIRELESS INTERNET ACCESS
abstract: NTT Mobile Communications Inc, Japan's largest mobile telephone service provider, says it will begin in summer selling all its cellular phones equipped to provide Internet access (S)

headline: LIONBRIDGE TO BUY INT'L.COM FOR $190 MILLION
abstract: Lionbridge Technologies Inc agrees to acquire Int'l.com for about $190 million in stock (S)

headline: CORECOMM IN AGREEMENT TO ACQUIRE VOYAGER.NET
abstract: CoreComm Ltd acquires Voyager.net Inc for $540 million in cash and stock (S)

headline: In Japan, The Legacy Of a Phone Monopoly
abstract: American trade negotiators to meet with their Japanese counterparts, Tokyo, in what may be the last in long series of skirmishes over Japan's regulation of its telecommunications market before US takes its case to World Trade Organization; Japanese regulators have single-mindedly promoted interests of Japanese business--particularly Nippon Telegraph and Telephone, by many measures Japan's most formidable company and its telephone monopoly; rules, which add months to every project, have made Japan most expensive telecommunications market in the industrialized world (M)

headline: Bonds' Rise Sends Traders Into Turmoil
abstract: Chaos sweeps through bond market as traders and investors try to make sense of spectacular and damaging rise in prices of longer-term Treasury bonds as rumors of significant losses sustained by banks, brokerage firms and hedge funds said to be on wrong side of Treasury's market's move roil market; investors and traders, tripping over themselves to buy 30-year bonds, drive price of bonds up unusual 3 percent; yield on bond falls from Feb 2 close of 6.28 percent to as low as 5.93 percent before settling at 6.13 percent; yield on 10-year note falls from 6.57 percent to 6.44 percent; yield on 30-year bond has moved sharply lower in recent days, falling below yield on 2-year note; result is unusual occurrence, inverted yield curve, in which investors who take on more risk by owning long-term debt are paid less than those holding short-term instruments; graph; chart on US key interest rates (M)

headline: U.S. Worried About Tension on Kosovo Border
abstract: US Sec of State Madeleine K Albright says US is very concerned about growing tensions in Presevo valley, area of Serbia on boundary with eastern Kosovo; says she has spoken to Kosovo Albanians and urged moderation; urges Yugoslav government in Belgrade not to interfere in area, which is not in Kosovo (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   8.50   8.50   8.50       Discount rate   5.00   5.00   5.00       Federal funds   5.50   5.59   4.82       3-month T-bills   5.23   5.27   4.31       6-month T-bills   5.42   5.44   4.24       10-yr. T-infl.   4.34   4.38   3.78       10-yr. T-note   6.62   6.69   4.60       30-yr. T-bond   6.65   6.71   5.05       Telephone bd.   8.50   8.54   6.84       Municipal bds.   6.29   6.29   5.16          (Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Telerate; The Bond Buyer)

headline: STOCK PRICES DROP IN U.S. AND EUROPE
abstract: Stock prices fell sharply in the United States and Europe yesterday on concerns that interest rates will rise higher than had been anticipated. End-of-year tax moves and investing strategies were also cited as reasons.    The Dow Jones industrial average had its worst day since the autumn of 1998, when world markets were roiled by Asian economic problems and the collapse of the Russian ruble.

headline: Banks Post Higher 4th-Quarter Profits
abstract: Bank of America, J P Morgan & Co, Wells Fargo & Co and Bank of New York post higher fourth-quarter earnings; Bank One Corp posts lower profit; Bank of America says profit rose to $2.12 billion from $1.60 billion in year-earlier quarter; Morgan's net income climbed to $509 million from $175 million in last year's quarter; revenue rose 44 percent, to $1.83 billion, as investment-banking revenue rose 17 percent, to $309 million, and asset management revenue rose 27 percent, to $352 million; Wells Fargo reports net income rose to $970 million from profit before charges of $768 million; net interest income rose 3.9 percent, to $2.41 billion; Bank of New York's fourth-quarter profit rose 4.5 percent, to $327 million; Bank One Corp's profit from operations fell to $904 million from $1.04 billion; net income rose 82 percent, to $411 million from $226 million (M)

headline: Fund Company Adds Software
abstract: Federated Investors Inc, a fund company, buys InvestLink Technologies, software developer, from United Asset Management Corp to expand in the 401(k) retirement plan market (S)

headline: More Foreign High-Tech Workers Sought
abstract: More Foreign High-Tech Workers Sought

headline: ASTRA BIDDERS PICKED
abstract: Indonesia's bank restructuring agency picks three consortiums to bid for its 40 percent stake in Astra International; says Singapore government's investment arm will be included in all three, which are led by Cycle & Carriage Ltd, Gilbert Global Equity Partners and Lazard Freres & Co unit (S)

headline: KEEBLER SELLING TWO PLANTS TO CONSOLIDATED BISCUIT
abstract: The Keebler Foods Company agreed to sell two cookie plants and its Sunny and Gregs cookie brands for undisclosed terms to the Consolidated Biscuit Company as the last step in integrating a baking company bought in 1998. The plants in Birmingham, Ala., and North Little Rock, Ark., had revenue of $54 million in 1999. Keebler, the second-largest United States cookie and cracker maker, acquired the plants and the brands in September 1998 when it purchased the President Baking Company. Keebler is 55 percent-owned by Flowers Industries, a baked-goods company based in Thomasville, Ga.

headline: Finding Ways to Dabble in Cuba, Legally
abstract: Since Soviet Union's collapse, Cuba has been forced to flirt with capitalism and US dollar; while investors from Canada and many other countries have poured huge sums into Cuba, and a few Americans are putting their money into third-world companies and closed-end mutual funds with exposure in Cuba; legality of some of this investing by Americans is, at best, blurry; Cuban investments are not for faint of heart but do have the advantage of being in place if and when the American embargo against that country ends; some ways Americans can invest in Cuba noted (M)

headline: Greenspan Urges Congress To Fuel Growth of Derivatives
abstract: Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, urges Congress to encourage the growth of complex financial contracts known as derivatives before the United States share of that market and associated benefits are lost to other countries, testimony to Senate Agriculture Committee; Greenspan and Treasury Secretary Lawrence H Summers both back an exclusion from commodities laws for professional investors, which they previously recommended (M)

headline: In Japan, Life Insurers Losing Popularity
abstract: TOKYO—  Japan's life insurance industry is on the verge of a monumental change. That is because people like Shinichi Suda are increasingly unhappy with the way they are initiated into insurance products.

headline: A Plan for Online Trading of Metals and Oil
abstract: Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, Royal Dutch/Shell and five other banks and energy companies say they will create Web site for trading precious metals and oil; Atlanta-based Web site, named IntercontinentalExchange, will start operating this year and could expand to other commodities; partnership, which includes Goldman Sachs and BP Amoco, is latest use Internet to capture share of estimated $1.8 trillion commodity contracts traded each year; other partners in site are TotalFina Elf, Deutsche Bank and Societe Generale (M)

headline: CMGI Reorganizes to Compete with Doubleclick
abstract: January 20, 2000

headline: Equity and Debt Scheduled to Be Offered
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:    ActivCard S.A., France, 4 million American depository shares, each representing one ordinary share. J. P. Morgan Securities.

headline: BRAZIL THREATENS TRADE LAWSUIT
abstract: Brazil's Development Min Alcides Tapias, escalating trade dispute over tariffs imposed by US on steel imports, says country might file complaint with World Trade Organization; last week, US imposed tariffs of up to 19 percent on some steel imports from Brazil and other countries; displeasure with measure soured brief visit by Commerce Sec William M Daley (S)

headline: Deutsche Bank to Sell Stake in Holzmann
abstract: Deutsche Bank, which holds 15 percent of the near-bankrupt German builder Philipp Holzmann, said over the weekend that it intended to sell the stake as it divests itself of industrial holdings.    ''It's our long-term strategy to sell our industrial portfolio, Holzmann included,'' said Klaus Thoma, a spokesman for Deutsche Bank. He denied the bank intended to sell the stake ''soon,'' as reported in a prerelease of Frankfurter Allgemeine Sonntagszeitung.

headline: German Chosen Managing Director of I.M.F.
abstract: Horst Kohler of Germany becomes managing director of International Monetary Fund just as Clinton administration and members of Congress are discussing how agency might be improved; Kohler is unanimously endorsed by 24 members of IMF board; he succeeds Michel Camdessus of France, who retired; US Treasury Sec Lawrence H Summers defends core mission of IMF and its sister institution, World Bank, testimony before House Banking Committee; photo (M)

headline: Money Management Company Acquires a 6% Stake in Aetna
abstract: Southeastern Asset Management Inc acquires 6 percent stake in Aetna Inc for $444 million (M)

headline: Start-Ups Raise Pay and Offer Options as Candidates Dwindle
abstract: Pay experts say executives at start-up companies are receiving not only potentially enormous stock options, but large salaries as well; survey, published by Venture-One, San Francisco research company, shows average vice president for sales at start-up makes $165,000 a year in salary and bonus; finds average chief operating officer earns $190,00, and typical chief executive makes more than $200,000; also finds that chief executives in Washington area typically make 10 percent more than those in California and Northeast and that employee turnover is higher in California than in eastern part of country; chart (M)

headline: DoubleClick Reverses on Using Personal Data
abstract: March 2, 2000

headline: China and Taiwan Pursue Secret Nuclear Waste Deal
abstract: Taiwan and China, despite verbal hostilities over Taiwan's political status, secretly sign letter of intent to pursue surprising multibillion dollar deal in which more than 200,000 drums of radioactive wastes from Taiwan's nuclear power plants would be disposed of on mainland in return for money and technical aid to mainland's nuclear power industry; no contract has been signed and talks on issue have been suspended amid heightened tensions as March 18 presidential elections approach (M)

headline: Warning of Earnings Shortfall Sends BMC Software Shares Tumbling
abstract: January 05, 2000

headline: Tough Fight Ahead for Operator of Sports Betting Site
abstract: March 10, 2000

headline: CABLETRON SYSTEMS TO SELL MANUFACTURING OPERATIONS
abstract: Cabletron Systems Inc agrees to sell its manufacturing and repair operations to Flextronics International Ltd for $100 million (S)

headline: The New York Times: Circuits - Game Theory Index
abstract: The New York Times: Circuits - Game Theory Index

headline: When You Are First, And Still Don't Succeed
abstract: Steve Lohr (Economic View) article discusses reasons why innovative risk-taker like Iridium, global satellite phone system, failed and turned to bankruptcy court for permission to shut down completely (M)

headline: GERMAN-FRENCH INTERNET DEAL EXPECTED
abstract: Deutsche Telekom, Germany's largest telecommunications company, agrees to acquire Club Internet, France's third-largest online service provider; Lagardere, Club Internet's parent company, will receive about 5 percent stake in T-Online, Deutsche Telekom's Internet service provider; Deutsche Telekom is planning to spinning off T-Online this spring and taking company public (S)

headline: ´Coolio´ May Be Charged in Other Hacker Attacks
abstract: 'Coolio' May Be Charged in Other Hacker Attacks

headline: A Second Chance for Some Authors
abstract: Is there a market for the words of authors ignored and scorned by traditional publishers?     At least two California-based companies are wagering that they possess a keener literary sensibility for electronic titles than New York-based publishers. Do-it-yourself electronic publishers Fatbrain.com, of Santa Clara, and iUniverse.com, in Campbell, are trying to twist the conventional publishing paradigm by allowing amateur and professional authors to publish directly online for royalties ranging from 20 to 50 percent.

headline: Namibia Death Toll Rises With Encroaching Angolan Civil War
abstract: Death toll is mounting in Namibi

headline: Third-Quarter Profit at Heinz Rose by 3.5%
abstract: H J Heinz Co says third quarter profit rose 3.5 percent, smallest gain in three and a half years; in quarter ended Jan 26, profit rose to $227.2 million, compared with $219.5 million in year-earlier period; sales rose less than 1 percent, to $2.29 billion from $2.28 billion (S)

headline: Something Borrowed May Leave Market Blue
abstract: Gretchen Morgenson Market Watch column discusses possible move by Federal Reserve to raise margin requirements in response to spurt in margin borrowing; notes Chmn Alan Greenspan opposes raising requirements to tone down stock prices, but has asked securities regulators to weigh move; graph (M)

headline: Ads Speak to Asian-Americans
abstract: Advertising column on recent efforts by mainstream marketers to reach Americans of Asian ancestry; niche is seen as most desirable of nation's demographic markets, but problems involving language and cultural barriers could lead advertisers astray in embarrassing ways; as example, number four cannot be used in telephone number because it implies death in various Asian cultures; likewise, color blue denotes mourning; significant differences among ethnicities that compose Asian-American population require marketers to spend additional time and money to communicate with group that is relatively small and at same time highly fractionated; appeal to advertisers is that Asian-Americans make up fastest-growing population group, they are generally most affluent, best-educated and most likely to hold technology jobs; photos; graph (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Graph depicts decline of euro against dollar on February 4 after economic reports showed decline in factory orders in Germany and lower unemployment in US

headline: Lagging Happily In Russian Race
abstract: Profile of and interview with Ella Pamfilova, only woman in field of 11 in Russia's presidential election on March 26; photo (M)

headline: SIEMENS TO ACQUIRE MOORE PRODUCTS, INSTRUMENT MAKER
abstract: Siemens AG acquires Moore Products Co for $170 million (S)

headline: FELCOR LODGING EXPANDS ITS STOCK BUYBACK PROGRAM
abstract: FelCor Lodging Trust Inc. said yesterday that it expanded its stock buyback program by $200 million. The hotel and real estate investment trust, based in Irving, Tex., said that the increase came after the repurchase of about 5.8 million common shares for about $98.4 million. FelCor's announcement prompted a downgrade of its senior unsecured debt to Ba2 from Ba1 by Moody's Investors Service. Moody's said that the additional stock repurchases -- to be financed primarily with debt -- would result in a ''weakened credit profile.'' The company has about 65.9 million shares outstanding shares. FelCor owns 188 hotels in 35 states and Canada. They include the Embassy Suites, Crowne Plaza, Holiday Inn, Doubletree, Sheraton and Westin chains.

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; AOL Time Warner may inflate Internet stock values even more. Yet its own could falter.
abstract: Market Place column on America Online's acquisition of Time Warner Inc focuses on future of AOL Time Warner stock; says most analysts think that new company's benefits to shareholders will be immediate and that deal will justify even higher valuations among already manic Web stocks (M)

headline: Text of Fed's Statement
abstract: Text of statement by Federal Open Market Committee, Federal Reserve's monetary policy panel, after its decision to raise short-term interest rates

headline: Ernst & Young Cutting Consulting Jobs
abstract: Ernst & Young LLP, world's third-largest accounting and consulting firm, is eliminating 400 consulting jobs as firm shifts its focus to electronic commerce; firm is dismissing 5 percent of its total consulting staff in North America (S)

headline: Mandalay Forecasts a Fall
abstract: Mandalay Resort Group, which owns and operates casinos in Nevada, said late today that it expected to report fourth-quarter earnings that are less than the 16 cents a share it earned last year. The company's earnings projection is also below the average estimate of 25 cents a diluted share among 19 analysts surveyed by First Call/Thomson Financial. Mandalay said that customer volumes in Las Vegas were below expectations ''as negative Year 2000 media reports discouraged the public's travel plans.''

headline: Mexico City Journal; Can't Find Juarez Street? There Are Hundreds!
abstract: Mexico City Journal on confusion of Mexico City street names; photo; map; developers each year carve out some 1,500 new streets, another 300 are renamed because honorees have fallen out of favor; 1998 survey found 80,000 blocks lack signs, thousands of avenues have no official name, and others carry names of politicians in ill repute; favorite names are repeated dozens of times; current review appears prompted by 17 streets named for Carlos Salinas de Gortari, former president associated with plunder of public treasury (M)

headline: Oh, It's You Again
abstract: Letter by Lance Williamson responds to March 16 article on cell phones/pagers as means for parents to keep track of their teenage children; discusses pros and cons of electronic security for children

headline: IT'S A SONY BANK
abstract: Sony Corp announces formal plans to start online bank; Sony will contribute 30 billion yen, or $285.6 million, to online bank, while Sakura Bank and J P Morgan will contribute combined 7.5 billion yen to give them stakes of 16 percent and 4 percent, respectively; Sakura president Akishige Okada and Sony Corp president Nobuyuki Idei comment; photo (S)

headline: Most Treasury Prices Fall on Expectation of Higher Rates
abstract: Treasury bond prices, with exception of 30-year bond, are lower; 30-year bond is up 22/32, to 94 28/32, as yield falls to 6.52 percent, from 6.57 percent; graph on tax-exempt yields; chart on US key interest rates (M)

headline: Brightening Up By Wrapping Up Shawls Add a Dash of Flair
abstract: PARIS—  The current craze for pashmina shawls of all styles and prices might in the end prove to be detrimental to the status of cashmere as a luxury product. But its impact on women's wardrobes is likely to be lasting by focusing on an accessory — the shawl — which has become a hot fashion ticket.

headline: MERCK TO REPURCHASE $10 BILLION OF SHARES
abstract: Merck & Co will buy back as much as $10 billion of its shares, which have fallen 18 percent this month (S)

headline: STRONG FOREIGN INVESTMENT IN KOREA
abstract: Foreign direct investment in South Korea reached $627 million in February, double level of year earlier (S)

headline: To Boldly Go to the Supermarket With Captain Kirk
abstract: FOR weeks, I avoided using Priceline's new online grocery service because I was sure I would hate it.    Let's leave aside for the moment Priceline's reputation in the name-your-price airline ticket business (too many stopovers, crazy departure times) and the annoying television ads for the new grocery service featuring the ''Star Trek'' actor William Shatner (as if Captain Kirk ever set foot inside a Waldbaum's, much less knew the first thing about how to keep a low profile with extra items in the express line). More important, Priceline's online grocery service, called the Priceline WebHouse Club, would force me to confront one of life's worst weekly horrors -- grocery shopping -- not once, but twice.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: BOMBAY CO., Fort Worth, a furniture retailer, named Carmie Mehrlander, president and chief operating officer, to the additional post of chief executive. Mr. Mehrlander replaces Robert S. Jackson, who remains chairman of the board, and Mr. Mehrlander is succeeded by Michael Florio.     CENDANT CORP. named Samuel Katz, senior vice president for strategic development, to the post of chief executive for a new Cendant Internet group. Also, Brian Oakes was named executive vice president and chief investment officer at the Internet group; he had been senior Internet analyst at Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc.

headline: DRUGMAKER HIRES FIRM TO ADVISE IT ON STRATEGIC OPTIONS
abstract: Liposome Co, struggling to get Food and Drug Administration approval for its cancer drug Evacet, hires investment firm Warburg Dillon Read for advice on strategic alternatives, including mergers (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent           Yesterday   Day Ago       Prime rate   8.75   8.75   7.75        Discount rate   5.25   5.25   4.50        Federal funds   5.75   5.77   4.75        3-month T-bills   5.72   5.68   4.50        6-month T-bills   5.87   5.83   4.62        10-yr. T-infl.   4.16   4.17   3.91        10-yr. T-note   6.20   6.24   5.17        30-yr. T-bond   6.00   6.04   5.55        Telephone bd.   8.15   8.15   7.25        Municipal bds.   6.07   6.09   5.17          (Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Telerate; The Bond Buyer)

headline: MediaTalk; Going Down to the Wire in San Francisco
abstract: Speculation is increasing about who will run combine newsroom of San Francisco Examiner and San Francisco Chronicle as Hearst Corp's self-imposed deadline for selling Examiner looms; Hearst seems likely merge papers if no buyer appears; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: EUROPE    RUSSIA: CHECHEN VILLAGE SEIZED  Russian forces said they had seized the Chechen village of Komsomolskoye and were searching the ruins for rebels. Hundreds of Chechens captured the town on March 6, an embarrassing setback for the Russian military, which had sought to trap the rebels in the highlands. Gen. Anatoly Kvashnin, the chief of the Russian general staff, said the military was stepping up its efforts to capture or kill rebel leaders.    Michael R. Gordon (NYT)

headline: Hold Resume Truths to Be Self-Evident? No Way
abstract: Article on companies that specialize in background checks of job applicants; says some companies, especially Internet start-ups desperate to fill large numbers of openings, openly acknowledge that they lack time and resources to verify all information that job seekers submit; photo (M)

headline: A Calling of Faith and Art in a Russian Church
abstract: Rev Andrei Davydov is using his art to finance restoration of 12th century church in Pskov, one of oldest cities in all Russia; Cathedral of the Nativity of St John the Baptist, which dates to 1124, was in shambles when Russian Orthodox patriarchate regained it in 1991; Rev Davydov, who has worldwide reputation for his painted icons, now accepts commissions from other churches to pay for his church's repairs and rebuilding; photos; map (M)

headline: British Airways Cut Its Losses Last Quarter
abstract: British Airways PLC reports better-than-expected third-quarter financial results but still shows loss from fare discounting and surge in fuel prices; third-quarter pretax loss narrowed to 60 million pounds, or $95.78 million, from 75 million pounds a year earlier; company had operating loss of 2 million pounds, or nearly $3.2 million, in period ended Dec 31, in contrast to operating profit of 92 million pounds a year earlier (M)

headline: DEXIA BUYS BOND INSURER
abstract: French-Belgian banking concern Groupe Dexia will acquire New York-based municipal bond insurer Financial Security Assurance Holdings Ltd for $2.6 billion in cash; deal values Financial Security at $76 a share (S)

headline: Austria Won't Crawl, Its Chief Says, Scolding Europe
abstract: Austrian Chancellor Wolfgang Schussel, reacting to denunciations of his decision this month to form coalition government with Freedom Party of Jorg Haider, declares 'Nobody is going to bring down this government from the outside,' int; vows that Austria, a small, independent country, stands firm; declares that 'Isolation may last days, weeks or even one year, but we are not going to come crawling and asking for favors'; photo (M)

headline: Time Warner To Acquire Control Of EMI Music
abstract: Time Warner Inc plans to acquire control of music business of EMI Group and merge it with Warner Music, creating what could become world's largest record company; deal will shrink oligopoly of music companies that dominate world business from five to four; merged music company, to be known as Warner EMI Music, will sell about one of four records in United States and also have vast international presence; Time Warner and EMI Group will each own 50 percent of Warner EMI, but Time Warner will have slight majority on board of directors and ultimate control; Roger Ames, chief executive of Warner Music, will hold same post in new venture; Ken Berry, head of EMI, will be chief operating officer (M)

headline: Beginning Of Time: Jan. 4, 1980
abstract: Q&A on why computers think time began on Jan 4, 1980 (S)

headline: Digital Commerce; Technology has transformed the economy and made some people a lot of money, but is that all there is?
abstract: Denise Caruso writes her last Digital Commerce column, discussing cries of alarm over the focus on money that has prevailed in e-commerce over the last few years and new demands for greater emphasis on common sense and ethics; cartoon (M)

headline: Investors Seem to Want to Keep AOL-Time Warner Asunder
abstract: Investors send shares of America Online and Time Warner plunging for second consecutive day; combined market value of two companies is less than before merger deal was announced; AOL and Time Warner are feverishly working to reassure investors that their combination makes strategic sense, meeting with top shareholders, extolling virtues of deal to the press and promising more details about linkups between two companies soon; many shareholders are concerned that Time Warner's lacklackster growth will dampen America Online's growth; combined market value of two companies stands at about $280 billion, compared with total value of $300 billion on Jan 8, last trading day prior to announcement of merger; if America Online's stock falls too far, shareholders may consider acquisition of Time Warner unfair and rebel against it; graphs (M)

headline: PROCTER & GAMBLE MEETS IN PURSUIT OF MERGER TALKS
abstract: Procter & Gamble board considers stepping up merger talks with American Home Products and Warner-Lambert that would create one of world's largest consumer products and drug companies; historically conservative company would be betting it could apply is powerful marketing and distributing methods to help pharmaceutical companies market their products, which can carry higher profit margin; profile of three companies (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Deutsche Telekom Seeks Path to Three-Way Merger  Lawyers for Qwest Communications International and Deutsche Telekom of Germany spent the weekend exploring ways to unravel Qwest's pending agreement to acquire U S West in an effort to set up a three-way merger, executives close to the talks said.    But many people close to the discussions between Qwest and Deutsche Telekom put the chances of any deal being struck over the next few weeks at less than 50 percent.   [Page C2.]    Two New Books Coming on Giuliani  Two New York journalists who have had difficult relations with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani are writing books about him that are scheduled to be published this summer, just as the mayor's race for the United States Senate against Hillary Rodham Clinton would be heading into the stretch. Andrew Kirtzman, a political reporter for New York One, a local cable TV news station, who has covered Mr. Giuliani since 1993, is writing ''Rudy Giuliani: Emperor of the City,'' a look at the mayor's administration. Wayne Barrett, a longtime investigative reporter for The Village Voice, is writing ''Rudy: Gotham's Goliath,'' a biography of Mr. Giuliani.   [C14.]

headline: BRISTOL-MYERS SQUIBB SAYS IT WILL SELL ITS MATRIX UNIT
abstract: The Bristol-Myers Squibb Company said yesterday that it planned to sell its upscale Matrix Essentials hair care products unit and concentrate on its Clairol retail and professional beauty care business. Bristol-Myers, the New York-based maker of health and personal care products, had sales of $14.81 billion for the first nine months of 1999. Matrix Essentials, which makes upscale hair care products sold in salons, had more than $340 million in sales in 1999. Bristol-Myers Squibb stock rose 87.5 cents, to $59.50, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: Deal to Sell Film Rights to 'Harry Potter'
abstract: Bloomsbury Publishing PLC, British publisher of 'Harry Potter' series, agrees to work with Creative Artists Agency to sell film rights for its books to Hollywood studios (S)

headline: Bombay Journal; A World Pays Tribute to India's Master Drummer
abstract: Relatives, friends and admirers of Alla Rakha Qureshi, tabla master who died on February 3 at age of 80, gather at large family apartment in Bombay, India, to pay respects and to console family; photos (M)

headline: FRANCE TELCOM READY TO SHOP
abstract: France Telecom SA, Europe's second biggest telephone company, is seeking to acquire Orange PLC to strengthen its international business and better compete with Vodafone AirTouch (S)

headline: As the Pariah of Europe, Austria Seems Unbowed
abstract: European Union is proving unimpressive in efforts to bring Austria to its diplomatic knees following inclusion of Freedom Party of Jorg Haider, alleged Nazi-sympathizer, in coalition government; support for its public threat to isolate Austria has cooled after Austria promptly called its bluff; aggressive public posturing may have exposed Union to series of humiliating and very public compromises as Haider's prediction that censure effort would quickly crumble seems to have proved right; small and large countries alike are expressing skepticism (M)

headline: India Increases Its Military Budget by 28 Percent
abstract: India, with relations with Pakistan at their worst point in three decades, announces 28.2 percent increase in military spending; it is largest single-year increase in nation's history (M)

headline: Profit at Borders Increases 14%
abstract: Borders Group Inc says fourth-quarter earnings increased 14 percent; net income was $98.5 million, compared with $86.7 million a year ago; same-store sales at its superstores rose 6 percent, while sales at its Waldenbooks chain increased 2.7 percent (S)

headline: Still a Big Fish, Even in a Big Pond
abstract: Enormous economic and political clout possessed by Nippon Telegraph and Telephone, Japan, discussed; employees at NTT's local phone service subsidiaries make average of $93,458 (US), one of highest average salaries in Japan, and their average age is 43; NTT's political power is expansive, and regulators and politicians arguably have little incentive to force more competition on NTT, particularly with tough parliamentary election looming (M)

headline: BP AMOCO MAKES AN OFFER FOR VASTAR STAKE
abstract: BP Amoco PLC offers to buy out minority shareholders of Vastar Resources Inc for about $1.25 billion, or $71 a share; ARCO owns 82 percent of Vastar; offer values all of Vastar at about $6.9 billion (S)

headline: The New York Times: Technology - Circuits
abstract: January 6, 2000           Jane Sanders

headline: Bank One Announces New Chief
abstract: Bank One Corp names James Dimon, former Citigroup president, as its chairman and chief executive; Dimon says bank is not for sale and the board shares his desire to keep Bank One independent; Verne G Istock, who has been acting chief executive since December, will leave that post but remain as president; Istock replaced former chief executive John B McCoy, who was forced to resign; photo (M)

headline: A Consumer Products Giant Will Most Likely Stay With What It Knows
abstract: Investors and stock analysts say that with end of merger discussions with Warner-Lambert and American Home Products, Procter & Gamble Co will probably stick to consumer products rather than court another big pharmaceutical company anytime soon; brace for changes at Procter in light of the surprising aggressiveness shown in this adventure by Durk Jager, chief executive, who has said he will find ways to grow beyond consumer products (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Dizzying Day For Investors In Canadian Phone Giant
abstract: BCE Inc's announcement that it would distribute almost all of its 39.2 percent interest in Nortel Networks Corp to BCE's nearly 500,000 investors is tantamount to windfall; BCE, which holds intests in communications and media companies across Canada, contends that its current valuation does not reflect combined worth of its many units by at least $20 billion; BCE chief executive Jean C Monty says distribution of Nortel Networks shares will begin to unlock significant and sustainable value for BCE shareholders (Market Place column) (M)

headline: Clinton Lauds Technology As Key to India's Economy
abstract: Pres Clinton salutes India's information-technology industry, core of country's steady economic growth and supplier of brain power to Silicon Valley in California; says India is fast becoming one of world's software superpowers; says significant effects of Indian computer engineers on American industry, where estimated 30 percent of software engineers are of Indian origin, are beginning to pay off at home with many veterans returning to economy growing at 6 percent per year and with 10 percent growth within sight; says India is in special position to show how its brains and inventiveness in new technologies can improve country's social well-being; photo (M)

headline: CARLYLE GROUP IN TALKS WITH GERMAN AUTO PARTS MAKER
abstract: Carlyle Group, a United States buyout firm, said yesterday that it was in takeover talks with Beru A.G., a German maker of car ignition systems, even though Beru had rejected an initial proposal valuing the company at $310 million. Carlyle bought 26.3 percent of Beru from family shareholders for 30 euros a share last month, and said it would make a similar offer for the rest of the outstanding shares in February. Beru rejected the proposed offer on Dec. 20, saying that, based on its earnings, it is worth as much as 40 euros a share.

headline: CLINTON TO SEND CHINA TRADE BILL TO CONGRESS SOON
abstract: Pres Clinton will send Congress within days bill to permanently normalize trade relations with Beijing, amid signs that support for important trade accord is slipping away; accelerated timetable answers call from pro-trade members of Congress who have urged administration to push for early vote because of mounting evidence that measure will be even tougher sell as election-year politics intensify; opposition of organized labor, which has made defeating bill top priority, noted; even pro-trade Republican leaders report trouble rallying support among members; China's renewed threats to use force against Taiwan and administration's own report on China's deteriorating human rights situation have given fresh impetus to right-wing opponents of measure, as well as to those on left (M)

headline: Simondium Journal; No Wine Sold Before Its Time, Very Little Since
abstract: South Africa's wine producers expect bumper crop of grapes this year, but many could not be gloomier; about 21 million gallons of white wine--nearly 20 percent of last season's drinking wine harvest--is still sitting unsold and unwanted in cellars across region; glut has sent prices plunging, and many fear new crop will make matters worse; South African farmers who flooded post-apartheid market with not-so-tasty white wines are now focusing on quality; photo; map (M)

headline: 1999: Extraordinary Winners and More Losers
abstract: When they were hot, they were very, very hot. But when they were not, they were losers.    The story of the stock market in 1999 was of stocks that flew higher than at any time in the last decade. Enough of them soared that the major market indexes all closed the year at record highs. The best-performing stocks leaped not by hundreds, but by thousands of percentage points. Applying that standard, it was the year of the decade.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: AOL Deal for Time Warner Spurs Stocks to Big Gains  Stock prices posted sharp gains, spurred in part by America Online's $165 billion takeover of Time Warner. The deal touched off demand for entertainment and Internet shares as investors piled into companies that might be merger candidates.     The Nasdaq composite index recorded its biggest one-day point gain, rising 167.05 points, or 4.3 percent, to 4,049.67. Led by Hewlett-Packard, I.B.M. and Intel, the Dow rose 49.64 points, to 11,572.20. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 16.13 points, or 1.12 percent, to 1,457.60. [Page C17.]

headline: NYT Article
abstract: Microsoft Foils Hacker Assault on Web Site

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)

headline: Conservative Is Decisively Re-elected in Spain
abstract: Spain's conservative Prime Min Jose Maria Aznar wins decisive victory for second four-year term; his center-right party wins 44 percent of vote in parliament, or 183 seats, giving him majority control over government; his conservative fiscal policies have steered country during sustained period of economic growth; photo (M)

headline: Allende's Daughter Sees a Circle Closing
abstract: Isabel Allende, daughter of Salvador Allende, celebrates her 55th birthday and election of Ricardo Lagos, first Socialist to win power in Chile since her father died in military coup in 1973; interview; photo; she predicts subdued reaction if former dictator Augusto Pinochet returns from Britain (S)

headline: People
abstract: * Denise Silber was named managing director at Healthtech Digital Communications, New York, succeeding Meg Walsh, who became president for the consumer division at Medscape, New York. Ms. Silber had been general manager at Worldcare.com, Cambridge, Mass. Healthtech Digital is part of the Lowe McAdams Healthcare division of Lowe Healthcare Worldwide, a unit of the Lowe Group subsidiary of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

headline: Talks With Europeans End
abstract: Talks in Beijing break off without a deal between China and European Union over terms of China's entry into World Trade Orgn (S)

headline: G.M. Is Said To Choose A New Chief
abstract: General Motors Corp is expected to announce it will promote G Richard Wagoner Jr its president and chief operating officer, to chief executive as John F Smith Jr relinquishes that job but stays on as chairman; vice chairman Harry J Pearce will remain in that position; GM says it will distribute about half value of its Hughes Electronics stake in complex deal that would let GM's shareholders swap some stock tax-free for Hughes tracking stock; GM shares rise nearly 6 percent in response to deal (M)

headline: Key Thai Minister Resigns in Corruption Case
abstract: Thailand's powerful interior minister, Sanan Kachornprasart, resigns after anticorruption agency charges that he concealed his assets by fabricating million-dollar loan; forced resignation is most effective action yet by National Countercorruption Commission, formed in 1997 in wide-ranging attempt to reform politics; fact that independent body is able to topple one of most influential figures in Thai politics is sign that landscape has begun to shift in deeply corrupt political system; Sanan proclaims his innocence (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Supply Is Low As Gas and Oil Prices Increase
abstract: Price of crude oil jumps 4 percent, to more than $31 a barrel, and gasoline prices rise 6 percent; inventories of both are so low that moderate increase in output from major crude oil producers would provide only little price relief; if crude oil prices stay over $30 a barrel, Clinton administration might finally pump some out of Strategic Petroleum Reserve; Energy Sec Bill Richardson opposes such a move, saying at Congressional hearing that it would be unwise to tap petroleum reserve while major oil producers are still discussing production increases ahead of March 27 meeting of OPEC; warns that we cannot sustain imbalance between supply and demand without risking serious repercussions for world economy; crude oil for April delivery rises $1.34,to $31.77 a barrel on New York Mercantile Exchange, while April gasoline futures contract jumps 5.80 cents, to 99.38 cents a gallon; graph; chart (M)

headline: No Headline
abstract: Ruhiyyih Rabbani, who became pre-eminent member of Bahai faith after death of her husband, last official leader of faith, dies at 89; photo (M)

headline: Congo's War Overshadows Tribal Fight
abstract: Warfare between Hema and Lendu tribes in northeastern Congo spins out because the much larger fighting inside the country has so weakened the government that it cannot intervene effectively; there are also allegations that rogue soldiers from neighboring Uganda have not only sided with the Hema in conflict but have also killed Lendu for hire; Hema-Lendu conflict is fought mostly with machetes and barbed arrows; photos; map (M)

headline: Mixing the Personal And the Professional
abstract: Michael Wade letter on Jeffrey L Seglin's Jan 16 column on response by Atlanta Braves and Major League Baseball to offensive comments made by pitcher John Rocker and how business world would handle situation; says most business organizations would have suspended him as Major League Baseball did and warned him that future misconduct would result in termination (S)

headline: UNILEVER ENTERS HONDURAS
abstract: Unilever acquires Honduran consumer products company Grupo Cressida for $314 million (S)

headline: With the Right Address, Access to a New Portal
abstract: EdificeRex.com becomes first real-estate-based Web portal; developer Insignia Financial Group calls site first 'building-specific portal designed to create unique online community for New York's apartment dwellers'; Insignia is parent of Insignia Residential Group, which manages about 65,000 co-op and condo apartments in city, and Douglas Elliman, largest residential sales and rental brokerage firm in city; other management companies are also participating in project, which will initially be available to 85,000 to 90,000 apartment dwellers, most of them in Manhattan; services provided by the free portal noted; photo (M)

headline: WELLS FARGO IN $480 MILLION DEAL FOR FIRST COMMERCE
abstract: Wells Fargo & Co agrees to acquire First Commerce Bancshares Inc for $480 million in stock (S)

headline: As Ye Profit, So Shall Ye Pay
abstract: Percentage of taxpayers reporting capital gains and share of income attributable to capital gains have risen as number of Americans who own stock has reached record levels; dividends have not risen as share of income, despite increased stock ownership, as companies increasingly held down dividend growth; ways in which Federal tax law discourages dividends noted (M)o

headline: E*Trade Filings With S.E.C. Omitted Data
abstract: E*Trade Group on two occasions in recent months excluded information about its executives' pay packages from Securities and Exchange Commission filings; compensation experts and lawyers say omissions are apparent violation of SEC rules; E*Trade spokesman Patrick Di Chiro says company has strong record of disclosing information and has done nothing wrong; SEC declines comment (M)

headline: Honors
abstract: Two trade publications--Media in Asia, and Strategy in Canada--name Optimum Media Direction, part of Omnicom Group, agency of year (S)

headline: Evidence Indicates Uganda Cult Held an Eerie Prelude to Fire
abstract: Police in Uganda say at least some of 153 people who were killed at secluded compound of Movement for the Restoration of Ten Commandments of God died several weeks before hundreds of followers of doomsday cult died in raging inferno in their church week ago; say fire at compound gutted five small dwellings and scorched much of surrounding earth in eerie prelude to catastrophe that unfolded in Kanungu, where cult made its home; there is growing sense that what happened at compound and in church was carefully orchestrated act by cult's leader, Joseph Kibwetere, and some of his lieutenants, whose whereabouts are unknown (M)

headline: Education: Web's New Come-On
abstract: Group of Internet entrepreneurs is trying to offer e-commerce sites that include educational courses as new way to lure shoppers; have adopted philosphy that students should be treated as valued consumers and offered convenient courses at prices they can afford; some Web sites that hope to profit from student shoppers are: Learn2.com, which offers free turorials to consumers as well as tuition-based courses, Smart Planet (smartplanet.com) and Hungry Minds (www.hungryminds.com); in addition to courses, sites display advertising banners and links to shopping sites; photo; chart on Web sites (L)

headline: Ambition Turns to Crisis Control as Clinton Visits the Subcontinent
abstract: Fall of two Indian governments and nuclear tests of May 1998 have conspired against Pres Clinton's long-held desire to visit India; Clinton will embark on five-day, five-city journey to India, and five-hour stop in Pakistan, at time when tensions on subcontinent are high; confrontation between two countries over kashmir is seen as most likely dispute on earth to spark nuclear clash; Clinton hope his trip can somehow defuse situation in Kashmir, although he and his aides are pessimistic about chances for actual progress; Clinton aides fear that original intention of trip, to display India as economic and strategic power of region, will be undermined by increasingly strong-willed attitude of Indian government toward nuclear weapons, Pakistan and Kashmir (M)

headline: A Trump Card for Unusual Risks
abstract: Article profiles Robert D Hamman, founder of SCA Promotions, which covers risk for radio, TV contests, games and promotions that fan can beat the odds; photo (M)

headline: QRS TO BUY MAKER OF INTERNET PROCUREMENT SOFTWARE
abstract: QRS Corp acquires RockPort Trade Systems Inc for about $100 million in stock (S)

headline: Akamai to Open California Office
abstract: Akamai Technologies, which provides services that help Web sites perform more efficiently, to open new office in San Mateo, Calif; move is in part because some of its biggest clients are nearby and also to tap highly trained labor pool of Silicon Valley (S)

headline: Notes From 1994 Show Fed's Inner Workings
abstract: Transcripts released of Federal Reserve's policy meetings for 1994 show central bank began its last big round of interest rate increases, in 1994, without any clear sense of how strong economy was, how many rate increases would be needed or how stock and bond markets would react; transcripts show sway held over policy-setting Federal Open Market Committee by chairman Alan Greenspan, and reveal how concerned Greenspan was even then with possibility that stock prices were becoming out of hand (M)

headline: Group of Seven Is Gearing Up for an Expected Nonevent
abstract: Group of Seven meeting in Tokyo is expected to be nonevent; compared with last two years, global economy is in relatively serendipitous state; Europe is enjoying strong recovery, Asian economies have rebounded from crisis to post impressively high growth rates and US economy continues to defy naysayers; Japanese may pay high price for harmony; advance teams that have been working to hammer out language for communique that will be issued at end of meeting have failed to reach agreement on statement about foreign exchange; Japanese have been pushing for reiteration of statement issued after last G-7 meeting in September, when yen's rapid appreciation was perceived as threat to feeble economic recovery in Japan; yen fell to low of 124.32 against dollar last year, and stands now at 105.29 to dollar (M)

headline: Compressed Data; Hollywood's Content Is Grist for a Start-Up
abstract: Brian Bedol, former Time Warner executive, and others form Fusient Media Ventures, a venture incubator that will focus on Internet; Bedol says aim of company is to identify and develop material for coming era of broadband, which is supposed to enable all companies to broadcast virtually any kind of programming over Internet; Fusient is seen as providing more evidence that line between new media and traditional entertainment business is blurring; Bedol will serve as Fusient president and chief executive; his photo (M)

headline: Shopping With Priceline: Promise and Problems
abstract: Steven Permut letter on Michelle Slatalla's Jan 6 article questions how much grocery shoppers save and how much time they must spend on Priceline

headline: Interpublic Buys Suissa Miller Stake
abstract: Interpublic Group of Companies in New York acquires unspecified stake in Suissa Miller in Los Angeles (S)

headline: Top Regulator Tells Investors It's Time to Be More Prudent
abstract: Arthur Levitt, SEC chairman, warns investors to exercise prudence on some of the most popular stock market strategies, including buying stocks with borrowed money and rushing into hot issues; feels that too many investors are making decisions on impulse rather than thoughtful analysis (M)

headline: Ghani Khel Journal; Distress in the Opium Bazaar: 'Can't Make a Profit'
abstract: Description of scene in opium bazaar in Ghani Khel, Afghanistan; opium traders are complaining that sales are down and prices low; problem is ruling Taliban, who finally seem to be putting limits on drug trade; in Ghani Khel, where opium is sold as openly as onions, traders grumble about crackdown on their best customers; photo; map (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: VF CORP., Greensboro, N.C., an apparel maker, has bought the Eastpak business of the Sunbeam Corp., Boca Raton, Fla., which makes backpacks, book bags and other school accessories. Terms of the agreement were not disclosed.

headline: People
abstract: Dan Velez, account executive at Milton Samuels Advertising, is named senior account executive at Mano, New York, spin-off from Samuels specializing in Hispanic advertising; Andieh Aviles, art director at Samuels, is named creative director; Chris Hackett, account supervisor at Empower Mediamarketing, is named to head new office in Columbus, Ohio, as vice president (S)

headline: To Put G.E. Online Meant Putting a Dozen Industries Online
abstract: General Electric has put into effect an ambitious strategy for establishing itself on the Internet, part of its battle to become a leader of the new economy; the manufacturing and financial services giant, working in teams and sharing information across company's global span, has developed novel ways to do everything from speeding up the overhaul of jet engines to buying a staple gun (M)

headline: Net Draining Talent From Print Media
abstract: Newspapers and magazines are losing many seasoned journalists to Internet; journalists from trade publications and recent journalism school graduates are also being lured to dot-coms; even journalists familiar with unproven financial strategies of many sites are taking the leap; they are attracted by prospect of making great deal of money and excitement of being part of Internet revolution; Peter Gumbel, departing Los Angeles bureau chief of Dow Jones newspaper, is preparing to be editor of Business.com, enterprise whose journalists are mostly yet to be hired and whose editorial product is yet to be shaped; in some cases, people have joined sites after writing about them; some defectors do return; Danny O'Neil has returned to Seattle Times, saying people on Internet are not interested in long articles; photos (M)

headline: One Complaint or Many?
abstract: Letter from Michelle Mills Strout comments on Jan 20 article on complaints that Barbie PC has fewer educational titles than other Mattel sites (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: GENERAL ELECTRIC CO., Fairfield, Conn., the No. 1 maker of gas-fired turbines, said it won a $900 million order to supply 10 turbines for Turkish power plants being built by InterGen, Boston, a joint venture of Royal Dutch/Shell Group, and Enka Holding Yatirim, Istanbul, one of Turkey's biggest construction companies.

headline: Pace of '99 Retail Sales Fastest in 15 Years
abstract: Commerce Dept reports that retail sales in 1999 surged at the fastest pace since 1984 and producer prices outside of food and energy rose at less than half the rate in previous year; retail sales in December rose 1.2 percent, topping November's 1.1 percent gain; 8.9 percent rise for year is largest since 10 percent gain 15 years earlier; Labor Dept reports that Producer Price Index rose 0.3 percent last; notes that core rate, which excludes food and energy costs, rose just 0.1 percent; Labor Dept reports that first-time claims for state unemployment benefits were unchanged at seasonally adjusted 309,000 last week; charts show producer prices and retail sales (M)

headline: EXPANDING IN PRIVATE BANKING
abstract: Competing with American challengers for the $6 billion market in fees from rich private clients in Europe, Schroders P.L.C. said it would expand in private banking and hedge funds after the sale of its investment banking unit to Citigroup Inc. Schroders -- Britain's second-largest pensions manager -- said second-half earnings, through Dec. 31, rose to $211.9 million, twice the year-earlier figure.   Alan Cowell

headline: A New Sermon of Peace on the Mount
abstract: A Newo

headline: BG TO SPIN OFF PIPELINES
abstract: Shares of BG Group jump after company says it will spin off its pipeline division, Transco, as part of strategy to diversify into telecommunications; graph (S)

headline: E-Commerce Report; Web merchants are incorporating audio and video features on their sites to keep buyers' attention.
abstract: E-commerce merchants are devoting increasing amount of time and money to implementing audio and video features on their Web sites, hoping to provide so entertaining an experience that users will stay glued to their computer, ready to buy products; photo (M)

headline: HIGHER CANADIAN INFLATION
abstract: Statistics Canada says rising oil prices pushed Canada's annual inflation rate to five-year high of 2.7 percent in February, up from 2.3 percent in January; excluding energy, consumer price index rose by 1.6 percent last month (S)

headline: James Ottaway Sr., 88, Executive Who Started Newspaper Chain
abstract: James H. Ottaway Sr., the founder and former chief executive of Ottaway Newspapers Inc., a chain of newspapers based in Middletown, N.Y., that is now owned by Dow Jones & Company, died on Tuesday at a hospital in Goshen, N.Y. He was 88.    In 1976, he stepped down as chief executive of Ottaway and gave the job to one of his sons, James H. Ottaway Jr., who is now chairman of the company and a senior vice president of Dow Jones.

headline: $6 Billion Champion Paper Sale
abstract: UPM-Kymmene of F

headline: Russell L. Wenkstern, 87, Toy Chief and Dump Truck Co-Developer
abstract: Russell L Wenkstern, Tonka Toys chief executive who developed big yellow Mighty Dump truck, dies at age 87; photo of famous toy(M)

headline: Kosovo's Ex-Guerrillas Turn to Ice-Clearing Duty
abstract: Former fighters of Kosovo Liberation Army are turning their attention to more mundane tasks such as clearing ice from Pristina streets following heavy snowfalls; ethnic killings have not completely halted, but principal battle being waged now is against winter; map; photos (M)

headline: EUROPE-CHINA TRADE TALKS RESUME
abstract: European Union trade negotiator Pascal Lamy arrives in Beijing to resume talks on China's entry to World Trade Organization (S)

headline: Awaiting Clinton, Pakistani Takes Election Step
abstract: Gen Pervez Musharraf, military ruler of Pakistan, announces first step toward gradual return of democracy--local elections that are to begin in December; Pres Clinton is due to visit Pakistan on March 25 (S)

headline: Kozmo.com and Starbucks Enter Marketing Deal
abstract: February 14, 2000

headline: RECOVERY FOR AIR CANADA
abstract: Air Canada reports strong recovery in its profit for fourth quarter and for all of 1999 and says it has begun to reorganize Canadian Airlines Corp, which it acquired last month; fourth-quarter profit for Air Canada was 13 million Canadian dollars, or $9 million, reversing loss of 20 million Canadian dollars a year earlier; profit for year was 213 million Canadian dollars, in contrast to 1998 loss of 16 million Canadian dollars (S)

headline: In Congress, Scorn for U.S. Oil Diplomacy
abstract: US Energy Sec Bill Richardson faces sharp questions over high price of oil products as legislators heap scorn on his cautious forecast that oil-exporting countries will increase production later this month and reverse steep yearlong climb in fuel costs; Richardson rejects calls from lawmakers to draw down emergency government oil reserves, move that advocates say would lower prices, testimony before House International Relations Committee; Richardson urges patience while talks continue with OPEC and other important producers like Mexico; photo (M)

headline: ADIDAS TO STREAMLINE
abstract: Adidas-Salomon AG says it will narrow its product range and streamline management to raise per-share earnings by 15 percent a year, starting in 2001; graph (S)

headline: Interpublic to Take 4th-Quarter Charge
abstract: Interpublic Group of Companies will take an after-tax restructuring charge of $110 million to $115 million associated with the recent merger of two of its biggest agencies, Lowe & Partners Worldwide, part of the Lowe Group, and Ammirati Puris Lintas (S)

headline: Chechnya's Capital Becomes A Deadly Zone for Russians
abstract: Grozny, capital of Chechnya, becomes a deadly killing zone as Russian troops run into fierce resistance from heavily armed, experienced and motivated rebels; make inroads, but still do not control city center; official casuality figures understate Russian losses, which are estimated at 10 soldiers a day; popularity of Vladimir V Putin, acting president, is based in large part reports of low casualties; photos; map (M)

headline: Chechen Refugee Camps: From Crude to Abysmal
abstract: Abysmal conditions in Chechen refugee camps in neighboring Ingushetia described; state of barely 300,000 residents has already absorbed 210,000 war victims and tide is again rising by 300 per day with Russian government's seizure and purging of Chechen capital of Grozny; conditions in camp at abandoned pig farm near Karabaluk described; maps; photos (M)

headline: Two Are Nominated for Board of Times Company
abstract: Board of New York Times Co nomin

headline: Rally Ends Abruptly in Asia As Stock Markets Plummet
abstract: Stock markets across much of Asia plummeted today, abruptly ending a post-millennium rally, as investors here reacted with alarm to Wall Street's stumble on Tuesday.    Fears that the United States plans to raise interest rates prompted investors to dump shares in blue-chip companies from Seoul to Singapore. The selloff was most severe in Hong Kong, where the benchmark Hang Seng index plunged 7.2 percent, or 1,226 points, its second-largest point loss in history.

headline: Textron in Deal With Safeguard
abstract: Safeguard Scientifics Inc agrees to sell $100 million in stock to Textron Inc; Safeguard and Textron will work together to sell products over Internet as part of agreement (S)

headline: Nine West In Settlement On Shoe Prices
abstract: Nine West Group, maker of women's shoes, agrees to pay $34 million to settle civil charges brought by federal and state investigators who contended company illegally fixed shoe prices since 1988; Government officials say they will divide settlement among 50 states and other US territories to be used for women's health, education and safety programs; agreement must still be approved by Federal Trade Commission as well as by federal court for Southern District of New York; Nine West, which was purchased by Jones Apparel Group last year, also agrees to end show pricing practices that federal and state governments contended were illegal; company agrees to settle case without admitting any wrongdoing (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: HEATING OIL RISES***Heating oil prices rise more than 3 percent as cold weather persists in Northeast and supplies dwindle; in New York, heating oil for delivery in March rises 2.37 cents a gallon, to 77.80 cents; graph; chart (S)

headline: SWISS REINSURANCE SAYS IT TRIED TO ACQUIRE PARTNERRE
abstract: Swiss Reinsurance Co discloses that it offered in November 1999 to acquire Bermuda insurer PartnerRe Ltd a month before it agreed to pay $725 million to buy Underwriters Re Group Inc; Swiss Re would have had to spend about $1.2 billion for PartnerRe; Swiss Re, which already has 26 percent stake in PartnerRe, says two sides could not agree on price; Swiss Re tells PartnerRe it disclosed talks to Securities and Exchange Commission because it might raise its PartnerRe holdings to 30 percent (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: WAL-MART STORES INC., Bentonville, Ark., the nation's biggest retailer, is closing meat-cutting operations at 180 stores in six states.    PHILIP MORRIS, New York, disclosed in a regulatory filing that its Kraft Foods unit, Northfield, Ill., paid about $100 million for Boca Burger Inc., Chicago, a maker of soy burgers and other meat alternatives. The price was not previously disclosed.

headline: EToys Loss Widens, Even as Sales Climb
abstract: EToys Inc says its fiscal third-quarter loss widened because of higher costs of doing business on its Web site; loss grew to $75.5 million in period ended Dec 31, from $9.8 million a year earlier; sales quadrupled to $106.8 million from $22.9 million (S)

headline: Greenlight Offer for BNC
abstract: BNC Mortgage Inc says hedge fund Greenlight Capital Inc has offered to buy company for $56.1 million in cash, just two weeks after BNC agreed to be acquired by management-led group of investors (S)

headline: In Malaysia, Question of Day:Why Did Mahathir Skip Davos?
abstract: KUALA LUMPUR—  Why did Malaysia's prime minister, Mahathir bin Mohamad, cancel his trip to Davos?

headline: Old-Line Women's Magazines Turn to Sex to Spice Up Their Sales
abstract: Once sacrosanct sisterhood of women's magazines are feeling same pressures that prompted many American consumer magazines to heat up frank sexual discussion to spur sales in magazine market; seven magazines (Redbook, Ladies' Home Journal, Good Housekeeping, McCall's, Family Circle, Woman's Day and Better Homes and Gardens) are known as 'women's service' magazines and in past traditionally aimed at stay-at-home mothers; now Redbook and Ladies' Home Journal regularly include more explicit sexual content, reflecting fact that sex sells; magazines are retooling their images in face of declining circulation; photo (M)

headline: CASTLE & COOKE'S CHIEF OFFERS TO BUY REST OF COMPANY
abstract: Castle & Cooke Inc says its chief executive David H Murdock has offered to pay $17 a share, or $212.2 million, for roughly 73 percent of company that he and his associates do not already own (S)

headline: MOULINEX CUTBACKS
abstract: A big European appliance maker, Moulinex of France, will shed 9 of its 13 European factories and eliminate 2,100 jobs over two years to cut costs and reduce debt. The company, best known for its Moulinex and Krupps appliances, has been struggling with increased losses, and earlier this year it announced an ambitious plan to raise as much as $133 million in fresh capital and reduce costs by subcontracting outside Europe the production of vacuum cleaners, microwave ovens and components like electric motors.   John Tagliabue

headline: U.S. Warns Pakistan It May Be Branded a Sponsor of Terrorism
abstract: Clinton adm issues public warning to Pakistan that it could be branded a state sponsor of terrorism--ending any hope for a resumption of large-scale American aid--if Pakistani Army continues to support terrorists blamed for hijacking of Indian Airlines jet last month (S)

headline: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: AMERICAS; OVERSEAS CALLS STRENGTHEN TELMEX
abstract: International long-distance earnings at Telefonos de Mexico (Telmex) almost tripled, to $271 million, in fourth-quarter 1999, compared with year-earlier period; company cites factors (S)

headline: VIRATA AGREES TO ACQUIRE VOICE SOFTWARE DEVELOPER
abstract: Virata Corp agrees to acquire D2 Technologies Inc, a developer of voice software, for $90 million in stock; acquisition adds voice capabilities to Virata's digital subscriber line software (S)

headline: Argentina's Former President Still at Center Stage
abstract: As president, Carlos Saul Menem dominated Argentine news coverage for more than a decade by selling off much of the government and pegging the peso to the dollar -- not to mention racing sports cars, throwing his wife out of the presidential palace and dating women half his age.     Now out of power for barely three weeks, Mr. Menem has managed to remain at the center of attention. He has sometimes even managed to overshadow the always demure President Fernando de la Rua, who campaigned promising a new style of government.

headline: Web Petroleum Marketplace Unveiled
abstract: Web Petroleum Marketplace Unveiled

headline: Patents; Measuring pain on a universal scale, and comparing it with the pain of fellow sufferers.
abstract: Dr A Vania Apkarian and Dr Nikolaus Szeverenyi are granted patent for system of measuring human pain, to allow for better treatment of pain; Motorola wins patent for 'silent answer' key on incoming cellular telephone calls (M)

headline: Political Motive Suspected in Killing of Serbian Warlord
abstract: Zeljko Raznatovic, Serbian paramilitary leader assassinated on Jan 15, reportedly made overtures to Serbian political opposition in last few months because he was worried about his security; immediate assumption in Belgrade is that government of Pres Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia ordered and carried out killing because Raznatovic knew too much about the activities of Milosevic and his associates during Bosnian and Croatian wars; photo (M)

headline: Former iVillage Officials Sue the Company
abstract: Computer Security Methods Weighed

headline: Commission Will Work to Protect Children After Legislation Fails
abstract: March 7, 2000

headline: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: AMERICAS; NEW OFFER FOR STEEL COMPANY
abstract: Altos Hornos de Mexico (Ahmsa) gets takeover bid from Aceralia Corporacion Siderurgica of Spain that is significantly higher than Grupo Imsa's bid (S)

headline: Getting Colors Right With New Technology
abstract: E-Color, computer graphics company, has introduced technology designed to assure Internet shoppers that goods are displayed in their true colors; technology works by recording data about how monitor displays color, taking into account factors like computer's video card configurations, monitor's control settings and environmental lighting (M)

headline: Brian M. Barish And John D. Freeman AHA Diversified Equity Fund
abstract: Carole Gould (Investing With) article discusses $138.8 million AHA Diversified Equity fund, run jointly by Brian M Barish, senior vice president of Cambiar Investors, money management firm in Englewood, Colo, and John D Freeman, president of Investment Research Co, money manager in Rancho Sante Fe, Calif; says each man oversees one-half of portfolio; says fund has gained 23.4 percent a year, on average, for three years through March 17; chart on fund; photos of two fund managers (M)

headline: Harmony and Bottom Line: Hmm . . .
abstract: Article on use of alternative therapy called feng shui, ancient Chinese principles of creating harmonious environment, in the workplace; chart; photo (M)

headline: Yahoo Says It Is Discussing Internet Privacy With the F.T.C.
abstract: Yahoo Inc notifies Securities and Exchange Commission that it is voluntarily cooperating with inquiry by Federal Trade Commission into how Internet sites gather personal information; David Medine, associate director for financial practices for FTC, declines to acknowledge that inquiry is under way (M)

headline: A Child´s Guide to the World of Knowledge
abstract: A Child's Guide to the World of Knowledge

headline: Stretching It a Bit
abstract: Letter by Theresa A Healy responds to Feb 17 article on senior citizens and computer literacy; says learning site for seniors is available at www.senior.net.org

headline: INVIVO RAISES TAKEOVER OFFER FOR PROTOCOL SYSTEMS
abstract: Invivo Corp increases its bid to acquire Protocol Systems Inc, offering $100.6 million in cash and stock for company; in November, Invivo offered to buy Protocol for $84 million in cash and stock (S)

headline: BUDGET ENTERS MARKETING ALLIANCE WITH HOMESTORE.COM
abstract: Budget Group says it will get $64.8 million in Homestore.com Inc stock in marketing alliance that links Budget with largest Internet list of homes for sale; under 10-year agreement, Budget will get almost 1.1 million shares of Homestore.com; Homestore.com's logo will go on Budget's fleet of 45,000 Ryder and Budget rental trucks (S)

headline: FOAMEX DISCUSSES ACQUISITION WITH INVESTMENT GROUP
abstract: Foamex International Inc is in talks to be acquired by group that includes its chief executive, John Johnson Jr; company's market value is about $230 million; Foamex says potential all-cash sale is tied to last year's bankruptcy of its largest shareholder, Trace International Holdings (S)

headline: Judge Overrules F.C.C. on Wireless Licenses
abstract: US bankruptcy judge Adlai S Hardin nullifies decision by Federal Communications Commission that would have 90 wireless telephone licenses claimed by NextWave Telecom Inc; FCC said in early January that licenses were automatically canceled when NextWave missed interest payment on its debt to agency (S)

headline: Closing the Digital Gap
abstract: Letter by Ronda Hauben on Jan 27 article on making Internet available to all; says she is disappointed that there was not broader discussion of social issues involved

headline: ENHANCE FINANCIAL TO CONSIDER SALE AND OTHER MOVES
abstract: Enhance Financial Services Group hires investment banker Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Co for advice on improving shareholder value, including possible sale of company (S)

headline: Yet Another Mass Grave Is Uncovered in Uganda
abstract: Carnage in Uganda deepens as investigators unearth 81 bodies at home of member of doomsday cult, Movement for Restoration of Ten Commandments of God, village of Rushojwa; 44 of the dead are children; it is fourth day in row that police pull rotting corpses from ground; photo; map (M)

headline: E-Vectra Desktop PC Is Smaller and Simpler
abstract: Hewlett-Packard's introduces new series of smaller and simpler desktop PC's, called e-Vectra; new computer is aimed at business market but is also designed to appeal to home users; price of low-end model starts at about $549; photo (S)

headline: INTER-KOREAN JOINT VENTURE
abstract: South Korean government has authorized project by Samsung Electronics to begin joint venture with North Korea to set up software company in Beijing in April to develop word processors and other software (S)

headline: Ugandans Count Cult's Bodies, and Ask Why
abstract: Ugandan police bury remains of 330 followers of doomsday cult, including those of 78 children, who died in apparent mass suicide in apocalyptic inferno in tin-roofed chapel in village of Kanungu; say death toll could exceed 500 since untold numbers were burned to ashes; sect identified as Movement for Restoration of the Ten Commandments of God; its leaders are believed to have perished in flames; proliferation of number of mystical religions in Uganda in recent decades as social and political problems have worsened noted; photos; map (M)

headline: TECHNOLOGY: Out on a Limb as Technologies Converge; True Believers Push Satellite Telephones
abstract: The satellite telephone business has two strikes against it, but that has not stopped some entrepreneurs and investors from betting that the next multibillion-dollar swing for the fences will indeed produce a home run.    Now at bat: Globalstar Telecommunications, which is controlled by Loral Space and Communications. Globalstar is just starting to introduce its service -- a $3.3 billion system of 48 satellites designed to provide telephone calls nearly anywhere in the world.

headline: WEYERHAEUSER WILL CLOSE FOUR PACKAGING PLANTS
abstract: Weyerhaeuser Co plans to close four packaging plants as it consolidates operations after its January acquisition of MacMillan Bloedel Ltd; plants have 400 employees (S)

headline: Financial Times Wades Into Germany
abstract: Boom in German high-technology stocks and revolution in attitudes toward investing transforms Germany into battleground for new business publications; Pearson Group, publisher of Financial Times of London, will start German version of business daily; plans by other publications to enter German market discussed; photo (M)

headline: Seeing Psychics Clearly
abstract: Letter by Dr Neala S Schwartzberg responds to Feb 6 article on telephone psychics serving as mental health professionals; says costs in using psychics make visit to professional psychologist better choice

headline: In Mexico's Election, the Race Is Real
abstract: For months, Mexico's presidential race seemed headed inexorably toward a 14th consecutive victory by the governing party. Suddenly, it has turned into a real race because Vicente Fox Quesada has made advances that give him a better chance at the presidency than any other opposition figure since the Mexican revolution.    Mr. Fox, a former Coca-Cola executive who usually wears cowboy boots, has considerably narrowed the once-overwhelming lead in public opinion held since last fall by Francisco Labastida Ochoa, the nominee of the president's party, the Institutional Revolutionary Party, or PRI, recent polls indicate.

headline: The Idea That Almost Got Away
abstract: Fishing net developed by Kent Thomas and his Ocean Friendly Co promises to prevent indiscriminate killing of juvenile fish and protected species; allows unwanted fish to be sorted out and returned to sea; photo (M)

headline: Georgia City Putting Entire Community Online
abstract: La Grange, Ga, will become the largest entirely wired town so far in US by the fall; every household, school, government office and retail store in town of 27,000 will be connected to one giant high-speed network using town's existing fiber-optic network with coaxial cable from Charter Communications, the local cable provider; any home without a computer will receive an access device and keyboard to attach to the television set; municipal government will pay for system; photos; map (M)

headline: Foreign Stock Markets Post Gains and the Dollar Ends Mixed
abstract: Most major foreign stock markets end higher while US markets are closed in observance of Martin Luther King's birthday; dollar edges up against euro, but falls against Japanese yen in overseas trading (M)

headline: Sites and Events This Week
abstract: Sites and Events This Week

headline: Pro-Western Opposition Defeats Croatia's Ruling Nationalists
abstract: Croatia's center-left opposition won a sweeping victory in parliamentary elections on Monday, official results indicated today. The elections delivered a rebuke to the governing party and opens up the prospect of much warmer ties with the West.    The opposition victory dethroned the Croatian Democratic Union, the umbrella nationalist party founded by Franjo Tudjman, the president who died last month. The party has ruled Croatia since Mr. Tudjman took the country to independence in 1991 out of the wreckage of Tito's Yugoslavia.

headline: Sun-Netscape Alliance Targets Wireless Internet
abstract: Sun-Netscape Alliance Targets Wireless Internet

headline: NatWest Board Gives In to Buyout by Royal Bank
abstract: Royal Bank of Scotland acquires National Westminster Bank for $36.3 billion after bruising four-month battle for control; merger terms noted (M)

headline: Snyder Executive Opens an Agency
abstract: Lance Jensen, a top creative executive on the Volkswagen of America account at Arnold Communications in Boston, is leaving to open his own agency.    Mr. Jensen, 36, has been at Arnold, part of Snyder Communications, for almost 10 years, most recently as executive vice president and creative director, heading up the VW account with Alan Pafenbach. Mr. Jensen, a copywriter, has worked on the ''Drivers Wanted'' campaign for VW models like the New Beetle and the Jetta.

headline: Ella Goldberg Wolfe, 103, Communist Turned Reaganite, Dies
abstract: Ella Goldberg Wolfe, member of Communist Party of the US, who later became one of Moscow's severest critics, dies at age of 103; photo (M)

headline: North and South Koreans Meet on a Mountain Path
