abstract: Approximately 150,000 South Korean tourists have visited scenic mountain region north of demilitarized zone separating North and South Korea since North opened parts of Mount Kumgang to commercial tours in 1998; tours have become hallmark of South Korean Pres Kim Dae Jung's so-called sunshine policy of constructively engaging North in effort to hasten reconciliation between both nations; tours have been breakthrough in long-frozen relations, even while underscoring difficulties in reuniting both countries; maps; photos (M)

headline: AOL Chief Relaxes a Dress Code But Not His Vision of the Internet
abstract: Profile of America Online chairman and chief executive, Stephen M Case, who will head new AOL Time Warner; he has survived Internet's accelerated evolution with series of transformations; Time Warner head Gerald M Levin comments on Case's approach (M)

headline: DAIMLERCHRYSLER TO EQUIP VEHICLES WITH SATELLITE RADIO
abstract: DaimlerChrysler AG will invest $100 million in Sirius Satellite Radio Inc and install its receivers in its cars and trucks, giving customers access to uninterrupted radio across US; Sirius's digital satellite-radio system will provide coast-to-coast coverage with up to 50 channels of commercial-free music and another 50 channels of news, sports and entertainment for $9.95 monthly fee (S)

headline: Prague Ends Dispute Over Medieval Dead
abstract: Czech government says it will pay to preserve medieval Jewish cemetery that was discovered during construction project in downtown Prague three years ago (S)

headline: Move over, dot-coms. There are other first-time advertisers gearing up for the Super Bowl.
abstract: First-time advertisers other than Internet companies, including Tropicana orange juice, are gearing up for Super Bowl, to be broadcast by ABC on Jan 30; more than dozen Internet companies are scheduled to make their Super Bowl advertising debuts during game, compared with three in 1999 and one apiece in 1998 and 1997 (M)

headline: The Grand Exit
abstract: Readers are invited to offer anecdotes about way in which they or others quit jobs

headline: Go Network Selects Agency for Portal
abstract: Go.com, company formed by merger of Infoseek and online operations of Walt Disney Co, names Cliff Freeman & Partners as first ad agency of record for its Go Network portal Web site; billings estimated at more than $30 million (S)

headline: Spotlight on Arafat, Capital's Lone Mideast Player
abstract: Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat, with Syrian-Israeli talks in abeyance, has full attention of Pres Clinton and State Sec Madeleine K Albright, capped by lunch with Albright at her Georgetown house (S)

headline: Dire Warnings Over China in a Taiwan Race
abstract: Political opponents say election of Chen Shui-bian as president of Taiwan would cause dangerous tensions, perhaps war, with China; speculation about China's view of Chen intensify after China warns in report that any step toward formal independence, or even indefinite delay in negotiations toward reunification, could lead to military attack; Chen's party, from its founding in 1980's, has called for Taiwan's formal independence; party has moderated that stance recently, and Chen expresses exasperation at warnings about what his election might bring; insists he is peacemaker, not troublemaker; photo (M)

headline: The Fantasy and the Fact Of New Stock Offerings
abstract: Mark Hulbert (Strategies) article discusses initial public offerings (IPO's); says rarely have investor expectations diverged as much from reality as they do now with regard to IPO's; says reality of such offerings is that even if you are lucky enough to be among few allowed to participate in the offering at its opening, odds are slim of being able to double or triple your money on offering day, and even if you can, chances are less favorable that stock will continue to perform well (M)

headline: Belgian Stance on Austria Reflects Worry Over 'Haiderization' at Home
abstract: BRUSSELS—  Under a newly activist foreign ministry, Belgium has taken the lead in the European ostracism of Austria and other "moral" issues, seeking to erase its poor international reputation. But many political analysts here say the rhetoric about the rise of the far right in Austria has much to do with fears that an identical phenomenon may be on the rise here as well.

headline: Top Executives Quit Sotheby's As Art World Inquiry Widens
abstract: Sotheby's, leading worldwide auction house, announces resignations of A Alfred Taubman, its major shareholder, as chairman and Diana D Brooks, most powerful woman in art world, as president and chief executive as Sotheby's deals with widening federal antitrust investigation; Michael I Sovern will replace Taubman, and William F Ruprecht will take over Brooks's jobs; resignations rock art world already shaken by criminal inquiry and leaves open questions about future of company, including possible sale of Taubman's interests, and high-end auction business in general; art world and Wall Street have been waiting for Sotheby to respond to accusations that it conspired with its archrival, Christie's, to fix commissions houses charge buyers and sellers (M)

headline: Egypt's Women Win Equal Rights to Divorce
abstract: Egypt puts in place one of Muslim world's most far-reaching overhauls of family law, enabling woman to divorce her husband, with or without his consent; woman will also be able to garnishee her husband's wages if he refuses to provide for her; Pres Hosni Mubarak proposed changes late last year; they drew fierce opposition, but alliance of moderate Muslim clerics, women's advocates, civil court judges and divorce lawyers endorsed reforms; photo (M)

headline: Land Rover Puts Account in Review
abstract: Land Rover North America in Lanham, Md., part of BMW A.G., said yesterday that it had placed the creative part of its account in review. Billings were estimated at $30 million.    Diane Rothschild, president at Grace & Rothschild in New York, which has handled that assignment for 13 years, said her agency would not participate in the review because the account had become less profitable. The agency does not anticipate layoffs as a result of resigning the account, Ms. Rothschild said, which takes effect on Feb. 29.

headline: World Briefing
abstract: EUROPE    NETHERLANDS: NEW CHIEF FOR WORLD COURT  The International Court of Justice in The Hague elected a new president and vice president for three-year terms. The head of the panel, known as the World Court, will be Judge Gilbert Guillaume of France. The new vice president is Judge Shi Jiuyong of China. The court, with 15 members, is part of the United Nations system and hears cases between countries.   Barbara Crossette (NYT)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: TYCO INTERNATIONAL LTD.,  Bermuda, the world's largest maker of electronic connectors, said it would consider selling shares to the public in its businesses that make wireless-network semiconductors and fiber optics.    CORNING INC.,  New York, the world's No. 1 maker of glass fibers used in telecommunications networks, plans to make at least two or three acquisitions this year to broaden its line of fiber optic components.

headline: Creative Executives Leave Two Agencies
abstract: Euro RSCG Tatham chairman-chief executive Robert H Welke resigns; he will be replaced on interim basis by Helayne Spivak; Sam Gulisano, executive vice president and co-executive creative director with Rich Russo at FCB Worldwide, is resigning to start his own shop; Russo will serve as sole executive creative director (S)

headline: Bertelsmann's Chairman to Leave Board of AOL
abstract: Bertelsmann AG chairman Thomas Middelhoff says he will step down from board of America Online as result of proposed takeover of Time Warner; his decision is suggestion of jolt that deal has inflicted on Bertelsmann, which has joint venture with America Online in Europe and Australia; photo (M)

headline: Plan for Free Access in Britain
abstract: March 7, 2000

headline: WELLSPRING BUYS 97% OF PARAGON FOR $115 MILLION
abstract: Paragon Trade Brands Inc exits Chapter 11 bankruptcy; investors led by Wellspring Capital Management buy 97 percent of company's new common stock for about $115 million in cash; rest of new stock will go to former shareholders (S)

headline: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: AMERICAS; LITTLE HOPE FOR MEXICAN AIRLINE
abstract: Worï

headline: Accounts
abstract: Recent account changes noted (S)

headline: Network Solutions Jumps After Investigation Ends
abstract: February 1, 2000

headline: Trips to Renew Jewish Ties Set Off Debate Over Costs
abstract: Over 400 American Jewish college students arrive in Israel, first planeload in program to stem erosion of Jewish communities abroad by bringing tens of thousands of young Jews on free educational visits; program seeks to strengthen ties of Jewishly uninvolved to Israel and Judaism; $210 million project, first of its kind funded by Israeli government and Jewish philanthropists and communities abroad, stirs heated debate about allocation of Jewish resources; map (M)

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: AFRICA    NIGERIA: VIOLENCE OVER MUSLIM LAW -- At least 10 people were killed as mosques and churches were set on fire in clashes between Christians and Muslims in the northern city of Kaduna after thousands of Christians marched to protest plans to carry out Islamic law in Kaduna state. Another state, Zamfara, formally adopted Shariah last month, and other northern states have announced plans to do the same.   Norimitsu Onishi (NYT)    BURUNDI: TALKS IN TANZANIA -- Nelson Mandela opened a new round of peace talks on Burundi, combining diplomacy and showmanship in an effort to end six years of ethnic civil war. To increase international pressure on the combatants, Presidents Clinton and Jacques Chirac of France were scheduled to address the talks via closed circuit television. But any immediate breakthrough seemed remote because the two main armed groups did not attend.   Ian Fisher (NYT)

headline: When Button-Down Meets Buttonless
abstract: Article on stark communications gap that more and more workplaces are experiencing as bricks-and-mortar behemoths team up with Web companies; focuses on communications gaps between employees of 'button-down' Pricewaterhouse Coopers and methodfive Inc, Web design firm, following PricewaterhouseCooper's 12 percent acquisition of methodfive; photo (M)

headline: INFOSYS PROFIT SOARS
abstract: India's Infosys Technologies Ltd says its third-quarter profit rose 96 percent; profit rose to 737.9 million rupees ($16.9 million) before extraordinary gain of 23.5 million rupees in three months ended Dec 31, from 377.4 million rupees in year-earlier period (S)

headline: EFFICIENT NETWORKS PLANS TO BUY NETSCREEN
abstract: Efficient Networks acquires NetScreen Technologies for $905 million in stock (S)

headline: Extra Layer of Protection For All of Those Discs
abstract: Optidisc offers new product, consisting of thin disk of clear polycarbonate treated with chemical that binds it to bottom of compact disk, to protect all sorts of CDs; photo (M)

headline: Remade Militant Group Learns Press Kits and Web Sites Have Their Uses
abstract: Hezbollah, Lebanon-based Party of God, has new populist image, with representatives forming largest single-party group in Lebanese Parliament; it also has impressive network of schools, hospitals and welfare centers that cater to tens of thousands of families, and information network that may be unrivaled anywhere in world, at least by organization that many Western nations still list as terrorist group (M)

headline: Reminder From Greenspan: Expect Interest Rates to Rise
abstract: Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan says Fed intends to raise interest rates until it is sure it has squeezed any inflationary imbalances out of economy, speech to conference on 'new economy' at Boston College; repeats his message that wealth being created in stock market is creating more demand than economy can satisfy; says nation cannot afford any further widening in its trade deficit; says he remains concerned as ever that economy is running out of workers, leaving it vulnerable to upward spiral in both wages and prices; photo (M)

headline: CABLE COMPANIES GET CLOSER
abstract: Rogers Communications Inc and Shaw Communications Inc, Canada's largest cable companies, agree to swap some assets and merge Internet operations, escalating their war with telephone utilities for supremacy in electronic commerce; two will combine Internet divisions, providing single national portal (S)

headline: NATO-LED  TROOPS CAUGHT IN BATTLE OVER KOSOVO TOWN
abstract: French troops kill Albanian gunman as fierce fighting continues in streets of Mitrovica, Kosovo, in most sustained clashes involving NATO peacekeepers since arrival in June 1999; more than dozen people are wounded, including two French soldiers, and 17 are arrested; French, Italian and British troops come under fire from snipers; former commander of Kosovo Liberation Army says Serbs attempted to attack Albanian area and that fighters of outlawed guerrilla force fought back to defend it; both Serbs and Albanians regard Mitrovica as last battlefield in war for Kosovo; thousands of Albanians, still unable to return to homes, consider Mitrovica last place still to be liberated from Serbian persecution; Serb community leader blames Albanians; both sides accuse other of wanting to control area beacuse of presence of iron ore and precious-metals mines; photos; maps (M) (M)

headline: ECHOSTAR REPORTS ITS LOSSES GREW TO $219.9 MILLION
abstract: EchoStar Communications Corp says its losses widened to $219.9 million in fourth quarter from $113.3 million in previous year (S)

headline: Off to the Web to Join the Legion
abstract: French Embassy in Wshington, DC, posts Web site dedicated to history of French Foreign Legion (www.info-france-usa.org/america/embassy/legion/legion.htm); since 1831, 902 officers, 3,176 non-commissioned officers and more than 30,000 legionnaires have died for France; some other Web sites on legion noted; photo (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: GALILEO INTERNATIONAL INC., Rosemont, Ill., a travel information company, said it would buy Travel Automation Services Ltd., which operates Galileo's distribution arm in England, from British Airways P.L.C. for an undisclosed amount.    INTERNATIONAL SPECIALTY PRODUCTS INC., Wayne, N.J., a specialty chemicals maker, said it planned to seek to elect a majority of the board of Dexter Corp., Windsor Locks, Conn., which makes materials ranging from tea-bag paper to computer chip coatings, in its effort to take over the company.

headline: Saving Lives in Fires, and Preventing Them
abstract: Firefighting sites on World Wide Web cover topics from home-escape drills to smoke detectors; sampling of issues discussed on New York City Fire Dept's site, and on National Fire Protection Assn's site; photo (M)

headline: What's in an I.D.
abstract: Letter by Robert Yesselman responds to March 23 letter on March 16 article about selling hi-fi equipment to women; questions why letter writer found it necessary to identify himself as heterosexual

headline: THIRD WAVE TECHNOLOGIES BEING BOUGHT BY PE
abstract: PE Biosystems Group of PE Corp agrees to acquire Third Wave Technologies, a developer of DNA and RNA analysis technologies, for about $336 million in stock; plans to combine Third Wave's nucleic acid detection technology with its technology for genetic analysis (S)

headline: Glaxo and SmithKline Try Again After Costly Failure : Drug Giants Talk Merger
abstract: LONDON—  Glaxo Wellcome PLC and SmithKline Beecham PLC, whose botched merger attempt two years ago stood out as one of the costliest failures of the 1990s merger boom, said Friday that they had revived talks toward a combination that would create the world's largest pharmaceutical company.

headline: Web Service's News Reports To Be Carried By The A.P.
abstract: Associated Press will begin distributing work of Cnet News.com, Internet site, as part of AP's overall offering of financial news; deal with Cnet Inc is AP's first with nontraditional news organization and provides another validation of Internet journalism; Associated Press's deal with Cnet represents major news organization's desire to compete more aggressively in new media world; AP's chief rival, Reuters news service, earned 55 percent of its revenue in 1998 from online sites; Robert Crooke, Reuters spokesman, says there are 250 online sites that buy Reuters service, 20 percent of them owned by traditional newspaper and broadcast companies (M)

headline: A Presidential Favor For a Steady Supporter
abstract: Michael D. Granoff offered President Clinton an invitation he could not refuse.    A young financier, Mr. Granoff decided to start an annual lecture series, aptly if not humbly named the Granoff Economic Forum, at his alma mater, the University of Pennsylvania. His goal was to bring together academics, politicians and businesspeople to grapple with the challenges of the new economy.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Icahn Seeks to Take Control Of Nabisco Group Holdings  Just 15 days after being rebuffed by the board of Nabisco Group Holdings, the investor Carl C. Icahn appealed to shareholders in a campaign to take over the troubled maker of Oreo cookies and Ritz crackers.   In a letter to the board that was widely distributed, Mr. Icahn offered shareholders a premium of 40 percent for 100 million shares that would give him control of the company. Once in control, Mr. Icahn said, he would try to sell the company at what he expects would be a ''very attractive price.''   [Page C2.]    Greenspan Responds to Congress  Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, told members of Congress in a letter that the central bank's goal in raising interest rates was not to bring down the stock market, and he reiterated his opposition to growing calls for the Fed to make it more difficult for investors to buy stock with borrowed money. The letter was in response to written questions from the committee to Mr. Greenspan.   [C2.]    Dime Sues Salomon Smith Barney  Dime Bancorp is suing its former investment banker, Salomon Smith Barney, for going to work for North Fork Bancorp, which is pressing Dime to accept a $1.9 billion buyout offer. Dime, which owns the Dime Savings Bank of New York, contends that Salomon Smith Barney agreed in May 1997, while advising Dime on an acquisition, not to represent any company on a bid for Dime without its consent.   [C5.]

headline: Young Designers Give Artisan Traditions a Sassy Spin
abstract: MILAN—  Marco Mazzocchi, the model of a modern businessman, sits in a Milan showroom extolling the virtues of mink hotpants.

headline: House Passes $6.9 Billion Computer Research Bill
abstract: House Passes $6.9 Billion Computer Research Bill

headline: Keeping His Promise, Pope Opens New Year
abstract: John Paul II gave his first blessing of the Year 2000 as fireworks exploded and church bells tolled, ushering in the new year across Rome.    ''As we cross the threshold of the new year, I would like to knock at the door of every home, to bring to each of you my cordial good wishes,'' the pope said to about 100,000 people gathered in St. Peter's Square beneath his study window, many holding up torches and candles.

headline: Jobs Outside the Ivory Tower
abstract: Jane Merino Morais and Robert Morais letter on Jan 16

headline: Taiwan Market Shakes Off Vote Results
abstract: Taiwan stock market jumps 5.5 percent on March 21, more than making up for its 2.6 percent loss on March 20 following victory of opposition leader Chen Shui-bian in presidential election (M)

headline: Bit by Bit, Met´s Artworks Move Online
abstract: News Watch: Bit by Bit, Met's Artworks Move Online

headline: Healtheon/WebMD to Purchase Quintiles´ Envoy for About $2.5 Billion
abstract: January 24, 2000

headline: 2 New Systems to Help Deaf and Blind at Movies
abstract: National Center for Accessible Media, joint venture of Corporation for Public Broadcasting and WGBH, public television station in Boston, develops technology to help deaf and blind filmgoers, and systems are being tested at theaters in the General Cinema chain; one is a translucent screen that can carry text and images and allow the deaf to view subtitles that are not visible to those in the audience able to hear the dialogue and soundtrack; the other lets blind people use headphones to hear a running description of the on-screen action; photos (M)

headline: Led by Technology Issues, Main Gauges Rally Sharply
abstract: Nasdaq composite index gains 149.60 points, or 3.05 percent, to finish at record 5,046.86; Dow Jones industrial average ends with gain of 154.20, or 1.56 percent, at 10,010.73; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index advances 34.99 points, or 2.56 percent, to end at 1,401.69; graph; chart (M)

headline: Scary Stuff, Indeed: Halloween as Bellwether
abstract: Mark Hulbert (Strategies) article discusses stock strategy, sometimes called the Halloween Indicator, that says sell all your stocks at very end of April and reinvest money on Oct 31; says he has comes to believe there is something to concept, noting it has withstood considerable amount of statisical scrutiny; notes historical record from year end 1925 through 1998, as compiled by Ibbotson Associates, shows that over this period large capitalized stocks returned 4.9 percentage points more, annualized, between Nov 1 and April 30 than they did between May 1 and Oct 31; says difference is even more impressive for small-cap stocks; graph (M)

headline: An Elusive Date With History
abstract: Jane Perlez analysis, citing new crisis in southern Lebanon and other circumstances in region, holds that time is running out on Clinton administration in its attempt to forge Middle East peace accord (M)

headline: TRADE DEAL JEOPARDIZED
abstract: A South African-European free trade agreement, stalled earlier by Portuguese and Spanish objections to South Africa's use of traditionally European terms like port and sherry, is again in jeopardy. Italy wants South Africa to phase out use of the term grappa and is threatening to withhold endorsement of the trade accord, which had been scheduled to go into effect on Jan. 1. It would eliminate tariffs on most goods between European Union nations and South Africa. The objections of Portugal and Spain have since been resolved.   Henri E. Cauvin

headline: Citigroup Offers Partner Benefits
abstract: Citigroup will extend benefits it gives employees' spouses to unmarried partners of same or opposite sex later this year (S)

headline: AT&T Seeks Action On Bell Atlantic
abstract: AT&T Corp chairman C Michael Armstrong says AT&T will ask federal regulators to halt Bell Atlantic Corp's long-distance service in New York until company corrects problems in order-processing system; says at end of February, 50 percent of its orders were unfilled by Bell Atlantic (S)

headline: China Is Said to Hold Devotees Of Sect in a Psychiatric Hospital
abstract: Hong Kong human rights group says more than 50 followers of banned Falun Gong spiritual group are being held at a psychiatric hospital on outskirts of Beijing (S)

headline: Clinton to Offer Aid in Colombia Drug War
abstract: Pres Clinton plans $1.28 billion emergency aid program to help Colombia fight growing drug trade and to prop up its democracy over next two years; much of money would be spent on military hardware to upgrade Colombian forces battling narcotics traders, many of whom are aligned with antigovernment rebels; funds would also be used to help strengthen justice system and aid people displaced by civil war (M)

headline: Potent Software Escalates Music Industry's Jitters
abstract: Napster, free online service created by 19-year-old college dropout that helps computer users find music to download free from Internet, shakes music industry, already disturbed over ease of copying music via worldwide Web without paying for it; has spread quickly among college students, traditionally most avid consumers of recorded music, resulting in glut of digital traffic that has overloaded university networks forcing dozens of colleges to ban use of service; sharpens fears among record industry executives and some artists that Internet will undermine control of copyright holders over distribution of their music; prompts lawsuit by Recording Industry Assn of America, seeking damages and injunction that would effectively shut down service; Napster argues that it is not liable for music piracy since it does not keep music files on its own servers; says software simply allows people to share information, and that many of songs have been authorized for copying by copyright holders; copyright experts say industry has strong case since while 'fair use' doctrine of copyright laws gives consumers right to make copies of music for personal use, Napster complicates matters by making copying possible at much greater order of magnitude; software was developed by former Northwestern University computer science student Shawn Fanning; photo; diagram (M)

headline: A D.S.L. Success Story
abstract: Al Tech letter on Jan 13 on DSL Internet connections; says he is pleased with his service

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: EUROPE    BRITAIN: EX-CABINET AIDE FREED  Jonathan Aitken, 57, a former Conservative Party cabinet minister found guilty of perjury last year in a doomed libel action, was freed from jail after serving 7 months of an 18-month sentence. He must now spend months under curfew in his London house, wearing an electronic ankle tag that allows his movements to be monitored. Once considered likely to become a leader of his party, he is now planning to study theology at Oxford University.   Warren Hoge (NYT)    BRITAIN: SUPPORT FOR CANING  Fifty-one percent of British parents want to see the return of corporal punishment to schools, a survey for The Times of London shows. Caning was outlawed in public schools 14 years ago and in private ones last year, and teachers' union officials said there was no chance of its return. They also said parents must share the blame for discipline problems.   Warren Hoge (NYT)

headline: 300 Rabbis In U.S. Group Say Jerusalem Is Shareable
abstract: Group of American rabbis, concerned that Israeli-Palestinian peace talks might collapse over tangled issue of Jerusalem, signs petition calling on both sides to share city; Jewish Peace Lobby says pursuit of peace requires that Jerusalem be shared with Palestinian people, in some form; founder Jerome Segal says outside groups must force debate on most sensitive Israeli-Palestinian issues, now that peace talks are edging toward final, knotty differences; of 1,200 rabbis who were initially approached, more than 800 refused to sign, saying they could not envision practical way of sharing city (M)

headline: Treasuries Rise on Hopes Of Slowdown
abstract: US Treasury bond prices rise; price of 30-year Treasury bond rises 8/32, to 102 15/32; yield falls to 6.07 percent from 6.09 percent; graph on Freddie Mac yields; chart on US key interest rates (M)

headline: Transition in the Chief Executive Post at Coca-Cola Comes Early
abstract: Transition in the Chief Executive Post at Coca-Cola Comes Eara

headline: If Democracy Is Not Enough
abstract: Roger Cohen analysis holds that European Union demonstrated its abrupt development into serious political force when it demanded that Austria keep party of Jorg Haider, rightist politician, out of government (M)

headline: Our Money's Worth
abstract: Letter from Dorothy M Grady on Jan 30 article on new dollar coin (S)

headline: Success Story for the Bundeswehr / 10% of Its 30,000 Officers Come From the East : German Army Smoothly Makes Room in the Ranks for Former Foes
abstract: BERLIN—  Among the many Western institutions trying to spread democratic stability in Central Europe, few boast a greater success story than the German Army, the Bundeswehr.

headline: Stock Accord With Canada Reconsidered
abstract: Canadian companies in last nine years have raised about $153 billion through debt and equity issues in US, usually with little screening by US Securities and Exchange Commission because their filing documents had already been approved by Canada's provincial regulators; agreement that is unique to Canada and US, known as multijurisdictional disclosure system, has allowed issuers of Canadian securities to file in US quickly, saving enormous sums in costs and time; issuers fear their advantage may soon disappear; threat lies in proposals first made by US securities regulators in 1998 for revising registration system; SEC questioned whether Canada should have edge that other major trading partners do not (M)

headline: No Free Lunch, Indeed
abstract: Pfizer Corp cuts back culinary treats at shareholders' annual meeting because of increasing attendance (S)

headline: Oneok Buys Gas Plants
abstract: Oneok Inc agrees to buy Kinder Morgan Inc's natural gas processing plants and pipelines in Oklahoma, Kansas and Texas for $114 million (S)

headline: Equity and Debt Expected to Be Offered
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:    Abiomed Inc., Danvers, Mass., 1.5 million shares. BancAmerica Securities.    American Superconductor Corp., Westborough, Mass., 3 million shares. BancAmerica Securities.

headline: Anger Still Fires the Hell That Was Sierra Leone
abstract: Outlook for rebuilding Sierra Leone after country's nine years of brutal civil war is uncertain; rebels, ex-soldiers, militiamen and traditional hunters are supposed to be giving up their weapons and start becoming law-abiding citizens; what happens to tens of thousands of angry ex-combatants may well determine future of Sierra Leone; even if United Nations peacekeepers eventually succeed in deploying throughout entire country and all of 45,000 estimated combatants give up their weapons, most people regard that as only the first, and perhaps easiest, step in rebuilding Sierra Leone; weakened by decades of corrupt governments, devastated by one of most brutal wars in Africa, Sierra Leone needs to be remade from scratch; photo; map (L)

headline: Shelburne Journal; Tales of Sex, Violence and Greed in a Small Town
abstract: Lee Keating, former supervisor at Shelburne School for Boys, reformatory in Nova Scotia, is among 84 former employees who object to decision of Nova Scota provincial government to accept largely on face value charges of former residents of school that they were physically or sexually abused by staff members, and to pay them from $25 million compensation fund for victims; one former employee was convicted of sex abuse in 1993, after which many suits were filed by former residents against virtually entire staff; Keating and others say they are victims of witch hunt; photos; map (M)

headline: NYT Article
abstract: U.S. Lets Professor Put Encryption on Internet

headline: Little Progress Is Reported in Antitrust Talks
abstract: Microsoft's top executives, chairman William H Gates and president Steven A Ballmer, say they are still hopeful of settling government antitrust case against company before Federal Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson issues his final ruling (S)

headline: Misjudging a Book by Its Cover
abstract: Inflated claim of investment success made on cover of The Beardstown Ladies' Common-Sense Investment Guide inspired two false advertising suits in California and New York that resulted in vastly different legal judgments; suits have also spurred class-action suits against other major publishers testing whether hyped claims on book's jacket are free speech protected by First Amendment; Justice Herman Cahn rejected New York suit; California judge also dismissed suit, but higher court ruled false commercial speech is not protected; photo (M)

headline: ORACLE TO SELL PART OF LIBERATE TECHNOLOGIES STAKE
abstract: Oracle Corp to sell almost 10 percent of its stake in Liberate Technologies as part of larger stock offering; Liberate files for sale of 8.5 million shares by company and existing shareholders; Liberate shares rise $19.50, to $106 (S)

headline: People
abstract: Martin Macdonald is named senior vice president and executive creative director on Cadillac account at Troy, Mich, office of D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, succeeding Jon Parkinson, who resigned; Clint Schramm, executive vice president and executive broadcast producer at Christopher Thomas Associates, is named president of agency's Stamford, Conn, office, succeeding Arlene Saffron, who will head research there; Fred Korge, president at Baxter & Korge, is named to new post of president at Bates Corporate Design Group; Jackie Dryden, vice president at Baxter & Korge, is named general manager at Bates Corporate Design; David Salomon, executive vice president for marketing at Millsport, part of Omnicom Group, is named to president, succeeding Bob Basche, who is promoted to new titles of vice chairman and managing partner (M)

headline: First Listen, Then Teach
abstract: In high school, I wanted to be a history teacher. My favorite teacher, Mr. Batchelder, had us read the Federalist papers and newspaper articles from the 1780's, not some boring textbook. He made history come alive.    But those were the days when a son did what his father told him to. My father said: ''Well, technology is coming up. We've got these new I.B.M. machines, sputnik has just gone up.'' He wanted me to be an engineer. He figured I'd be able to do anything if I mastered technology. He told me to go to M.I.T., so I went.

headline: BLACKSTONE GROUP REDUCES ITS OFFER FOR KROLL-O'GARA
abstract: Kroll-O'Gara Co says Blackstone Group LP has reduced its cash buyout offer to $16 a share from $18 it offered in November; new bid values transaction at $422.2 million, 11 percent less than original offer (S)

headline: Theft Under the Taliban? Perish the Thought
abstract: Rise in robberies and burglaries in Kabul embarrasses Taliban authorities, who thought that prospect of having one's hands and feet cut off would be a sufficient deterrent to theft; theft of $200,000 from city's main money bazaar appears to have been an inside job, since the Taliban soldiers who guarded the bazaar at night were gone as well by morning; photo; map (M)

headline: When the Age of Courtship Ends
abstract: Lisa Belkin's Life's Work column on growing number of perks employers offer would-be employees at a time of low unemployment; says people who make their living from work-life programs at corporations understand some of perks are likely to disappear when economy weakens; drawing (M)

headline: Aetna's Chief Steps Down Under Pressure From Shareholders
abstract: Richard L Huber resigns as Aetna Inc chief executive under pressure from shareholders frustrated by stock price slide; is succeeded by William H Donaldson, board member who will step down as senior adviser at Donaldson Lufkin & Jenrette; Donaldson, 68, says he will not be interim chief; board waives its mandatory age 65 retirement policy for him; photo (M)

headline: Carbon-Copy Madness
abstract: Letter by William Rivelli responds to Feb 10 article on e-mail; questions why software is not written that would allow him to send carbon copies without putting his recipients at risk of being bombarded by unwanted e-mail

headline: The Grand Exit
abstract: On the Job column of Money & Business section of The New York Times invites readers to send in their most memorable stories of leaving a job or most striking departure they have witnessed

headline: Hezbollah Not Moved By Barak Vow To Pull Out
abstract: Hezbollah leader Sheik Hassan Nasrallah says his forces in southern Lebanon will continue to kill Israeli soldiers despite Prime Minister Ehud Barak's pledge to make unconditional withdrawal from area by July 7 (M)

headline: Istanbul Journal; Where the Mighty Splash (Even Qaddafi's Camels)
abstract: Interview with Ethem Erkoc, Turkish swimming pool contractor who has built pools for prominent Middle East leaders; photo (M)

headline: Young & Rubicam Out of Army Review
abstract: Young & Rubicam Advertising has declined to participate in review that began in January for US Army advertising account; Army's ad spending is estimated at $110 million annually (S)

headline: Engineers Reject Offer In Strike Against Boeing
abstract: Talks between Boeing Co and its striking engineers and technical workers break down after three fruitless days of discussions with federal mediator; at least 17,000 employees have been on strike since Feb 9; they belong to Society of Professional Engineering Employees in Aerospace; union seeks bonuses and other benefits that match those Boeing gave its machinists last year; because of strike Boeing has missed delivery dates on several planes and its stock is down 8 percent; union members may have to begin paying for their own medical coverage on March 1 (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Price of heating oil surges 8 percent as frigid weather in Northeast increases demand and exporters restrict supplies; February contract gains 7.04 cents, to 93.5 cents a gallon; graphs (S)

headline: Wired for Sound
abstract: Bob DeVore letter on Dec 23 article on high-end speaker wires (S)

headline: SOFTBANK TO SPIN OFF ZIFF-DAVIS'S ONLINE UNIT
abstract: Softbank Corp, which owns 69 percent of Ziff-Davis Inc, plans to spin off company's ZDNet unit and is in talks to sell its events unit; will hold 45 percent of ZDNet; Ziff-Davis will wrap its remaining assets into ZDNet (S)

headline: Deal for Swiss Drug Labs
abstract: Solutia Inc agrees to buy Swiss research and development company, CarboGen Laboratories, as first step in its plan to enter drug-ingredients manufacturing; financial terms undisclosed (S)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    TUESDAY  Retail Sales -- Feb.    WEDNESDAY  Inventory-Sales Ratio -- Jan.  Industrial Production -- Feb.    THURSDAY  Weekly Jobless Claims  Housing Starts -- Feb.  Producer Price Index -- Feb.    FRIDAY  Consumer Price Index -- Feb.

headline: Radios Watch Weather So You Don't Have To
abstract: National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) has several new technologies that provide alerts over portable weather radios; use of weather radios is especially important at night, when storms usually catch sleeping populations unawares; new technology can operate on standby, coming alive only when weather watch or warning is broadcast; photos of some portable weather radios and prices (M)

headline: Pinochet Receives Hero's Welcome on Return to Chile
abstract: Gen Augusto Pinochet receives muted hero's welcome from military command on return to Chile from Britain after 16 months of house arrest; thousands of detractors and supporters stage competing demonstrations on streets of capital of Santiago; he spends first day at military hospital undergoing medical tests; is expected to keep low profile through March 11 inauguration of Ricardo Lagos, first Socialist party president since Pinochet overthrew Salvador Allende Gossens in violent coup in 1973; photo (M)

headline: I.N.S. Is Looking the Other Way As Illegal Immigrants Fill Jobs
abstract: Hundreds of thousands of illegal immigrants are working in United States, largely unimpeded by Immigration and Naturalization Service; service has made crossing border harder than ever and it has stepped up patrols and is prosecuting companies that smuggle in aliens, but once inside country, illegal immigrants are largely left alone; even when these people are discovered, arrests for purpose of deportation are much less frequent; agency's new focus is to pick up aliens who have committed crime; rest are in effect allowed to help American employers fill jobs in booming economy running short of labor; new lenience helps explain why overall wage increases have been less than many economists and policy makers had expected; immigrants--legal and illegal--are feeding pool of people available to take lowest-paying jobs, which constitute 25 percent of all jobs; graph (M)

headline: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: AMERICAS; AMERICAN EXPRESS IN MEXICO
abstract: American Express Bank (Mexico), offering direct banking services in Mexico for first time, introduces mutual fund and three other personal investment products that are aimed at middle- and higher-income families (S)

headline: Modestly, India Goes In for a Swim
abstract: New middle class is evolving in India; members of India's middle class have far higher standard of living than their parents did, but also work more hours to enjoy their prosperity; Iswar Natarajan, chief economist of National Council of Applied Economic Research, New Delhi, says better term for this group might be the consuming class; estimates number of households in this class, with incomes of $1,200 to $6,000 a year, has almost doubled in past decade, to about 39 million; economists caution that being in middle of Indian income range does not yield anything like buying power of middle-class income in West; photos (L)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: CHASE MANHATTAN CORP., New York, the second-largest bank in the United States, will split its stock three shares for two and raise its quarterly dividend by 17 percent. The split is scheduled for May 17 if approved by shareholders at the bank's annual meeting on May 16.    ROADWAY EXPRESS INC., Akron, Ohio, the second-largest trucker in the United States, said it was seeking an acquisition to enter the next-day freight market and expects double-digit revenue growth in the first quarter.

headline: Bugs in the Bug Fixer
abstract: To the Editor:    I downloaded the trial Norton Antivirus 2000 program from the Microsoft Web site, as suggested in ''Viruses and Their Cures'' (Dec. 16). What a disaster.

abstract: EU Investigates Windows 2000

headline: People
abstract: Richard Constant is named chief executive at Gavin Anderson & Co, succeeding Gavin Anderson, who remains chairman; Robert Mead, president and chief executive of New York office, is named to new post of president of agency, and Eugene Golembeski, chief financial officer, is named to new post of chief operating officer; Brian Booker is named to post of president and chief creative officer for advertising at Barkley Evergreen & Partners, succeeding David Farmer, who resigned; Doria Steedman, executive vice president and director for creative development at Partnership for a Drug-Free America, is named to new position of vice chairwoman; Jan Sneed is named senior vice president and director for corporate affairs at Grey Advertising, succeeding Owen Dougherty, who resigned to join J Walter Thompson as executive vice president and director for corporate communications (S)

headline: Shopping With Priceline: Promise and Problems
abstract: Ted Davis letter on Jan 6 article holds he saves money buying groceries from Priceline

abstract: Spain's government says that it will not send London a request for an appeal from Judge Baltasar Garzon if Gen Augusto Pinochet is freed on medical grounds (S)

headline: AT&T Puts a Price on Wireless Offering
abstract: AT&T Corp says it intends to raise up to $13.2 billion in initial public offering of shares to track AT&T's wireless communications unit, biggest US IPO ever; AT&T estimates tracking shares will be offered at $26 to $32 each (M)

headline: Productivity Finally Shows The Impact Of Computers
abstract: Louis Uchitelle Economic View column on question of whether productivity of nation's workers has finally shifted into higher gear; says remarkable economic boom since 1995 has at last brought enduring improvement in output of goods and services for each hour spent on job, showing impact of computers in workplace; graph (M)

headline: AOL, PurchasePro.com Enter Alliance
abstract: March 20, 2000

headline: Technologists Get a Warning and a Plea From One of Their Own
abstract: Bill Joy, chief scientist of Sun Microsystems, issues impassioned critique of uncontrolled progress in digital, biological and material sciences; his essay in April issue of Wired magazine challenges scientists and engineers to rethink their ethical standards and step back from advances that might ultimately threaten human species; Joy writes that world has survived potentially devastating technologies developed in 20th century, but that several new branches of research pose threats of technological devastation at hands of small group or even individual; says some 21st century technologies--genetics, nanotechnology and robotics--are so powerful they can spawn whole new classes of accidents and abuses; calls on scientists to limit development of technologies that are too dangerous; photos (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: SOYBEANS SOAR***Soybeans hit their highest price in more than a year, as forecasts for dry weather in Brazil raise concern about prospects for crop there; soybeans for March delivery rise 13.75 cents a bushel, to $5.27; graph; chart (S)

headline: BESTFOODS BUYING INTO BRAZILIAN COMPANY
abstract: Bestfoods will pay $490 million for controlling stake in Arisco Produtos Alimenticios SA, one of Brazil's leading makers of processed foods (S)

headline: Long History of Intercepting Key Words
abstract: Description of Echelon system, developed in 1970's, which links computers in at least seven sites around world to receive, analyze and sort information captured from satellite communications (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Euro climbs on speculation that European Central Bank policy makers will raise interest rates soon as this week; in New York, euro settles at 96.73 cents, up from 96.49 cents; graph; chart (S)

headline: Wall Street Shrugs Off Higher Rates Hike? No Problem
abstract: Week ends with major gains by Dow Jones, Nasdaq composite and S&P 500 indexes after Federal Reserve meets Wall Street's expectations of modest increase in interest rates (S)

abstract: Credit Suisse Group says second-half profit more than tripled, beating analysts' forecasts; net income rose to 2.5 billion Swiss francs ($1.5 billion) from 700 million francs a year earlier (S)

headline: Kuwaitis Are Exasperated By America's Oil Politics
abstract: Interview with Kuwaiti oil minister Sheik Saud Nasser al-Sabah; he voices displeasure over US pressure to raise production quotas as oil and gasoline prices have soared in recent months (M)

headline: Closing the Digital Gap
abstract: Letter from Ben Austin agrees with Jan 27 article that there is disparity of use of computers among low-income families in New York

headline: Executives Form Zoom City Agency
abstract: Dan McMahan and Bob Sarlin, co-creative directors at Charron, Schwartz & Partners, leave agency to form Zoom City in Chapel Hill, NC; McMahan will be chief executive and Sarlin will be president (S)

headline: Short Takes
abstract: After years of rapid growth, U.S. waste-recycling efforts are leveling off. The percentage of municipal solid waste diverted to recycling rose from 10 percent in 1980 to 28.8 percent in 1998 before flattening out, The Washington Post reports.

headline: Small Brokers Become an Issue On N.A.S.D. Plan to Go Public
abstract: Plan by National Association of Securities Dealers to become publicly held company hits snag after Independent Broker-Dealer Association president Alan Davidson urges organization's 5,565 members to vote against deal unless small brokerage firms are consulted on how they will be regulated in new organization (S)

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: EUROPE    GERMANY: CALLS TO QUIT GROW  Wolfgang Schauble, leader of the embattled Christian Democratic Union, faced growing calls to quit after admitting to a third meeting with a fugitive arms dealer, Karlheinz Schreiber. Initially Mr. Schauble told Parliament that he may have ''run into'' Mr. Schreiber once. Then he acknowledged a second meeting at which he received 100,000 marks. After consulting his diary he conceded that there was a third meeting, on June 2, 1995.   Roger Cohen (NYT)

headline: Executives Form E-Commerce Agency
abstract: Mark A Toner and Rich Feldman, senior executives formerly at Wilton, Conn, office of Brann Worldwide, have joined with Source Marketing of Westport, Conn, to form advertising agency, eSource, dedicated to encouraging loyalty among customers of e-commerce brands (S)

headline: Ford to Offer Workers PCs and Online Access at Low Cost
abstract: Ford to Offer Workers PCs and Online Access at Low Cost

headline: Boeing Profit Rises by 42% On Improved Jet Operations
abstract: Boeing Co says its fourth-quarter profit jumped 42 percent, far outpacing most Wall Street estimates; reports profit of $662 million compared with $465 million in year-earlier quarter; sales dropped 11 percent, to $15.2 billion, from $17 billion a year ago; for the year, sales increased 3 percent, to $57.9 billion, up from $56.1 billion; earnings for last year increased 106 percent, to $2.3 billion, up from $1.1 billion (S)

headline: Summer's Colorful Helpers
abstract: PARIS—  This season you can't see the clothes for the accessories — from extravagant gypsy head scarves to colorful sling-back beaded mules — and everything seems to be covered in beads and jewels.

headline: Equity Issues Planned This Week
abstract: The following equity offerings are expected this week:    American Classic Voyages Co., Chicago, 2 million shares. Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette.

headline: TOM.COM SHARES SOAR
abstract: Shares of Tom.com, start-up backed by Hong Kong billionaire Li Ka-shing soar more than fivefold in its first day of trading (S)

headline: . . . And on the Greens
abstract: Golf Digest magazine which ranks top business executives by their handicaps, gives top ranking to Sun Microsystems head Scott G McNealy; McNealy recalls losing to General Electric head Jack Welch, whose own ranking fell from second to 16th; photo (S)

headline: Judge in Microsoft Case Delays a Ruling as Mediation Intensifies
abstract: Richard A Posner, federal mediator in Microsoft Corp antitrust case, tells officials that he may be able to broker settlement, prompting trial Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson to delay his ruling, which was due March 28; Posner has laid out aggressive weeklong schedule of proposals and counterproposals between Microsoft and Justice Department; state attorneys general are protesting schedule, which allows them only two days to review any agreement between Microsoft and federal government (M)

headline: The Watergate Tapes: Nixon and Dean Online
abstract: Prof Jerry Goldman is posting 12 1/2 hours of Watergate-related tapes from Nixon White House recently released by National Archives on online library of American political recordings he runs with Michigan State University; photo (M)

headline: Citigroup Raising Stake in Nikko
abstract: Citigroup Inc says it will double its stake in Nikko Securities Co to 20.7 percent from 9.5 percent stake (S)

headline: Hezbollah Says It Will Not Halt Its Attacks as Long as the Israelis Remain in Lebanon
abstract: Hezbollah, militant Islamic group that has waged three-week offensive against Israeli forces in southern Lebanon, says it has no plans to halt attacks so Israel can fulfill its promise to withdraw from area by early July without further losses; Hussein al-Khalil, spokesman, says as long as there are Israeli forces in southern Lebanon, resistance will continue; photo (M)

headline: Debating Retirement's New Lines
abstract: Alan Flaherty letter comments on Fred Brock's Jan 2 column, which suggested that raising retirement age to 70 would be difficult for Americans whose jobs require hard physical labor

headline: US Airways Strike Threat Shows Drawbacks of E-Tickets
abstract: Threat of strike against US Airways, now lifted, exposes the drawbacks of the paperless electronic ticket, or e-ticket, which exists only on an airline's computer and has become the standard air ticket today; other airlines said they would try to accommodate US Airways passengers with paper tickets, but travelers with e-tickets could not expect such service; travel agents, gloating somewhat, said they were ready to issue paper tickets to customers who had booked e-tickets through them, but noted that they could not help travelers who had bypassed travel agents to buy tickets online from an Internet travel site or by telephones; photo (M)

headline: Microsoft Names a New Chief Executive
abstract: William H Gates steps aside as chief executive of Microsoft after a quarter-century of running company day to day and gives that role to his long-time partner Steven A Ballmer, company's president; Gates will remain as chairman and says he will take on new role as 'chief software architect,' declaring his conviction that 'in the revolution ahead of us, software will be at the center'; photos (M)

headline: The Frigid Majesty of the Far North
abstract: The Frigid Majesty of the Far North

headline: Journal Escalates Battle With British Rival
abstract: Wall Street Journal is set to unveil its Continental edition, hoping to overcome The Financial Times in their competition for European consumers of financial news; photo (M)

headline: Keeping a High Tone at Christie's
abstract: Profile of Edward Dolman, new chief executive of Christie's, who discusses decision not to forge a link with an Internet company, as Sotheby's has done with Amazon.com; instead, Christie's plans to make all aspects of the company interactive, with online auctions, Internet views of auctions in sales rooms and technology that lets clients view merchandise on a virtual-reality Web site; photo (M)

headline: Report on bin Laden Altered Clinton Plan
abstract: US officials say that Pres Clinton's plan to visit rural Bangladesh village was canceled after terrorist threat possibly linked to Osama bin Laden (S)

headline: Airplane Flight Recorders: The Boxes That Live to Tell the Tale
abstract: Since the early days of jet travel in 1950's, airplanes have carried flight recorders to reveal clues to why planes have crashed and to help prevent such disasters in the future; most flight data and cockpit voice recorders on commercial aircraft use tape loops to record information, but newer recorders use banks of memory chips; descriptions and diagrams of how new recorders work, how air speed is measured, and how recorders are tested for survivability in crash (M)

headline: Machine Tool Orders Down 13% in Month
abstract: United States orders for tools that make manufacturing parts fall in January, with decreases in Northeast, South and Midwest (S)

headline: Goodrich Stock Buyback
abstract: B F Goodrich Co will buy back up to $300 million, or 10 percent, of its common stock (S)

headline: Changes Are Under Way at Several Stock Markets in Europe
abstract: Bourses from London to Paris begin to position themselves for what many expect to be radical shake-up in way investors trade stocks in Europe; in London, members of London Stock Exchange vote overwhelmingly to end almost two centuries of clubby mutual ownership by converting their stakes in exchange into tradeable shares; in Belgium, Finance Min Didier Reynders tells news conference that Brussels, Paris and Amsterdam stock exchanges are in advanced talks to merge to form some other kind of alliance; traders and analysts say that investors want easier and cheaper access to trading in Europe as a whole--region has 23 separate exchanges (M)

headline: As Peace Talks Flounder, Barak Praises Assad's Commitment
abstract: Prime Min Ehud Barak showers praise on Syrian Pres Hafez al-Assad's character, in statement seemingly aimed at luring Syrians back to negotiating table; statement calls Assad leader who is serious and trustworthy and honors his word (S)

headline: Ballmer Says Breaking Up Microsoft Would Be ´Reckless´
abstract: Ballmer Says Breaking Up Microsoft Would Be 'Reckless'

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: EUROPE    RUSSIA: MIR REPRIEVE  The space station Mir got a reprieve when the government came up with more money to keep it in orbit for another seven months. Private investors, some from the United States, are expected to provide $28 million for the station. A crew is expected to arrive in April for a mission of 45 to 72 days, said Yuri Koptev, head of the space agency. Mir, in its 14th year, has been empty since August, and was due to crash into the Pacific.   Celestine Bohlen (NYT)    POLAND: 9 RUSSIANS OUSTED AS SPIES  Poland ordered nine Russian diplomats out of the country for spying, a blow to the countries' already uneasy relations. Moscow called the expulsions an ''explicitly unfriendly and provocative action'' and warned that ''appropriate response measures become inevitable.''   (Reuters)

headline: Microsoft's Quarterly Earnings Exceed Expectations
abstract: Microsoft Corp reports second-quarter earnings exceeded Wall Street analysts' expectations; for quarter ended Dec 31, Microsoft reports earnings of $2.44 billion, up 23 percent, compared with $1.98 billion in year-earlier period; revenues rose 18 percent, to $6.11 billion from $5.20 billion (M)

headline: SOFTWARE.COM AGREES TO BUY @MOBILE FOR $400 MILLION
abstract: Software.com acquires Atmobile.com for about $400 million in stock (S)

headline: H & R Block's Tax Web Site Has a Mix-Up
abstract: H & R Block says at least nine people who logged on to its Web site to do their taxes last week ended up with data from other customers' returns mixed in with their own; says problem may have allowed customers doing their returns online to see confidential data like Social Security numbers from other customer's file but did not affect other applications on Web site; says it shut down online service on Feb 14 as soon as it learned of problem (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEF
abstract: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS MACHINES CORP., Armonk, N.Y., sold most of its home-networking business to Spencer Trask & Co., an investment firm based in New York. Terms were not disclosed.    SARATOGA BEVERAGE GROUP INC., Saratoga Springs, N.Y., a spring water and juice company, agreed to be taken private by North Castle Partners for $6 a share, or $31.8 million.

headline: The New York Times: The Internet and Political Campaigns
abstract: The New York Times: The Internet and Political Campaigns

headline: When the News Turns Bad, Valuation Suddenly Matters
abstract: Floyd Norris column on revival of importance of corporate valuation; says this week's debacle in Procter & Gamble, in which moderate profit shortfall caused company to shed $40 million in market value, may be precursor to what will happen as other beloved stocks fall by wayside; graph (M)

headline: Ziff-Davis to Spin Off Events Group
abstract: Ziff-Davis to Spin Off Events Group

headline: AMDOCS TO PURCHASE NET SOFTWARE COMPANY IN TORONTO
abstract: Amdocs Ltd acquires Solect Technology Group for about $1.1 billion in stock (S)

headline: A Software Shortcut Is Drawing Attention
abstract: Kate Berry (Investing) article on analyst interest in application service providers (ASP's), companies in business of renting software to corporations over Internet; says blue chip stock in field is Citrix Systems; notes other companies in field; graph on APS revenues from 1998 projected through 2003; sketch (M)

headline: Russian Aide Opens Door a Bit to U.S. Bid for Missile Defense
abstract: Sergei B Ivanov, head of Rur

headline: Asian Exchanges Ushering In A Smooth Start to the Century
abstract: The first worldwide trading day of 2000 opened without difficulty this morning at stock exchanges in Hong Kong, Singapore and Malaysia, reassuring market officials that the global market is coping with the computer-related hurdles that arrived with the new millennium.    Electronic trading systems at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange and the Chicago Board of Trade, which handle trades in futures and options, also opened for business last night without a hitch.

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Euro slips against the dollar, falling to 98.62 cents, from 99.27 cents, in New York trading; graph; chart (S)

headline: F.C.C. TO APPROVE LOW-POWER RADIO FOR WIDER ACCESS
abstract: Federal government moves to open radio airwaves to hundreds of small broadcasters and will approve rules allowing educational, religious and community groups to run inexpensive low-power FM radio stations; Federal Communications Commission, over objections of nation's largest broadcasters, will adopt licensing rules permitting addition of noncommercial stations with broadcasting circles as much as seven miles in diameter; government officials say rules hold great promise to transform airwaves at time when rise of broadcasting conglomerates has sharply reduced diversity of voices; low-power station licenses have not been issued for more than 20 years; efforts of major broadcasters to block new rules through intensive lobbying and legislation noted; many contend so-called micro-radio stations can create interference for established stations in form of static or distorted signals (M)

headline: HONG KONG COMPANY IS ACQUIRED
abstract: Venture capital firm Hambrecht & Quist Asia Pacific Group and other investors are paying $26 million for Acme Landis Holdings Ltd to use as a base for Asian Internet investments; Acme Landis will be renamed i100 Ltd (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: SILVER DROPS. Silver prices fell more than 3 percent on a report that China was poised to sell some of its central bank reserves. In New York, silver for March delivery fell 16.5 cents an ounce, to $5.21.

headline: World Briefing
abstract: Judge in Zimbabwe rules in favor of white farmers, saying black squatters on their farms are breaking law; squatters, veterans of Zimbabwe's war of independence, had invaded hundreds of farms to speed pace of land reforms; photo (S)

headline: The Art of Reading Television
abstract: Television captions are appearing on growing number of television programs, with advertisers and television networks recognizing their value; they are appearing on screens in public places, like sports bars, where audio would be distracting or difficult to hear; they are also being used to help teach English language; captioning got jump-start when Federal Communications Commission, seeking to help deaf and hard of hearing, set schedule mandating that captioning be phased in for most television programming by 2006; major broadcasters and some cable companies are well ahead of schedule; for-profit companies like VITAC are competing with Caption Center and National Captioning Institute for federal grants and advertising dollars that pay for captioning; photos (M)

headline: For Drivers of S.U.V.'s, Ways to Make Amends
abstract: Letter by Jacqueline Whipple responds to Jan 30 article on air pollution cause by SUV's and ways to reduce air pollution; says much energy could be saved by hanging laundry outdoors to dry instead of using electric clothes dryers

headline: In Chechnya, an Undaunted Diplomat
abstract: Nikolai Koshman, Russia's deputy prime minister, embarks on task of re-establishing normal life in Russian-controlled regions of breakaway Chechen republic; sees his mission as not just restoring gas and electricity, reopening schools and hospitals and generating jobs, but also as securing the loyalty of a wary population and depriving the separatist militants of the popular support they need to wage a long guerrilla war; photo; map (M)

headline: Dow Up As Shares Recover From 5-Day Losing Streak
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average gains 21.72 points, or 0.2 percent, to 11,029.89; Nasdaq composite index rises 71.33 points, to 4,167.41; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index climbs 8.50 points, or 0.6 percent, to 1,410.03; graph; chart (M)

headline: Adrian Lajous, 79, Opponent Of Mexico's Nationalized Banks
abstract: Adrian Lajous Martinez, finance official in Mexico who resigned his cabinet post in 1982 to protest nationalization of the banks, died on Jan 24 at age 79 (M)

headline: New Multiplication Tables
abstract: letters; new multipl

headline: Microsoft Suspends $400 Rebate Program in Two States
abstract: Microsoft Suspends $400 Rebate Program in Two States

headline: Three Firms Invest $40 Million In Times Company's Digital Unit
abstract: The New York Times Co, which plans public offering of new class of stock in its Internet business division this spring, says venture capital firms Flatiron Partners, Highland Capital Partners and Chase Capital Partners, unit of Chase Manhattan Bank, have invested $40 million in division, Times Company Digital; firms acquired three-year debt that will be convertible--after the offering--into Times Co's new Class C shares, which will track performance of Times Co Digital; Jerry Colonna, managing partner of Flatiron Partners, and Daniel Nova, managing general partner of Highland Capital, also agreed to join new advisory board for digital division; other members of board from outside company are Red Burns, chairwoman of interactive telecommunications program at New York University, and Mark Walsh, chief executive of VerticalNet Inc; company filed registration statement for stock with Securities and Exchange Commission on Jan 28, but offering cannot be made until it is cleared by SEC and approved by shareholders at meeting scheduled for April 27 (M)

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; Land Rover Narrows List to 5 Agencies
abstract: Land Rover North America, part of BMW AG, narrows review for its advertising account, with billings estimated at $30 million to $35 million, to give agencies from nine (S)

headline: In World of Hackers, Good Guys And Bad Guys Are Often a Blur
abstract: Computer industry has long, respected tradition of hiring professional hackers to attack computer system to determine how secure it is; that hacker tradition has grown to embrace unauthorized attacks in which programmers find way to invade or cripple system, then publish details of vulnerability--often accompanied by software that exploits weaknesses they discover; while wisdom and ethics of these practices have long been debated, recent attacks that blocked access to several prominent Web sites have fueled controversy (M)

headline: Russia and NATO, Split Over Kosovo, Agree to Renew Relations
abstract: Acting Pres Vladimir V Putin, in sign of his desire to cultivate closer ties with West, agrees to end 11-month estrangement between Russia and NATO and rebuild what Kremlin calls alliance aimed at 'stable and indivisible Europe' (M)

headline: CROSS TIMBERS CANCELS ITS PUBLIC OFFERING FOR TRUST
abstract: The Cross Timbers Oil Company said yesterday that it had canceled a public offering for its Texas Permian Royalty Trust because energy stocks are depressed. The company will instead sell the oil and natural gas fields in Texas and New Mexico that it had intended to include in the trust. Bids for the fields will be accepted next month, and Cross Timbers expects to complete the sale by the end of March. Daily production for the fields averages 15 million cubic feet of gas and 1,050 barrels of oil.

headline: 2 New Signs Of Hot Pace In Economy
abstract: National Association of Purchasing Management says its factory index rose to 56.9 in February from January reading of 56.3, where analysts had expected it to remain; Commerce Department says construction spending rose 2.7 percent in January after increasing 2.1 percent in December; graph on construction spending (M)

headline: Chancellor Proposes to Compensate Austria's Wartime Slaves
abstract: Austrian Chancellor Wolfgang Schussel, trying to calm foreign fears about his coalition with rightist Freedom Party, presents his government's platform to Parliament and says he wants to compensate people forced into slavery in Austrian factories during World War II (M)

headline: HONG KONG STOCK FUND
abstract: Hong Kong government will sell as many as 715 million new Tracker Fund units, valued at about 12 billion Hong Kong dollars, or $1.5 billion, in April through June; fund comprises all 33 Hang Seng Index stocks (S)

headline: Compaq Matches Forecasts, But Chief Sees a Strong 2000
abstract: Compaq Computer Corp posts fourth-quarter profits in line with analysts expectations, and its chief executive Michael Capellas predicts that revenue will grow by at least 15 percent this year; reports revenue of $10.5 billion in fourth quarter compared to $10.9 billion a year ago (M)

headline: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: EUROPE; BIG CZECH BANK SOLD
abstract: Czech government will sell country's largest savings bank, Ceska Sporitelna, to Austrian bank Erste Bank der Osterreichischen Sparkassen; Erste agrees to pay $515 million for 52 percent stake in Ceska Sporitelna (S)

headline: Arafat and Barak Meet, With Mubarak as Host
abstract: Israeli and Palestinian officials, after more than month of sniping at each other, meet in Sharm El Sheik, Egypt, for an informal lunch and pep talk from Pres Hosni Mubarak as they prepare to resume peace talks in Washington this month; Mubarak holds discussions with Prime Min Ehud Barak of Israel and Yasir Arafat, Palestinian leader (M)

headline: In Hostile Bid, Germans Buy 35% of Japan Drugmaker
abstract: German pharmaceutical company Boehringer Ingelheim, in hostile bid, raises its stake in Japan's SS Pharmaceutical Co to 35.86 percent; Boehringer action reflects deregulation that is reshaping Japan's drug industry, which has increased ability of foreign drugmakers to operate there; Boehringer had seat on SS Pharmaceutical's 16-member board and already owned 19.61 percent of its shares (M)

headline: Lawrence of Arabia and the Web
abstract: Jeremy Wilson has created Lawrence of Arabia Web site to supplement his scholarly biography of T E Lawrence; site provides access to much of historical background and many of his sources; Wilson also moderates public discussion group on Lawrence (M)

headline: OPEC Strategy Is Beginning To Be Noticed By Consumers
abstract: Oil prices have begun surging again in last two weeks, with OPEC vowing to continue restraints on production; price of crude oil is now $29.20 a barrel and is expected to reach $30 or more; gasoline prices are at 77.33 cents a gallon in futures market and heading to over $1.30 at the pump; near-term home heating oil futures contract is up to 86.46 cents a gallon, after climbing 8.6 percent on Jan 20; price jumps are spilling over into financial markets; concerns about oil's impact on inflation have sent bond prices lower and yields higher; if OPEC does not relent, relatively low levels of oil inventories and strong demand mean that prices will move higher; Energy Information Administration and American Petroleum Institute say total US inventories of crude oil are at their lowest level since end of 1996; demand in December was 19.8 million barrels a day, highest for month since 1978; International Energy Agency forecasts that worldwide demand will rise 2.4 percent this year, biggest gain since 1997; many analysts do not expect OPEC officials to risk pushing price of oil too far above $30 a barrel; graph; chart; photo (M)

headline: EXXON MOBIL AGREES TO SELL STAKES IN 430 GAS STATIONS
abstract: Exxon Mobil Corp will sever ties with about 430 gasoline stations in Texas, step it agrees to take to win approval of $85.2 billion deal that created company; terms undisclosed; company will sell Mobil's 49 percent stake in more than 315 stations in Austin, Dallas and San Antonio to Tetco Inc, Mobil's partner in venture that owns the stations; 7-Eleven agrees to buy Mobil's stake in 7 Dallas-area service stations plus 3 stations in Fort Worth area; Mobil's supply contracts in Houston and Bryan-College Station, representing about 102 stations, will go to Petroleum Wholesale Inc (S)

headline: Yahoo Seeking to Avoid Mutual Fund Status
abstract: Yahoo Inc has asked Securities and Exchange Commission to exempt company from regulation as mutual fund, request that could set precedent for other Web businesses; Yahoo risks falling under legal definition of mutual fund because it holds stock in other Web companies that have soared to such values they represent at least three-quarters of Yahoo's total assets (M)

headline: TECHNOLOGY: Too Close to Call; Mannesmann Vote on Vodafone Bid Should Be a Squeaker
abstract: Vodafone AirTouch's offer of nearly $282.50 for each share of Mannesmann AG stock is biggest hostile takeover ever attempted; outcome may determine who will dominate Europe's booming market for wireless communications; Klaus Esser, Mannesmannn's chairman, is desperately trying to persuade shareholders to reject takeover bid; he and Vodafone's chief executive, Chris Gent, are waging battle that resembles political campaign, with public appearances and newspaper advertisements; Esser suffered major defeat when Vodafone announced major alliance with Vivendi, which would be contingent on success of Vodafone's bid; Vivendi's chief, Jean-Marie Messier, has been longtime ally of Esser's; photos; graph (M)

headline: Mexican Buys Stake in Philip Morris
abstract: Carlos Slim Helu, richest man in Mexico, buys $90 million of stock in Philip Morris Companies, as shares in company trade near four-year low; despite disclosure, shares of Philip Morris fall 58 cents, to $22 (S)
