headline: Bradley Out; McCain Yields : Challengers Quit Presidential Race
abstract: WASHINGTON—  Former Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey and Senator John McCain of Arizona, two insurgents whose candidacies had made the 2000 primary contests among the most passionately fought in years, bowed out Thursday, but neither offered a full endorsement to his victorious rival.

headline: TELENOR TO GET STAKE IN ESAT
abstract: British Telecommunications and Telenor, Norway, settle battle for control of Esat Telecom Group, Ireland, with Telenor getting almost half of Esat; agreement detailed (S)

headline: Subsidies And Mergers Roil Outlook For Drugs
abstract: Kenneth N Gilpin (Market Insight) question-and-answer article with Tom Malley, portfolio manager of $1.2 billion Janus Global Life Sciences fund, on mergers, politics and prospects in prescription drug industry; his photo (M)

headline: A Wisp of Carbon, a Whiff of Gases
abstract: Research teams at University of California, Berkeley, under Dr Alex Zettl, and at Stanford University, under Dr Dr Hongjie Dai, demonstrate how nanotube, hollow molecules built of carbon atoms that are condensed into sheets of graphite one atom thick and then rolled into cylinder about billion of meter in diameter, can be used to detect faint amounts of gas; Zettl says nanotube's potential as chemical sensor was so unexpected that work on tubes will have to re re-evaluated; Dai says his device might be fabricated very cheaply making it competitive with larger, more expensive sensors currently in use (M)

headline: PAREXEL CUTS 500 JOBS BECAUSE OF LOST CONTRACT
abstract: Parexel International Corp, drug research company, says it will cut as many as 500 jobs and lower its earnings estimates through 2001 because Novartis AG canceled contract (S)

headline: BERINGER TO SELL NAPA RIDGE BRAND TO BRONCO WINES
abstract: Beringer Wine Estates Holdings Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Napa Ridge brand and inventory to the Bronco Wine Company of Ceres, Calif., for about $40 million. Beringer said no winery facility, vineyard holdings or other real estate would be included in the sale, which is expected to close this week. Beringer reported revenue of $391.6 million for the last 12 months.

headline: Hungary's Millennium Fireworks: a Royal Puzzle
abstract: And now, said Hungary one day late, let the millennial celebrations begin.     Not the worldwide ones, but rather those marking 1,000 years since Hungary became a nation. And what a nation: a windswept battlefield settled by Siberian horsemen on the doorstep of Europe, a vast plain whose borders have always been up for grabs, a history of angry subjugation at the hands of Ottomans, Austrians and Soviets, a disenfranchised nobility scattered across the globe, and all of it linked by a language whose only living relative -- and not a close one at that -- is Finnish.

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: NATURAL GAS CLIMBS***Natural gas prices rose as meteorologists forecast colder than normal temperatures in parts of the country; in New York, natural gas for delivery in March is up 13 cents, at $2.662 for a million BTU's (S)

headline: CNL GROUP SCRAPS ITS PLAN TO CREATE A $1.5 BILLION REIT
abstract: CNL Group Group calls off plan, announced in 1999, to merge 16 partnerships it manages and other assets into $1.5 billion real estate investment trust (S)

headline: VIOLENT PROTESTS IN TAIWAN FOLLOW ELECTION DEFEAT
abstract: Violent protests erupt in Taipei, Taiwan, day after defeat of ruling Nationalist Party after 50 years in power; forces outgoing Pres Lee Teng-hui to barricade himself inside party headquarters; thousands of disaffected supporters battle with police for hours; Lee bows to intense anger and calls for his immediate resignation by agreeing to step down as party chairman in September, year earlier than planned; three senior party leaders submit resignations; potential dangers for Taiwan from unraveling of Nationalist Party, whose candidate finished last in bitter three-way race, discussed; newly-elected president and opposition leader Chen Shiu-bian is viewed with deep suspicion by China for his past advocacy of Taiwan independence; photos (M)

headline: Frustrated Arafat and Barak End Session
abstract: Israeli Prime Min Barak and Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat end summit meeting in Erez Crossing, Gaza Strip, in frustration, still bogged down in disagreement over interim issues and far from bridging gaps on thorny final issues that stand between them and a permanent peace (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Autobytel to Sells Cars Directly Over Internet  Autobytel, the Internet car-buying service, plans to announce today that it will act as a car broker by selling cars directly over the Internet.    The announcement at the annual convention of car dealers in Orlando comes on the heels of Friday's news that Amazon.com would get into the online car-selling business by taking a 5 percent stake in Greenlight.com, and is part of a broader scramble by high-flying Internet companies to get into the business of selling cars and car parts.   [Page C2.]    Ms. Hires Former Globe Columnist  Ms. magazine said it had hired Patricia Smith, the former Boston Globe columnist who admitted fabricating information. Ms. Smith's first column for the magazine, titled ''Fools in Love,'' will appear in the February/March issue, and center on a visit to her 22-year-old son in prison. Marcia Ann Gillespie, the magazine's editor in chief, said that she had long been an admirer of Ms. Smith's work, adding that she was ''delighted'' to have Ms. Smith on staff and that she had no qualms about the writer's editorial integrity.   [C11.]

headline: Britain Agrees to Support Germany's I.M.F. Candidate
abstract: Prime Min Tony Blair of Britain endorses Horst Kohler, German, to head International Monetary Fund; it remains uncertain whether European Union will unite behind choice (M)

headline: U.N. Names Ex-Head of Atomic Energy Agency to Lead Iraq Monitoring
abstract: United Nations Security Council names Hans Blix, former director of International Atomic Energy Agency, as chief inspector of new disarmament commission for Iraq; photo (M)

headline: Bell Microproducts in Deal With I.B.M.
abstract: International Business Machines Corp says it will sell data-storage products and flat-panel screens through Bell Microproducts Inc, bringing in as much as $2 billion (S)

headline: Ads Lift Gannett Profit by 14%
abstract: Gannett Co says fourth-quarter profit increased 14 percent, spurred by more growth in advertising sales at USA Today; says profit from continuing operations rose to $284 million from $248 million a year earlier; revenue increased 13 percent, to $1.50 billion from $1.33 billion (S)

headline: Patents; Bar coding of medication may help hospitals and patients prevent many accidental deaths.
abstract: SEVERAL years ago, Scott Sullivan had a hallway conversation at work with Robert Hess about an idea: putting Braille on pills.     But Mr. Sullivan, a patent agent, and Mr. Hess, a patent lawyer, realized their concept had a flaw. What if one of the raised dots chipped off? A blind person might misread the pill and take the wrong medication. But as they tossed the notion around and realized that Braille was just a code, it came to them: Why not use a bar code instead?

headline: Corrective Medicine; New Technology Helps Health Care Avoid Mistakes
abstract: Hospitals nationwide, faced with growing concern about sometimes fatal medical errors, are increasingly turning to computers for timely safety check; LDS Hospital in Salt Lake City is in vanguard, one of handful of medical centers that have spent several years developing electronic systems that make treatments safer and more effective; but big New York medical centers are also in thick of trend; at least dozen technology companies, like Cerner and McKesson HBOC, are selling off-the-shelf versions of systems; many have been developed at teaching hospitals; they include Internet links to doctor's laptop, advice-giving software equipped with artificial intelligence, wireless devices that transmit medical orders and bar-code systems to avoid drug errors; computer systems developed by Cerner, Eclipsys Corp and Shared Medical Systems Corp discussed; graphs; photos (M)

headline: Their Way: Short, but Straight Down the Fairway
abstract: Many less affluent retirees bask in freedom to play at municipal and nine-hole golf courses on uncrowded weekdays; drawing (special section, Retirement)

headline: Senior Bank Official Took Bribe, U.S. Says
abstract: Justice Dept has evidence that senior Bank of New York official accepted bribe from Peter Berlin and Lucy Edwards, husband and wife implicated in money laundering investigation at bank; law enforcement officials say identity of banker cannot be determined; say it was someone senior to Edwards, former Bank of New York vice president who, along with Berlin, are expected to plead guilty to money laundering charges; Berlin, through his company, Benex International, controlled several accounts at bank that moved billions of dollars from Russia between 1996 and last year (M)

headline: LIFELINE FOR ASHANTI
abstract: Ashanti Goldfields Co, Ghana, secures credit line of $100 million and renews $270 million in revolving credit, enabling it to keep operating despite bungled hedging operations last year that threatneed company; Ashanti secures loan after agreeing to changes, including its board (S)

headline: People
abstract: Jim Kobs, chief executive at Kobs Gregory Passavant, Chicago, will also head a new division, Kobs Strategic Consulting, as president (S)

headline: CAMERON ACCEPTS BUYOUT OFFER FROM INVESTMENT GROUP
abstract: Cameron Ashley Building Products accepts buyout offer worth about $159 million from investment group that includes members of Cameron's senior management; investment group, which also includes CGW Southeast Partners IV LP and affiliate of Citigroup's Citicorp Venture Capital Ltd, is offering $18.25 a share; deal includes assumption of about $189 million in debt (S)

headline: Buying Airlines' Mutual Funds: Is It the Return, or the Miles?
abstract: British Airways, Virgin Group, parent of Virgin Atlantic, and AMR Corp, parent of American Airlines, offer mutual funds, but investors are warned that returns on most of these airlines funds have been subpar and that frequent-flyer miles that investors can earn through them are not all that generous; photo (M)

headline: Amazon.com Jumps After Living.com Deal
abstract: February 1, 2000

headline: Compressed Data; 'Push Technology' Returns In a Form That Is More Polite
abstract: Pointcast news and information service automatically delivers news and other information from Internet to users' screens, in so-called 'push' technology; service is being canceled by Pointcast's new owner, Launchpad Technologies; push technology consumes more than five megabytes of user's hard drive and is notorious for clogging corporate networks (S)

headline: For an Inept Band of Burmese Rebels, Only Death Was Clear
abstract: Ten Burmese gunmen are shot to death by Thai troopers who storm hospital and release hundreds of patients, doctors and nurses who were held hostage for 24 hours; photo; map; aim of raid by inept band may have been medical treatment and some sort of safe haven for comrades in Myanmar; result is disaster for cause of Burmese dissidents and tens of thousands of refugees in Thailand; furious Thai officials vow to review its policies (M)

headline: SCHLUMBERGER TO BUY MAKER OF ENERGY DATA NETWORKS
abstract: Schlumberger Ltd agrees to buy money-losing CellNet Data Systems Inc for $55 million in cash and assumption of $120 million in CellNet debt; CellNet says it plans to file for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection; it expects court to approve its sale to Schlumberger by April 30 (S)

headline: NEWFIELD EXPLORATION TO INVEST IN TEXAS GAS FIELDS
abstract: Newfield Exploration Co agrees to acquire interests in south Texas gas fields from undisclosed seller for $142 million; producing gas fields are in Hidalgo, Brooks and Kenedy counties (S)

headline: A Political Twilight in Germany
abstract: News analysis of implications of financial scandal involving Germany's Christian Democratic Union that resulted in resignation of party leader, former chancellor Helmut Kohl; even though party that governed Germany for 33 postwar years is by no means moribund, there are signs that Kohl's refusal to reveal source of secret payments to him of over $1 million has crippled party; photo (M)

headline: Turkey Delays The Execution Of Rebel Kurd
abstract: Turkish leaders postpone execution of country's most prominent Kurdish rebel, Abdullah Ocalan, in response to European pressure; postponement of his sentence means he will probably remain alive for at least year, and perhaps escape death sentence altogether; decision is to postpone execution until European Court of Human Rights rules on Ocalan's appeal, but there is no guarantee that Turkey would accept court's ruling; Ocalan's fate has become major factor in debate among European leaders over Turkey's entry into European Union; all current members have banned death penalty; latest Turkish decision also holds possibility of improved relations between Turkish government and Kurds who sympathize with Ocalan; government decision marks victory for Prime Min Bulent Ecevit, who opposes death penalty and is very eager to lead his country toward European Union (M)

headline: In No Hurry, Israel-Syria Talks Edge Toward Specifics
abstract: On the third day of talks, Israeli and Syrian officials today slowly began tackling specific questions of how they might normalize relations.    They also took up security arrangements, with an eye to persuading Israeli voters to approve a return of the Golan Heights.

headline: Not Just Silly, but Also Useless
abstract: Not Just Silly, but Also Useless

headline: Official Resigns At Nordstrom
abstract: Nordstrom Inc, operator of upscale department stores, says co-president Jim Nordstrom has resigned; no replacement has been named (S)

abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   8.50   8.50   8.50       Discount rate   5.00   5.00   5.00       Federal funds   5.44   5.58   4.68       3-month T-bills   5.24   5.23   4.31       6-month T-bills   5.42   5.42   4.27       10-yr. headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)

headline: MemberWorks Acquisition
abstract: MemberWorks Inc to buy eNeighborhoods Inc and combine it with its ConsumerInfo.com unit to form iPlace Inc (S)

headline: Car Dealers' Driveway Blues; Pushing for a Crackdown on Sales Done Directly Online
abstract: Internet companies that sell cars directly to consumers encounter stiff opposition from auto dealers, who are using their influence in state legislatures and with state regulators to protect their businesses; car dealers fear being undercut or bypassed entirely by the new services; also fear that car makers may begin selling cars on Internet themselves or through Internet services; consumer advocates welcome extra competition from Internet services, and state regulators say only complaints they are hearing about Internet services come from dealers, not consumers; evidence of whether consumers save money buying cars online is mixed; photo; graph (M)

headline: Marketing departments are turning to poets to help inspire their companies' clientele.
abstract: Marketing departments at companies nationwide are distributing books of poetry, hoping that few of their customers will appreciate it; some corporate executives are turning to poetry for inspiration; poetry campaigns of some major companies noted (M)

headline: Auction Site Settles Dispute Over eBay Data
abstract: January 6, 2000

headline: EXXON FILES SUIT TO BLOCK ARCO'S ALASKA SALE
abstract: Exxon Mobil Corp sues to block sale of Atlantic Richfield Co's Alaskan oil fields to Phillips Petroleum Co (S)

headline: Kohl Party Reports More Moving Of Money
abstract: Christian Democratic Union in state of Hesse says that it illegally transferred $10 million to overseas accounts, more than double amount it had previously disclosed; almost daily revelations of illicit financial dealings by opposition Christian Democrats have prompted deep political unease in Germany (M)

headline: Debating Retirement's New Lines
abstract: Don M Blandin letter comments on Fred Brock's Jan 2 column, which suggested that raising retirement age to 70 would be difficult for Americans whose jobs require hard physical labor

headline: NYT Article
abstract: High-Tech Visas Are Used Up

headline: State TV Ties a Putin Rival To Jews, Gays and Foreigners
abstract: Russia's state-owned television broadcasts reports that Grigory A Yavlinsky, leading challenger to Acting Pres Vladimir V Putin, is supported by Jews, homosexuals and foreigners; prime-time reports by ORT television are intended to exploit anti-Semitism, homophobia and suspicion of foreigners that still pervade Russian society, as well as its enthusiasm for conspiracy theories; Yavlisnky, who is running distant third in field of 11 candidates, stands to siphon most votes from Putin; poses greatest danger to Putin's chances of winning mandate in first round of voting; Putin implores Russians to go to polls and to pick leader who can restore country's prestige; photos (M)

headline: Changes Are Made At Omnicom Shops
abstract: Team South in Atlanta and New York, direct marketing agency that has been part of Rapp Collins Worldwide unit of Omnicom, is being merged with Omnicom's Merkley Newman Harty; Team South will function as direct marketing unit of Merkley Newman; Francine Edelman is named president of unit, which will be renamed soon; Bob Scarpelli, vice chairman and chief creative officer at Chicago office of DDB Worldwide, is named to additional post of chief creative officer (S)

headline: Bertrand Fox, 92, an Economist And Securities Expert at Harvard
abstract: Bertrand Fox, economist and expert on securities industry who taught for more than 20 years at Harvard Business School, dies at age 92; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Investor Group May Provide Emergency Funds to Iridium  A group of investors led by Craig O. McCaw, the cellular telephone pioneer, is expected to provide at least $20 million of emergency financing to Iridium, the troubled global satellite telephone company that filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection last August, according to people close to the negotiations.    The investment, which is expected to be announced early this week, would allow Iridium to continue to operate its network of 66 low-orbit satellites for the next few months, while Mr. McCaw and his team of investors negotiate to take control of the company.   [Page C2.]

headline: Ending Pilgrimage, the Pope Asks God for Brotherhood
abstract: Pope John Paul ends six-day personal pilgrimage to Holy Land; visits Al Aksa Mosque and later Wailing Wall in Jerusalem, where he leaves note to God tucked in crevices bearing message of reconciliation and asking forgiveness for Church's treatment of Jews; photos (M)

headline: RECORD PROFITS FOR MANUFACTURERS
abstract: Korea Stock Exchange says South Korean manufacturers posted record profits last year; says profits of manufacturers listed on exchange totaled 14.46 trillion won ($12.93 billion), significant turnaround from net losses of 9.06 trillion won in 1998 (S)

headline: Internet Recharges Reformers In Korea
abstract: Internet has become powerful political tool for South Korean opposition parties hankering for reform in ways unimaginable two or three years ago; more than 500 civic groups and nongovernmental organizations have shaken established parties under online banner of Citizens Solidarity; are demanding elimination of reportedly corrupt politicians from their slates in nationwide legislative election in April; are enforcing demands by posting lists of politicians deemed unworthy to hold office; are publishing reports on Internet of allegedly shady dealings by politicians, their poor attendance records in legislature and their votes for unpopular bills (M)

headline: For Drivers of S.U.V.'s, Ways to Make Amends
abstract: Letter by Lorraine Mesagna on Jan 30 article pollution caused by SUV's and ways to reduce air pollution and global warming; says she accomplised this by getting rid of her SUV

headline: General Electric Forms E-Commerce Division
abstract: General Electric Co forms electronic-commerce unit that will offer data exchange, purchasing software and services and trading-partner exchanges over Internet; GE hopes to tap business-to-business Internet market expected to rise to $1.3 trillion in 2003 (M)

headline: Federal Panel Visits Texas to Probe Shortage of Tech Workers
abstract: Federal Panel Visits Texas to Probe Shortage of Tech Workers

headline: Healtheon/WebMD Stock Down as Losses Widen
abstract: March 3, 2000

headline: U.N. Scrambles to Choose Chief Iraqi Arms Inspector
abstract: UN Security Council's differences harden as deadline nears for naming new chief arms inspector for Iraq; Sec Gen Kofi Annan comments; two steady contenders are Pasi Patokallio of Finland and Rolf Ekeus, Swedish diplomat who led inspections until 1997 (M)

headline: Training Programs Often Miss the Point on the Job
abstract: Article on many employee training program intended to build leadership skills and companywide bonding that offer no practical value; notes American Society for Training and Development says American companies spend about $55 billion a year on formal training of all kinds; photo (M)

headline: San Francisco Museum Creates $50,000 Internet Art Award
abstract: January 20, 2000

headline: Governors Say Congress Shouldn´t Bar State Internet Sales Tax
abstract: Governors Say Congress Shouldn't Bar State Internet Sales Tax

headline: More Experts
abstract: Steve Gordon letter on Feb 3 article on experts cites omission of his Internet question-and-answer service

headline: Sales of New Homes Fall 4.2%, To Lowest Level in Four Months
abstract: Commerce Department reports sales of new homes declined 4.2 percent in January, to annual rate of 882,000 homes, after rising 4 percent in December; number of homes for sale, 326,000 at annual rate, is highest in more than three years, and average price, $154,400, is lowest in a year; drop in sales linked to higher mortgage rates; Freddie Mac says average interest rate on 30-year fixed home mortgage fell to 8.27 percent, still close to 3 1/3-year high of 8.42 percent; Conference Board says its index of leading economic indicators increased 0.3 percent in January, same as in December (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: GOLDEN OCEAN GROUP LTD., Guernsey, England, a privately owned crude-oil and dry-bulk shipping company with a fleet of 17 vessels, filed for bankruptcy court protection with $881 million in assets and $880 million in debts.    CORNING CONSUMER PRODUCTS CO., Elmira, N.Y., the maker of housewares products, said it had changed its name to World Kitchen Inc.

headline: COHOES BANCORP TO BUY BACK 10 PERCENT OF ITS STOCK
abstract: Cohoes Bancorp Inc says it set one-year repurchase program for 10 percent of its common stock; buyback is company's third in last six months (S)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY  Federal Budget Feb.

headline: Turkish Military Accuses Religious Political Party
abstract: Turkey's military commanders charge that Virtue, country's religious-oriented political party, represents the extremist mentality of Hizbullah, a terrorist group that claims to be acting in the name of Islam; Turks are stunned by disclosures that Hizbullah apparently tortured and killed dozens of people that it considered heretical; clerics at mosaques throughout the country condemn Hizbullah; Numan Kurtulmus, who heads Virtue, denies link between party and Hizbullah (M)

headline: Shock of Kosovo Violence May Prove Incentive for Peace
abstract: Leaders in Kosovo say that explosion of violence in and around northern town of Mitrovica during past two weeks, which left 11 dead and dozens wounded, may not prove so much as disaster for Kosovo as an event that shocks and galvanizes society; immediate result has been to bring hundreds more peacekeeping troops to streets of Mitrovica to enforce curfew with foot patrols and post armored vehicles at almost every junction; photo (M)

headline: Thousands Vote Online in Arizona
abstract: March 8, 2000

headline: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: AMERICAS; PROMINENT JOURNALIST MOVES TO WEB
abstract: World Business Briefing: Prominent Journalist Move

headline: VERITAS CASH PRICE FOR ATP IS CUT TO $67 MILLION
abstract: Veritas Capital Fund revises deal to acquire Advanced Technical Products; cuts cash part of deal from $76.9 million to $67.6 million (S)

headline: INDUSTRY WEB SITE OPERATOR TO ACQUIRE SOFTWARE MAKER
abstract: Web site operator VerticalNet Inc acquires Internet software company Tradeum Inc for $475 million in stock (S)

headline: Internet Board Agrees to Overhaul Election Plan
abstract: March 10, 2000

headline: W.T.O. Head Hopeful on China Entry
abstract: World

headline: Ivan Hirst, British Officer Who Revived VW, Is Dead at 84
abstract: Maj Ivan Hirst, British Army officer responsible for getting Volkswagen factory running again after World War II, dies at age 84; photo (M)

headline: The U.S. Scrambles to Keep a Lid on Tensions and to Rescue Its China Policy
abstract: Victory by pro-independence party in Taiwan's presidential elections sends White House and State Department scrambling to prevent escalation of tensions with China; may well change calculus for Clinton administration's biggest foreign policy push in Congress, namely, getting China into World Trade Organization--deal ultimately more about security and China's role in world than about regulating trade (M)

headline: Defanging the Great Inflationary Forces
abstract: Louis Uchitelle Economic View column on failure of jump in oil prices, strong consumer demand and labor shortage to greatly spur United States inflation; questions why bond traders and Federal Reserve remain convinced that robust economy will spur inflation; warns Federal Reserve tactic of driving up interest rates in anticipation of inflation endangers economy; graph of crude oil prices (M)

headline: HYUNDAI TO BUY BACK STOCK
abstract: Hyundai Electronics will buy back some of its shares this year in bid to prop up stock price while auctioning off several of its struggling overseas units (S)

headline: Newest and Trendiest Autos Bring Americans to Dealers
abstract: Every auto manufacturer except DaimlerChrysler AG announces big gains in sales in January; General Motors Corp says sales rose 11.5 percent compared with January 1999; Ford Motor Co's sales rose 4 percent; DaimlerChrysler AG's sales dropped 4.8 percent; Toyota Motor Corp says sales increased 35.7 percent and Nissan Motor Co's sales rose 26.7 percent; figures for Volkswagen AG, Subaru unit of Fuji Heavy Industries Ltd, Mitsubishi Motors and Honda Motor Co noted (M)

headline: S.E.C. Examines Fake Lucent Warning
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating fake profit warning on Yahoo Inc message board that was designed to look like news release from Lucent Technologis Inc; Lucent shares had fallen as much as 3.6 percent before company said it had not issued warning; they rose after Lucent's statement (S)

headline: Twilight Of Turboprops?; Passengers Go Out of Their Way To Catch Jets
abstract: Nation's major airlines, responding to passengers' objections to turboprops airplanes, plan to acquire hundreds of small jets over next few years; beyond replacing most of their turboprops, airlines are also counting on regional passenger jets to expand their reach in smaller markets; Continental Airlines will spend around $2 billion to supplant all its turboprops with regional jets; Delta Air Lines will pay $4 billion for 200 regional jets and start service to 100 cities; American Airlines, Continental, United Airlines and Northwest Airlines will more than double number of regional jets operated by their feeder airlines in next three years; orders are going primarily to Empresa Brasileira de Aeronautica, or Embracer, of Brazil and Bombardier of Montreal; graphs; photo (M)

headline: Paris Journal; A Mayor Fights for City Hall, and Its Foie Gras
abstract: Paris Mayor Jean Tiberi wants to run for re-election in 2001 despite polls that show only 5 percent of Parisians believe he is honest; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Graph plots surge of Swiss franc against dollar on currency markets on March 24 to close at 1.6277, up from 1.6465

headline: ECHOSTAR TO USE OPENTV TECHNOLOGY IN RETURN FOR STAKE
abstract: EchoStar Communications Corp says it got $339.5 million in OpenTV Corp stock in return for agreeing to use OpenTV's interactive television technology on its satellite dish network (S)

headline: OVERSEAS MOVES ARE QUESTIONED
abstract: South Korean watchdog agency weighs imposing heavy fines on Hyundai, Samsung and LG, charging that when the conglomerates issued bonds overseas in 1999, they were seeking not only to attract foreign capital, the stated purpose, but also to defend the managerial rights of founding family members (S)

headline: Aetna Moves to Streamline Its Operations Worldwide
abstract: Aetna Inc will combine its global operations into two main units serving its health and financial businesses as it tries to raise its lagging share price; Thomas J McInerney, president of Aetna Financial Services, will lead financial services businesses, while Michael J Cardillo, president of Aetna US Healthcare, will oversee health care unit (M)

headline: S3 TO POST GAIN FROM BUYOUT OF INTEREST IN CHIP PLANT
abstract: The S3 Corporation, the designer of fast graphics chips for personal computers, will post a first-quarter gain of $500 million after one of its partners bought out its share of a semiconductor plant in Taiwan. The United Microelectronics Corporation bought S3's stake in the United Semiconductor Corporation and completed the purchase of three other former joint-venture chip makers yesterday. S3, which is based in Santa Clara, Calif., invested $90 million in United Semiconductor in 1995.

headline: Ford Posts Higher Earnings, But Shares Still Take a Hit
abstract: Ford Motor Co posts slightly better earnings for fourth quarter than financial analysts had expected, but automaker's shares fall on fears that further profit gains might prove elusive; Ford earned $1.81 billion, up 73.2 percent from profits of $1.04 billion a year earlier; sales rose to $44.42 billion from $37.90 billion; company earned $7.24 billion for all of 1999 on sales of $162.56 billion (M)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: MIDDLE EAST    WEST BANK: PARLIAMENTARY LEADER MEETS ARAFAT -- Yasir Arafat met the speaker of the Israeli Parliament, Avraham Burg, the highest-level public encounter in a month. Mr. Burg said he presented ''the full commitment of Prime Minister Ehud Barak to accomplish a historic breakthrough and agreement.'' But Palestinians cautioned that the meeting did not represent a resumption of talks, which have been on hold largely because of a dispute over transferring land to the Palestinians.   (Agence France-Presse)

headline: Slowly, Slowly, Slowly, The Year's First Dawn
abstract: The first to greet the new day on Taveuni Island were the birds, singing from the treetops at the ocean's edge, skimming along the surf, filling the pale pre-dawn with celebration.    As the glittering surface of the ocean turned from black to iron gray to silver, a flock of crimson lorys landed for just a moment on the red fronds of an umbrella tree, then disappeared.

headline: Losing Privacy in the Age of the Internet
abstract: Peter H Lewis reviews book Database Nation: The Death of Privacy in the 21st Century by Simoson Garfinkle; photo (M)

headline: Gunman in Iran Seriously Wounds a Top Reform Figure
abstract: Saeed Hajjarian, close associate of Iran's reformist president Mohammad Khatami, who was one of main organizers of the reformers' landslide victory in recent parliamentary elections, is shot in face and critically wounded by unidentified gunman riding on back of motorcycle in Tehran; is reportedly fighting for life with bullet lodged in neck; government says it knows identities of assailants, who escaped; attack raises doubts about ability of reformers to carry out program of broader democracy and respect for human rights in face of bitter opposition from stalwarts of system of Islamic rule; photo (M)

headline: In Israel, Making the Shovels for the Internet Gold Rush
abstract: Internet infrastructure Internet, has become Israel's entree to e-commerce; established and start-up companies are providing technologies that allow people to search, find and buy products relatively easily and with some measure of security on World Wide Web (Special Section, E-Commerce); photos (M)

headline: Eaton to Retire From DaimlerChrysler
abstract: Robert J Eaton, former chairman of Chrysler Corp, will retire, effective March 31, as co-chairman of DaimlerChrysler; Eaton says he is leaving because his corporate goals have been reached; Eaton leaves DaimlerChryslers's top management exclusively peopled by company's German executives from former Damiler-Benz; Jurgen E Schrempp, Eaton's co-chairman, will become sole chairman; photo (M)

headline: In a Speedy World, Software's a Snail
abstract: Steve Lohr article says making computer software remains a remarkable painstaking and time-consuming process; says inability to produce faster, cheaper, better software will become a drag on progress in many fields but especially on the development of electronic commerce as an engine of economic growth in the coming century (M)

headline: Stock Surges on Fiber Optic Development
abstract: Shares of Agilent Technologies Inc, test measurement company being spun off by Hewlett-Packard Co, gain $43.25, to $151.25, in New York Stock Exchange trading of four million shares (S)

headline: Internet Capital Group Buys Majority Stake in RightWorks
abstract: March 8, 2000

headline: SHOPPING; The Web Adds Exotic Colors, but at the Garden's Edge
abstract: Web sites devoted to gardening are proliferating, and many feature more exotic offerings than do traditional mail-order catalogues; several sites noted; photos (M)

headline: IDT Says Liberty Media Will Buy Stake
abstract: John C Malone's Liberty Media Group agrees to invest about $130 million for a stake of almost 10 percent in the IDT Corp, communications carrier that regularly takes a leading role in creating new communications niches (M)

headline: UNEMPLOYMENT RATE FALLS
abstract: Britain's unemployment rate fell to 4 percent in December from 4.1 percent; annual growth in wages in three months through November held steady at 4.9 percent (S)

headline: Who Needs Tear Gas?Seoul Puts Policewomen Out Front
abstract: SEOUL—  The national police agency has devised what it believes to be a sure-fire way to turn off demonstrations without firing the peppery tear gas that once floated over the center of Seoul and other large cities during the spring riot season.

headline: Signs of Iraqi Arms Buildup Bedevil U.S. Administration
abstract: Satellite photographs and American intelligence reports show Iraq has in past year rebuilt military and industrial sites damaged by American and British air strikes in late 1998; findings raise concerns among Defense Dept and Clinton administration officials that government of Pres Saddam Hussein is pursuing development of chemical and biological weapons in prolonged absence of international weapons inspectors; administration's policy is drifting despite concerns, leaving US unable to force Iraq to accept resumption of inspections even after resolving impasse in UN Security Council; Iraq's refusal has left administration in quandry over how to respond at time when international support for its policy and for sanctions against Hussein is waning (M)

headline: Managers Shuffled At Omnicom Unit
abstract: Alan Pilkington, chairman of DDB Worldwide Communications office in Chicago, is named to additional post of president for North America and Latin America; Dick Rogers, president at DDB Chicago, is named president for US operations; duties being assumed by Pilkington and Rogers had been handled by Ken Kaess, who was promoted in December to president at DDB Worldwide; Keith Bremer, chief financial officer at DDB New York, is named to new post of chief operating officer; Herve Brossard, president for southern Europe and president at DDB Group in Paris, is named to new post of president for continental Europe; James Best, chairman of DDB in London, is named to additional new post of global chief strategic officer; Michael Bray is named to new post of president for international brands (S)

headline: HUNTINGTON TO BUY EMPIRE, A MICHIGAN BANKING COMPANY
abstract: Huntington Bancshares Inc agrees to acquire Empire Banc Corp for about $138 million in stock (S)

headline: Lebanon Fighting Ebbs in Claims of Victory
abstract: Fighting in Lebanon subsides as people in northern Israel emerge from bomb shelters and US calls meeting of monitoring group to curb hostilities; Israel and Iranian-backed Hezbollah declare victory in latest round of violence, indication that it may be coming to end; photo (M)

headline: The Defector From the Big Board
abstract: Michael Gorin comments on his decision to get his company, Aeroflex Inc, to voluntarily leave New York Stock Exchange and list on Nasdaq; says he felt company was 'getting lost' on Bid Board; photo (S)

headline: Web Attacks Might Have Many Sources
abstract: Computer security experts say evidence now suggests that the three days of attacks on leading Web sites may have been the work of more than one person or group; this analysis calls into question conclusion of some security experts who were initially skeptical that following attack on Yahoo, multiple vandals would have been able to muster large 'copy cat' assaults on other sites; CERT, federally financed computer security organization, formerly known as Computer Emergency Response Team, says it is no longer seeing an unusual number of reports of attacks; security experts say, however, that Web sites and the Internet in general will remain vulnerable for near future because so many organizations are failing to take necessary security precautions (M)

headline: A Whiff of the '80s in a Rich Woman's World
abstract: PARIS—  The brilliant John Galliano can't seem to get his ready-to-wear collections for Dior on the right track. Tuesday's show was a literal translation of his sensation-making couture line, inspired by hobos and the homeless. But without the bravura context of that compelling presentation, with thrusting music, sexual charge, madhouse makeup and political undertones, the clothes just seemed ridiculous: newspaper prints of the "Christian Dior Daily" on bias-cut dresses or visible underpants.

headline: Getting Started; Don't Take No for An Answer, at Least Not Too Readily
abstract: Advice for computer users on ordering DSL service (M)

headline: Procter & Gamble Ends Drug Merger Negotiations
abstract: Procter & Gamble ends merger talks with Warner-Lambert and American Home Products, citing selloff of its stock by investors worried that deal would hurt Procter's earnings; Procter stock, off by as much as 19 percent since talks were reported, recovers after announcement; Warner-Lambert must now seek another suitor or face likely prospect of acquisition by Pfizer; American Home is also expected to become target of other bidders; photo; graph (M)

headline: Rio de Janeiro Journal; Famed Carnival Beaches Incur Share of Indignities
abstract: Beaches of Rio de Janeiro are fouled by series of manmade disasters, turning prime vacation and tourist season into ordeal; have been fouled by series of oil and sewage spills and washed-up body parts; problems are exacerbated by growing number of women who insist on going topless in defiance of police, who have launched crackdown; map; photos (M)

headline: Showdown on Irish Pact in Today's Unionist Vote
abstract: Northern Ireland peace agreement faces crucial vote on March 25 as members of Ulster Unionists decide whether to keep David Trimble as leader or return party to hardline past; 850-member party council will vote on leadership challenge by Rev Martin Smyth, former grand master of militant Protestant Orange Order (S)

headline: NYT Article
abstract: Free Scholarships Site Reports Technical Problems From Huge Demand

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Coffee prices gain for third consecutive day on reduced exports from Mexico, biggest supplier to US; in New York, coffee for March delivery rises 2.3 cents a pound, to $1.1515; graph; chart (S)

headline: Turning On the TV May Soon Require Real Expertise
abstract: Eric A Taub (Downtime) discusses complexity of installing components for new entertainment systems; says with new crop of digital televisions manufacturers continue to argue over technical standards to receive digital and high-digital signals; says trick for people who use number of devices with their television sets is to figure out best connections to use to get optimum picture and sound; offers rundown of options, their results and newest complications; photo; schematic of component connections to television (M)

headline: Keeping Your Laptop Secure on Your Lap
abstract: Lap Lounger, new product from Seaweed, design company, is intended to stabilize laptop computer on lap, keeping it from sliding; diagram (S)

headline: Malaysia Extends Deadline in Singapore Exchange Dispute
abstract: Malaysia announces that it has extended by six months a deadline for resolving impasse on $3.8 billion worth of Malaysian stocks frozen on Singapore exchange; Malaysia had earlier threatened to unilaterally transfer all shares to Ministry of Finance if issue was not resolved; problem began when Malaysia imposed capital controls in September 1998, and suspended trade of Malaysian shares off shore; Malaysian and Singapore market authorities have clashed ever since over how to return shares to Malaysian marketplace; most of investors in shares are Singaporeans (M)

headline: NISSAN LOWERS FORECAST
abstract: Shares of Tokyo-based Nissan Motor Co fall after company says it is likely to miss its operating profit forecast for year ending next month; graph (S)

headline: A Kinder, Gentler Workplace
abstract: Japan to introduce new medical insurance program meant to prevent death from overwork; Danish legislators spar over bill to require pig farms to give pigs daily showers; workers at Lacey, Wash, plagued by droppings from large numbers of seagulls attracted to nearby landfill, carry umbrellas for protection (S)

headline: Fiat Weighs Sale to G.M. Of a Stake In Auto Line
abstract: Fiat is said to be close to selling minority stake in its car operations to General Motors after apparently failing to sell entire division to DaimlerChrysler; Fiat's board may ask negotiators to continue working, especially if DaimlerChrysler comes back with more attractice proposal at last moment; Italian newspapers say Fiat would hand over 20 percent stake in its car operations in exchange 5 percent stake in GM and possibly seat on GM's board (M)

headline: LENNAR AGREES TO BUY U.S. HOME FOR $476 MILLION
abstract: Lennar Corp agreø

headline: An Impatient BP Amoco Tells F.T.C. to Decide on Its Deal
abstract: BP Amoco, frustrated with its discussions with Federal Trade Commission (FTC) about its plans to acquire Atlantic Richfield, takes step to force agency to either approve deal or go to court; action by London-based oil giant, which says it will invoke right to set 20-day deadline for FTC to challenge deal, makes clear that two sides are still far apart about what oil companies must do to satisfy regulators (M)

headline: The New Draw on Michigan Avenue
abstract: Article on American Girl Place, 35,000-square-foot building in 'Magnificent Mile,' Chicago's most expensive shopping district; says store has lured 750,000 girls and women from around world since it opened in November 1998, and in its first year in business has made $25 million more than twice original projection, for its parent, Pleasant Co; photo (M)

headline: Federal Budgeteers Ponder A Multiple-Choice Surplus
abstract: Richard W Stevenson (Economic View) article discusses Federal budget surplus, which everyone agrees is growing but not everyone agrees as to just how large it will be; some estimates of the capped baseline--surplus generated by general tax revenue rather than Social Security payroll taxes--put surplus at nearly $2 trillion for decade; Democrats and some Republicans say this is fantasy because spending assumptions behind it are unrealistic; Stevenson notes four factors to keep in mind regarding any surplus (M)

headline: TECHNOLOGY: Out on a Limb as Technologies Converge; A Merger Sets Off An Information Rush
abstract: The merger last year of Doubleclick and Abacus Direct was the first official marriage of companies that gathered information about people's activities online and off line. Doubleclick, which serves advertisements on thousands of Internet sites and monitors users' activities on those sites, could suddenly combine that information with catalog purchases tracked by Abacus.    Previously Doubleclick had ignored the personal identity of Web surfers, but by using information about users' offline purchases, it can charge higher ad rates. Since the merger was announced in June, Internet advertising companies have forged ahead with efforts to identify people on Web sites, find out more about their offline lives, and show them ads that match that information.

headline: Lilly Profit Rises Despite Prozac Decline
abstract: Eli Lilly & Co says fourth-quarter profit rose 20 percent, to $671.7 million, from net income of $561.6 million a year earlier; sales rose 7 percent, to $2.82 billion (S)

headline: Rise in Import Prices Last Month Is Attributed to Surging Oil Costs
abstract: US Labor Department says cost of imported goods rose in December for sixth consecutive month, led by surging oil costs; index of import prices rose 0.7 percent after rising 0.6 percent in November; excluding petroleum, import prices were unchanged; for all of 1999, import prices rose 7 percent, after falling two consecutive years (M)

headline: New Violence Ends Lull in South Lebanon
abstract: Shiite Muslim guerrillas kill another Israeli soldier in southern Lebanon, and Israeli warplanes respond with air strikes at suspected guerrilla targets; map; photo (M)

headline: Zimbabwe Constitution Vote Is a Showdown for Mugabe
abstract: Zimbabwe Constitution

headline: Interpublic in Deals For Two Agencies
abstract: Interpublic Group of Companies is making two acquisitions for undisclosed terms; Jack Morton Co, part of Allied Communications Group of Interpublic, acquires Production Design Group; Jim Fenhagen and Erik Ulfers, co-principals at Production Design, become presidents at Morton; Interpublic is also acquiring M Gould & Co; Michael Gould, president and chief executive at Gould, will continue in those posts (S)

headline: Bomb Explodes in Northern Israeli Town
abstract: Bomb explodes in garbage can in northern Israeli town of Hadera, injuring 20 people; police suspect members of Islamic Holy War (S)

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Letters to the Editor

headline: Russians Vote Under the Spell of Putin's Many Promises
abstract: Pollsters say Russians clearly want Vladimir V Putin to be elected president, although Putin's intentions remain, so far, largely blank slate; Putin's brief campaign has cast him as all things to all people: brutal warrior against Chechens, dog lover who cries at funerals, supporter of basic rights, supporter of crackdown on politically unruly journalists; Putin has managed to remain remarkably popular because he has religiously shunned any one ideology; beyond war in Chechnya, gamble that paid off royally among voters, Putin's actual policies have been few and uncontroversial; photo; map (M)

headline: Sure, Banks Are Down, But Maybe Not Out
abstract: Market Insight interview with Thomas K Brown, chief executive of Second Curve Capital, financial services research and money management firm, on his projections for regional banks in year to come; photo (M)

headline: Clinton Begins Visit to India, But First Comes Bangladesh
abstract: Pres Clinton, accompanied by daughter Chelsea, arrives, New Delhi, India, for state visit that administration hopes will set foundation for new relationship with India; will make one-day side-trip to neighboring Bangladesh, where visit is being curtailed because of security concerns; is first American president to visit India in 22 years; preparations in New Delhi for his visit described; some major issues besetting US-Indian relations noted (M)

headline: Tribune Co. Is Seen in Talks On Union With Times Mirror
abstract: Boards of Times Mirror Co and Chicago Tribune are reportedly discussing merger; photo (S)

headline: Can't Stay Out of the Headlines
abstract: In bizzare coup of sorts, Financial Times features review of book Sense and Nonsense in the Office, Lucy Kellaway's new book about good management; reviewer was Robert J Ayling, who had just been ousted as chief executive of British Airways for poor management; newspaper says Ayling wrote review about week before his surpirse dismissal; Ayling photo (S)

headline: Microsoft Moving to Ban Long-Term Temp Workers
abstract: Microsoft Moving to Ban Long-Term Temp Workers

headline: RAMBUS, COMPUTER CHIP CONCERN, PLANS TO SPLIT STOCK
abstract: Rambus Inc plans four-for-one stock split (S)2

headline: France Telecom Buying Big Stake in German Rate-Cutter
abstract: France Telecom scores rare strategic victory in jockeying for advantage in European telecommunications industry with $3.6 billion deal to acquire 28.5 percent stake in MobilCom AG, aggressive provider of low-cost phone service in Germany; MobilCom gets strong partner to help bid later this year for a German license in newest generation of wireless phone service, which is expected to flourish as European countries develop wireless systems geared to Internet; deal is significant setback for Stuttgart-based cellular phone provider Debitel, which had arrangement for joint bid with MobilCom when Germany auctions licenses this summer for next generation of wireless phone systems (M)

headline: And Let the Lawyers Sing: 'Glory to the Salary King'
abstract: Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom, nation's largest law firm, sends memos to associates telling them they will receive raises of about 40 percent; first-time associates will now make $140,000 a year in base salary, about $15,000 more than they will at other firms that announced large raises in last two weeks; big increases are latest sign of widespread effect that Internet is having on highly skilled workers in range of professions; Silicon Valley law firms started bidding war over last month and a half to keep their younger lawyers from defecting to dot-com start-ups, and other firms have reacted to keep pace with salaries of California firms, many of which of have offices on East Coast (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: F.T.C. Postpones Decision On Amoco-ARCO Merger  The Federal Trade Commission decided to postpone a decision on whether to block the proposed $30 billion merger of BP Amoco and Atlantic Richfield after the companies made a new offer to sell additional assets, people involved in the discussions said.     While the agency's decision represented the first significant progress for the companies in their talks with government officials, people involved in the talks said the two sides still appeared to be far apart. [Page C10.]

headline: Europe Plans Advisory Unit on Food Safety
abstract: European Commission proposes creation of all-Europe food safety agency following series of food scares on continent; proposal falls so far short of what consumer groups hoped for that David Byrne, European Union commissioner for health and consumer affairs, is bombarded with questions from skeptical press; proposed new body would have no power to inspect food, seize tainted shipments, punish violators or even propose rules; Byrne contends that authority to enforce food safety should remain with politicians; 15 countries in European Union are, collectively, world's largest importers and exporters of food (M)

headline: An Atlanta Developer Returns to Downtown
abstract: Letter by Richard R Espey responds to March 5 article on Atlanta developer John Williams; says he enjoyed living in Williams's development just outside Atlanta from 1990 to 1994 but was troubled that he had to rely on his automobile for just about everything

headline: INFINITY TO EXPAND EUROPEAN OPERATIONS WITH BUYOUT
abstract: CBS Corp's Infinity Broadcasting Corp acquires Paris billboard owner Giraudy for about $425 million; Infinity purchases Giraudy from Deutsche Bank unit, Morgan Grenfell Private Equity (S)

headline: Boeing Bonus Plan For 80,000 Workers
abstract: Boeing Co will offer more than nonunion employees annual cash bonuses if company meets or beats new financial targets; bonuses are worth up to two weeks' salary, with first possible payout scheduled for early 2001; incentives will be based on Boeing's profit; plan is intended to encourage managers to be more efficient (S)

headline: PIRELLI DEAL RUMORED
abstract: Stock of Italy's largest producer of tires and cables, Pirelli SpA, jumps amid talk that either French tire maker Michelin or its rival Continental might bid for company's tire business (S)

headline: India and U.S. Set Technology Forum
abstract: India and U.S. Set Technology Forum

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Intel's 4th-Quarter Profit Tops Wall Street Forecasts  After three quarters of results that disappointed investors, Intel posted fourth-quarter earnings that exceeded Wall Street's expectations because of strong demand for personal computers and a shift toward higher-performance chips that have bigger profit margins.    Excluding costs related to acquisitions, profit rose 15 percent, to 69 cents a share, topping forecasts of 63 cents, while revenue rose 8 percent. Shares of Intel edged down to $91.0625 in regular trading but soared as high as $95.75 in after-hours trading. [Page C3.]

headline: Marketing Executive At G.M. to Retire
abstract: Philip Guarascio, General Motors Corp's vice president in charge of advertising and corporate marketing, will retire effective May 1 after 14 years with company (S)

headline: Mandela Asks For Assistance In Resolving Burundi War
abstract: Former South African president Nelson Mandela addresses UN Security Council, where he calls civil war in Burundi self-inflicted tragedy and outlines his plans and hopes for country as he takes on new role as mediator and enforcer of faltering peace agreement; asks for help from world leaders; says absence of political solutions to long-running ethnic conflict, coupled with failure to reorganize armed forces and integrate rebel soldiers, has sustained situation in which country's population has become hostage to violence from all sides in conflict (M)

headline: Geoffrey E. Perry Dies at 72; Monitored Soviet Satellites
abstract: Geoffrey E Perry, British teacher who used rudimentary equipment to uncover secret details of Soviet space program during cold war, dies at age 72; photo (M)

headline: ASK JEEVES BUYS INTERNET SEARCH BUSINESS IN STOCK SWAP
abstract: Ask Jeeves Inc to acquire Direct Hit Technologies Inc for about $506.9 million in stock (S)

headline: The Suicide, and the Hoard of Cash, of a Top Mexican Official
abstract: Authorities investigating suicide of Juan Manuel Izabal, senior official in Mexico's attorney general's office, are trying to find out where he had obtained $700,000 that he kept in safe-deposit box; suicide is latest scandal to hit country's top law enforcement agency, which Mexican and US officials say has been corrupted by drug traffickers (M)

headline: Xerox Plans Deal To Make Printers
abstract: Xerox Corp will detail next week its plans for alliance to make inexpensive ink-jet printers for small and home offices (M)0

headline: SWATCH PROFITS SURGE
abstract: Swatch Group, world's leading watchmaker, says 1999 profits rose nearly 24 percent, to $265 million; also says sales in first quarter of 2000 appear to be more than 20 percent higher than a year earlier; photo (S)

headline: Business Travel; A rising number of laptop computers are being stolen at airports by organized rings of thieves.
abstract: Growing number of laptop computers are being stolen at airports by organized rings of thieves; Safeware Inc, largest insurer of laptops and other computers, says its clients reported 319,000 laptop computers stolen in 1999, a 5 percent increase over 1998 (Business Travel column) (M)

headline: For the Moment, at Least, Small Is Beautiful
abstract: Market Watch column on outperformance of big blue-chip stocks by small-capitalization stocks that are currently fueling bull market; graphs (M)

headline: Goldman Sachs Proxy Shows Chief Made Over $25 Million
abstract: Goldman Sachs Group's first proxy statement shows chairman-chief executive Henry M Paulson was one of at least five top executives on Wall Street to take home more than $25 million last year (M)

headline: W. W. GRAINGER WARNS ABOUT FOURTH-QUARTER EARNINGS
abstract: W W Grainger Inc warns that its fourth-quarter earnings might be as much as 45 percent less than estimates because of higher costs and inventory troubles (S)

headline: MACHINERY ORDERS ARE UP
abstract: Japan's Economic Planning Agency says core machinery orders to Japanese manufacturers rose in January to 991.72 billion yen, or $9.3 billion, up 0.8 percent from December (S)

headline: Advanced Micro Devices Names a President
abstract: Advanced Micro Devices names Hector Ruiz, head of Motorola's computer-chip business, as its new president and chief operating officer; Ruiz replaces Atiq Raza (S)

headline: All's Not Fair in E-Mail
abstract: Letter by William E Howard responds to Feb 17 article on sharing e-mail accounts between husband and wife; says good relationship also calls for willingness to have some privacy

headline: Members of Congress Attack Tax Loophole for Insurers
abstract: Members of Congress from both parties call for inquiry into tax shelter that makes it possible for American insurance companies to stop paying income taxes by moving their headquarters to Bermuda; Sen Charles E Grassley, second-ranking Republican on Senate Finance Committee, calls for re-examination; Reps Mark Foley and Lloyd Doggett of House Ways and Means Committee says shelter must be shut down, in part because it will encourage other companies to move offshore or ask for similar big tax breaks (M)

headline: John Hancock Sells Stock In a $1.7 Billion Conversion
abstract: John Hancock Financial Services, 15th-largest life insurer in US, raises $1.734 billion in initial sale of stock that is priced at $17 each; sale of 102 million shares ends 137 years of ownership of John Hancock Mutual Insurance Co by its policyholders; John Hancock also distributes 229.7 million shares of stock to policyholders in exchange for their ownership of company (M)

headline: An Editor's Heavy Load In Reshaping Harper's Bazaar
abstract: In a battle that features elements of Greek drama, Katherine Betts, the 35-year-old editor in chief of Harper's Bazaar, must take on her former mentor, Anna Wintour, the editor in chief of Vogue magazine, as she reshapes Hearst Magazine's faltering 132-year-old fashion flagship.     Ms. Betts, who was hired after the previous editor, Liz Tilberis, died last spring, has said she plans to take more of a lifestyle approach and pay more attention to celebrities, in the spirit of magazines like In Style, published by Time Warner's Time Inc.

headline: Demand for Technology Shares Drives Nasdaq to Record
abstract: Nasdaq composite index closes at record 4,321.77, up 77.63 points, or 1.8 percent; Dow Jones industrial average drops 58.01 points, or 0.5 percent, to 10,905.79; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index falls 0.13 point, to 1,424.24; graph; charts (M)

headline: Former iVillage Officials Sue the Company
abstract: Joanne O'Rourke Hindman, iVillae Inc's former chief financial officer, and Steven D Carter, former vice president, file lawsuits contending that concern lured them with promises of lucrative compensation packages it had no intention of delivering; former executives further contend that they left secure positions at other companies when iVillage aggressively recruited them through 'a calculated pattern' of deceptive practices; suits name iVillage's chief executive Candice Carpenter and seeks unspecified damages (S)

headline: STANDOFF ON ARMS POSES NEW THREAT TO ULSTER ACCORD
abstract: Gerry Adams, president of Sinn Fein, rules out possibility that Irish Republicn Army will meet Jan 31 deadline for beginning to disarm, throwing the future of the fragile Northern Ireland peace settlement into turmoil; Seamus Mallon, senior official of largest Catholic party in Northern Ireland, charges that IRA cannot continue to claim to act on behalf of the people of Ireland while defying their clearly expressed will that decommissioning happen now; Ulster Unionists indicate that they will consider a report of no progress as cause to withdraw their leadership positions in Northern Ireland assembly and the new cross-border political structures with Republic of Ireland (M)

headline: INGERSOLL-RAND AGREES TO SELL PUMP UNIT TO FLOWSERVE
abstract: Ingersoll-Rand Co to sell its pump unit to Flowserve Corp for $775 million in cash in a deal that would make Flowserve the world's second-largest maker of pumps (S)

headline: ´Simpsons´ Producer Plans Animation
abstract: 'Simpsons' Producer Plans Animation

headline: Palestinians Freeze Peace Talks And Release a Militant Leader
abstract: Middle East peace efforts suffer additional setback as Palestinian Authority freezes talks with Israel and releases from prison Dr Abdel-Aziz Rantisi, charismatic Islamic fundamentalist leader who is outspoken opponent of peace effort and Authority itself; US and Israel interpret move as provocative and intentional; outlook for peace is further complicated as Israel conducts air strikes in southern Lebanon against Hezbollah guerrillas in retaliation for deaths of five Israeli soldiers in past two weeks; escalation may affect resumption of talks with Syria, which Israel holds responsible for recent fighting in Lebanon; leaves Israeli Prime Min Ehud Barak, whose agenda has focused almost entirely on peacemaking since taking office in July 1999, struggling on two fronts at once; photos (M)

headline: U.S. Removes More Limits On Encryption
abstract: The Clinton administration today lifted more of the licensing requirements on software products that are used to keep computer data and communications secure after industry complaints last fall that its efforts to rewrite the rules still placed American companies at a disadvantage.    Under the new rules, virtually any program sold on the retail market to encrypt data can be sold overseas after what the Commerce Department said today would be a ''one-time review'' to give it an exemption from export license. But more important, for the first time the administration said it would allow the export, without licenses, of most types of ''source code,'' the computer code used to create programs that encrypt data. The only exceptions would be to nations on the State Department's terrorist list, including Cuba, Iran, Iraq, Libya and Sudan.

headline: 3Com's Shares Surge in Anticipation of Offering
abstract: Shares in 3Com Corp surge to record high in anticipation of initial public offering of its Palm Inc unit; after close of market, Palm sells 23 million shares, or 4.1 percent stake, at $38 each, valuing company at about $21 billion; 3Com shares close at $104.125, up $6.125 (S)

headline: PRIVATE SECTOR; Nurturing Diplomacy At the Waldorf-Astoria
abstract: Alon Ben-Gurion comments on how he, grandson of David Ben-Gurion, got into hospitality business, becoming manager of Waldorf-Astoria in New York; photo (S)

headline: Priceline.com's Latest Turn Takes It to the Gas Station
abstract: Priceline.com says it will begin offering people a way to shop around and bid, via the Internet, for lowest gasoline prices in their neighborhoods; promises savings of 10 cents to 20 cents a gallon, as long as customers give a choice of at least three gas stations they would be willing to patronize, and do not insist on buying a particular brand; prices will be paid ahead of time online; discounts will be subsidized by paid online advertising, as well as payments, described by company as 'a few cents a gallon,' from local gas stations that sign up for program; program, which will not go into effect until May 20, limits each household's purchases to 50 gallons a month (M)

headline: Theglobe.com Founders Step Down as Co-Chief Executives
abstract: January 27, 2000

headline: Confronting the Reality Of a Health Care Vision
abstract: Healtheon/WebMD hopes to transform nation's unruly, fragmented health system into digitally disciplined online universe; vision is to link patients, doctors and insurers online, promoting self-help for patients while saving time and money by eliminating paperwork and insurance company phone centers; Jeffrey T Arnold, chief executive, says company now has assets in place to execute its vision, after dizzying array of mergers and alliances announced in last year; analysts say it may take years for Healtheon to accomplish daunting task it has undertaken; company's major stakeholders include Microsoft, DuPont and Rupert Murdoch's News Corp; photos; chart; graph (M)

headline: Luxury Sportswear Casually Trumps the Suit
abstract: MILAN—  As dress codes in the workplace continue to ease up, the race is on to find a comfortable alternative to the conventional suit and a new generation of designers see sportswear as the best solution.

headline: Religious Sequel To Start Next Week
abstract: Outdoor ad campaign created by SmithAgency.com, which generated considerable attention when it began in 1998 because it was presented as signed by 'God,' is inspiring sequel by anonymous donor; new campaign will be signed by 'God' and will cover topics like sex, hatred and alcohol and drug abuse (S)

headline: Nasdaq Wants to Delay Switch to Decimals
abstract: Nasdaq stock market tells Securities and Exchange Commission that it will not be able to comply with commission's order that all stock markets begin trading stocks in decimals, rather than fractions, on July 3; New York Stock Exchange says that exchange is ready to move to decimals by July 3 deadline (S)

headline: Charges of Fraud At Sterling Foster
abstract: Former managers and sales representatives with Sterling Foster & Co, defunct New York brokerage firm, are accused of defrauding investors in what authorities say is $75 million securities swindle; prosecutors say Foster vice president and 20 others misled investors about six microcap stocks, including Advanced Voice Technologies; seven others have already been indicted in case (S)

headline: GILLETTE IN DEAL TO SELL WHITE RAIN SHAMPOO BUSINESS
abstract: The Gillette Company, the world's biggest maker of razors and blades, said yesterday that it had reached an agreement to sell its White Rain shampoo business to an undisclosed buyer. The company, which makes Mach 3 razors, Duracell batteries and Oral-B toothbrushes, said the sale would include a factory in St. Paul that employs about 270 people. The White Rain unit has about $100 million in annual sales, including hair products under the Adorn, Tame, Toni, Mink Difference and Dippity-Do brands. The buyer and other details will be disclosed after a final agreement is reached this month, Gillette said.

headline: Saudi Oil Minister Hints OPEC May Feel Compelled to Raise Output
abstract: Saudi oil minister Ali al-Naimi signals that oil prices have climbed too high and may need to fall to ensure stable growth in world's economies; OPEC meeting in late March to debate output levels, and comment is strongest indication so far that OPEC's recent policy of restricting output may change; crude oil prices for March delivery settles on New York Mercantile Exchange at $30.05 a barrel, down one cent, after selling as high as $30.45 during session; graph; chart (M)

headline: US LEC TO RECEIVE ABOUT $300 MILLION FROM INVESTORS
abstract: US LEC Corp, which sells telecommunications services in Southeastern US, says it will get as much as $300 million from Thomas H Partners LP and Bain Capital Inc to finance expansion (S)

headline: EBay Minus the Cash: Trading Haves for Wants
abstract: Number of Internet sites for the swapping of used items have begun operating in last several months with intention of making online swapping as attractive as online auctions; some swapping sites are WebSwap, Swap.com (www.swap.com) and SwitcHouse (www.switchouse.com); photo (M)

headline: For Museum, Online Way Is Only Way, for Now
abstract: Women of the West Museum, unable to get sufficient financial backing for a 'real' space, opens on the Web; first exhibition combines a public mural project in downtown Denver with corresponding online images and text; photo (M)

headline: Nortel Continues DSL Buying Spree With $778 Million Promatory Deal
abstract: January 6, 2000

headline: Merrill's Chief Financial Officer Moves Into Line for Top Position
abstract: Merrill Lynch & Co has put its chief financial officer E Stanley O'Neal in charge of nation's biggest brokerage operation and on track to be next chairman of firm; O'Neal, one of the highest-ranking blacks on Wall Street, is first person to be named to oversee Merrill's 14,200 brokers without having been stockbroker himself; he succeeds John L Steffens, who has been president of brokerage unit for 15 years; Steffens is named chairman of unit; Merrill names Thomas Patrick, executive vice president who once was firm's chief financial officer, to replace O'Neal in that job; analysts and people inside Merrill interpret O'Neal's job switch as sign that he has early lead to succeed David H Komansky as chairman and chief executive in few years; firm's presidency, slot directly below Komansky's, has been vacant since Herbert M Allison abruply left firm in July (M)

headline: Jerry Springer on People, Internet and Chewing Gum
abstract: Jerry Springer, popular TV talk show host, is asked to give keynote address at Internet conference in Redwood City, Calif, called Shout 2000; organizers say they wanted Springer because his show makes stars out of real people in same way Internet supposedly can; photo (M)

headline: They Know What You Listened to Last Summer on Your Car Radio
abstract: Mobiltrak markets device that finds out what radio stations people listen to inside their cars; clients include concert arenas, shopping malls and car dealerships, all of whom pay to install shoebox-size devices at entrances of their businesses; photo (M)

headline: Waste Management Revamps Asset Sale
abstract: Waste Management Inc expects to sell its international assets in pieces, after it is unable to find buyer for all the businesses; company is selling assets outside North America to cut debt and finance buyback to raise its share price (S)

headline: A Top Official Has Plans to Leave G.M.
abstract: Roy S Roberts, General Motors Corp's group vice president for North American vehicle sales, says he will retire on April 1, as company struggles to reverse decline in its share of US vehicle market; GM says his replacement, William J Lovejoy, currently vice president for auto repair parts and accessories, will be promoted on Feb 1 to share Roberts' job during two-month transition; photo (M)

headline: Northwest Airlines Offers New Type of Business Fare
abstract: Northwest Airlines offers new business fare aimed making business travel less onerous; fare will eliminate overnight Saturday stay required for carrier's discounted 14-day advance purchase tariff (M)

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Letters to the Editor

headline: A General Whose Time Ran Out
abstract: Article on questionable management style of Mark H Willes, Times Mirror Co's chief executive and self-appointed publisher of Los Angeles Times, in light of Tribune Co's acquisition of Times Mirror; says during Willes's tenure, executives came and went with alarming regularity as well as strategies; says newspapers were closed, businesses sold, hundreds of employees laid off and costs cut, leaving trail of bitter bystanders; photo (M)

headline: Suicide Web Site Sparks Controversy in the Netherlands
abstract: Suicide Web Site Sparks Controversy in the Netherlands

headline: What Loan Valuations Mean to Shareholders
abstract: Differences in loan valuations are common and wide enough that Securities and Exchange Commission recently reminded funds to pay closer heed to market prices of loans; investor concern that some closed-end loan funds will respond by sharply marking down net asset values has led to drop in prices of some funds to record lows (M)

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of DataBank Dec 31 article which misspelled name of market analyst at Prudential Securities who commented on preholiday gains in stocks; he is Larry Wachtel, not Watchtel (S)

headline: Souped-Up Maps
abstract: Letter from Teresa A Pitts on Jan 20 article on geographic information systems (S)

headline: Kurdish Rebels Tell Turkey They Are Ending Their War
abstract: Kurdish rebels who have been fighting for self-rule in Turkey since 1984 announce that they have given up their war and will press their cause 'within the framework of peace and democracy'; Kurdish leader Abdullah Ocalan has urged his followers to lay down their weapons since he was captured year ago (M)

headline: SOFTWARE MAKERS AGREE TO MERGE IN $180 MILLION DEAL
abstract: OnDisplay Inc acquires Oberon Software Inc for about $180.7 million (S)

headline: The Pope Opens a Door, but Not All Christians Feel Welcome
abstract: Some of world's largest Christian denominations boycott ceremony in Rome celebrating start of Roman Catholic Holy Year because Pope John Paul II is using occasion to highlight importance of indulgences, practice that helped set off Protestant Reformation; gathering at St Paul's Outside the Walls Basilica is one of largest interfaith gatherings since Second Vatican Council, and it is attended by representatives from 22 Christian churches; pope delivers homily on need to repent for divisions within Christianity; photo (M)

headline: Out Magazine Acquired by The Advocate, a Key Rival
abstract: Out magazine, nation's most widely read magazine aimed at gay men and lesbians, is acquired by Liberation Publications, publisher of major rival, The Advocate; Out publisher Robert Hardman will join board of Liberation (M)

headline: Sites Remember the Irish Potato Famine
abstract: Screen Grab article lists number of Internet sites that provide information on Ireland's great potato famine of 1840's; photo (M)

headline: Rift Deepens Between Britain and Germany Over Rover Deal
abstract: Increasingly bitter dispute between Germany and Britain over BMW sale of Rover Group threatens to spill onto streets after British labor unions call for huge demonstration on April 1 to protest thousands of job losses expected from deal; British Prime Min Tony Blair's spokesman says Blair is furious that BMW had not consulted his government in merger talks; BMW announced last week that its was selling Rover's main car production plant in Longbridge near Birmingham to Alchemy Partners, British investment group; BMW also said it would sell Rover's profitable Land Rover sport utility vehicle division to Ford Motor Co for $2.9 billion (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: EURO GAINS***Euro rises against US dollar as Federal Reserve raises interest rates and traders speculate that European Central Bank might follow suit; euro gains 0.46 cent, to 97.57 cents, in New York; graph; chart (S)

headline: A Way to Talk on a Cell Phone Without a Word Being Spoken
abstract: Bell Laboratories, research and development unit of Lucent Technologies, and the Bell Atlantic Mobile division of the Bell Atlantic Corp announce technology that will allow people with hearing and speech impairments to make digital cellular calls using text-telephone, or teletypwriter, devices; Bell Atlantic official says company plans to market phones that are compatible with devices. known as TTY equipment, in its stores and online in second half of 2001; Lucent and Bell Atlantic say they will make technology available at no cost to other wireless carriers and handset manufacturers; photo of portable text-telephone devices that connect with cellular phones (M)

headline: A Look at the Numbers in Internet Commerce
abstract: Despite oversized advertising spending, almost none of the new Internet companies appear to have gotten any traction this Christmas; rather, it was Internet affiliates of well-known store chains, such as Toys 'R' Us and Gap, that surged to top of ratings; chart on how dot.coms fared in 10 areas, including department stores, electronics and apparel (M)

headline: Glory Days of the Incline, Before the Decline
abstract: Joyce Cohen (Screen Grab) article on funiculars, half train, half elevator, that are often billed as world's shortest, steepest or shortest-steepest railway; says this type of transport, used for ascending and decending steep hills, is far more common in Europe than in the US; says two biggest funicular attractions in US are Lookout Mountain, Tennessee-Georgia border, and Royal Gorge Bridge and Park, near Pikes Peak, Colo; says there are number of Web sites devoted to funiculars, but the definitive site is run by Michel Azema of France (www.imaginet.fr/åmikeaz); photo (M)

headline: Minimal Research Prepared On AOL-Time Warner Deal
abstract: America Online-Time Warner Inc merger, which is biggest combination ever of major Internet company with traditional company, has gone largely uncovered by analysts like Merrill Lynch and Goldman, Sachs; almost six weeks afer announcement, merger firsm have failed to produce comprehensive look at combined company's prospects; supporters of merger say paucity of research is at least part of reason America Online's stock has lost nearly a third of its value since combination was annonced on Jan 10; graph (M)

headline: WALES UTILITY IN TALKS
abstract: Shares of Wales-based Hyder PLC rise 48 percent after company confirms it is in talks with several suitors about being acquired; graph (S)

headline: ADIDAS TESTING SHIRTS
abstract: Adidas Salomon AG says it is testing its soccer shirts for contamination, one day after German retailers pull Nike soccer shirts off shelves on suspicions they contain dangerous chemical tributyltin (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)

headline: ABC and Time Warner Extend Deadline
abstract: ABC and Time Warner Cable agree to another last-minute extension to keep ABC's Houston station on Time Warner cable system to Mar 31 while talks continue on how cable company will compensate ABC (S)

headline: Rylstone Journal; The Stately 'Calendar Girls' Dressed So Simply in Pearls
