abstract: Eleven members of Rylstone, England, chapter of Women's Institute, aged 45 to 66, provoke wide-eyed interest by posing nude and substituting photos on their annual calendar, instead of usual images of watery sunsets and hiking paths bursting with buttercups, in ploy to raise money for leukemia research; wholesome rural service organization, better known for 'jam and Jerusalem'--home of bottled preserves from English country kitchens and Blake poem enshrining 'England's green and pleasant land'--raises $550,000 from calender sales, surpassing projected $2,000, and even wins unexpected praise from thousands of middle-aged women who say calender has restored their own flagging self-esteem; photos; map (M)

headline: Blue Chips Falter as Nasdaq Sets Another Record High
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average declines 99.59, to 11,251.71; Nasdaq composite index gains 45.89, to record 4,235.40; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index declines 4.21, to 1,441.36; graphs; chart on stocks with largest price percentage gains and losses (M)

headline: 37 Hurt and 248 Held in Clash Of Students and Mexico's Police
abstract: Students and workers opposed to nine-month strike at National Autonomous University of Mexico clash with strikers in battle that leaves at least 37 people injured and 248 under arrest in Mexico City (M)

headline: For Ireland and U.S., a Lost Chance on Terror Plot
abstract: Irish and US authorities believe that release of five North African immigrants rounded up in Dublin may have cost them chance to learn more about terrorist network; one of five, Hamid Aich, may have ties with Ahmed Ressam, who was arrested in Seattle in December after explosives were found in his car; Irish officials decided to question Algerians and Libyans in Dublin, and US officials say they asked that five be held (M)

headline: PERSONAL BUSINESS; Protecting Your Good Name
abstract: Here are some ways to avoid becoming a victim of identity fraud.  * Guard your Social Security number and other identification numbers. Give them only to people you trust. Do not give out personal information on the phone, through the mail or over the Internet unless you have initiated the contact or know the person with whom you're dealing.

headline: Remnants of Schism Vivid At Gathering of Christians
abstract: Pope John Paul II attends ecumenical meeting in Jerusalem given by Diodoros I, Greek Orthodox Patriarch of Jerusalem; meeting underlines deep divisions among Christians in Holy Land; schism between Catholicism and Orthodoxy dates back more than 1,000 years; fear that Roman Catholic church uses its resources and clout to convert Orthodox believers is acute in Israel; photo (M)

headline: Even Through Coal Dust, Russia's Miners See Putin With Sharp Skepticism
abstract: Russian coal miners in Shakhty 600 miles south of Moscow find themselves, like other Russians, trying to decide whether to support front-running Vladimir V Putin, acting president, in presidential elections or to cast protest vote for one of other 10 candidates; many express skepticism; accuse Putin of continuing tradition of predecessor, Boris N Yeltsin; coal industry has been ravaged by country's economic collapse and wage arrears are among worst in country; photo; map (M)

headline: The Metamorphosis Of Germany Inc.
abstract: Germany's large corporations are spinning off companies and reducing their stakes in others, encouraged by radical tax plan that will allow corporations to sell off investments without paying capital gains taxes; industrial holdings now worth more than $100 billion are expected to be sold; sales will essentially unravel country's corporate safety net, and to many Germans it comes as shock; experts are convinced that changes are healthy, that German companies are becoming more competitive, more flexible and more innovative; many Germans are showing new willingness to take on risk in their investments; photos; graphs (L)

headline: A Most Delicate Balancing Act
abstract: Lisa Belkin's Life's Work column on balancing career and care for elderly relatives; work of American Business Collaboration for Quality Dependent Care, coalition of 17 big companies that has spent $100 million in last seven years to improve quality of such care in nearly 70 communities, discussed; drawing (M)

headline: CALIFORNIA REFINERY IS TO BE SOLD FOR $895 MILLION
abstract: The Exxon Mobil Corporation, the world's largest publicly traded oil company, said late on Thursday that it had agreed to sell its refinery in Benicia, Calif., and about 340 gasoline stations in the state to the Valero Energy Corporation for $895 million. The stations are among the 2,431 that the Exxon Corporation agreed to sell to win United States antitrust clearance for its $85.2 billion purchase of the Mobil Corporation last year. Exxon Mobil agreed to sell 1,740 East Coast stations to the Tosco Corporation in December and must still sell or sever supply contracts with outlets in Texas.

headline: Job Growth in February Way Off the Recent Pace, U.S. Says
abstract: Labor Dept reports sudden weakening in job growth in February, but nothing to suggest softening of economy itself; employment grew by 43,000 jobs, way off recent pace of 250,000 or more a month, and unemployment rate edged up to 4.1 percent from 4 percent; economists say February performance is mostly result of abnormal weather; stock market investors are bullish about weak employment report, seeing it as sign that Federal Reserve would not have to raise interest rates that much because economy is beginning to slow on its own; but Alan Greenspan, chairman of Fed, has said he also wants to slow stock market, on ground that growing market wealth encourages people to spend freely, thus contributing to inflationary shortages; he was hinted that Fed might raise interest rates partly to cool stock market (M)

headline: In Search Of Loopholes In the Offer By Microsoft
abstract: Analysis of several offers Microsoft Corp has made to settle antitrust suit, including agreeing to separate its Web browser from Windows; says Microsoft resisted such offer for several years but would agree to it because browser war is over and Microsoft has won; says industry studies show that Netscape Communications Corp's share of browser market--about 50 percent when trial opened two years ago, has precipitously declined since then, though precise estimates vary (M)

headline: CAROLINA FIRST AGREES TO ACQUIRE ANCHOR FINANCIAL
abstract: Carolina First Corp acquires Anchor Financial Corp for $300 million in stock (S)

headline: Lands' End Expands Role of Omnicom Unit
abstract: Lands' End, catalog and online retailer, names DDB Chicago as agency of record, replacing Biederman Kelly Krimstein & Partners (S)

headline: E.D.S. and Ariba Invest in Each Other
abstract: Electronic Data Systems Corp and Ariba Inc agree to invest in each other as part of venture to sell office supplies over Internet; EDS will get warrants to buy as much as 7.3 percent of Ariba's stock; Ariba will get warrants for 5 percent of EDS CoNext, unit that supplies goods and services to businesses over Internet (S)

headline: Do Viewers Even Want To Interact With TV?
abstract: Millions of Americans will be given opportunity to sample updated trials in interactive TV in next year or so; several hundred industry executives attend conference in New York to promote their industry and learn from one another; boosterism is tempered by grudging consensus that nobody really knows what public may want; so far, only modest forms of interactivity seem to have won over enough consumers to remain viable; on-screen program guides have proved popular, but companies showing their wares at conference are promoting more ambitious services; photo (M)

headline: Exploring Zulu History on the Web
abstract: Province of KwaZulu-Natal establishes an economic and tourism Web site (www.kzn.deat.gov.za/tourism /kzntour.htm) that focuses on Zulu kingdom as living people and not relic of history; Zulus cannot be studied apart from rest of South Africa in which they are largest ethnic group; other Web sites on Zulu history listed; photo (M)

headline: Japan's Investors Become Bullish On Merrill Lynch; Focus on the Personal Touch
abstract: The ''ginza,'' or shopping street, of this quintessential Japanese town on the island of Shikoku looks much like the ginza of any other moderately sized city here.    Covered to protect shoppers from rain, the thoroughfare is lined with mom-and-pop stores selling everything from ramen to slippers.

headline: Companies Want You To Like Internet Radio
abstract: Audioramp.com and Kerbango offer stand-alone Internet radios that can receive stations that broadcast over Internet and play stored MP3 files with PC connection; both companies have Web sites that offer extensive playlists of audio files; photos (M)

headline: BAE'S NET RISES
abstract: BAE Systems PLC says its second-half net income rose 29 percent, to $374 million, as result of cost reductions that increased margins; company wants to buy back up to 10 percent of its stock (S)

headline: CANADIANS RAISE RATES
abstract: Bank of Canada raises its rate for loans to banking system a quarter of percentage point, to 5.25 percent; banks follow with increases in their prime lending rates to 7 percent (S)

headline: MACROVISION IN STOCK DEAL FOR SOFTWARE DISTRIBUTOR
abstract: Macrovision Corp agrees to buy Globetrotter Software for $861 million in stock (S)

headline: Albright Visits Post-Tudjman Croatia and Hails the New Leadership
abstract: Sec of State Madeleine K Albright visits Zagreb, Croatia, and praises government of Prime Min Ivica Racan; says US will support integration of 'new Croatia' into NATO, European Union and West; photo (M)

headline: Windows Lost And Found
abstract: Q. Sometimes I accidentally move a window off the screen on my Windows 98 system and can't get the mouse cursor on it to drag it back and close it. Is there any way short of rebooting to get that window back?    A. Windows can seem to slide off your desktop if you've just changed your screen resolution and made your display area bigger, or even if you simply have a lot of windows open and are moving them around.

headline: Toys 'R' Us Hires F.A.O. Chief, Hoping to Coax Back Customers
abstract: Toys 'R' Us Inc, hoping to coax back customers, hires FAO Schwarz's chairman-chief executive John Eyler as president and chief executive; appointment comes at critical time for company, which has been operating without permanent chief executive since August, had dismal Christmas and expects to miss earnings forecasts for full year at time when strong economy has propelled sales at other big chains; photo (M)

headline: NATWEST POSTS A GAIN
abstract: National Westminster Bank PLC says its profit increased 6.4 percent, to 1.67 billion pounds, up from 1.57 billion pounds a year ago; second-quarter net income dropped to 853 million pounds from 876 million pounds a year earlier (S)

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: A partial list for this week.  MONDAY    Ft Dearborn Incme  Genl Mlls  Genuine Parts  Met Pro

headline: Wal-Mart Lowers Its Prices At Stores Across Germany
abstract: Wal-Mart Stores Inc. has circled quietly over German retailers for nearly two years. Today, it attacked.     The company, which acquired two German supermarket chains in the last two years, began its first big price-cutting campaign, on products ranging from white chocolate to vacuum cleaners.

headline: TROUBLED LENDER SEEKS PROTECTION
abstract: First Alliance Corp in Irvine, Calif, nationwide home equity lender facing host of lawsuits accusing it of deceptive sales practices, announces it has stopped making new loans and has filed for bankruptcy protection; mortgage company, which has offices in more than dozen states, including New York, New Jersey and California, says that it has closed its loan offices and laid off 85 percent of its work force of roughly 480 employees; under federal law, one immediate effect of bankruptcy filing is to freeze all pending lawsuits facing company and force those plaintiffs, who include many elderly homeowners and AARP, to pursue their claims in bankruptcy court; other lawsuits caught in bankruptcy litigation noted; bankruptcy cases cover parent company and several subsidiaries, including its flagship, First Alliance Mortgage Co; graph (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: * The Richards Group, Dallas, was named the first agency to handle two accounts. One was Guaranty Bank, Dallas, part of Temple-Inland Financial Services, with billings estimated at $10 million to $15 million. The other was Friendly Robotics, Las Colinas, Tex., a robotic appliances maker, for its North American account, with billings estimated at $5 million.

headline: After Space, Hughes Battles Time; Chasing Cable Foes To a Web Future
abstract: Profile of Hughes Electronics, which having developed successful DirectTV satellite system, and its recent agreement to sell its satellite manufacturing operations to Boeing Co, is now moving into content business, taking stakes in programming ventures and, with its funds from Boeing sale, continuing to look for acquisitions; Hughes has transformed itself in way no other military contractor has: moving from military contractor to consumer and business service fields; Michael T Smith, chief executive of Hughes, and Eddy W Hartenstein, president of its DirecTV unit, comment; photos; charts and graphs on company's reorganization (L)

headline: Born to Take Things Apart
abstract: The Boss column profiles SoftBook Press Inc chief executive-co-founder James Sachs, whose company was acquired last week by Gemstar International Group; Sachs comments; photo (M)

headline: Four Are Acquitted In Stock-Fraud Case
abstract: Stephen Kiront, Barry Kiront, John Patrick Clancy and Steven Anello, former executives with defunct brokerage firm of Monroe Parker Securities Inc, are acquitted of charges that they cheated investors of $74 million, after trial in which firm's owner testified against them, White Plains, NY (S)

headline: HYUNDAI FORMS CHINA VENTURE
abstract: South Korea's Hyundai Motor Co signs joint-venture agreement with Kia Motors Corp and Jiangsu Yueda Group of China to manufacture up to 300,000 cars in China each year; Hyundai Motor will own 50 percent stake in joint venture, while Chinese company will hold remaining stake (S)

headline: Thinking Great Thoughts Without Great Money
abstract: Article on Peter F Drucker Foundation for Nonprofit Management; foundation's objectives discussed; Frances Hesselbein, board chairman, and honorary chairman Peter F Drucker comment; photo (M)

headline: Those Distasteful Cookies
abstract: Letter from Bill Takacs responds to Feb 24 article on cookies (computer files); offers ways users can avoid them by modifying browser files and by using trialware product he has found to be excellent

headline: U.S. Fights Tide on a Move to Raise the Military Service Age
abstract: US finds few international supporters for proposal that any global pact on military service age allow volunteers younger than 18 to fight for their country; US allows volunteer enlistments at age 17 with parental consent; Britain recruits at age 16; human rights campaigners seek minimum age of 18 (S)

headline: Private Sector; Software as a Lifesaver
abstract: Computer software developed by Autodesk Inc has variety of purposes, including helping to locate land mines (S)

headline: Consumers Kept Spending In December
abstract: Commerce Department reports consumer spending grew 0.8 percent in December, fastest rate in four months, after rising 0.7 percent in November; that lifts increase for 1999 to 10-year high of 6.9 percent, after 5.9 percent gain during 1998; report also shows nation's saving rate fell to record lows for month and for the year; December savings rate of 1.5 percent was down from 2 percent in November; annual savings rate declined to 2.4 percent, from 3.7 percent in 1998; average hourly earnings rose 0.4 percent in December, more than 0.1 percent increase in November; average weekly earnings rose to $464.37 in December from $462.40 a month earlier; January index issued by Chicago affiliate of National Association of Purchasing Management shows it slipped to 55.6 from 56 in December; readings higher than 50 indicate businesses are expanding; graph (M)

headline: EUROPEAN BEER DEAL
abstract: British brewer Scottish and Newcastle PLC will acquire Groupe Danone SA's brewing business for 1.7 billion pounds, or $2.66 billion, to become number 2 brewer in Europe (S)

headline: On the Road Again
abstract: Readers are asked to submit accounts of good, bad or remarkable moving experiences; cartoon (S)

headline: U.S. Criticizes U.N. Backers Of Iraq's 'No' To Appointee
abstract: Clinton Clinton administration warns against allowing government of Saddam Hussein to exercise veto power over UN decisions on how to resume arms inspections in Iraq; criticizes members of Security Council blocking Sec Gen Kofi Annan's appointment of Rolf Ekeus as head of new disarmament commission for Iraq; Russia, France and China have objected to return of Ekeus, executive chairman of first disarmament commission for Iraq from creation after Persian Gulf war in 1991 until 1997; say Ekeus, who cooperated closely with US, is unacceptable to Iraqis (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   8.50   8.50   8.50       Discount rate   5.00   5.00   5.00       Federal funds   5.50   5.41   4.49       3-month T-bills   5.23   5.26   4.31       6-month T-bills   5.42   5.47   4.32       10-yr. T-infl.   4.39   4.34   3.80       10-yr. T-note   6.53   6.59   4.77       30-yr. T-bond   6.56   6.62   5.22       Telephone bd.   8.51   8.47   6.84       Municipal bds.   6.27   6.27   5.19          (Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Telerate; The Bond Buyer)

headline: Oxford English Dictionary on Web
abstract: Oxford English Dictionary on Web

headline: COMPANY NEWS
abstract: PRIME HOSPITALITY CORP.,  Fairfield, N.J., which operates more than 200 hotels in the United States and the Virgin Islands, said it had sold its five remaining HomeGate hotels to the Amerand Corp., a hotel operator in Texas, for $17.7 million.

headline: Walter Frank, 91, Ex-Chairman of the Big Board
abstract: Walter Nils Frank, Wall Street executive who served as chairman of board of governors of New York Stock Exchange in mid-1960's, dies at age 91; photo (M)

headline: Britain Grants Embryo Cloning Patent
abstract: Britain becomes first country in world to grant patent covering cloned early-stage human embryos; decision could ignite new controversy among biotechnology critics even though Geron Corp, company licensed to use patent, has no intention of creating cloned humans (S)

headline: MONSANTO SPURNED OFFER FOR $49 A SHARE, FILING SHOWS
abstract: Monsanto Co regulatory filing shows it spurned $49-a-share offer before deciding to merge with Pharmacia & Upjohn Inc in deal that values it at $36 a share (S)

headline: Coca-Cola Previews Summer Promotions
abstract: Coca-Cola Co announces details of its major promotional effort for the important summer selling season for its flagship product, Coca-Cola Classic (S)

headline: Mixing the Personal And the Professional
abstract: Saint Mary's University Associate Prof David Kaiser letter on Jeffrey L Seglin's Jan 16 column on response by Atlanta Braves and Major League Baseball to offense comments made by pitcher John Rocker and how business world would handle situation; says managers and executives who behave in manner of Rocker are treated in one of two ways: they are disciplined severely, including termination, or sent to some cursory form of charm school (S)

headline: Internet Board Faces Heavy Opposition on Voting Plan
abstract: March 10, 2000

headline: Saul Steinberg: A Model for Today's Internet Barons
abstract: Floyd Norris comment on resignation of Reliance Group Holdings chief executive Saul P Steinberg focuses on his business dealings of 1960's, including his founding of company called Leasco, company's takeover of Reliance Group and failed attempt to acquire Chemical Bank; photo (M)

headline: Lowe Lintas Forms A Marketing Unit
abstract: Lowe Lintas & Partners Worldwide forms direct and retailing marketing unit, Lowe Lintas Direct, by combining two divisions, APL Direct and Lowe Fox Pavlika, that had been part of agencies that merged to form Lowe Lintas, Ammirati Puris Lintas and Lowe & Partners/SMS; Daniel Flamberg is named to head Lowe Lintas Direct (S)

headline: TRANSPORTATION TECHNOLOGIES AGREES TO A BUYOUT
abstract: Transportation Technologies Industries agrees to be acquired by investor group led by members of its management for $221 million; group's members include Thomas M Begel, company's chairman and chief executive, and Andrew M Weller, its president and chief operating officer (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Platinum futures rise 1.8 percent after Russian exports delay shipments; graphs; table (S)

headline: Apple Chief Rewarded for Company's First-Quarter Results
abstract: Apple Computer Inc surpasses analysts' estimates for its first quarter ended Jan 1, 2000, and grateful board thanks its chief executive Steven P Jobs for company's turnaround by giving him Gulfstream V jet and 10 million stock options; Apple director Jerry York says under Jobs and his executive team, Apple's market valuation increased from less than $2 billion to more than $16 billion, and that $90 million cost to Apple for jet and tax offset is about 6.5 percent of gain; Apple reports earnings of $183 million, up 20 percent from $152 million in year-earlier period; revenue rose 37 percent, to $2.34 billion, from $1.71 billion in first quarter of fiscal 1999 (M)

headline: Austrians Defend Austria, but Views on Haider Party Range Wide
abstract: Review of Austrian reaction to threats from European Union, Israel and United States to isolate Austria diplomatically if Jorg Haider joins government; some Austrians suggest that other countries should get their own houses in order; are concerned about influx of immigrants, who are seen responsible for disproportionate amount of small crime rate; photo (M)

headline: Leak of Negotiating Document Puts Focus on Golan Settlers
abstract: American working draft of Israeli-Syrian peace treaty, leaked to Israeli newspaper, creates stir with its suggestion that Israel is seeking to keep its settlers in Golan Heights after military pullback from area; draft treaty does include two passages that could be interpreted as such, although they appear under introductory disclaimer about not necessarily reflecting views of any party; notion that Israeli settlers would remain under Syrian sovereignty has been rejected by both Syrians and settlers themselves (M)

headline: HILFIGER SAYS EARNINGS WILL FALL SHORT OF EXPECTATIONS
abstract: Tommy Hilfiger Corp says that it expects its fiscal third- and fourth-quarter earnings to be below analysts' expectations because of slower-than-expected sales and price cuts during the holiday season; says earnings for quarter ended Dec 31 may be in range of 58 to 64 cents a share (S)

headline: ALCOA MOVES TO BUY BACK SOME 20 MILLION SHARES
abstract: Alcoa Inc plans to buy back up to 20 million shares, 5.5 percent of stock outstanding (S)r

headline: The Strength of the Internet Proves to Be Its Weakness
abstract: Analysis of recent attacks on some major Internet sites; says Internet's greatest strength has proved to be its most disturbing weakness; holds network's designers acknowledge that attacks exploit same attributes of Internet that have made it one of world's most effective engines for commercial and technical innovation over last five years; says finding ways to contain antisocial acts in such a system--one that by its very design permits anonymous behavior--without compromising its openness is proving increasingly thorny for network designers, law enforcement officials and civil libertarians; charts on how sites were besieged; photo of Attorney Gen Janet Reno with law enforcement representatives and computers experts (M)

headline: USA Networks Takes $500 Million Stake in Styleclick.com
abstract: USA Networks Takes $500 Million Stake in Styleclick.com

headline: Extra-Credit Class: Figure Out 401(k)'s
abstract: David J Wallace article on generation of financial educators that has sprung up to offer money counseling to future retirees; notes younger as well as older workers are keeping watchful eye on their retirement accounts; cites employer efforts to provide as much data as possible to workers; photos (special section, Retirement) (M)

headline: As Relations Warm, Greece and Turkey Sign Series of Accords
abstract: Greek and Turkish foreign ministers meet in Ankara, Turkey, and sign series of accords and pledge themselves to peace, four years after Greece and Turkey went to brink of war over barren islet in Aegean Sea; Turkish Foreign Min Ismail Cem calls accords 'a successful beginning toward a new era in relations'; photo of Cem with George Papandreou of Greece (M)

headline: Revitalized UPN Is at Center of a Struggle for Ownership
abstract: UPN, struggling television network that reinvented itself as network of young male viewer, thanks to its wrestling programs, is at center of takeover battle that has implications for proposed CBS-Viacom merger; UPN is 50-50 partnership between Viacom and Chris-Craft Industries; Viacom and CBS have given Chris-Craft ultimatum to sell its UPN shares to Viacom or buy Viacom out; Christ-Craft wants to maintain partnership to help absorb financial losses that continue despite network's improving prospects; it has gone to court to stop merger, accusing Viacom of violating clause in their partnership agreemement that forbids Viacom from making deal with any competing network (M)

headline: . . . to the Pedicarts That Link Shanghai's Streets to the Internet
abstract: Article on increasing use of e-commerce to transact business in Shanghai, China (Special Section, E-Commerce); photos (M)

headline: In Tribute To Your Year Of Service
abstract: Most companies have abandoned tradition of awarding gold watches to retirees, shift that has not hurt sales of premium watches; shift reflects tendency of workers to change jobs more frequently, retirees's interest in active pursuits and influx of women into workplace; photo (special section, Retirement) (M)

headline: LUCIO TAN'S BANK HOLDING
abstract: Philippine investor Lucio Tan says he controls almost half of shares in Philippine National Bank, making him single biggest stockholder; does not disclose details on price he paid for stock or timing of share purchase; his photo (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: EQUITABLE RESOURCES INC.,  Pittsburgh, owner of a natural gas utility, agreed to sell its exploration business in the Gulf of Mexico, to the Westport Oil and Gas Co., Denver, for $50 million and a stake in the closely held company.

headline: Cyberworkplace Meets Real Work World
abstract: Growing number of current and former employees of Internet companies are starting to talk to lawyers, US Labor Department and state labor agencies about brutal hours and near-anarchy at Internet companies; consultants say unionization efforts at Internet companies have made little headway because independent contractors who make up big part of work force are difficult to mobilize and because many employees seem to take perverse glee in being exploited; Forsyth Alexander comments on her experience at working for Navant Corp, Internet start-up in Raleigh, NC; photo (M)

headline: Technology Investors Tune Out Greenspan
abstract: Analysis of Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan's warnings that short-term interest rates will continue to rise focuses on reaction on Wall Street, where technology investors ignore warning and Nasdaq composite sets new record; says consensus reaction on Wall Street seems to be that little was new in Greenspan's testimony (M)

headline: AOL and Airline To Link Programs
abstract: American Airlines unit of AMR Corp and America Online Inc will combine their frequent-flier and rewards programs as early as May 1 in three-year agreement; program, called AOL AAdvantage, will allow members to redeem points for air travel, AOL membership fees and products; America Online will benefit by adding American's more than 38 million frequent-flier members to its network (S)

headline: France Provides Morning-After Pill to Schoolgirls
abstract: France gives school nurses right to dispense emergency contraception pills to students, becoming first country in world to do so; pills will be available at high schools and junior high schools, where students are as young as 12 years; although nurses are advised to make efforts to inform child's parents, they are not required to; French health and education officials hope policy will help reduce unwanted pregnancies and lower country's abortion rate, among highest in European Union; while measure faces opposition from some parents and family rights groups nationwide, its has found wide supporters in working-class city of Trappes on outskirts of Paris, where many of students come from North African immigrant families who rarely discuss sex with children; women's groups, abortion rights activists and some parents groups see it as major step toward making contraception more accessible to young people; map (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: LUCENT TECHNOLOGIES INC., Murray Hill, N.J., the phone-equipment maker, plans to spend $30 million to hire at least 500 people and quadruple production of parts used in fiber optic gear.

headline: Setback in Court for Big Credit Card Issuers
abstract: Federal Judge John Gleeson certifies as class action suit by large and small retailers charging Visa USA Inc and MasterCard International Inc use their monopoly power in credit card industry to dominate debit card industry; plaintiffs seek $8.1 billion in actual damages, which would be tripled under antitrust law (S)

headline: The Honeymoon's Over
abstract: Henry M Paulson, chairman and chief executive of Goldman Sachs Group, gets his first taste of shareholder criticism at company's first shareholder meeting; questions directed at him noted (S)

headline: Greenwich Journal; What Can the Matter Be? Britain's Dome Falls Flat
abstract: Millenium Dome, Labor government's $1.3 billion celebration of national pride, has become a colossal national joke; British press and Prince Charles have ridiculed it; ticket sales have been sluggish; company that manages dome fires its chief exec and hires as replacement Pierre-Yves Gerbeau, young, energetic former exec from Disneyland Paris, and orders him to fix situation; photo; map (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Israeli Leader Wins Fight Over Banking Nomination  The Israeli cabinet, over the public objections of the finance minister, narrowly approved Prime Minister Ehud Barak's choice of a conservative central bank economist as the bank's next governor.    David Klein, who now heads the Bank of Israel's monetary affairs division, was endorsed in a 10-to-7 vote after a long afternoon of contentious debate that exposed stark economic policy divisions within Mr. Barak's center-left coalition.   [Page C2.]    A Friendlier Anti-Snoring Machine  A chronic snorer has been granted a patent for a device he contends will provide relief to serious snorers like himself. His invention, an attachment to the previously used ''continuous positive air pressure machine,'' makes that device more comfortable to wear during sleep. The inventor said half of those who are prescribed the machine stop using it because of discomfort.   [C2.]

headline: Vatican Outline Issued on Apology for Historical Failings
abstract: Vatican document is released outlining conditions and limits to sweeping apology Pope John Paul II plans to deliver later this month for Roman Catholic Church's historical failings; among errors listed in document are divisions within Christianity, forced conversions, use of violence and anti-Jewish prejudice; document stresses that many acts of earlier centuries cannot be judged solely by contemporary standards, and it draws sharp line between sins committed by church's 'sons and daughters' and church itself; Pope has made repentence one of key themes of this Holy Year and of his papacy (M)

headline: A Few Holiday Tokens In the Middle of a War
abstract: Fighting still rages in Grozny, but the soldiers there made a few bows to the holiday, and seemed oblivious to the political earthquake of President Boris N. Yeltsin's resignation.     In a hospital's mess tent, cooks prepared a special holiday dinner. One soldier, a woman, dragged a yolka, a Russian holiday tree, past a row of corpses and toward a complex of tents.

headline: Adventures in Branding
abstract: Examples of promoting places, events or issues--for or against, in three unrelated areas (S)

headline: German Cleared to Head I.M.F. as Rivals Bow Out

headline: Treasury Set to Auction Bills This Week

By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 5.22 percent and a six-month bill was 5.41 percent.

headline: Group Files a Brief Supporting Microsoft

headline: Influx of New Immigrants Found in Silicon Valley
abstract: The Internet boom is bringing sweeping demographic changes to Silicon Valley, according to an annual report card for the region, which shows that the number of nonwhite residents surpassed whites for the first time in 1999.    The influx of new immigrants, particularly Asians and Hispanic people, also is increasing a ''digital divide,'' said an annual report to be issued on Monday by Joint Venture Silicon Valley, a coalition of corporate and civic groups.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Unemployment Rate Stayed At 4.1 Percent in December  Employers created 315,000 new nonfarm jobs in December, 75,000 more than economists had predicted and the biggest one-month gain since July. With more people entering the work force, the unemployment rate remained at a 30-year low of 4.1 percent, where it has been for the last three months. The report showed that unemployment for all of 1999 averaged 4.2 percent, down from 4.5 percent in 1998 and the lowest rate since 1969, when it was 3.5 percent.    Average hourly earnings for the month rose by 0.4 percent, slightly more than expected. But because workers are producing more for each hour worked, the growth in wages so far shows few signs of setting off a surge in inflation. The figures increased the likelihood that the Federal Reserve would increase interest rates next month.   [Page A1.]

headline: A Rock Shop With Nary a Hammer or Loupe, but Lots of Visitors

headline: Taiwan's President Steps Down as Leader of Nationalist Party

headline: Pfizer Approves $90 Billion Deal for Warner-Lambert
abstract: Pfizer's board of directors approves acquisition of Warner-Lambert for more than $90 billion in stock; Warner-Lambert board is expected to follow suit; merger will create largest drug company in US; leaves American Home Products, spurned suitor of Warner-Lambert, alone again for third time in two years (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Warner-Lambert and American Home Seek New Merger Suitors
abstract: Warner-Lambert and American Home Products are looking for other possible suitors, including Procter & Gamble Co; Warner-Lambert executives have been trying to fend off takeover offer from Pfizer, but last week tacitly acknowledged strength of Pfizer's bid by agreeing to hold merger discussions; Warner-Lambert and American Home are working together because they remain legally tethered by their merger agreement reached in November; Procter & Gamble is considered unlikely partner; stock analysts doubt Procter & Gamble's conservative board would be willing to make sudden shift into drug business, which requires big bets on risky research for big payoffs; cost of merger with Warner-Lambert would be high (M)

abstract: Justice Department Issues A Rebuttal to Microsoft  The Justice Department and 19 states suing Microsoft jointly issued a stinging and disdainful rebuttal to the company's legal arguments last week that it had not violated the nation's antitrust laws.

headline: After Tudjman, Croatia May Look to a Low-Key Leader
abstract: Croatian voters seem leaning toward Stipe Mesic as successor to late Pres Franjo Tudjman in February 7 election in tightening race that hinges more on personality than on policy; both Mesic and rival, Drazen Budisa, are pro-Western and relatively liberal, favor membership in European Union and NATO and are part of six-party opposition coalition that won parliamentary elections month ago, defeating Tudjman's once dominant Croatian Democratic Union; Mesic, whose positions are less overtly nationalist than Budisa's, has been hurt by charges that he lacks substance, that his campaign has mysterious financing and that he was once informer for Yugoslav secret police; Mesic denies allegations (M)

headline: Hostages Land in India After Deal Is Made With Hijackers
abstract: More and 150 people held hostage on a hijacked Indian Airlines plane for eight days arrive safely in New Delhi from Afghanistan after India secures their freedom by agreeing to release three jailed militants; five hijackers leave plan in Kandahar, Afghanistan, where they are joined by the released militants, who include a Muslim cleric named Maulana Masood Azhar; analysts say hijacking may have long-term political consequences in region, helping to legitimize Taliban, Afghan group that helped to end crisis, and further souring relations between India and Pakistan, which Indian officials and press have portrayed as hidden hand behind the hijacking; criticism in India over government's handling of hijacking intensifies in hours after hostages' release militants; photos (M)

headline: Directing Traffic in the Radio Spectrum's Crowded Neighborhood
abstract: In the past decade there has been an explosion in number of wireless devices-- cellular telephones, satellite television dishes and pagers, among others--that has has led to crowded airwaves; so far, range of radio frequencies has been able to accommodate all the increased uses; different uses are allotted different portions of usable spectrum and result has been crazy quilt of frequency bands reserved for variety of civilian and military applications; in the United States, the agencies responsible for managing spectrum are National Telecommunications and Information Administration and Federal Communications Commission; chart on radio spectrum and technologies using lower- and upper-end of it (M)

headline: A Papal Pilgrimage Reaches to the Past
abstract: Pope John Paul II opened the first official visit by a pope to Israel, declaring after he arrived in Tel Aviv that he felt ''deep emotion'' on setting foot ''in the land where God chose to pitch his tent.'' Among the people he will meet are several elderly Jews, Holocaust survivors, from his own hometown in Poland.      Articles, Page A8.

headline: Canada Screening Licenses For Gun Imports From U.S.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: A Senior Official Decides To Leave General Motors  Roy S. Roberts, General Motors' group vice president for North American vehicle sales, service and marketing, announced that he would soon retire.     Mr. Roberts, who has held his current job for 15 months, set April 1 for his retirement, when he will be 61. G.M. said that his replacement, William J. Lovejoy, currently vice president for auto repair parts and accessories, would be promoted on Feb. 1 to share Mr. Roberts' job during a two-month transition. [Page C2.]

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: More and More Companies Deciding Against Dividends  A growing portion of corporate America appears to be concluding that dividends are no longer needed to attract investors and are therefore an unnecessary cost of doing business. Fewer companies are raising dividends, and more and more large companies do not bother to pay them at all.

headline: Dow Climbs Over 11,000 In Wide Rally
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average climbs above 11,000 for first time in six weeks, gaining 253.16 points, or 2.3 percent, to 11,119.86; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index sets its third consecutive record, rising 26.71 points, or 1.8 percent, to 1,527.35, while Nasdaq composite index gains 75.86 points, or 1.6 percent, to 4,940.61; bond prices also gain, with price of benchmark 30-year issue rising 26/32, to 104 25/32; yield falls to 5.91 percent from 5.96 percent; graph; charts on stocks with large price percentage gains and losses and US key interest rates (M)

headline: Global Elite Are Fretting On Response To Backlash
abstract: DAVOS, Switzerland—  When the talk is of digital convergence or financial markets, the optimism, even euphoria, is palpable throughout the conference halls and corridors of the annual meeting of the World Economic Forum now under way in this chic Alpine ski resort.

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Euro sinks against US dollar as investors continue to sell currency on expectations that European Central Bank will not raise interest rates soon; in New York, euro falls to 97.19 cents, from 97.42 on Feb 25; graph; chart (S)

headline: COREL RAISES BET ON LINUX
abstract: Canadian software maker Corel Corp will buy Inprise/Borland Corp of Silicon Valley in $1 billion stock deal that reflects Corel's bet on Linux operating system as a rival to Windows; Corel's founder Michael Cowpland will be president and chief executive (S)

headline: Cable Dispute May Leave Houston Viewers Without ABC Station
abstract: ABC television station in Houston is scheduled to go dark on March 3 in more than 650,000 homes served by Time Warner cable system in increasingly bitter dispute between Time Warner and Walt Disney Co; Disney, ABC's parent, has asked for several concessions from Time Warner for right to continue to transmitting signals from its Houston station, KTRK, on the cable system; Disney has asked Time Warner to change its Disney Channel from premium or pay cable channel to basic channel and to pay it 71 cents for every subscriber to its cable systems, relatively high figure; outcome in Houston, which could spill over to other places, including New York City, will be closely watched for what it could mean for future negotiations between broadcasters and cable operators and how networks might use growth of satellite television service as leverage; Time Warner executives assail Disney's tactics as 'blackmail,' 'terrorism,' and 'extortion'; Disney executives say Time Warner has engaged in pattern of 'preferential treatment' for its own channels at expense of channels owned by Disney and other companies (M)

headline: U.S. Takes Aim At Tax Shelters For Companies
abstract: Federal government issues new rules to discourage abusive corporate tax shelters, which Treas Sec Lawrence H Summers says may be most serious compliance issue threatening American tax system; regulations are aimed at forcing disclosure of new kinds of tax shelters as soon as they are created so they can be reviewed by Internal Revenue Service and banned if found improper before they become widespread; are intended to curb use of accounting methods that have no legitimate business purpose and are intended solely to lower company's taxes; would replace current practice of uncovering abuses through audits, often years later, and trying to undo them in courts (M)

headline: The New York Times: Technology - Circuits
