headline: Kosovo Peacekeepers Warn That Extremists 'Want Peace to Fail'
abstract: UN administrator in Mitrovica, Kosovo, and French commander of peacekeeping forces in northern Kosovo say they are counting on two foreign judges to punish extremists after 12 days of violence; warn unless violence stops ethnic relations will be poisoned permanently; French Gen Pierre de Saqui de Sannes blames violence on both sides; says individuals are instigating attacks purposely to escalate violence and destroy last multiethnic town in Kosovo; administrator Mario Morcone says it is clear who perpetrators are and it is critical to move against them; photo (M)

headline: Indonesian Describes Sectarian Massacre at His Factory : The Man Who Outran Death
abstract: AMBON, Indonesia—  Agus Lekatompessy survived the massacre at the Wainibe plywood factory because he ran faster than the mob with machetes.

headline: IPALCO AGREES TO SELL THERMAL SYSTEMS FOR $162 MILLION
abstract: Ipalco Enterprises Inc sells thermal energy systems owned by three of its units to Citizens Gas and Coke Utility for $162 million; Ipalco is holding company for Indianapolis Power and Light; systems being sold are Perry K Steam Plant and downtown steam-distribution system operated by Indianapolis Power and Light, central city chilled-water cooling and distribution system owned by Mid-America Energy Resources Inc and chilled-water cooling services provided by Indianapolis Campus Energy (S)

headline: The Higher Stakes of Business-to-Business Trade
abstract: Investors are paying enormous multiples for shares in business-to business electronic commerce firms, also known as B2B's; as e-commerce takes hold, question arises who will exert the most control over marketplaces and exchanges, and the rewards that come from them; growing number of software companies and dot.com start-ups are pouring in, enticed by prospect of billions of dollars of transactions, such as in auto parts, freight-hauling services or specialty chemicals passing through Web-based 'exchange' or 'marketplace,' along the lines of an eBay for big business, that they could build and control; analysts say control over such suppliers will ultimately be claimed by B2B players or Old Economy companies they want to serve; Gartner Group says total B2B transactions are expected to rise from $145 billion last year to $7.3 trillion in 2004; charts (M)

headline: 2 Days of U.S.-China Talks Said to Aid Relations
abstract: Samuel R Berger, White House national security adviser, completes two days of talks in Beijing that an American official describes as 'serious and thoughtful'; senior official says that United States reaffirms to China its support for 'one China,' but also stresses need for peaceful dialogue between Beijing and Taipei (M)

headline: MANAGEMENT: THE BOSS; Business Was the Easy Part
abstract: The Boss column profiles Joseph Neubauer, chief executive of Aramark Corp; photo (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)

headline: In Policy Shift, G.M. Will Rely On Alliances
abstract: General Motors Corp, in policy shift, says company will rely more on partnerships and will better be described as 'the General Motors group' ; GM chairman-chief executive John F Smith Jr says company approach is to develop long-term relationships with other companies that offer unique advantage to General Motors group of brands and businesses, speech to Automotive News World Congress, Detroit (M)

headline: Y.& R. and Emotion Form Partnership
abstract: Young & Rubicam Inc forms partnership with Emotion Inc, digital media management company; Emotion will operate Young & Rubicam Teamspace, technology that serves as archive of marketing material that can be shared in real time by both agencies and clients; in exchange, Young & Rubicam will receive unspecified equity stake in Emotion; financial terms undisclosed (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: TIFFANY & CO., New York, a specialty retailer, said it planned to discontinue wholesale distribution of Tiffany brand jewelry, watches and accessories in Europe starting July 1.    PETSMART INC., Phoenix, the largest United States retailer of pet supplies, said it planned to open 50 stores this year.

headline: World Briefing
abstract: THE AMERICAS    CHILE: PINOCHET IMMUNITY CHALLENGED  Judge Juan Guzman Tapia requested that the Appeals Court revoke Gen. Augusto Pinochet's immunity so that he can proceed with indictments against the former dictator involving charges of torture, kidnappings and executions. Should the Appeals Court agree, General Pinochet's lawyers can be expected to appeal the decision to the Supreme Court. General Pinochet has been a Senator for Life, a position that grants him broad immunity from prosecution, since 1998.    Clifford Krauss (NYT)    MEXICO: TAKEOVER AT UNIVERSITY  About 60 hooded protesters carrying clubs and rocks took over the building that houses the offices of the president of the National Autonomous University of Mexico in Mexico City. The demonstrators, who broke windows and cut through steel bars to enter the building, demanded the release of dozens of students jailed after the police ended a 10-month strike at the university on Feb. 6.    Julia Preston (NYT)    EUROPE    RUSSIA: COURT RULES ON ZHIRINOVSKY  The Supreme Court ruled that the ultranationalist leader Vladimir Zhirinovsky must be allowed to run in presidential elections on March 26 despite alleged financial irregularities. Mr. Zhirinovsky had been barred from the race by the Central Election Committee for allegedly misreporting his assets. A court spokeswoman said the judge had not disclosed the reason for the reversal.   (AP)    RUSSIA: BLAIR TO VISIT  Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain will on Friday become the first Western leader to visit Russia since Acting President Vladimir Putin took office. A spokesman for 10 Downing Street said the agenda includes Russia's military campaign in Chechnya. ''Nobody is pretending we like what is going on there,'' he said, adding that Mr. Blair will argue that ''these problems cannot be solved by force without a political process.''    Warren Hoge (NYT)    BRITAIN: 'RED KEN' BREAKS PLEDGE  Ken Livingstone, a Labor left winger known as ''Red Ken,'' defied Prime Minister Tony Blair by declaring himself an independent candidate for mayor of London. He acknowledged that he was breaking a pledge not to break ranks with his party but said that he was justified because the choice of the official Labor candidate in the May 4 election, former Health Secretary Frank Dobson, was ''rigged.'' Mr. Blair said Mr. Livingstone as mayor would be a ''a disaster in terms of crime and police and business.''    Warren Hoge (NYT)    SWITZERLAND: VOTE ON U.N.  Advocates of joining the United Nations have collected enough signatures -- more than 125,000 -- to force a popular vote on membership. The last effort, in 1986, was resoundingly defeated even though Geneva is the United Nation's European headquarters. A nationwide vote will be held within three years.    Elizabeth Olson (NYT)    SPAIN: REBELS SUSPECTED IN BOMBING  A car bomb exploded in the northern Basque city of San Sebastian, injuring two Civil Guard officers and three other people, Spanish news media reported. The blast, six days before the general elections on Sunday, was blamed on the separatist group E.T.A., which is also blamed for two car bombings since January that have killed three people.    Al Goodman (NYT)    GREECE: PROSTITUTES PROTEST  Some 200 prostitutes demonstrated in Athens, demanding that the Socialist government repeal a law barring renewal of their licenses that was intended to clear the city of brothels ahead of the 2004 Olympics. The prostitutes vowed to march to the Prime Minister's office on Tuesday to press their demands.    Anthee Carassava (NYT)    ASIA    VIETNAM: CELEBRATIONS BEGIN  Vietnam began two months of celebrations commemorating the 25th anniversary of the end of the Vietnam War, which came with the fall of Saigon on April 30, 1975. Washington and Hanoi normalized relations in June 1995 and William Cohen will become the first Defense Secretary to visit since the end of the war when he arrives on March 13 for talks on greater cooperation.   (AP)    INDIA: CLINTON'S ITINERARY  Ambassador Richard Celeste said President Clinton would visit New Delhi, Agra -- site of the Taj Mahal -- Jaipur, Hyderabad and Bombay on his visit to India from March 21 to 25. He will land in New Delhi on the evening of March 19, then fly to Dhaka, Bangladesh, the next day. The envoy said it was not clear yet whether the president would visit Pakistan.   Celia W. Dugger (NYT)    INDIA: COPING WITH TB  In India, where two million people develop tuberculosis each year and nearly 500,000 die from it, an intensive treatment program has saved more than 40,000 lives and achieved cure rates of more than 80 percent, according to a review by a team of 25 national and international experts.   Hari Kumar (NYT)    INDIA: DEATH ON THE ROADS  About 70,000 Indians die and more than one million are seriously hurt each year in road accidents caused by faulty vehicles, bad roads, improper traffic controls and other problems, according to Dinesh Mohan, secretary general of an Asian conference on injury prevention in New Delhi sponsored by the World Health Organization.P. J. Anthony (NYT)    INDONESIA: VIOLENCE IN ACEH  Soldiers burned down 15 shops, two houses and a village council office after searching unsuccessfully for insurgents as 27 families fled their homes in the strife-torn province of Aceh, authorities said. It was the latest in a string of violent outbursts in the oil-rich region on the northern tip of Sumatra, about 1,100 miles northwest of Jakarta. (AP)    MIDDLE EAST    YEMEN: POLE TELLS OF KIDNAPPING  Ambassador Krzysztof Suprowicz of Poland, who was kidnapped in Yemen on Wednesday and released unharmed on Sunday after being held for four days by armed tribesmen, told Polish public radio yesterday that he had gone on a hunger strike after he was abducted. ''The aim was to show to these proud and dignified people that they had no power over me and my body, that in fact it was me who would decide the end of the operation,'' he said. The ambassador was freed after the government deployed troops and issued an ultimatum to the hostage-takers, who had wanted to trade him for one of their leaders held by the government.   (Agence France-Presse)    IRAN: PRIVATIZATION BLOCKED  Parliament has endorsed a move by a clergy-based council to block President Mohammad Khatami's plan to revive the economy by ending a state monopoly on banks and major industries. The shift came after the Guardian Council, which reviews parliamentary legislation, rejected most privatization proposals under Mr. Khatami's five-year development plan as unconstitutional. (Reuters)    AFRICA    ZIMBABWE: MORE FARMS OCCUPIED  Squatters occupied at least 214 white-owned farms across Zimbabwe yesterday, defying orders by the police to return home. The squatters are angry about the rejection in February of a new Constitution that would have permitted seizure of white-owned farms without compensation. President Robert Mugabe plans to reintroduce the land provision in 30 days as an amendment to the current Constitution.   (AP)    RWANDA: AIDE AMBUSHED  An adviser to President Pasteur Bizimungu was killed in his car outside his home in the capital, Kigali. The adviser, Assiel Kabera, had been a prominent figure among survivors of the 1994 genocide -- in which at least 500,000 ethnic Tutsi and moderate Hutu were killed by Hutu extremists -- in western Rwanda.    Ian Fisher (NYT)    SUDAN: U.S. ENVOY VISITS  It was a ''mistake'' that Sudanese warplanes bombed a school last month, killing 14 children and a teacher in the rebel-controlled Nuba mountains, the nation's justice minister, Mustafa Osman Ismail, told the United States envoy to Sudan, Harry Johnston. Sudan is under criticism for the bombing of a hospital on March 1 that killed at least two people. Government planes yesterday dropped two bombs on the compound of the Irish aid group, Concern Worldwide, in southern Sudan.    Ian Fisher (NYT)

headline: Madison Avenue considers the benefits and drawbacks of media megadeals.
abstract: Madison Avenue advertising industry weighs benefits and drawbacks of recent media megadeals, including Tribune Co's acquistion of Times Mirror Co (M)

headline: Restoration In Search Of a Revival; Furnishings Chain Hurt By Its Own Strategy
abstract: Article on financially-plagued Restoration Hardware, home furnishings chain that is known for selling quality goods; company, which went public almost two years ago, has been struggling to make profit ever since; sales in stores open a year were flat over last year; for fourth quarter of 1999, which included important Christmas season, sales fell 5.8 percent; company's share price has plummeted from high of $37 in July 1998, to $5 on March 20; chief executive Stephen Gordon comments; graphs; photos (M)

headline: I.M.F. Directors Fail to Rally Around Any New Leader in Poll
abstract: Directors of International Monetary Fund fail to rally around any of people who want to lead world financial institution, and expectations rise that Europe will search for new candidate to keep its lock on job; European, American and Japanese contenders for post all fall short of majority of votes in straw poll; no further poll is scheduled; Caio Koch-Weser, German deputy finance minister, gets 43 percent of votes, Stanley Fischer, American candidate, finishes distant second, with 12 percent, and Japanese favorite, Eisuke Sakakibara, former finance ministry official, gets 9 percent; European Union says Koch-Weser's candidacy is effectively dead and that Europe should find someone US can support (M)

headline: BOOM YEAR FOR WATCHES AND CHOCOLATE
abstract: Swatch Group reports record 1999 sales of $2.21 billion, up 11 percent from 1998; Lindt & Spruengli AG says 1999 sales grew 7.1 percent, to $880 million (S)

headline: Defense in Trial of Ousted Pakistani Leader Quits in Protest
abstract: Entire defense team at trial of deposed Pakistan Prime Min Nawaz Sharif quits in protest against alleged government unfairness; says Sharif is being denied right to speak; cites decision by Judge Rehmat Hussain Jaffri accepting prosecution request that any testimony by Sharif be given in secret and not released to public until court determines that statements pose no threat to nation (M)

headline: New Candidate Proposed for I.M.F.
abstract: German Chancellor Gerhard Schroder withdraws Caio Koch-Weser as his candidate for managing director of International Monetary Fund and proposes Horst Kohler, head of European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, for IMF job; Kohler is not particularly well known or prestigious figure in international financial circles; it remains unclear whether he has support of other countries within European Union, and American officials remain unenthusiastic when his name emerges; photo (M)

headline: News Corporation Studying Merger of Its Satellite Units
abstract: Rupert Murdoch's News Corp is strongly considering consolidating all its satellite-related businesses into single company that could provide Internet service from space to nearly entire globe; News Corp is expected to control new company but could offer minority stake to public (M)

headline: Surging Profits May Indicate a Longer Life for the Bull Market
abstract: As more American companies report surge in earnings, overall earnings growth for Standard & Poor's 500 is on track to exceed 17 percent in 1999; earnings rose more than 22 percent in third quarter and are now estimated to be about 21 percent for the fourth; First Call/Thomson Financial says industry analysts are projecting 17 percent growth in earnings in 2000; even though bullish stock market experts say rising interest rates may well crimp stocks for next couple of months, stocks track corporate earnings over the long run; graph on corporate earnings, 1997-1999 (M)

headline: The Threat From China Makes Campaign Fodder for Taiwan Presidential Candidates
abstract: Taiwan's presidential candidates Vice Pres Lien Chan, Chen Shui-bian and James Soong are trying to gain political advantage from China's belligerent warnings against talk of island's independence; Pres Lee Teng-hui seeks to dispel rumors that he secretly supports opposition candidate Chen (M)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY: Personal Income -- Dec.  TUESDAY: Construction Spending -- Dec.  WEDNESDAY: New-Home Sales -- Dec.  Leading Indicators -- Dec.

headline: Increasingly, E-Mail Users Find They Have Something to Hide
abstract: Dealing with recipient lists in electronic mail messages has become more complicated with growing use of e-mail; use of Bcc, or blind Cc field, instead of To or Cc areas, enables sender to hide addresses of other recipients; using Bcc can be devious in workplace, but is gaining popularity for personal correspondence sent to large group of people, especially among those who have had their Cc lists reused without their consent; photo (M)

headline: TAKE-TWO INTERACTIVE IS ACQUIRING PIXEL BROADBAND
abstract: Take-Two Interactive Software acquires Pixel Broadband Studios for $50.4 million in cash and stock (S)

headline: MediaTalk; A Star Is Born (or Morphed Is More Like It)
abstract: Ananova Ltd, interactive-services division of Press Association, British news agency, develops computer-generated newscaster who will begin broadcasting news from its Web site in April; photo (M)

headline: Out on a Limb as Technologies Converge
abstract: Out on a Limb as Technologies Converge

headline: Opponents of a Golan Heights Deal Rally in Tel Aviv
abstract: Some 100,000 Israelis rally, Tel Aviv, to oppose any withdrawal from Golan Heights in peace deal with Syria; turnout disappoints organizers; photo (M)

headline: A Blanket of Snow Brings Some Warmth
abstract: The snow everyone had been waiting for all winter finally came. The narrow streets leading down to Red Square, usually clotted with traffic, were empty. For all its imperfections, Moscow on New Year's Eve seemed suddenly, subtly perfect.    Muscovites who would normally elbow each other rushing to work flowed out of the subway station and toward the edges of the Kremlin. All that had changed in Moscow and all that had stayed the same in this decade of unimaginable twists was here.

headline: Radio Squeezes Empty Air Space for Profit
abstract: Rush Limbaugh said he noticed it about two months ago. Listeners to his daily radio show were sending in e-mail messages by the thousands, asking why there were more commercials on his three-hour talk-radio program.    ''At first I didn't know what they were talking about,'' Mr. Limbaugh said. ''I was talking for the same amount of time every day.''

headline: Merrill Lynch Reimburses Client For Loss Linked to Ex-Employee
abstract: Merrill Lynch & Co says it reimbursed money to client Arab International Bank and is pursuing prosecution of former Egyptian employee, Ashraf Raffa, who may have misappropriated funds; Merrill pays back about $40 million; Raff was arrested in Egypt on Dec 9, 1999; it is trying to recover misappropriated money through legal proceedings; Raffa is believed to have made several transfers of fixed income securities from Arab International Bank's funds to account with UBS AG in Geneva between 1996 and 1998 by forging signature of former employee of bank who died three months before transactions started (M)

headline: FIVE QUESTIONS for ROY S. ROBERTS; G.M. Official Gives Sales A Once-Over
abstract: Question-and-answer interview with Roy S Roberts, General Motors Corp group vice president for North American vehicle sales and marketing, on decline in GM's market share; his photo (M)

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: THE AMERICAS    CANADA: MISSING MONEY  Conservative opponents of Prime Minister Jean Chretien are demanding the resignation of his minister of human resources development, Jane Stewart, after a government audit found that the ministry lost track of $700 million in job-training and development grants. Ms. Stewart insisted that ''money is not missing'' after the audit found that it had not been adequately accounted for.   James Brooke (NYT)    ECUADOR: OFFICERS ARRESTED  Four colonels and 12 lieutenant colonels have been arrested and 300 officers are being confined to barracks for their roles in the uprising last week that led to President Jamil Mahuad's overthrow, officials said. Gen. Telmo Sandoval, the new head of the armed forces, said the officers would receive fair trials.   (AP)

headline: CAPITAL FOR DAEWOO MOTOR
abstract: Korea Development Bank says South Korean creditor banks will inject fresh money into ailing Daewoo Motor Co as part of its preparations to sell automaker; capital injection involves 1.5 trillion won ($1.3 billion) worth of debt-to-equity swaps, 7.3 trillion won in convertible bonds and 900 billion won in fresh operational capital; domestic creditors have also promised to provide $2.35 billion in trade finance, in addition to reducing interest rates (S)

headline: G.E. Achieves Breakthrough In Gas Power-Turbine Design
abstract: US Energy Department and General Electric Co will announce major breakthrough in natural-gas powered generating plants that will result in production of electricity using 5.3 percent less fuel than best current technologies; while that percentage may seem small, it is enormous by standards of industry in which technologies often compete on basis of fractions of percentage point; Energy Sec Bill Richardson praises new technology; diagram (M)

headline: Kremlin Insiders Acquire Big Siberian Aluminum Plants
abstract: Boris A Berezovsky and Roman Abramovich, financiers with close ties to acting Russian Pres Vladimir V Putin, have acquired three important Russian aluminum smelters in eastern Siberia in deals that would give them nearly full control over country's enormous aluminum industry; Abramovich is already principal owner of Sibneft, leading Russian oil conglomerate; some of Sibneft's major shareholders acquired controlling interests last week in Bratsk aluminum plant and Krasnoyarsk aluminum plant from Lev Cherny, Russian emigre business executive with extensive interests in metals industry, and in Trans-World Metals Ltd, British trading company tht is heavily engaged in Russian mining and smelting; owners of Novokuznetsk aluminum plant announced last week that they sold their 70 percent stake in smelter to LogoVaz, company controlled by Berezovsky; Bratsk, Krasnoyarsk and Novokuznetsk factories together account for two-thirds of 3.4 million tons Russia produced in 1999 (M)

headline: Settlement Reached in Ferrofluidics Case
abstract: David J Chester, accused of being sham investor in Ferrofluidics Corp, agrees to pay $50,000 to settle regulators' charges that he helped company carry out phony sale of $12 million worth of shares in 1992; Securities and Exchange Commission contended Chester was one of five people who agreed to serve as nominal buyers of 620,000 Ferrofluidics shares until company could find acutal investors; SEC said none of four people paid for stocks or planned to do so, yet company issued statement in April 1992 that it had '$12 million of added capital' as result of sham private placement (S)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: EUROPE    FRANCE: TRUCK PROTEST CONTINUES -- Thousands of trucks stayed backed up at France's borders on the second day of a blockade by truck owners protesting higher fuel prices and a government-imposed move to reduce the workweek, without reducing wages. The owners have vowed to keep the barricades in place unless talks with officials produce results.   Suzanne Daley (NYT)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: PANTRY INC., Sanford, N.C., a chain of independently operated convenience stores, agreed to buy 15 stores in two separate deals involving closely held companies. The stores are expected to generate $25 million in annual revenue. The purchase prices were not disclosed.

headline: China's Sniping Heeded By Some Taiwan Voters
abstract: Chen Shui-bian, presidential candidate in Taiwan, is being vilified by China; Chen says this would play to his advantage by raising hackles of voters in Taiwan; but some party officials and political analysts and voters say Chen's identification with cause of Taiwanese independence could hurt him; Chinese newspapers say troops are on alert to 'crush' any move toward independence by Taiwan; photo (M)

headline: Taking the Dangers Out of Hanging Around the House
abstract: Donna Wilkinson article on interior design changes and products to make homes safe environment for older adults; key issue is avoiding falls, leading danger in home; designer Rosemary Bakker cites importance of proper lighting and flooring; photos (special section, Retirement (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: COPPER MOUNTAIN NETWORKS INC., Palo Alto, Calif., agreed to acquire OnPrem Networks Corp., Fremont, Calif., which is privately held, for about $75 million in stock. Both companies make equipment for high-speed Internet access.    SABRATEK CORP., Skokie, Ill., a maker of medical equipment, sold the assets of its intravenous medicine pump business to Baxter Healthcare Corp., Deerfield, Ill., for $48 million as it tries to pay off creditors during bankruptcy proceedings.

headline: Two Utilities Amend a Merger Agreement
abstract: Carolina Power & Light Co, which agreed last year to buy Florida Progress Corp in $8 billion deal, says two companies have amended their merger agreement to give Florida Progress shareholders additional money (S)

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: THE AMERICAS    CANADA: RIGHTIST'S UNITY PLAN -- Canada's leading conservative politician, Preston Manning, embarks this week on a nationwide tour to unite the political right, bolstered by a 75 percent endorsement at the Reform Party convention for his plan to create a new national party, the Canadian Alliance. The Liberal Party has governed Canada on the federal level since 1993, largely because conservatives have been split along regional lines.   James Brooke (NYT)    CANADA: ONTARIO GETS TOUGH -- Starting Monday, the police in Ontario, Canada's most populous province, can arrest people for aggressive begging and offering to clean windshields at traffic lights. In December, Ontario's Conservative-controlled legislature banned intimidating panhandling after complaints from the mayor of Toronto. It is now illegal to beg anywhere there is a ''captive'' audience -- at bank machines, bus stops, or in a line of vehicles stopped at a red light.   James Brooke (NYT)

headline: Vault.com Narrows Review to Four
abstract: Vault.com, career information and development World Wide Web site, narrows review for its first online and offline advertising account, with billings estimated at $5 million to $10 million (S)

headline: Amid Garbage and Disdain, China Migrants Find a Living
abstract: Some 82,000 rural migrants in Beijing, nearly half of them from Sichuan, rummage through city's waste, extracting everything of value and selling it to recycling factories; sprawling enterprise was organized over last dozen years by few migrant 'garbage kings' who have divided up city and made fortunes as middlemen; most of garbage pickers lack documents required for outsiders to live in Beijing; they live in constant fear of police harassment and deportation to their former homes; photos (M)

headline: Claude Raymond, 70, Duvalier Era General
abstract: Retired Lt Gen Claude Raymond, feared chief of staff of Haitian Army and minister of interior and defense during successive dictatorships of Francois (Papa Doc) Duvalier and his son Jean-Claude (Baby Doc), dies at age 70; photo (M)

headline: Finding a Substitute For Office Chitchat
abstract: Many retirees who miss work's daily social interactions find replacing office camaraderie takes conscious effort; some turn to Internet to make new friends or communicate with old ones via e-mail; others end up returning to work, or consulting; photo (special section, Retirement) (M)

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Letters to the Editor

headline: Internet Shows Signs of Becoming Top Marketplace in the Book Business
abstract: A new holiday survey of seasoned Internet users indicates that customers are straying from the bookshelves to buy titles online, with a majority actually making more literary purchases in virtual book shops than in standard stores.    Andersen Consulting released the results last week of an eight-day survey that showed that old-fashioned shopping remains an enduring and robust custom but that books are the leading product that this bellwether group of customers prefers to purchase online.

headline: If Pinochet Goes Home, an Official Welcome Won't Be Waiting
abstract: Chilean government and armed forces decide against welcoming ceremony for Gen Augusto Pinochet if he returns from Britain, where he has been under house arrest for past 15 months on human rights charges; government hopes to discourage strong reactions either by his supporters or detractors on his return (M)

headline: PEROT SYSTEMS SELLS STAKE IN SWISS SOFTWARE COMPANY
abstract: The Perot Systems Corporation, the computer services company founded by the billionaire Ross Perot, plans to sell its 40 percent stake in Systor A.G. for about $55 million to UBS A.G. of Zurich. UBS, which is Europe's No. 2 bank, already owns 60 percent of Systor. Perot Systems, of Dallas, expects to gain $40 million from the sale of its stake in Systor, a Swiss-based software maker. The sale enables Perot Systems to pursue plans to extend its presence with Internet-based businesses and invest in electronic-business ventures, said Mr. Perot, the company's chairman. Mr. Perot said in May the company planned to invest in technology start-ups.

headline: 2 Online Services Appoint Agencies
abstract: New travel services Web site whose major investors include four airlines names TBWA/Chiat/Day in New York as its first agency; billings are estimated at $55 million; Camdens Gifts awards account to Merkley Newman Harty in New York; billings estimated at $20 million (S)

headline: As the Good Times Roll, The Marxists Are Mellowing
abstract: Louis Uchitelle column on how Marxist economists are being forced to rewrite their theories in light of nation's continuing economic boom; says that while mainstream economists see the economic expansion as a phenomenon that can continue indefinitely, until some outside shock or policy mistake provokes a recession, Marxist economists believe the expansion contains the seeds of its own undoing (M)

headline: Naming Names: An Alley Roll-Call
abstract: February 8, 2000

headline: Intel Wins Latest Battle in War of PC Chips
abstract: Intel Corp, seeking to one-up archrival Advanced Micro Devices, introduces its latest Celeron processor for personal computers priced under $1,000; new processor, which comes in 600- and 566-megahertz versions, includes advances that should enhance low-cost computers' multimedia capabilities (M)

headline: Russia's Communists, Still Alive, Await an Opening
abstract: Prospects are almost hopeless for Russia's Communist Party in March 26 presidential election, in which voters will pick from field dominated by Acting Pres Vladimir V Putin; strong general bias exists toward party, which is object of ridicule in much of Russia; what remains of its strength, though still considerable, has been fractured by defections and infighting among hard-liners, nationalists and those trying to craft more centrist model based on social democratic parties of Europe; photo (M)

headline: Ion Gheorghe Maurer, 97, Romanian Premier From 1961 to 1974
abstract: Ion Gheorghe Maurer, who was prime minister, foreign minister and titular head of state of independent-minded Romania from 1950's to 1970's, dies at age 97 (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Strategist Suggests Curb On Stocks, and Prices Fall  Stock prices fell as investors took profits and Abby Joseph Cohen, the influential stock market strategist at Goldman, Sachs, recommended that her firm's clients reduce their allocation of stocks to 65 percent from 70 percent. It is the first time Ms. Cohen has reduced the stock allocation since January 1999.    The Dow Jones industrial average fell 89.74 points, or 0.8 percent, to 10,936.11. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index slumped 16.13 points, or 1.1 percent, to 1,507.73, and the Nasdaq composite index fell 124.67 points, or 2.5 percent, to 4,833.89.   [Page C15.]    The decline in stock prices lifted bond prices modestly. The yield on the benchmark 30-year issue was unchanged at 5.98 percent.   [C15.]

headline: Winners Don't Yet Have the Final Answer
abstract: Interviews with recent television quiz show big winners suggests they have generally taken some sensible, long-term views, but have made some costly errors; most are refusing to spend profligately and are thoughtfully weighing options; photos (M)d

headline: DOUBLECLICK SET TO SELL SHARES TO FINANCE ACQUISITIONS
abstract: DoubleClick Inc will sell as many as 8.63 million shares to help raise about $805 million for expansion and acquisitions (S)

headline: Even S.U.V. Drivers Can Find Ways to Hug a Tree
abstract: Environmentalists and energy experts offer advice to sports utility vehicle owners who feel guilty about causing extra air pollution on ways to compensate in home; note typical SUV generates nearly three tons more carbon dioxide annually than typical car; table; drawings; photo (M)

headline: Study Finds Gaps in Internet Content
abstract: In separate studies by Children's Partnership, Santa Monica, Calif, and Conference Board, business research group, New York, researchers find significant gaps in Internet content geared to needs of low-income and immigrant groups in America, although these groups are seen gaining access in increasing numbers to the Internet (M)

headline: Tandycrafts to Sell Unit
abstract: Tandycrafts Inc plans to sell its Sav-On Office Supplies unit (S)

headline: Tears of Gratitude, Remembering Poland
abstract: Mrs Edith Tzirer, Holocaust survivor, is overcome with emotion at Pope John Paul's appearance at Yad Vashem Holocaust memorial, saying she had waited 54 years to thank Pope in person for saving her life in 1945 in small town near Cracow, Poland; photo (M)

headline: Hard to believe, but the direct marketer Draft Worldwide will acquire the iconoclastic AG.
abstract: Draft Worldwide is expected to announce that it is acquiring AG Worldwide for undisclosed terms (M)

headline: AMKOR AGREES TO BUY THREE PLANTS IN SOUTH KOREA
abstract: Amkor Corp agrees to acquire three semiconductor assembly factories in South Korea from Anam Semiconductor Inc for $1.4 billion cash and stock; plants, which are around Seoul, have about 6,600 employees; purchase will give Amkor seven semiconductor testing and packaging plants (S)

headline: Treasury to Auction Bills This Week
abstract: Treasury's schedule of financings noted (S)

headline: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: AMERICAS; MEXICAN BANK IN TALKS
abstract: Mexican branch of Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria of Spain enters into talks with Mexico's second-largest bank, Grupo Financiero Bancomer, to develop 'program of alliances and capitalization' in Mexico; Spanish bank denies trying to take over Bancomer at this time (S)

headline: Serbs on Edge After a Rally by Albanians in a Kosovo City
abstract: Serbs living on northern side of Mitrovica remain on edge following show of force by tens of thousands of Albanian protesters on February 21; city remains relatively calm, despite attack on German armored vehicle by group of Serbian men; photo (M)

headline: Technology in the Cockpit
abstract: Letter by John Tanaka responds to March 9 article on airline flight recorders; says digital video should be included in data collected by black boxes on planes

headline: Ex-Chairman of Aetna to Get $3.4 Million
abstract: Aetna Inc, whose share price has fallen 35 percent in last year, is paying its former chairman and chief executive, Richard L Huber, $3.4 million to $3.6 million in severance; Huber resigned on Feb 25 (S)

headline: KOREAN TRADE SURPLUS DROPS
abstract: Rising imports drove South Korea's current account surplus down in January, to 26-month low; surplus of $316.5 million was well below $1.84 billion surplus a year earlier (S)

headline: From Disneyland to London Dome
abstract: LONDON—  The former Disneyland Paris executive recruited to revive the fortunes of Britain's Millennium Dome promised Thursday to turn the attraction into the "hottest ticket in town" with sharper marketing and management and a dose of Disney-style fun and excitement.

headline: World Briefing
abstract: EUROPE    BRITAIN: ANTI-PUNISHMENT LAW  Parents who smack their children on the head or beat them anywhere on their bodies with objects like canes or belts could face jail under a new law being formulated by the government. Britain has to bring its laws into compliance with decisions outlawing corporal punishment by the European Court of Human Rights despite polls showing that most British parents are against the changes.     Warren Hoge (NYT)

headline: U.S. to Drop Longtime Ban On Luxuries From Iran
abstract: Clinton administration is about to ease import bans on some Iranian consumer goods to encourage reformers in Iran who recently won victory in elections for Parliament (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: FEDEX CORP.,  Memphis, the largest overnight-delivery company, said it would buy a shipping unit, Tower Group International, Buffalo, from McGraw-Hill Cos., New York, publisher of Business Week magazine and textbooks, for an undisclosed price and create a new division, FedEx Trade Networks Inc., to help businesses with international shipping.    INDEPENDENT BANKSHARES INC.,  Abilene, Tex., an owner of more than a dozen banks in West Texas, said it had received an acquisition proposal of about $45.5 million from State National Bankshares Inc., Lubbock, Tex.

headline: Luce's Magazine Was First Information 'Portal'
abstract: History of Time Warner Inc in light of America Online Inc's acquisition of company; notes company was founded in 1923 when Henry R Luce and Briton Hadden, with borrowed $86,375, introduced Time magazine; chart on major events in company history, 1923-2000; photos (M)

headline: A Different Kind of Test Puts Value Funds at the Bottom
abstract: Study from Morningstar Inc says value funds lag behind their growth-oriented rivals in socially conscious investing as well as performance-wise (S)

headline: SLOW RESTART AT VW PLANT
abstract: Volkswagen's South African plant reopens one week after wildcat strike forces it to close, but more than half the workers stay away, and production does not resume; workers called strike in protest over union's suspension of 13 shop stewards (S)

headline: Round, Opulent and Very Young and Hip
abstract: PARIS—  Ever since queens and courtesans began to emphasize their necks with precious opalescent spheres, pearl necklaces have been every woman's best friend. In the 1930s, Coco Chanel wore her sumptuous rope of natural pearls — the token of a grand duke's affection — mixed with a cluster of costume jewelry, inventing a style that was to become a classic. In the '50s, their image became proper and ladylike. A few seasons ago, John Galliano triggered a new craze for pearls when he dressed up a Dior collection with spectacular pearl chokers.

headline: Tobacco Companies Are Sued By Distributors Over Pricing
abstract: US cigarette wholesalers file lawsuit against five leading tobacco companies, accusing them of illegally fixing prices; wholesalers say tobacco companies convened regularly to rig prices to wholesalers and distributors; Michael York, spokesman for Philip Morris Companies, says cases have no legal merit; R J Reynolds Tobacco Holdings denies any wrongdoing; suit accuses companies of raising prices charged to cigarette distributors within hours and sometimes minutes of each other; also named as defendants are Brown & Williamson Tobacco unit of British American Tobacco; Lorillard unit of Loews Corp, and Liggett Group, unit of Brooke Group Ltd (M)

headline: PBS Reported Ready to Name A CNN Executive to Top Post
abstract: Public Broadcasting Service will name Pat Mitchell, longtime program executive for Turner Broadcasting, president, succeeding Ervin Duggan, who resigned in September; Mitchell is currently president of CNN productions; official announcement is scheduled for Feb 7 (M)

headline: Business and Investors Hope Putin Acts Quickly
abstract: Foreign investors and businesses comment on stated plans by Vladimir V Putin, Russia's president-elect, to create sounder economy and friendlier investment climate; say Putin must take decisive action in next few months for country to see marked increases in investment (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: European Union to Back German Official for I.M.F.  The European Union appears set to back a German finance ministry official to head the International Monetary Fund, giving a boost to a candidate Clinton administration officials privately argue is ill-suited for the job.

headline: WILLIS STEIN PAYS $282 MILLION FOR MAJORITY OF ORIUS
abstract: Willis Stein & Partners, leading private equity investment firm based in Chicago, acquires a majority stake in Orius Corp of West Palm Beach, Fla, for $282 million and merges it with LISN Inc, in which it already has controlling interest (S)

headline: BRAZILIAN POWER PURCHASE
abstract: Consortiums

headline: VIDEO GAMES FALL SHORT
abstract: Eidos PLC warns that this year's results will be well below expectations; cites factors; photo (S)

headline: Seeing Fickle Fingers In a Nasdaq Downturn
abstract: Interview with portfolio manager Kevin Landis (Firsthand Funds) on sharp 1999 run-up in Nasdaq stocks and this week's sell-off; photo (M)

headline: Teenager Denies Involvement in Crippling Net Assault
abstract: Teenager Denies Involvement in Crippling Net Assault

headline: FREESERVE SALES RISE
abstract: Freeserve P.L.C., the British provider of free Internet access, said its revenues increased to $:3.8 million ($6.25 million), beating expectations for its second quarter, which ended Nov. 13. The company, Britain's largest Internet service, lost $:3.6 million before exceptional items.   Andrew Ross Sorkin

headline: CARNIVAL AND FAIRFIELD END MERGER PLANS
abstract: Carnival Corp and Fairfield Communities Inc end previously announced plan to merge; on Jan 24, Carnival signed letter of intent to acquire Fairfield for about $775 million, including debt (S)

headline: Cell Phone Thieves Try to Stay a Step Ahead
abstract: Theft of cellular telephones and their identifying numbers (cloning) continue to be problem but safeguards in recent years have made cloning much harder to accomplish; Cellular Telephone Association, Washington, reports revenue lost by carriers because of calls made on stolen phones dropped to $166 million in 1999, down from $850 million in 1996; AT&T; official links decline in cloning to robust attack by telephone industry against it; Secret Servie agent Chip Smith comments on problem; Les Wilkinson, executive with Professional Security Bureau, loss-prevention and investigative services organization, NJ, cites statistics showing drop in cell phone fraud in part reflects lower costs of cell phone calls; photos (M)

headline: Swiss Voters Will Assess Immigrants, Stirring Alarm
abstract: Citizens in Emmen, Switzerland, population 27,000, on March 12 will vote on 56 people in town who are seeking naturalization; critics fear that process for determining naturalization is gaining ground in larger cities (M)

headline: Compressed Data; New AT&T System Displays a 'Millionaire' Bonus
abstract: Computer display at opening of AT&T's new network operations center, Bedminster, NJ, shows spectacular spike in business calls at end of television program Who Wants to be a Millionaire, representing hundreds of thousands of calls to toll-free line for would-be contestants; photo (S)

headline: INFINITY TO BUY 2 SAN ANTONIO RADIO STATIONS FOR STOCK
abstract: Infinity Broadcasting Corp acquires radio stations KTFM-FM and KTSA-AM in San Antonio from Waterman Broadcasting Corp for about $90 million in stock (S)

headline: Virginia Is First With Controversial Software Law
abstract: March 14, 2000

headline: CHIRON SHARES DROP SHARPLY ON RESULTS OF DRUG STUDY
abstract: Shares of Chiron Corp lose almost a quarter of their value after company's experimental heart drug, known ans FGF, appears ineffective in large-scale study; shares of Chiron fall $14.1875, to $45.75 (S)

headline: Sex and the Cybermale:Style for Virtual Vikings
abstract: MILAN—  Even before the AOL/Time Warner deal was inked, designers had set their sites on the cyber male. As though responding to the sudden arrival of a confident, even cocky, 20-something generation, conquerors of the virtual world, the Italian menswear shows offered streamlined, stylish, luxurious collections to help cyber millionaires part with their cash.

headline: At Akamai, Aloha to Decorum
abstract: Paul Sagan, president of Akamai Technologies, Cambridge, Mass, loses bet that his sales staff could not sign up 200 clients by Dec 31 and puts on coconut bra and grass skirt to hula dance for management earlier this month; company's name in Hawaiian means 'intelligent and clever'; Sagan photo (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Hong Kong has recovered its appetite for speculation.
abstract: Mark Landler (Market Place) column on Tom.com, month-old Chinese-language Internet service; says tens of thousands of Hong Kong residents besieged local banks to buy shares in its initial stock offering, which was oversubscribed by over 1000 percent; company is majority owned by flagship companies of Li Ka-shing; photo (M)

headline: Get ready: That guy from Brooklyn asks 20 more questions on advertising, marketing and media.
abstract: Stuart Elliott's Advertising column asks 20 questions on advertising, marketing and media (M)

headline: 724 SOLUTIONS IS ACQUIRING TWO SOFTWARE COMPANIES
abstract: 724 Solutions Inc acquires ezlogin.com for about $115.6 million and YRLess Internet Corp for about $5.8 million in cash and stock (S)

headline: AOL 5.0: Takeover Artist
abstract: Peter H Lewis column on user complaints about American Online upgrade, which can disable network configurations needed to gain access to Internet through other service providers; notes AOL, which faces class-action suit, holds upgrade seeks to make customers' computers easier to use; drawing (M)

headline: First Jury Conviction of Internet Gambling
abstract: First Jury Conviction of Internet Gambling

headline: Modigliani's Message: It's a Bubble, and Bubbles Will Burst
abstract: Floyd Norris column on interview with Dr Franco Modigliani, who believes current mania for Internet and other technology stocks is not irrational, but it is a bubble, and it will burst; says Modigliani thinks Dow Jones industrial average could fall to 8,000 or 9,000, but that technology stocks are far more vulnerable; photo (M)

headline: The Software Side Of Hardware Stores
abstract: Michelle Slatalla (Online Shopper) column discusses buying hardware supplies online; says with inventories that range from 25,000 to 45,000 items, biggest online stores can offer selection that can rival that of typical Home Depot warehouse store; says some online sites also offer instant online advice; lists some sites; photo (M)

headline: Predictions for the Top Tech Issues in Schools
abstract: January 5, 2000

headline: Lights, Camera, Marriage and Big Ratings
abstract: Fox Television broadcasts two-hour special, Who Wants to Marry a Multimillionaire, featuring parade of would-be brides competing to be chosen by multimillionaire, Rick Rockwell, and culminating in wedding presided over by Nevada judge; show's audience grew from 10 million viewers in its first half-hour to 22.8 million in final half-hour; ratings will probably place it among week's top five or six shows; show draws over third of all women younger than 35 watching TV on Feb 15; bride chosen is Darva Conger, 34-year-old nurse from Santa Monica, Calif; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: EURO FALLS. The euro declined against the dollar as weak economic data allayed concern that sharply higher U.S. interest rates were inevitable. In New York, the euro settled at 96.09 cents, down from 96.63 on Thursday.

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; CMS, a utility company formerly loved on Wall Street, cuts its dividend and faces disdain.
abstract: Market Place column on CMS Energy Corp's financial restructuring plan, which will deeply cut dividend payments while raising cash by selling tracking stock tied to its old-fashioned utility business in Michigan; investors react with anger, and company's stock price falls to four-year low as it drops $6.50 a share, to $23.50, a figure that is less than half the peak reached in late 1998, when Wall Street was most impressed by international diversification efforts (M)

headline: The Gigahertz Game
abstract: Letter by Jim Reynolds responds to March 9 article on faster speed of computer chips; notes limits on increases

headline: U.N. Increases Peacekeepers in Sierra Leone
abstract: UN Security Council increases peacekeeping force for Sierra Leone to 11,000 from about 6,000 and tells troops not to shrink from using weapons against brutal rebel army; expanded peacekeeping mission, approved unanimously, becomes organization's largest (S)

headline: Judge Lets Internet Primary in Arizona Proceed
abstract: March 1, 2000

headline: Closing Arguments Underscore Gap Between Microsoft and U.S.
abstract: Closing Arguments Underscore Gap Between Microsoft and U.S.

headline: For Holders Big and Small, an Explosion of Riches
abstract: Ted Turner, vice chairman of Time Warner, has more to gain than anybody from sale of company to America Online; he is biggest individual shareholder of Time Warner, owning about 100 million shares, or about 6.7 percent of company; Turner's stake has risen by $2.53 billion, to about $9 billion; Turner's wife, Jane Fonda, owns 770,000 shares of Time Warner; if she still owns them, their value increased by $19.5 million, to $69.3 million; Gerald M Levin, chairman-chief executive of Time Warner, owns about 876,000 shares, which means his stake rose about $22 million, to $78.9 million (M)

headline: Smuggling of Iraqi Oil Is Rising, U.N. Is Told
abstract: Vice Admiral Charles Moore, American coordinator of international fleet that patrols waters off Iraq, tells Security Council committee that steeply rising oil prices have brought huge increase in smuggling of Iraqi oil; diplomats say, after briefing, that Moore tells committee on sanctions against Iraq that much of oil passes through Iranian water; Moore reportedly says that at current rates of oil shipments, Iraq could eaarn up to billion dollars this year in illegal sales; diplomats say profits go directly to Pres Saddam Hussein or those he chooses to reward (S)

headline: Chechen Rebels Fiercely Attack Russian Forces
abstract: Encircled by Russian forces and subjected to constant bombardment, Chechen rebels in Grozny have begun to lash back, forcing furious firefights on the outskirts of the city.    Rebel officials asserted today that they had left their hiding places in Grozny and seized the village of Alkhan-Kala, on the southwestern outskirts of the Chechen capital, according to independent media outlets in Russia.

headline: LERNOUT & HAUSPIE PLANS TO BUY DRAGON FOR $593 MILLION
abstract: Lernout & Hauspie Speech Products acquires Dragon Systems for about $593 million in stock (S)

headline: 3 Concerns Form Printer Venture
abstract: Xerox Corp will announce venture with Fuji Photo Film Co and Sharp Corp to make low-cost inkjet printers; three companies plan to announce they will invest more than $2 billion in next five years in joint effort (S)

headline: Two companies say their new tests for cervical cancer will be more reliable than Pap smears are.
abstract: Two different companies receive new patents covering two new approaches to cervical cancer testing; each company contends its test promises to be much more reliable than traditional Pap smear; Matritech's process makes cancerous and precancerous cells obtained in Pap smear glow in dark or turn bright red, making them easier for cytotechnolgist to find; Digene Corp's approach is to look for evidence of certain strains of human papilloma virus that has been implicated in virtually all cases of cervical cancer (M)

headline: EBay and Wells Fargo Set Up New Payment System
abstract: EBay and Wells Fargo Set Up New Payment System

headline: Ponchos Reborn in Los Angeles
abstract: LOS ANGELES—  Those 60-degree winter days in Los Angeles may not warrant pulling out a mink, but they certainly call for something to cut the chill emanating from the Pacific.

headline: Packaging Graphics
abstract: Q. I need to save and scan copies of black-and-white cartoons as TIFF files because they print well, but I worry that this is not a good format for e-mail.    What type of file should I use when I send the files as attachments, and is it possible to convert the work I've already scanned?

headline: For Daimler, Mitsubishi Opens the Door to Asia
abstract: FRANKFURT—  DaimlerChrysler AG rounded out its vision for the creation of a global automaker with the announcement Monday that it had acquired a 34 percent controlling stake in Mitsubishi Motor Corp. of Japan.

headline: In Defense of Auditors
abstract: James E Copeland, chief executive of Deloitte & Touche, urges overhaul of rules governing auditors in light of SEC's complaint that most partners at PricewaterhouseCoopers violated rules forbidding them to invest in companies they audit (S)

headline: Pope Seeks to Heal Divisions With Egyptian Coptic Christians
abstract: Pope John Paul II holds first papal Mass ever in Egypt at newly built cathedral in Cairo, where he implores Pope Shenouda III, leader of Egypt's Coptic Church, to renew dialogue with Vatican and end 'painful divisions' within Christianity (M)

headline: Russian Video Is Said to Link Rebels to Blasts
abstract: Kremlin offers video of Chechen bomb factory, saying it proves that militants in Chechnya masterminded terrorist bombings last fall at several Russian apartment houses; film of factory appears to offer circumstantial evidence at best that militants were behind the blasts; video could contain compelling evidence of Chechen terrorist activity, or it could be element of Kremlin effort to bolster support for war at time when Russian troops are taking heavy losses (M)

headline: French Prime Minister Shuffles His Cabinet and Appoints a Rival
abstract: French Prime Min Lionel Jospin, after weeks of sinking ratings in polls, reshuffles cabinet; new appointments include main rival, former Prime Min Laurent Fabius, to important post of finance minister (M)
