headline: New ad agency prefers a homespun approach in pitching whiskey to savvy consumers.
abstract: Article on new ad agency called Hayseed House, which specializes in whiskey advertising; photo (M)

headline: WESTPOINT STEVENS CHIEF TO TAKE COMPANY PRIVATE
abstract: WestPoint Stevens Inc chief executive Holcombe Greene Jr offers to take company private in transaction that values company at about $1.12 billion (S)

headline: Now, A Few Words From Friends and Sponsors
abstract: Number of new Internet companies develop e-mail technology that enables your friends to include advertisements in their correspndence to you and earn commissions on any purchases you might be inclined to make; in each case company provides users with tools to create banners that will show up in text of their messages; Jason Catlett, founder of anti-junk-mail group called Junkbusters, is critical of practice (S)

headline: Croatia Elects a Moderate To Follow the Tudjman Era
abstract: Stipe Mesic is elected to succeed late Franjo Tudjman as president of Croatia; is former leader of collective presidency before Yugoslavia disintegrated in 1991; won 56.2 percent of vote, compared with 43.8 percent for rival, Drazen Budisa; photo (M)

headline: Factions Scuffle as Mexican Campus Reopens
abstract: Scuffles break out at national university in Mexico City as tens of thousands of students return for first official day of classes since strike started in April 1999 (S)

headline: Compressed Data; From Victim To Entrepreneur
abstract: Mark Andrew, who lost use of one eye as result of mugging in 1987, Portland, Me, developed Web site, Eyeglasses.com, that lets people shop for eyeglasses in privacy, with several dozen designer brands to choose among; says he acted out of frustration with eyeglass industry, in which he maintains opticians are not very helpful and range of suitable frames too limited; photos (M)

headline: Ex-Yeltsin Aide Denies Reports In Swiss Money-Laundering Case
abstract: Pavel P Borodin, a senior aide to former Pres Boris N Yeltsin, denies charges by Swiss investigators that he engaged in money-laundering and says he will face questioning in Switzerland if asked; Russian prosecutors cast doubt on nature of charges, saying Swiss warrant for Borodin seem to call only for his testimony and not, as the Swiss have said, for his arrest; photo (M)

headline: A Growing New Industry In Delivering Information
abstract: At least a dozen companies are selling computerized systems that can help hospitals and large medical groups avoid dangerous errors; analysts say health care purchasers spend $20 billion to $30 billion annually on information technology, mainly for billing and administration; systems that reduce errors in transmitting doctors' orders and warn of patients' problems are most rapidly growing segment of health care information systems; companies that supply such systems include McKesson HBOC, Eclipsys, Cerner Corp and Shared Medical System (M)

headline: Technology Stocks Gain Ground as Rest of Market Slides
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average loses 156.68 points, or 1.46 percent, to close at 10,561.41; Nasdaq composite index rises 6.88 points, to 4,427.65; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index falls 14.38 points, or 1.03 percent, to 1,387.67; graph; chart (M)

headline: Alfred Neal, 87, an Economist Who Influenced Trade Policy
abstract: Alfred

headline: A Major West Bank Campus Suspends Classes in a Protest
abstract: Students and teachers at Bir Zeit University, leading Palestinian academic institution in West Bank, suspend classes indefinitely to protest arrests of students by Palestinian security forces; arrests follow incident in which crowd of protesting students threw stones at Prime Min Lionel Jospin of France during campus visit (S)

headline: The New York Times: Technology - Circuits
abstract: January 13, 2000           Aaron Lee Fineman for The New York Times

headline: REALNETWORKS EXPANDS MULTIMEDIA SERVICES IN BUYOUT
abstract: RealNetworks Inc acquires Netzip Inc for about $268 million in stock (S)

headline: California Raisins Make Comeback in Campaign
abstract: California Raisin Marketing Board is bringing back 'dancing raisins' in promotional campaign scheduled to begin Feb 10 (S)

headline: Jobs Drops 'Interim' From Title at Apple
abstract: Ending more than two years of very public indecision, Apple Computer's co-founder, Steven P. Jobs, said today he was dropping the ''interim'' from ''interim chief executive,'' the title under which he has led the company back into prosperity in the last two and a half years.    The announcement that he was staying on indefinitely at the computer company he co-founded almost 25 years ago was made in typical Jobsian style before an overflow crowd of more than 4,000 Macintosh users -- as a footnote to a lengthy keynote presentation at the company's biannual Macworld exhibition, which opened here today.

headline: REUTERS EXECUTIVE RESIGNS
abstract: John Parcell, chief executive of Reuters Information, will leave company this week after 30 years of service; photo (S)

headline: Investors Sell Off Micron Technology Following Profit Surprise
abstract: March 21, 2000

headline: Agency Shift By Netpliance
abstract: Netpliance names BBDO New York to handle account of I-Opener, which provides access to Internet and E-mail without computer; billings estimated at $15 million (S)

headline: Is the relationship between inflation and unemployment a curve or more of an economics knuckleball?
abstract: Prof J Bradford DeLong (Economic Scene) column on relationship between inflation and unemployment; says Phillips curve, relationship between unemployment and inflation proposed by British economist A W Phillips late in 1950's used to be accepted doctrine in economics that period of low unemployment would create upward pressure on prices; holds 1990's have challenged conventional wisdom by combining both low joblessness and low inflation; graphs (M)

headline: EQUIFAX AGREES TO BUY POLK CONSUMER INFORMATION UNIT
abstract: Equifax Inc to buy the consumer-information division of the closely held R L Polk & Co, Southfield, Mich, for about $260 million (S)

headline: Reviving the Fine Art of Haggling, Online
abstract: Michelle Slatalla Online Shopper column says Internet has created new kind of marketplace, where bargaining may once again become routine; describes her experience using Nextag, Web site where shoppers can bargain simultaneously with number of merchants for variety of merchandise; says she saved money, but sometimes not very much; lists site's drawbacks; drawing (M)

headline: Sales of Licensed Items Set Record in 1999
abstract: Retail sales of licensed merchandise in North America rose to a record in 1999, according to the 23rd annual licensing industry survey by The Licensing Letter, a newsletter published by EPM Communications in New York.    The survey, published in the newsletter's January issue, showed that sales rose 4 percent in 1999, to $74.2 billion, from $71.2 billion in 1998; the 1998 figure represented a 3 percent decline from 1997.

headline: Mufti Says That Israel Uses Holocaust 'to Win Sympathy'
abstract: Mufti of Jerusalem, Sheik Ikrima Sabri, says Israel uses Holocaust to win world's sympathy and to avoid international censure for its behavior toward Palestinians; says he believes number of 6 million Holocaust victims is exaggerated; his words clash starkly with message of reconcilation spoken by Pope John Paul II during his visit to Holy Land; mufti, unlike Palestinian political leaders, has not acceded to pope's agenda of interfaith healing; he refuses to attend pope's interfaith gathering; pope will be in difficult situation if mufti repeats his remarks during their scheduled meeting (M)

headline: Carbon-Copy Madness
abstract: Letter by Marie Harris responds to Feb 10 article on e-mail; notes how in copying friends and associates about her new business, a friend used her Cc list to mail news of her new book and this in turn led to people demanding to be taken off list

headline: Raytheon Turns Downbeat On Earnings a 3rd Time
abstract: Raytheon Co shocks Wall Street again by lowering its profit forecast for third time since September, latest sign that military contractors created by wave of mergers in 1990's are proving difficult to manage (M)

headline: HOUSE APPROVES EXPANSION OF TIES TO TAIWAN'S ARMY
abstract: House votes, 341 to 70, to expand military ties between Taiwan and US, move that China and Clinton administration warn could aggravate regional tensions and jeopardize landmark trade agreement; critics say bill will upset Washington's 'one China' policy, which treats Taiwan as part of China and recognizes Beijing as China's capital, but also allows US to provide Taiwan with defensive weaponry; senior Republicans, led by Rep Tom Delay, choose security measure as first major bill for floor consideration this year precisely because it will challenge China (M)

headline: Treasury Offerings This Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's auction of three-  and six-month bills and two-year notes. Yesterday was Presidents' Day, a federal holiday; there was no trading in U.S. Treasury securities and no trading of futures on the Chicago Board of Trade.    By the close of the New York cash market last Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 5.56 percent and a six-month bill was 5.73 percent. In when-issued trading the two-year note was offered at a price to yield 6.25 percent.

headline: Putin to Keep Defense Chief, Affirming Chechnya Status Quo
abstract: Moscow is rife with behind-the-scenes intrigue as Pres-elect Vladimir V Putin and his aides try to decide which politicians, economists and tycoons should be included in his inner circle; Putin decides against replacing Marshal Igor D Sergeyev as defense minister, a move that appears calculated to give the impression that government is satisfied with how Russian military campaign in Chechnya is going (M)

headline: CANADIAN BUILDING SERVICES COMPANY REACHES U.S. DEAL
abstract: Bracknell Corp agrees to buy Sunbelt Integrated Trade Services Inc for at least $127 million (S)

headline: DaimlerChrysler Buying a Third of Mitsubishi for $2.1 Billion
abstract: DaimlerChrysler AG signs agreement to invest $2.1 billion in Mitsubishi Motors Corp, finally securing toehold in Asia it has long wanted; DaimlerChrysler will buy newly issued shares that will give it 33.4 percent stake in Mitsubishi, enough to guarantee it board representation and limited veto power (M)

headline: Bid for Japanese Drug Maker Is Latest Sign of Deregulation
abstract: Boehringer Ingelheim, large German pharmaceuticals company, starts tender offer for shares of SS Pharmaceuticals Co, Japan; offer values SS Pharmaceuticals at 134.6 billion yen, or about $1.28 billion (M)

headline: Investment in Health Site
abstract: Internet Healthcare, private company that finances Internet health care sites, says it received $70 million investment from Internet Capital Group (S)

headline: ERICSSON PROFIT JUMPS
abstract: Swedish cellular phone maker Ericsson reports fourth quarter net income rose to 6.32 billion kronor ($734 million) from 4.75 billion kronor a year ago; company shares soar (S)

headline: ECI TELECOM TO BUY HUBBLE UNIT FOR AROUND $90 MILLION
abstract: ECI Telecom Ltd, Israel's largest telecommunications equipment marker, will buy WavePacer, unit of Hubble Inc subsidiary of Pulse Communications, for as much as $90 million (S)

headline: CONCERN ABOUT EURO'S DROP
abstract: European Central Bank chief economist Otmar Issing says he is worried that euro's drop against dollar is damaging public confidence in 13-month-old single European currency; euro has fallen 15 percent since its inception on Jan 1, 1999; Issing says euro's drop is largely reflection of 'picture book' state of US economy, but that European growth is set to catch up with US this year and next; photo (S)

headline: Serta Names Doner to Account
abstract: Serta Inc. in Itasca, Ill., said yesterday it had awarded its account to Doner in Southfield, Mich., replacing the Chicago office of Publicis & Hal Riney, part of Publicis S.A. Billings were estimated at $20 million.

headline: MANAGEMENT: The Afterlife Of a Powerful Chief; 'I'm Actually Back Doing Things,' Says One Starting Anew
abstract: Profile of Lewis E Platt, former chief executive at Hewlett-Packard Co who retired after 33 years with company and immediately took job as chief executive at Kendall-Jackson Wine Estates; Platt comments; chart; photos (M)

headline: U.S. Draft of Israel-Syria Treaty Reported in Israeli Newspaper
abstract: Israeli newspaper, Haaretz, publishes what it says is draft peace treaty framed by Clinton administration for Israel and Syria, laying out marked differences between two sides on most difficult issues of borders and security; there are few surprises in document, and diplomats familiar with negotiations describe it as working tool that is not intended to be definitive; document published in Haaretz does not include rough timeline that was part of document Pres Clinton gave to Israeli Prime Min Ehud Barak and Syrian Foreign Min Farouk al-Shara (M)

headline: Tracking More Sectors
abstract: Merrill Lynch introduces two versions of one of its hottest investment products, securities that track specific industry sectors; securities represent specific shares of 20 underlying companies in sector (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Ralph Lauren and NBC Form A Joint Multimedia Venture  NBC and its Internet affiliates will join Polo Ralph Lauren in a new media company that will promote the designer's products online and on the air. The deal, a coup for Mr. Lauren, will further blur the line between content and commerce at traditional media companies.

headline: Syria Businessmen Yearn for Reforms
abstract: Young Syrian entrepreneurs like Hashem Akkad, legislator and businessman, are eager to catch up with their contemporaries in other Arab countries; say Pres Hafez al-Assad's economic policies are built on socialism and cronyism and should be liberalized; photo (M)

headline: Producer Price Index Is Flat As Cost of Cigarettes Drops
abstract: Labor Department's Producer Price Index held at same level in January as in December, when it rose 0.1 percent; core index, which excludes food and energy, fell 0.2 percent after growing 0.1 percent in prior month; index was held down by 4.9 percent drop in cigarette prices; Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia reports that regional manufacturing expanded at faster pace in February and that its index of prices paid by regional manufacturers was close to five-year high; general economic index rose to 13.3 in February from 9.1 in January; graph on producer prices (M)

headline: Paying the Price to Hunt In Hot-Ticket Territory
abstract: Carol Flake Chapman discusses her efforts to acquire basketball tickets to San Antonio Spurs game and how this resulted in her visiting several Web sites, then the so-called secondary, or resale market, and finally e-mailing site called Ticket Dog; says end of her search resulted in tickets that cost total of $206.80; says face value of ticket was $24 each, but adds transaction did not violate law; photo of Spurs game (M)

headline: FOUR-YEAR SENTENCE FOR TAX EVASION
abstract: Cho Yang Ho, chairman of South Korea's flagship carrier, Korean Air, receives four-year prison term for tax evasion and fine of $26.7 million (US) (M)

headline: URBAN DECAY FOR LVMH
abstract: LVMH Moet Hennessn

headline: Yahoo Plans To Remain Independent
abstract: Yahoo Inc executives say company could remain successful without merger with traditional media company; Yahoo says its sales more than doubled, its profit margins widened and its user base doubled last quarter from comparable period of 1998; company earned $57.6 million in fourth quarter, compared with $12.9 million in fourth quarter of 1998; revenue rose from $91.3 million to $201.1 million;, while its audience of users doubled to 120 million worldwide; analysts believe Yahoo is more likely to form partnerships with media companies than merge outright with one of them (M)

headline: Battling Little Monsters in the Schoolyard
abstract: J D Biersdorfer (Game Theory) article on Sissy Fight 2000, developed by editors of Word, an online magazine; says since free game's debut in Feb, it has developed something of a cult following; says game (www.sissyfight.com) is multiplayer free-for-all designed for adults, not children; notes game's creators say more than 17,000 people have signed up since its debut; describes game rules; photos (M)

headline: Afghanistan's Girls Fight to Read and Write
abstract: Afghanistan's Taliban rulers are relenting somewhat on their ban of schooling for girls; schools of varying sizes are opening in homes, some secretly, others discreetly; United Nations estimates that 10,000 young girls are going to classes in Kabul, and more all the time; women operating schools secretly rely on word-of-mouth to attract students; most girls are eager; one teacher notes country's young girls have lost four years of education, and that children with illiterate parents have suffered most; photo of one girl who dressed herself as boy to attend school (M)

headline: From Sweatshops to High Fashion : Thai Brands Seek To Upgrade Image
abstract: BANGKOK—  Jackets sporting odd spellings and ungrammatical English phrases aside, the Cha-Lom Company has achieved the dream of many Thai garment manufacturers.

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; All the Glitter Doesn't Mean Gold Is Golden
abstract: Market Place column on recent rise in price of gold and how far can rally go; says it seems something more has to change--both in market psychology and in global economy--before gold can move much higher and stay there; says speculators that have been betting for years that price of gold will fall have to change their minds and bet on rising price; graph (M)

headline: THE BOSS; Out of North Carolina
abstract: The Boss column profiles Luther Cochrane, chief executive of Bovis Lend Lease, New York-based construction and project manager; Cochrane comments; photo (M)

headline: Wall Street Meets the Strip
abstract: James J Murren, president of MGM Grand, describes how he can run a company and his wife, Heather Hay, can analyze stocks for Merrill Lynch from their home in Las Vegas (S)

headline: GILLETTE TO SELL SOME OF ITS BRAUN DIVISION
abstract: Gillette Co says it might sell its slumping Braun household appliance, hair care and health diagnostic operations; Gillette has hired J P Morgan & Co to help explore options for its businesses (S)

headline: NATO Chief in Kosovo Fears a Cross-Border Insurgency
abstract: Gen Klaus Reinhardt, commander of NATO peacekeeping troops in Kosovo, with former political leader of disbanded Kosovo Liberation Army beside him, vows to stop any insurgency mounted from Kosovo into Serbia; warning comes at joint news conference, with Reinhardt joined by Hashim Thaci, Albanian leader; Albanian leaders warn that tension in Presevo Valley between ethnic Albanian population and Serbian police forces is only going to worsen; photo; map (L)

headline: Christian Democrats Urge Hesse PremierTo Resign in Scandal : Kohl Party Split Over Succession
abstract: FRANKFURT—  Demands grew Thursday for the resignation of a second leader from Germany's Christian Democrats as a battle for succession broke into the open following the departure of Wolfgang Schaeuble, the party chairman.

headline: Canadian Software Deal
abstract: FutureLink Corp will acquire closely held Charon Systems for $31.4 million in cash and stocks (S)

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; Executives hope the marriage of interactive television and consumers will be prosperous.
abstract: Survey by Myers Group finds that 94 percent of 500 advertising agency, media-buying and planning executives who respond say it is important to explore interactive television advertising; Myers chairman Jack Myers projects online advertising spending will grow 80 percent this year, to $4.32 billion; he expects America Online to capture 'the major share' of the growth (M)

headline: ECUADOR WINS BANANA RULING
abstract: World Trade Organization arbitrator rules Ecuador may retaliate against European Union for import policies that favor bananas from former African and Caribbean colonies by imposing nearly $202 million in duties on European goods and other commercial activities (S)

headline: China's Controls on Rural Workers Stir Some Rarely Seen Heated Opposition
abstract: China's long-entrenched controls over where people may live and work have become a subject of unusual public debate, with critics attacking stringent efforts by cities to curb entrance of rural migrants and bar them from choice jobs; critics contend restrictions hold down economic growth, worsen country's growing disparities in wealth and violate basic rights of rural majority of China's population (M)

headline: Confidence Of Consumers Weakened For 2d Month
abstract: Conference Board's consumer confidence index fell to 136.7 in March from 140.8 in February and record of 144.7 in January (M)

headline: Egalite, Fraternite et Burgers
abstract: The Boss column on Denis Hennequin, president of McDonald's France, whose 791 'McDo' restaurants have come under attack as erosion of French culinary tradition; Hennequin comments; photo (M)

headline: Vodafone Sets Broad Alliance With Vivendi of France
abstract: Vodafone AirTouch says it has agreed to alliance with Vivendi of France, contingent on Vodafone's succeeding in its $155 billion hostile bid for Mannesmann AG; Mannesmann had hoped to link up with Vivendi to thwart Vodafone's bid; Vivendi board reportedly decided against deal with Mannesmann because of company's uncertain future and because they expect Vodafone to win its battle for Mannesmann (M)

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Letters to the Editor

headline: U.S. Is Moving to Crack Down On Discount Telephone Services
abstract: Federal Communications Commission and Federal Trade Commission say they will begin to crack down on what they say is widespread deception in way discount telephone services have been promoted; FCC chairman William E Kennard and FTC chairman Robert Pitofsky comment (M)

headline: DAYTON SUPERIOR AGREES TO BUYOUT BY INVESTMENT FIRM
abstract: Dayton Superior Corp agrees to be bought by investment firm Odyssey Investment Partners LLC for $315 million in cash and assumed debt, in transaction that will take company private (S)

headline: Catching Plagiarists
abstract: David Blatner letter comments on Jan 20 article on colleges using using Web sites to catch student plagiarists (S)

headline: The Dow Awakens From a Long Slumber
abstract: Dow Jones industrials, mired in two-month slump, stages record-shattering rally, ending last week at 10,595.23, up 666.41, including one-day record gain of 499 points (S)

headline: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: WORLD TRADE; RECORD IN FOREIGN INVESTMENT
abstract: United Nations Conference on Trade and Development says foreign direct investment grew worldwide by 25 percent in 1999, to record $827 billion; says main reason was cross-border mergers and acquisitions; report also shows Britain replaced US as largest investor (S)

headline: Vodafone Receives a German Bid for a Car-Parts Operation
abstract: Vodafone AirTouch PLC receives unsolicited offer from ThyssenKrup AG for auto parts and engineering unit of Mannesmann, which will be acquired by Vodafone for $183 billion in biggest hostile takeover ever (S)

headline: A 3-Hour Talk With Putin Leaves Albright Encouraged
abstract: Sec of State Madeleine K Albright meets with Russia's acting president, Vladimir V Putin, in Moscow and says she is taken with his 'can-do approach' and lack of dogma; meeting does not produce any breakthroughs in recently troubled relationship between Washington and Moscow (M)

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: ASIA    INDIA: EX-STATE CHIEF CLEARED  Jayalalitha Jayaram, the former actress and onetime chief minister of the state of Tamil Nadu, won an important victory in a criminal case when charges against her in a reportedly crooked land deal were dropped. The same state court also upheld an earlier ruling that absolved her of guilt in a reported coal-importing scam. Two other charges against her are still pending.   Barry Bearak (NYT)    MALAYSIA: CRACKDOWN CONTINUES  The government extended a crackdown on opposition figures, arresting another top political leader and charging two people with sedition. The latest arrest, the fifth since Wednesday, was that of Mohamed Ezam Mohamed Nor, left, a senior leader of the National Justice Party, which supports the jailed politician Anwar Ibrahim. Mr. Mohamed Ezam said he was being charged under the Official Secrets Act.   (AP)

headline: On CBS News, Some of What You See Isn't There
abstract: CBS television news programs are using digital images imposed over real objects like competitors' signs to transmit program logos to viewers; CBS Evening News broadcast live from Times Square on New Year's Eve showed billboard behind Dan Rather that was actually digital image covering NBC sign; photo of logo of The Early Show superimposed on General Motors building where show is broadcast; inserting digital images has become common in sports and entertainment programming to show advertising and corporate logos, but has been considered inappropriate for news shows; CBS defends its ethics; news director Eric Shapiro says Rather knew about use of virtual technology during his broadcast (M)

headline: Stocks Begin The New Year On Mixed Note
abstract: Stocks began the new year with a topsy-turvy performance yesterday, as technology and Internet shares bolted to new records even as broad swaths of the market slumped in the wake of a sharp rise in long-term interest rates.     Observers who only note the closing quotes for major market averages would probably comment that the Nasdaq composite index continued to perform as it did throughout much of December, when it rose in what seemed like a straight line.

headline: New Chief at Account For DaimlerChrysler
abstract: BBDO Worldwide says it will make changes in top managment of its Pentamark office in Troy, Mich, which oversees DaimlerChrysler account; Martin R Levine is leaving DaimlerChrysler to join Pentamark as president and chief executive, effective on May 1; will succeed J Thomas Clark, who will continue as vice chairman at BBDO Worldwide until retiring at end of 2001 (S)

headline: Wiesel Urges Germany to Ask Forgiveness
abstract: Germany ends decade of turbulent debate over how to commemorate Holocaust in its new capital by dedicating a vast site beside the Brandenburg Gate for a memorial designed by New York architect Peter Eisenman; most of German government stands in icy winds beneath new billboards announcing 'Memorial to the Murdered Jews of Europe' as Wolfgang Thierse, speaker of Parliament, explains that honor has to be accorded to six million Jewish dead 'in the heart of our capital city'; construction will begin next year on 4.9-acre site; field of more than 2,000 stone pillars of varying dimensions will be flanked by 'documentation center' whose precise role remains unclear; resistant to the last, Eberhard Diepgen, Berlin's Christian Democratic mayor, snubs ceremony; Germany, to complete its formal remembrance of Holocaust, on 55th anniversary of liberation of Auschwitz, invites Elie Wiesel, Nobel Peace laureate, to address lower house of Parliament; photos (L)

headline: IRELAND PHONE COMPANY CUTS JOBS
abstract: Eircom, Ireland's former state telecommunications company, announces $406 million restructuring plan that will cut 3,500 jobs and save $76 million annually (S)

headline: In Europe, Media Companies Are Seeing Phones as the Future
abstract: January 12, 2000

headline: DUPONT CONSIDERS ISSUING A TRACKING STOCK
abstract: E I du Pont de Nemours & Co is considering issuing tracking stock for one or more of its nonchemical units, altering its original plan to issue shares reflecting the performance of its entire life science business (S)

headline: Open Positions of Short Sales Climb 5.7% on the Big Board
abstract: Number of uncovered short sales on New York Stock Exchange rose 5.7 percent in month ended March 15; uncovered short sales totaled 4.11 billion shares, compared with 3.89 billion shares a month earlier; on American Stock Exchange, short interest also climbed, up 2 percent, to 187.2 million shares, compared with 183.5 million shares in previous month; chart (M)

headline: Is the Internet Endangering Sales Jobs?
abstract: Use of Internet for bond issues, which is direction corporate bond market is moving, is raising question about future role of sales representatives on Wall Street; Victor Simone, Goldman Sachs & Co's director for e-commerce, says his firm does not envision world without salespeople; Tim Bacik, fixed-income portfolio manager at Alliance Capital, says it appears that role of salesperson as it currently exists will be diminished by Internet (M)

headline: LATIN INTERNET INVESTMENT
abstract: Submarino.com, Brazil, in one of the largest private equity investments in Latin American Internet firm, gets $71.3 million from group of investors led by T H Lee Putnam Internet Partners (S).

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: EUROPE    GERMANY: ATTACKED OVER HITLER  Former Economics Minister Jurgen Mollemann, chairman of the Free Democratic Party in North Rhine-Westphalia, was sharply criticized for using an image of Hitler in his campaign posters for the state election on May 14. Hitler's face is above a warning saying: ''If we do not move quickly to put more teachers in the schools, our children will look for their own teachers.''   Victor Homola (NYT)    GERMANY: COMMUNIST'S PLEA REJECTED  Egon Krenz, the last leader of Communist East Germany, was ordered to begin a six-year sentence today after a federal court rejected his appeal. Mr. Krenz was found guilty of complicity in the shooting of people trying to escape across the Berlin Wall. The unrepentant former leader has a further appeal before the European Court of Human Rights in Strasbourg.   Roger Cohen (NYT)

headline: Michelin Has Awarded Its Marketing Account
abstract: Michelin North America in Greenville, S.C., said yesterday that it has awarded its first relationship marketing account, covering duties like direct marketing, database marketing and retail partnerships, to the Chicago office of Lowe Lintas & Partners Worldwide, part of the Lowe Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies. Billings have not been determined.

headline: VIASAT TO ACQUIRE SCIENTIFIC-ATLANTA SATELLITE BUSINESS
abstract: ViaSat Inc acquires satellite networking business of Scientific-Atlanta Inc for $75 million in cash (S)

headline: Banker and Husband Tell Of Role in Laundering Case
abstract: Former Bank of New York vice pres Lucy Edwards and her husband, Peter Berlin, plead guilty in Federal District Court, Manhattan, to helping group of small but politically connected Russian banks create elaborate money laundering scheme that moved over $7 billion out of Russia through American bank; say they were paid nearly $2 million for their services; say scheme allowed Russian bankers to conduct illegal banking activities in US that circumvented scrutiny of federal banking regulators and law enforcement officials (M)

headline: F.C.C. Is Expected to Reject SBC's Long-Distance Proposal
abstract: Federal Communications Commission is expected to reject SBC Communications' efforts to enter $80 billion long-distance telephone market (M)

headline: A Day at the Races, A Night of Big Parties
abstract: How do you mark the passage of 1,000 years of human history? Simple in Hong Kong, a city of chronic gamblers and cold-eyed oddsmakers: you head for the track.    At 12:45 a.m., as the last wisps of smoke from New Year's Eve fireworks drifted away from the Happy Valley Racecourse, the crack of a starter's gun set off the Millennium Cup.

headline: KOREAN TRADE SURPLUS RETURNS
abstract: South Korea posted trade surplus of $802 million in February, after $391 million deficit in previous month; trade surplus is lower than $1.7 billion surplus South Korea posted in February 1999 (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Currencies report; dollar gains on evidence that economy is growing without inflation; in New York, dollar closes at 106.13 yen, up from 105.98; rate against euro noted; graph (S)

headline: British, Under European Ruling, End Ban on Openly Gay Soldiers
abstract: British government ends its ban on openly gay men and women serving in armed forces, following European court ruling that Britain could no longer keep the exclusion; this ends Britain's decades-old practice of subjecting gays in military to intrusive investigations and dishonorable discharges; change brings Britain into line with almost all other NATO nations, which allow openly gay men and lesbians to serve in their armed forces; United States, with its 'don't ask, don't tell' policy, is at variance with trend; Britain's about-face became inevitable after European Court of Human Rights unanimously ruled last September in favor of four former servicemen and servicewomen who were discharged in mid-1990's because of their homosexuality; photo (M)

headline: Denny's Reviewing Its Account
abstract: Denny's, part of Advantica Restaurant Group, is starting review on its account after parting ways with its agency of five years, Lowe Lintas & Partners in New York (S)

headline: Suit Accuses Sony Music of Unfair Online Acts
abstract: Sony Music Entertainment is sued by National Association of Recording Merchandisers, trade association representing retailers, who charges company illegally steers customers to its online stores by including hyperlinks on music compact discs; suit accuses Sony of copyright misuse, false advertising, unfair competition and illegal price discrimination in favor of Sony's own record club and online retailer; retailers say they are being forced to direct their own customers to Sony's retail operation (S)

headline: A Splash of Color For Palm's New P.D.A.
abstract: Palm Inc, formerly called Palm Computing, announces its long-awaited color model: Palm IIIc, which features color screen that allows it to compete in one area where Windows CE devices had an edge; one application for new color Palm allows it to display photos, through downloads from either a computer or Club Photo's Web site; photo of new Palm (S)

headline: Marketers Try Infecting the Internet
abstract: March 22, 2000

headline: SAKS FORESEES PROFIT IN THREE YEARS FROM WEB SITE
abstract: Saks Inc, department store retailer, says it expects profit in three years from its Saks Fifth Avenue Web site, which will start online sales by June (S)

headline: Croatia Is Looking at a Runoff on Feb. 7
abstract: Stipe Mesic, former Communist leader, will face opposition politician Drazen Budisa in February 7 runoff to elect successor to late Franjo Tudjman as president of Croatia (S)

headline: A Fraternity of 34, Adding Members Very Slowly
abstract: Douglas Brinkley article reviews post-White House activities of some of 34 former presidents who lived long enough to retire from office; notes number experienced post-White House distress (special section, Retirement) (M)

headline: Estrongo Nachama, 81, Dies; Chief Cantor of Berlin's Jews
abstract: Estrongo Nachama, chief cantor of Berlin Jewish community and the man who did as much as anyone to revive Jewish life in the city after Hitler destroyed it, dies at age 81; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: CRUDE OIL RISES***Prices for crude oil climb on signs that OPEC will keep output limits in place beyond their scheduled expiration on March 31; in New York, crude oil for February delivery rises $1.10 a barrel, to $25.77; graph; chart (S)

headline: Warm and Sticky Feelings
abstract: Letter by Seymour Serebnick responds to March 9 article on trading stamps; questions need for all provisions and conditions user must agree to in using S&H Web site if you want to sign up for Greenpoints

headline: AOL in Venture With Liquid Audio
abstract: AOL in Venture With Liquid Audio

headline: Beyond.com Says Its Chief Has Quit
abstract: Beyond.com, an Internet software retailer, says chief executive Mark Breier has quit and that it will cut cut 20 percent of its staff, as company shifts from consumers to focus on business and government sales; company will cut 75 jobs, move workers from its consumer division and consolidate offices, resulting in quarterly charge of $2 million to $3 million; chief financial officer Rick Neely will serve as interim chief executive (S)

headline: ECLIPSYS MAKES HOSTILE BID FOR SHARED MEDICAL
abstract: Eclipsys Corp, maker of software for health care industry, makes $2 billion hostile bid for rival, Shared Medical Systems Corp, whose shares have fallen 28 percent in last year (S)

headline: Compressed Data; Old-Line Law Firm Links Up to the New Economy
abstract: Courtship of Internet startups by Verner, Liipfert, Bernhard, McPherson & Hand, powerhouse Washington law firm, demonstrates how little distance is left between high-technology world and Washington elite; Bob Dole, special counsel at firm, speaks at fete for new EqualFooting.com; photo (M)

headline: MANOR CARE GAINS ON DUELING BUYOUT OFFERS
abstract: Shares of Manor Care Inc. rose 28 percent yesterday after the company, a nursing home operator, received competing buyout offers from its chairman, Stewart Bainum Jr., and its senior management. Manor Care, which owns 301 nursing homes in 31 states, rose $2.8125 a share to close at $12.6875 on the New York Stock Exchange. At that price the company's stock is worth about $1.31 billion. Mr. Bainum, who owns more than 10 percent of Manor Care, proposed a recapitalization, buyout or similar transaction at a price ''significantly in excess'' of Manor Care's current stock price. The other offer for the company, which is based in Toledo, Ohio, came from a group that includes members of Manor Care's senior management. The company said it would review the options.

headline: Clinton Says Next Move For Peace Is Assad's
abstract: Pres Clinton, commenting publicly for first time on failure of his talks with Pres Hafez al-Assad of Syria, says the 'ball is in his court' now; aides continue to express disappointment at Assad's refusal to budge form his long-held view that Israel should return land seized from Syria during 1967 Arab-Israel war; Clinton meets with Pres Hosni Mubarak of Egypt, and they talk about intensifying efforts around Palestinian and Israeli negotiations (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)

headline: Redemptions at Tiger
abstract: Net assets of Tiger Management fall from about $15 billion to about $7 billion in 1999, a year in which the fund lost about 19 percent; Julian Robertson, fund manager, tells investors that reason does not prevail in this market; photo (S)

headline: So, Tune In Next Time For 'A Cool Sales Idea,' or 'Frozen Chocolate Moose'
abstract: Mars Inc, candy giant, is using imaginery home town, Frostbite Falls, Minn, home of cartoon characters from coming summer film The Adventures of Rocky and Bullwinkle, as tie-in promotion to get children and adults to enjoy their candy products this summer when sales are slow (S)

headline: Senator Proposes Reduction In Fees S.E.C. Puts on Trading
abstract: Sen Phil Gramm, who heads Senate Banking Committee, introduces legislation that would substantially cut fees that companies and investors pay Securities and Exchange Commission to register and trade stock; bill would also give many professionals at SEC, including lawyers and accountants, raises of up to 40 percent to help stem brain drain at agency; Gramm predicts over next 10 years, legislation would cut fees for companies and traders by almost $15 billion (M)

headline: SEMA TO BUY LHS
abstract: British-French computer services company Sema Group will acquire Atlanta-based LHS Group, developer of billing and support software, for $4.7 billion in stock (S)

headline: On the Trail of the Underground Railroad
abstract: Explosion of writing about history of American slavery, particularly about slave resistance, is emerging on Web sites; Anthony M Cohen, writer and lecturer on black history, established the Menare Foundation (www.ugrr.org) to document, preserve and restore safe houses on Underground Railroad; other Web sites on history slave efforts to escape bondage noted (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: Percent           Yesterday   Day Ago   Year Ago       Prime rate   9.00   9.00   7.75        Discount rate   5.50   5.50   4.50        Federal funds   6.13   5.98   5.41        3-month T-bills   5.70   5.70   4.29        6-month T-bills   5.86   5.87   4.32        10-yr. T-infl.   4.01   4.06   3.40        10-yr. T-note   6.05   6.15   5.27        30-yr. T-bond   5.87   5.97   5.67        Telephone bd.   8.08   8.10   7.38        Municipal bds.   5.98   6.01   5.25          (Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Telerate; The Bond Buyer)

headline: Apollo Group Offering
abstract: Apollo Group Inc, which runs programs that allow working adults to get college degrees, says it will seek to raise $75 million through initial public offering of tracking stock for its online business (S)

headline: Money, Money, Money. Guilt, Guilt, Guilt.
abstract: Abby Ellin (Preludes) article says she is glad she is not an Internet billionaire or worth an outrageous amount of money; cites Forum for Investor Advice, which found that only 42 percent of people who come into large sums of money initially react with happiness or excitement, and one in four express anxiety, numbness or even guilt; also cites Myra Salzer, president of Wealth Conservancy, financial planning firm, who found that trust-fund children and lottery winners have hardest time because they did not work for their money and there is disparity between their net worth and self-worth (M)

headline: SANDISK TO RECORD $344 MILLION GAIN FROM MERGER
abstract: SanDisk Corp says it will record first-quarter pretax gain of $344 million from merger of United Silicon and United Microelectronics Corp; SanDisk had invested $51 million in United Silicon (S)

headline: Subway Names Messner Vetere
abstract: Subway Franchisee Advertising Fund Trust, which oversees ad operations for the Subway chain of sandwich shops, names Messner Vetere Berger McNamee Schmetterer/Euro RSCG in New York, part of the Euro RSCG Worldwide unit of Havas Advertising, as its creative agency of record (S)

headline: SOUTH KOREA'S TRADE SURPLUS
abstract: South Korea's trade surplus widened 17 percent in December, as more shipments of semiconductors, automobiles and computers drove exports to a record for a third month. The trade surplus reached $2.9 billion from $2.5 billion in November, the Commerce, Industry and Energy Ministry said. The export boom -- fueled partly by the devaluation of the won in 1997 -- has allowed South Korea to rebound from its worst-ever recession in 1998. The trade surplus for all of 1999 fell to $24.5 billion from $39 billion in 1998.

headline: Dubious Technology
abstract: Letter from Philip Kessler on desciption of offerings at latest Consumer Electronics Show (Jan 13 article) (S)

headline: Wall St. Unimpressed By Price Rise In Oil Patch
abstract: Kenneth N Gilpin (Market Insight) question-and-answer article with William L Randol, senior petroleum analyst at Banc of America Securities. who discusses why investors continue to shun the oil stocks, and why they should take another look; Randol photo (M)

headline: Schroeder's Previous Nominee Withdraws : New German Candidate Proposed to Lead IMF
abstract: FRANKFURT—  Chancellor Gerhard Schroeder nominated Horst Koehler, the president of the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, to head the International Monetary Fund after the withdrawal Tuesday of his initial candidate, Caio Koch-Weser.

headline: NASHUA AGREES TO BUY RITTENHOUSE, A RIVAL PAPER MAKER
abstract: Nashua Corp agrees to buy rival Rittenhouse Paper Co for as much as $63 million; Nashua will pay $57 million in cash plus as much as $6 million more if Rittenhouse meets cash-flow levels (S)

headline: Moon Over...Nevada?
abstract: Studies of migration suggest areas other than Florida and Pennsylvania, which now have highest concentrations of elderly, have growing appeal for retirees; elderly populations have been rising faster in Nevada, Alaska, Arizona, Hawaii, Utah, Colorado and New Mexico than in Florida; map (special section, Retirement) (S)

headline: Share Prices End Volatile Trading Week on a Slow Note
abstract: Stock prices are mixed in March 24 trading, ending volatile week on Wall Street; Dow Jones industrial average loses 7.14 points, to close at 11,112.72; Nasdaq rises 22.42, to close at 4,963.03; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rises 0.11 point, to 1,527.46; benchmark 30-year bond falls 1 7/32, to 103 19/32; yield is 5.99 percent; graph (M)

headline: AMERICAN ELECTRIC BUYS 50% OF MEXICAN POWER PLANT
abstract: AEP Resources Inc., a subsidiary of the American Electric Power Company, said yesterday that it had acquired a 50 percent stake in a Mexican power plant from InterGen, a joint venture of Royal Dutch/ Shell and the Bechtel Group. The 600-megawatt plant is under construction in San Luis de la Paz, about 160 miles from Mexico City. AEP Resources is to assume half of the project's cost of about $430 million. Commercial operations are expected to begin in November 2001, and Mexico's state-owned electric utility has signed a 25-year agreement to buy 85 percent of the power.

headline: Ticketmaster Will Permit Home Printing of Tickets
abstract: Ticketmaster-Online CitySearch will allow customers to print tickets to events directly from their computer printers; bar code on printed ticket will provide security; system will spare consumers delivery charges and the long waits at will-call windows (M)

headline: For Bond Investors: Pick the Ugly Ducklings
abstract: Robert D Hershey Jr, as part of six articles dealing with impact of rising interest rates on consumer and investors in various areas, discusses impact on bond market; says investors should consider Treasuries, tax-free municipals and high-grade corporates (M)

headline: Internet Pioneer to Be Named Top F.C.C. Technologist
abstract: The Federal Communications Commission plans to announce today that it has appointed a pioneering computer scientist and telecommunications expert as the agency's chief technologist.    The appointee, David J. Farber, a University of Pennsylvania professor, drew attention last year when he served as a Justice Department expert witness in the Microsoft antitrust trial.

headline: SIDANKO SETTLEMENT ADVANCES
abstract: BP Amoco PLC moves significantly closer to shoring up its half-billion dollar investment in Sidanko, bankrupt Russian oil company, after creditors vote to halt the company's liquidation and accept settlement that essentially calls for a restructuring of its $431 million in debts (S)

headline: U.S. Helps Russia Turn Germ Center to Peace Uses
abstract: Clinton administration officials and scientists who have toured Vector, Siberian lab formerly used by Soviet Union to develop viral weapons, say quiet United States aid to convert lab to peaceful research seems to be paying off; some American intelligence analysts and Congressional staff members remain wary; photo (M)

abstract: Red Hat Files to Sell More Shares

abstract: News analysis of victory by Vladimir V Putin in Russia's presidential election; likely impact on US-Russian relations assessed; photo (M)

headline: NATIONAL-OILWELL IS BUYING IRI FOR $320 MILLION IN STOCK
abstract: National-Oilwell Inc acquires IRI International Corp for $320 million, about $8.04 a share in stock (S)

headline: Iranians in Huge Numbers Vote in Parliamentary Election
abstract: So many Iranians go to polls for parliamentary elections that officials extend voting by two hours; Interior Ministry says final results may take three weeks; election is seen as referendum pitting supporters of reform against hard-liners; photo (M)6

headline: Labs to Relax Security Limits on Israelis
abstract: Energy Department will lift security restrictions on visits by Israeli scientists to American national laboratories as part of agreement expanding scientific and technical cooperation between Israel and US in the energy area; Israeli scientists have faced these cumbersome security restrictions because Israel is on agency's list of sensitive countries that have refused to forswear nuclear weaons or are suspected of secretly pursuing unconventional arms (M)

headline: DaimlerChrysler Nears Deal To Buy 33.4% of Mitsubishi
abstract: DaimlerChrysler of Germany is expected to announce deal to acquire 33.4 percent of Japan's Mitsubishi Motors for about $1.3 billion; deal would make DaimlerChrysler world's third-largest automaker, behind General Motors and Ford; they share three main markets, in Western Europe, Japan and United States; if DaimlerChryusler-Mitsubishi deal is completed, Japan would be left with only two major independent car companies--Toyota and Honda; Mitsubishi has been in financial distress and is saddled with $16 billion in debt (M)

headline: American Airlines Selects Agency
abstract: American Airlines, unit of AMR Corp, names Don Coleman Advertising, which is 49 percent owned by True North Communications, as first agency to handle campaign for airline that will be aimed at African Americans; billings are undetermined (S)

headline: Coke's Black Employees Step Up Pressure To Resolve a Racial Discrimination Lawsuit
abstract: Coca-Cola's black employees are stepping up pressure to resolve racial discrimination lawsuit; black employees this month held rally outside Atlanta church to protest Coke's treatment of blacks; similar rally is scheduled for March 25; many of company's current and former black employees plan to travel to company's shareholder meeting on April 19 to make statement about their frustrations at company; Larry Jones, black employee who worked at Coke 15 years, most recently as benefits manager, before being dismissed last month, says if conditions do not improve for blacks, he may call for national boycott of Coca-Cola products; stock analysts say racial discrimination lawsuit is harming company's image with investors, at a time when Coke is trying to make itself attractive again after turning in one of its worst business performances in its history last year; photo (M)

headline: Past, Present and Future in One Stroke
abstract: ''But where are the snows of yesteryear?'' the poet Francois Villon asked in the 15th century, not even halfway through the millennium we are making a fuss about leaving. Nothing new under the sun, though in his case it was not an early global-warming alert but a lament for departed loveliness. Nothing new there either.    Maybe the past is prologue, but here at the changing of the hundred- and thousand-year guard, prologue is chiefly the past. The flood of writing on the subject, including this additional teacupful, looks back more than forward. ''Millennium'' has a great gong sound, but is it the gong announcing the end of an era or summoning the one to come? The first is bronze, the second is tin.

headline: Big plays, surprise heroes, shocking defeats and other Super Bowl XXXIV marketing memories.
abstract: Assessment of some of 53 paid commercials running during Super Bowl; photo (M)

headline: INVESTOR VICTORY IN RUSSIA
abstract: St Petersburg, Russia, appeals court reinstates privatization of Lomonosov Porcelain Factory, returning equity stakes to Congressionally financed US-Russia Investment Fund and other foreign shareholders that had been stripped from them by earlier nationalization of plant; in October, Russian government sued to annul privatization of plant, voiding majority stake held by $440 million fund and group of shareholders consisting of executives of Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co; government is not expected to challenge ruling (S)

headline: Japan Remains at Odds With U.S. on Telephone Deregulation
abstract: US and Japan fail to reach agreement on further deregulation of telecommications market in Japan after two days of meetings and extend their talks to third day; other areas of Japanese economy are also under discussion but it is telecommunications debate that has become heated because its outcome has important implications for future economic growth in Japan; US contends Japan is hurting itself economically by not creating basis for more competition in its telecommunications market; US is demanding immediate 41 percent reduction in fees that telecommunications companies pay to hook up to network owned by Nippon Telegraph and Telephone; but government says it can cut fees only 22.5 percent over four-year period, contending that more aggressive move would deal crushing blow to NTT; US is threatening to take matter to World Trade Organization if some agreement is not reached by end of month (M)

headline: Times Co. Plans Stock Issue To Track Its Internet Assets
abstract: New York Times Co to issue new class of stock to track value of its Internet properties; will use proceeds to finance Times Co Digital (M)

headline: Media Talk; Abrupt Departure By Executive Editor Of The Oklahoman
abstract: Stan Tiner leaves Daily Oklahoman just eight months after he was hired as executive editor; Columbia Journalism Review article year ago called paper 'worst newspaper in America' but was preparing follow-up article based on paper's accomplishments made under Tiner; Oklahoman officals have declined to comment on Tiner's departure, but culling of some articles Tiner had published suggest he may have gone counter to some of paper's previously stated editorial positions; Sue Hale is named to replace Tiner; his photo (M)

headline: CISCO TO BE INVESTOR AS SPANLINK GOES PRIVATE

headline: WEB SITE COMPANY INVESTS TO GAIN NET TECHNOLOGY
abstract: Web-site operating company Exodus Communications Inc agrees to invest $637.5 million in Mirror Image Internet Inc unit of Xcelera.com Inc; financial terms undisclosed (S)

headline: Gravity and the I.R.S. May Tug at Markets
abstract: As 1999 trading ended in an anticlimactic fashion, the date buzzing an alarm in investors' ears may have been Monday, April 17, not Jan. 1.     Joseph Barthel, chief investment strategist at Fahnestock & Company, told Reuters on Thursday that some people, who were waiting for tax reasons, to take profits in January chose to do it sooner, fearing that the rally was ending. Some portfolio managers all of a sudden as we step into the New Year think that people will start to sell on the first day of the year, he said.

headline: Consumer Goods Giant To Cut 25,000 Workers And Push E-Commerce : Unilever To Jettison Brands and Trim Jobs
abstract: LONDON—  For decades Unilever Group, the world's largest consumer products company, has generated billions of dollars in steady profits by selling household brands, ranging from Dove soap and Lipton tea to Calvin Klein fragrances, in more than 100 countries.

headline: U.S. Stiffens Its Opposition To European I.M.F. Choice
abstract: Pres Clinton vows to block Caio Koch-Weser, man Europe wants to head International Monetary Fund, setting off possibly protracted contest for control of financial institution and most likely casting US in role of kingmaker; Clinton administration says Koch-Weser does not have what it takes to be world's chief financial firefighter; administration is backing Stanley Fischer, number 2 official at IMF and an American; photo (M)

headline: Dell Says Notebooks May Have Flawed Chips
abstract: Dell Says Notebooks May Have Flawed Chips

headline: PUBLISHER REPORTS LOSS
abstract: Dorling Kindersley Holdings, British publisher, reports loss of 25 million pounds ($41 million) before taxes in the six months ending Dec 31 (S)

headline: MEDIA: Gambling Heavily on the Tried and the True; Primedia Ready to Polish 'A Diamond in the Rough'
abstract: How do you take a company known in part for its sleepy trade magazines like Soybean Digest and Lapidary Journal and transform it into a smoking hot new-media company?     Before Tom Rogers became the chief executive of Primedia last fall, the company was primarily known as a large publisher of special-interest and trade magazines. Apart from the most recognizable titles -- New York, Seventeen and Modern Bride -- the company publishes more than 100 niche magazines from American Baby to World War II, and also produces and distributes video products like Channel One and the Law Enforcement Television Network.

headline: IN MY . . . BRIEFCASE: THOMAS J. DONOHUE
abstract: Contents of briefcase carried by Thomas J Donohue, president of United States Chamber of Commerce described; photo of Donohue and briefcase (S)

headline: SPRINT SELLING INTELIG STAKE
abstract: Brazilian officials, citing competition concerns resulting from MCI Worldcom's takeover of Sprint Corp, say Sprint must sell its stake in Intelig, long-distance telecommunications company formed to compete with MCI's Brazilian business, Embratel; Communications Min Joao Pimenta da Veiga says Sprint and its partners in Intelig, National Grid Group and France Telecom, have one week to propose Sprint's exit strategy (S)

headline: Barterer Beware
abstract: Tony Bruno letter says swappers should beware of unscrupulous barterers on EBay and other Web sites (Mar 2 article)

headline: Amazon Bolsters Ties to Drugstore.com
abstract: Amazon.com agrees to make Drugstore.com its pharmaceutical provider, furthering its goal of becoming a diversified online retailer; will receive $105 million over three years; plans an additional $30 million investment in Drugstore.com, bringingits stake to 28 percent (S)

headline: Kohl, a Stubborn Statesman, May Be Wrecking His Party
abstract: Streak of obstinacy that helped Helmut Kohl unify Germany and persuade his countrymen to abandon their beloved mark for euro now appears to be unhinging his Christian Democratic party and unraveling Kohl's reputation; Kohl has opened devastating party divisions by admitting he accepted over $1 million in secret payments to party but refusing to reveal donors' names or leave politics in face of criminal investigation; Wolfgang Schauble, current party leader and Kohl protege, now admits to taking $52,000 in cash in 1994 from Karlheinz Schreiber, arms broker now fighting extradition from Canada; Schauble says he passed money along to party treasurer Brigitte Baumeister; Schauble has until now tried to distance himself from affair, but neither he nor Kohl appear to have entirely grasped gravity of scandal; photo (M)

headline: London Trial Opens Dispute On Rewriting The Holocaust
abstract: Revisionist historian David Irving gives opening statement as British High Court begins hearing libel case that he hopes will salvage his reputation; Irving, who claims Hitler did not approve mass kiling of Jews and that Auschwitz was merely labor camp with unfortunately high death rate, is suing Deborah Lipstadt and Penguin over her book Denying the Holocaust: The Growing Assault on Truth and Memory; book examines Holocaust deniers and their links to neo-Nazis; Irving charges Lipstadt and publisher are supported by 'organized international endeavor' to destroy his career (M)

headline: Data on Housing Industry Is Stronger Than Expected
abstract: Commerce Department says starts of new housing rose 1.5 percent in January to seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.775 million units after rising 5.1 percent in December; analysts had expected decline of 4 percent; increase was paced by 17.7 percent surge in starts of apartment buildings and other multifamily dwellings; construction of single-family houses fell 2.1 percent; permits for all new housing construction rose 8.7 percent to annual rate of 1.763 million units, highest since January 1999; graph (M)

headline: Business Travel; Try to relax. At least two psychologists are paying attention to stress from life on the road.
abstract: Business Travel column on study by University of Washington doctoral student of psychology Jonathan B Bricker and Prof Irwin Sarason entitled Something Stressful in the Air: Personality and Business Air Travel Stress; Bricker and Sarason comment (M)

headline: Business Travel; Some hotels are offering a flat daily fee that covers telephone service and other amenities.
abstract: Growing number of hotels are offering guests flat daily fee that covers telephone access and other amenities; some airlines, including American Airlines and JetBlue Airways, are stressing comfort by offering wider seats and more legroom in coach (Business Travel column) (M)

headline: Wall Street Embraces Deals That Could Speed up ´Entertainment-on-Demand´
abstract: January 7, 2000

headline: Not for a Nigerian Hero the Peace of the Grave
abstract: Remains of Ken Saro-Wiwa, author who was hanged nearly five years ago by Nigeria's military rulers, are in unmarked grave with those of eight other men who were also hanged; Saro-Wiwa's family wants to exhume body for proper funeral, but because of dispute with relatives of other men, burial scheduled for April 24 appears unlikely to take place; map; photo (M)

headline: Roche Revives Plans to Raise $1 Billion by Selling Bonds
abstract: Roche Holding AG revives plans to raise $1 billion by selling bonds that can be exchange for shares of Genentech; Roche, which owns about two-thirds of Genentech, is taking advantage of 84 percent increase in company's shares since day before Roche called off its original bond sale in October (S)

headline: Driving Simulator: Chills and Spills, All in the Name of Safety
abstract: National Advanced Driving Simulator (NADS), project of National Highway Traffic Adminitration and University of Iowa, is new research tool to improve vehicle and highway design and better predict driving behavior, all with the goal of saving lives; simulator will give researchers chance to test car safety systems or ride in virtual, setting with drivers whose abilities are impaired by alcohol or medication; $60 million simulator will be monitored by safety administration through its first year of operation then turned over to university; sketch of simulator (M)

headline: KOREA CARMAKER FALTERS IN AFRICA
abstract: Southern Africa automotive sales operation of South Korea conglomerate Hyundai, Hyundai Motor Distributors, has been placed into liquidation after its banks halt lending to troubled dealership network, which owes more than $120 million (S)

headline: Alaska Airlines Plane Took a Nosedive : 88 Feared Dead as Jet Crashes Off California
abstract: WASHINGTON—  The U.S. Coast Guard, Air Force and Navy continued an extensive search off the California coast Tuesday after an Alaskan Airlines jet airliner with 88 people aboard plummeted nose-first into deep waters northwest of Los Angeles.

headline: Regulators Take Action Against Bank of New York
abstract: New York State and federal regulators formally sanction Bank of New York for 'deficiencies' in its anti-money-laundering practices, according to agreement signed by bank at monthly meeting of its board; move, known as enforcement action, does not include monetary penalties against bank and falls short of more serious 'cease and desist' order that regulators could have imposed; Bank of New York is still in middle of federal investigation involving possible money laundering related to more than $7 million in funds transmitted from Russia and into bank through network of obscure companies tied to company, Benex International, that is now defunct (M)

headline: Stock of Company in Big Hong Kong Deal Is Sharply Lower
abstract: Stock of Pacific Century CyberWorks is sharply lower one day after its takeover bid for Hong Kong's flagship telephone company is accepted by company's British parent, Cable and Wireless; Pacific Century's stock declines 7.9 percent, slicing $3 billion from value of its $38.1 billion all-stock offer for Cable and Wireless HKT (M)

headline: In Greenspan Wake, Bad Day for Markets
abstract: The stock market plummeted a day after Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, warned that interest rates would continue to increase until economic growth slows and the stock market cools down.    Business Day, Page C1.

headline: A Sport for Purists: Belt-Sander Races
abstract: New and unusual sport, more of an event for kids than adults, is belt sander racing, which was introduced by Lorne Nielson, owner of Nielson Hardware, Point Roberts, Wash; sander racing has international championship, divisions, rules and specifications; International Belt Sander Drag Race Association has its own Web site (www.beltsander-races.com) and Web pages that provide instruction on how to build track and modify sander (M)

headline: ING SPENDING ON INTERNET
abstract: ING Group, largest Dutch financial-services company, plans to spend 2 billion euros ($1.9 billion) on the Internet; says it will make investment during next three years to expand its on-line banking and brokerage businesses (S)

headline: How to Get in Early on a Hot Offering
abstract: Even though February 28 initial public offering of Palm Inc will be unavailable to most public investors, those who buy shares in parent 3Com Corp could end up owning Palm stock and sharing in potentil upside since Palm is being spun off and 3Com will still own 80 percent of company after offering; graph; photo (M)

headline: Israel Plans to Recall Envoy Over Right-Wingers in Austria
abstract: Israel announces that it will recall Amb Nathan Meron if Austrian Pres Thomas Klestil authorizes new coalition government that includes rightist party led by Jorg Haider; Meron photo (M)

headline: F.T.C. Puts Off Hearing on BP-ARCO Deal
abstract: Federal Trade Commission delays hearing on staff proposal to block proposed merger of BP Amoco PLC and ARCO (S)

headline: Fate of 5 Terrorists Hangs Between Japan and Lebanon
abstract: Japan seeks extradition from Lebanon five Japanese Red Army terrorists who were involved in massacre at Israel's international airport near Lod on May 30, 1972; terrorists were sentenced to life in prison by Israel, but they were released by Israel in 1985 in prisoner exchange with Palestinians in 1985; they have been in prison in Lebanon for three years for living on forged passports; Japan wants to extradite Mariko Yamamoto, one of terrorists, to face trial for terrorism and acts against the state at home, and Lebanon, bowing to popular feelings, rejects Japanese request; photo of Red Army terrorists (L)

abstract: PlanetPortal.com is developing remote control for Web, called eGoPad, which will allow users to hit button on device and get immediately connected to specific site or to portal for specified categories; photo (S)

headline: Chilean's Homespun Record Could Make Him President
abstract: Joaquin Lavin, first conservative candidate with chance to win Chile's presidency since Gen Augusto Pinochet left power in 1990, has softened image of country's right wing, which still carries baggage of human rights abuses of Pinochet dictatorship; Lavin, mayor of Las Condes, is part of new wave of younger politicians who appear committed to overturning traditionally highly centralized power structures of Latin y America, parlaying local government success into capturing national attention, and even high office; photo (M)

headline: Fernando Benitez, 88, Mexican Writer, Dies
abstract: Fernando Benitez Gutierrez, journalist who helped formulate new visions of Mexican identity in his penetrating reports on Indian cultures and through cultural publications that he founded, dies at age 88; photo (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: TI GROUP,  London, a specialized engineering and manufacturing company, said its vehicle-parts manufacturing unit, TI Group Automotive Systems, would cut 105 jobs and close a factory in Valdosta, Ga., in July.    BROWN-FORMAN CORP.,  Louisville, Ky., which markets whiskies, wine products, china and luggage, said a wholly owned subsidiary, Lenox Inc., Lawrenceville, N.J., would cut 70 jobs at its Gorham factory in Smithfield, R.I., and move all stainless-steel flatwear production overseas.

headline: In a Survey, Americans Voice High Hopes for Cellular Phones
abstract: Yankelovich Partners survey of 1,013 cell phone users finds Americans are optimistic and imaginative about ways cell phones will be used in future, particularly as interactive devices (S)

headline: Dressing Up Your E-Mail By Putting In Some Emotion
abstract: Altec Lansing develops method that allows person to throw their voice across the Internet by using VoicePod, small USB-enabled voice recorder and player that allows users to record small voice messages and that can then be attached to e-mail messages (S)

headline: Big Day Spoiled for Bangladesh Villagers
abstract: Pres Clinton's visit to Bangladesh is dampened by security concerns; trip to rural village of Joypura is canceled at last minute, leaving many villagers disappointed because of weeks of preparation; hundreds are later bused in to meet Clinton at American Embassy in capital of Dhaka; Clinton, in decision likely to be seen as insult by Bangladeshis, also cancels stop at National Memorial, where world leaders traditionally pay homage to millions killed in war of independence against Pakistan in 1971; sudden shift in scheduling is ominous start to five-day visit to South Asia since Bangladesh was supposed to provide untroubled destination before President's visit to India and Pakistan; photos; maps (M)

abstract: Indonesia's government opens bidding for its 40 percent controlling stake in Astra International after efforts to sell it to US-led investment group fail because of resistance by Astra's management (M)

headline: On the Global, Faceless Web, Trust Counts for Even More
abstract: In a Web-based world, where electronic interaction is replacing the personal encounter, business-to-business entrepreneurs are rediscovering importance of building trust and forging longterm relationships; diagrams show variety of e-commerce transaction methods; drawing (M)

headline: CARMAKERS TO BUY PARTS ON INTERNET
abstract: General Motors, Ford and Daimler-Chrysler will establish world's biggest online marketplace for auto industry's private use; will buy nearly $250 billion worth of parts and other goods they need each year through giant auction site, which will dwarf all previous commercial activity on Web; hope to cut costs and save time by streamlining purchasing operations and putting them online; system will help them build more cars to customer specifiucations by allowing them to order parts for assembly plants far more quickly (M)

headline: Group Won´t Appeal Decision on Internet Voting
abstract: March 4, 2000

headline: A Richer Mix of Chips Helps Intel Exceed Expected Profit
abstract: Intel Corp, after three quarters of results that disappointed investors, posts fourth-quarter earnings that exceed Wall Street's expectations because of strong demand for personal computers and a shift toward higher-performance chips with better profit margins; Intel reports net income of $2.11 billion for quarter, or 61 cents a diluted share, up 2 percent from $2.06 billion, or 59 cents a share, in period year earlier; revenue rises 8 percent, to $8.21 billion from $7.61 billion (S)

headline: Becoming Bolder With Bets on Gold
abstract: Article discusses decision by Barrick Gold, most successful hedger in mining business, to place restrictions on hedging and to give up some of its locked-in gains in belief that prices will rally; graphs (M))

headline: Lucent Plunges in After-Hours Trading on Revised Outlook
abstract: Continuing a week of Wall Street disappointments, Lucent Technologies Inc., the maker of telecommunications equipment, said yesterday that its first-quarter sales and earnings would fall well short of analysts' expectations.    Lucent's troubles, which analysts insisted were primarily confined to the company, are expected to spark a selloff in technology stocks today. Lucent issued its earnings warning after the New York Stock Exchange had ended trading yesterday, but investors still rushed to sell their shares.

headline: EUROPEAN INQUIRY ON WINDOWS 2000
abstract: European Commission begins inquiry into Microsoft Corp's Windows 2000, new operating system scheduled to go on sale on Feb 17; commission says other software companies have complained that new system could help Microsoft extend its dominance from personal computer software to systems that run servers and manage electronic commerce; Microsoft says probe will not delay Windows 2000's introduction (S)

headline: BRAZIL SELLS EUROBONDS
abstract: Brazil sells $760 million of 10-year eurobonds; sale of securities, priced to yield 11.25 percent, illustrates how European financing is complementing Brazil's borrowing plans in dollars (S)

headline: Free-for-All on the Name Exchange
abstract: Recent surge in advertising by dot-com companies has heightened demand for names that are simple, memorable and immediately connote marketable product or service; rush has turned into free-for-all, with many people and companies registering, buying and selling names sometimes for astronomical sums; author Joan Kron, who registered Web site names to promote book and as speculative investment, comments (Special Section, E-Commerce); photos (M)

headline: INDIA RELAXES INVESTMENT BARRIERS
abstract: Indian government widens scope of industries that can accept foreign investment without special license, as broader effort to stimulate economic growth; under directive announced by Parmod Mahjan, parliamentary affairs minister, foreign investments will be allowed without license in all major business sectors except for alcohol, cigarettes, aerospace electronics and industrial explosives (S)

abstract: CNET to Buy MySimon.com

headline: Judge Says School May Have Overreacted to Student´s Site
abstract: March 3, 2000

headline: Audible Jumps After Amazon.com Deal
