headline: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: AMERICAS; MEXICO-EUROPE INSURANCE DEAL
abstract: Savia SA de CV, holding company of Mexico's largest insurance firm, Seguros Comercial America, joins partnership with ING Group, Amsterdam; ING will pay $555 million for 39.7 percent stake (S)

headline: Mailing Supplier and I.B.M. Try Postage Sales Over the Net
abstract: Neopost Online has formed partnership with IBM to build self-service kiosks that can dispense postage; kiosks, to be placed in grocery stores and on college campuses, will calculate postage needed, print digital stamp and charge customer's credit card; Postal Service can automatically replenish postage levels by computer via Internet, saving it labor costs; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Graphs plot decline in cocoa futures prices on March 24; May delivery fell $36, or 4.1 percent, to $840 per metric ton

headline: Journalist, Rearrested After Release by Chechens, Assails Russia
abstract: Journalist Andre Babitsky, re-arrested after surfacing from detention in Chechnya, has told Radio Liberty colleagues that Russian officials violated accord under which he agreed to be exchanged for Russian soldiers and forced him into Feb 2 roadside swap; his radio reports on civilian suffering and military brutality have angered Russian authorities; his account will probably further enrage Russian journalists angered at harsh treatment of colleagues unpopular with government (M)

headline: Israel-Allied Militia Officer InLebanon Killed By Bomb
abstract: Guerrillas fighting to oust Israeli troops from southern Lebanon kill Col Akl Hashem, second-most-senior officer of Israeli-backed militia with bomb that exploded near home; Iranian-backed Hezbollah, or Party of God, claims responsibility; Israel vows revenge; accuses Syria, which exercises wide influence in Syria, of showing bad faith in negotiations with Israel by failing to rein in Hezbollah (M)

headline: Dell Ventures to Provide Management Services
abstract: March 29, 2000

headline: Foreign Aid Donors Approve $4.7 Billion More for Indonesia
abstract: International donors meeting in Jakarta give Indonesia's government powerful show of support, agreeing to provide as much as $4.7 billion in credit to fill shortage in nation's budget and keep it tenuous economic recovery alive; support, pledged as part of $43 billion economic rescue package being overseen by International Monetary Fund, is provided by members of Consultative Group on Indonesia, umbrella organization of World Bank and several foreign governments; it is contingent on Indonesia's cooperation in stamping out what is seen as rampant corruption; support comes at critical time for government of Pres Abdurrahman Wahid; he is seeking to pull Indonesia out of economic crisis and to assert civilian control over previously dominant military; regional separatism and military resentment threaten to divide nation; Pres Wahid is facing resistance by former armed forces chief and now security minister, Gen Wiranto, whom Wahid has demanded resign (M)

headline: EURO DROP COULD SPUR INFLATION
abstract: European Central Bank president Wim Duisenberg says further declines in Europe's common currency, the euro, could spur faster inflation in region; euro sank to to record low of 97.35 US cents on Jan 28, down 16 percent since its inception in January 1999; photo (S)

headline: Barak Says Talks With Syria Have Reached Critical Juncture
abstract: Prime Min Ehud Barak returns to Israel and reports that peace talks with Syria have reached 'decisive stage' in which both sides will have to make difficult decisions, television interview; sees 'certain fissures' in Syrian rigidity but is not reading too much into them; dismisses concerns that Pres Hafez al-Assad shows disrespect by sending Foreign Min Farouk al-Shara, and declines to make issue of whether or not he and Shara shake hands; says no in-depth talks on borders have taken place and Israelis have made no political commitment on withdrawal from Golan Heights (S)

headline: Technology Lifts Nasdaq and Pushes S.& P. Over 1,500
abstract: Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gains 6.77 points, or 0.45 percent, to close at record 1,500.65; Dow Jones industrial average drops 40.64 points, to close at 10,866.70; Nasdaq composite index advances 153.07 points, or 3.25 percent, to close at 4,864.75; graph; chart (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Cocoa rises on expectations that economic recovery in Europe and Asia will bolster demand for luxury items like chocolate; in New York, cocoa for May delivery rises $37, or 4.1 percent, to $935 a ton; graph; chart (S)

headline: Prices Show A Small Rise For January
abstract: Consumer Price Index, best-known inflation measure, edges up only 0.2 percent in January; this is fourth consecutive mild increase, and it undercuts numerous forecasts that booming economy is creating shortages that must inevitably show up in more rapidly rising prices; separately, Commerce Dept reports that nation's trade deficit narrowed to $25.55 billion in December from $27.1 billion in November, largely because imports jumped; graph (M)

headline: Talk by Putin Skips the War, But Albright Reminds Him
abstract: Vladimir V Putin, acting president of Russia, makes surprise appearance at Middle East conference in Moscow attended by Sec of State Madeleine K Albright; uses occasion to deliver his first foreign policy statement, pointedly singling out Clinton administration's desire to modify Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty; Albright says progress toward political solution in Middle East should be used as example for how to resolve war in Chechnya (M)

headline: Start-Up Agency In Las Vegas
abstract: Advertising agency Schadler Kramer Salisbury is opened by John Schadler, Jerry Kramer and Mike Salisbury in Las Vegas, Nev (S)

headline: Campbell Soup Chief Resigns As Long-Term Slump Persists
abstract: Dale F Morrison, chief executive and president of Campbell Soup Co, resigns; move raises speculation that company could be for sale; David W Johnson, chief executive and president from 1990 to 1997 who retired last year, will take over while board forms committee to search for new chief executive; Philip E Lippincott will remain as chairman (M)

headline: Oh, It's You Again
abstract: Letter by Stephen F Bornet Jr responds to March 16 article on cell phones/pagers as means for parents to keep track to their teenage children; says while he did initially resent such oversight he has come to appreciate the technology now that he is a college student

headline: U.S. FRANCHISE SAYS IT IS CONSIDERING 'STRATEGIC OPTIONS'
abstract: US Franchise Systems Inc franchiser of Microtel Inn, Hawthorne Suites and Best Ins hotels, hires Banc of America Securities to explore strategic alternatives; says it has received few unsolicited inquiries regarding possible sale of company in recent months (S)
